HEADLINE: Bridge

BYLINE: By Alan Truscott

 BODY:
Seattle has some 7,000 hotel rooms, but it will be hard to find one around Thanksgiving. There will be at least 5,000 visitors bent on attending the football game between Washington and Washington State. There will be some 4,000 bridge players attending the Fall Nationals, with headquarters at the Sheraton Hotel. And there will be 3,000 delegates, staff members and journalists attending the Asia-Pacific Conference, an economic meeting of nations of the Pacific Rim.
There has already been some furor because one president, Barbara Nudelman of the American Contract Bridge League, has refused to surrender the presidential suite at the Sheraton to another President, Kim Young-sam of South Korea. 
 The Korean Consul in Seattle would not comment, but Mrs. Nudelman was forthright: "I can't believe this man has anything but an ego trip in needing this suite. Is he going to entertain every night? Who is he going to entertain? I entertain hundreds of people over 10 days."
The Sultan of Brunei, the world's richest man, was another unsucessful applicant for the suite, which covers 1,500 square feet and costs $2,000 a night. The Bridge League has it as part of a contract for space in the whole hotel.
 
High-Level Chinese Game
 A different, and more harmonious, relationship between an American official and Asian leaders will occur in January. Jim Cayne of Manhattan, president of the Bear, Stearns brokerage, will play bridge with members of the Chinese hierarchy when he goes to Beijing in January to open an office there. This repeats a similar visit to Shanghai last January, and again he will partner Kathie Wei-Sender, long a link between the Chinese Government and the United States.
In a recent practice match in Manhattan, preparing for their trip, Wei-Sender opened the North hand shown with two diamonds, a Precision bid showing a three-suiter short in diamonds. Over a double, showing diamonds, Cayne jumped to four hearts with the South hand. West might have saved in five diamonds, which would have failed by a trick, but chose to defend and lead the diamond jack.
South had to worry about the spade ace, the heart queen and the club king. He took the diamond ace and led a spade, testing the water in that suit. When West played low and the king won, South played another spade. This left all options open, and when East won and played a diamond dummy ruffed.
South was willing to lose a club trick, and East was likely to have the king. The queen was led from dummy, and East won and played another diamond. South ruffed in dummy and played trumps, surrendering a trick to the queen. He had made his game by avoiding the traps that defeated the declarer in the replay.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Harmonizing From a Forbes Quartet

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
The frenetic 1980's had been over for only two months when Malcolm S. Forbes, chief executive of Forbes Inc. and a flamboyant presence on the American business scene for almost 40 years, died unexpectedly in his sleep at the age of 70. It was, everyone said, the end of an era.
But it was also the start of an astonishingly compatible partnership, as his four sons assumed leading positions in the family publishing company that had been founded by their grandfather in 1917. 
 In 1992, under their leadership and during one of the worst economic periods in the history of magazines, Forbes magazine became the industry leader in ad pages. It was a feat their father had never accomplished. Since his death, the company has also brought out new magazines, started three foreign-language editions of Forbes, expanded its weekly newspaper chain in New Jersey and embarked on a custom textbook publishing venture. And it is about to open an executive conference center on the 255,000-acre Forbes Trinchera ranch in Colorado.
"I think a lot of people felt that when Malcolm passed away, the company was in trouble," said Frank Smith, vice president and group director of print services at the advertising agency Young & Rubicam. "The fact is that since Malcolm's passing, I think the company is stronger and the magazine is better."
Some things have not changed. The Forbes brothers have continued the extravagant business entertaining that was their father's trademark. On eight Saturdays in autumn, for instance, they invite groups of publishers, ad executives and others aboard the Highlander, their father's yacht, and take them up the Hudson River to West Point. The yacht is also used for dinners like one last Thursday, which included Margaret Thatcher and Ann Landers as guests.
The brothers continue to offer balloon meets at the family chateau in Normandy and paid trips to Europe for special advertisers. Last month, 10 advertising chief executives and their spouses were flown to Paris on the Concorde for two days of wining and dining and a private viewing of an exhibit of Faberge jewelry that included four Faberge Imperial eggs from the Forbes collection. Another group went to St. Petersburg, Russia, in June to see the same exhibit at the Hermitage Museum.
But more striking than the lavish entertaining style are the respect and affection that the brothers have for one another. They had known that when their father died, the eldest brother, Malcolm S. Forbes Jr., known as Steve, would inherit 51 percent of the voting stock and become president and chief executive. Steve Forbes, 46, is also editor in chief of Forbes magazine, chairman of the 17 Forbes newspapers and chairman of American Heritage magazine, which Forbes acquired in 1986.
Christopher Forbes, 42, who is known as Kip, is vice chairman of Forbes Inc., responsible for all advertising and promotion. He is also in charge of the German, Chinese and Japanese editions of Forbes and the company's real estate holdings in England, France and Morocco, as well the corporate art collection.
Robert L. Forbes, 44, is vice president of Forbes Inc. and president of Forbes FYI, a quarterly life style publication introduced in September 1990. And Timothy C. Forbes, 40, is president of the American Heritage division of Forbes, which includes five subsidiary magazines and a custom textbook publishing group.
 
'Genuinely Like Each Other'
 "I think the smartest thing Malcolm did was to raise four people who genuinely like each other," said Christopher T. Buckley, editor of FYI, and a friend of the family. "They tend to laugh with each other, and that's a pretty good sign. It's impossible to imagine a serious rift occurring in this family as has occurred in other American dynasties."
Why are the brothers so close?
In an interview, Kip Forbes grinned and said, "If you have all learned how to play the bagpipes together and wear kilts to church on Sunday, you have gone through the ultimate bonding experience."
Or, as Steve Forbes put it: "We trust each other totally. It's a nice relationship, one we would not have thought of when we were youngsters. We are not throwing balls at each other now, and we all have shares in the business so we all have a stake in doing well."
They also have a sister, Moira Mumma, 38, who shares in the inheritance. But she decided long ago not to become involved in the operations of the business, despite her father's urging.
Forbes is a privately held company and does not disclose its revenue or profit. Estimates about the worth of Mr. Forbes's estate at the time of his death ranged from about $400 million to $1 billion. Steve Forbes said that at the time of his father's death, the estate was worth "more than $100 million and less than $1 billion."
 
Gains in Circulation
 Sitting in his father's former office in the Forbes building on lower Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, Steve Forbes seemed to enjoy talking about the company. An original Gilbert Stuart portrait of George Washington stared down from behind the desk.
Steve Forbes said two-thirds of the company's profit comes from Forbes magazine, which he called "the core of the company." The magazine, published every two weeks, has long focused on the people and strategies of company management. Circulation is 767,789, up 3.7 percent from last year, enabling the magazine to raise the circulation it guarantees advertisers to 765,000 from its current 750,000, starting in January.
So far this year, ad pages have totaled 3,078, up 5.3 percent from the corresponding period last year.
"They inherited a magazine that is in very good shape, and Malcolm did groom Steve in a shrewd way," said Leo E. Scullin, president of Scullin & Company, a media consulting firm. "Forbes has managed to keep its edge through a very difficult time."
James Spanfeller, publisher of Inc., a magazine that covers growing companies, said that after Malcolm Forbes died, Forbes magazine organized a particularly aggressive and successful sales effort to maintain its position in the market. Some competitors say Forbes makes so many deals involving discounted pages -- like a free page in return for three paid ad pages -- that its position as the leader in advertising pages is meaningless.
Steve Forbes said that all discounts and bonuses are stated on the rate card. And media directors of advertising agencies say that almost all magazines offer advertisers some kind of bonus, ranging from free tickets to a tennis match to free ad pages in a sister publication.
 
The Forbes Spinoffs
 In recent years, Forbes has started a number of spinoff magazines that are aimed at segments of the Forbes readership.
FYI, for instance, goes to Forbes subscribers four times a year, free of charge. Robert Forbes, president of FYI, said advertiser response had been beyond expectations; FYI will carry 330 pages of advertising this year, up 32 percent from last year. FYI's ad pages are counted as part of the Forbes total by the Publishers Information Bureau, which tracks the magazine industry.
Last year, Forbes introduced ASAP, a magazine about technology for the general executive. Now a quarterly, it will be published six times a year starting in January.
American Heritage has also started several spinoffs under Timothy Forbes. These include Civil War Chronicles and Audacity, which focuses on the past as it relates to the present. Another spinoff, Invention and Technology, was started in 1987.
American Heritage has just introduced a consumer-oriented quarterly called Media Critic, which is a "look at ourselves and our colleagues with a critical eye," Timothy Forbes said. It has 25,000 subscribers and will also be sold on newsstands.
In separate interviews, the four brothers made the point that they would grow the business slowly, starting new magazines only when they saw a real need. And they seemed far more relaxed than many other industry executives on the subject of interactive media and the ramifications for magazines.
"If something comes along that intrigues us, we'll do it, but I don't think we'll have to do it to survive," Steve Forbes said.
"As long as you have information that is put together so it's of use to the person at the other end," he added, "you're in business. How the information is conveyed -- whether it's on paper or on a blank screen -- is immaterial to us."

HEADLINE: Hunter College's Playhouse Prepares for a New Beginning

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
Two seasons ago, the Hunter College Playhouse was the rundown home of a few rootless ensembles, and barely in use at that. Concertgoers old enough to remember the recitals and theater productions that had made Hunter a lively place between 1942 and 1975 could not help glancing wistfully around the tattered auditorium, or walking through the college's main building to peek into the larger Assembly Hall, where Horowitz, Heifetz, Segovia, Rubinstein, Pinza and other classical-music greats used to perform.
But after letting its performance series slide for nearly 20 years, to become a casualty of changing policies and campus overcrowding, Hunter is getting back into the business with a vengeance. The Playhouse, at 68th Street at Lexington Avenue, has been fully revamped, and Joseph A. LoSchiavo, its new administrator, has put together a schedule of 200 dance, music and theater performances. The hall opened for business quietly in April. But its official Inaugural Week begins tonight with a Lerner and Loewe revue, "The Night They Invented Champagne."
 
Stiff Competition
 Hunter's new program is likely to draw heavily on an audience already stretched thin by the recession and distracted by numerous other entertainment choices. On the East Side alone, the Playhouse is up against competition from the Tisch Center at the 92d Street Y, the Metropolitan Museum, the Frick Collection and Gould Hall. Across town, Lincoln Center, Carnegie Hall, Merkin Concert Hall, Town Hall, the Joyce Theater and other halls offer further diversions. 
 Hunter's revival is being closely watched by the 92d Street Y, 24 blocks up Lexington Avenue from the college. The competition between them may become more acute if Hunter goes through with a plan to renovate the 2,100-seat Assembly Hall and to build a new 200-seat recital hall. In a way, the performing-arts programs of Hunter and the Y intersect. Omus Hirshbein, the vice chairman of the Tisch Center, has built the Y into a major force in the New York concert world. Before he went to the Y in 1975, he ran the Hunter concert bureau until the college phased it out.
But in recent seasons his program has come under attack by a budget-conscious board. A recital series has been dropped, the series by the resident New York Chamber Symphony series has been scaled back, and an ambitious Schubertiade, which was to have presented all of Schubert's music over 10 years, has been reduced to a series of thematic Schubert concerts.
There are signs of revival this season: the Y's programs are livelier, and Mr. Hirshbein is projecting a 10 percent increase in ticket sales. But the program is still vulnerable, and the appearance of an eager competitor with a bright new hall has been met with some trepidation.
At Hunter, the 664-seat Sylvia and Danny Kaye Playhouse (named in gratitude for a $1 million contribution toward the renovation) was completed last spring, six months ahead of schedule and within its $4.8 million budget. Its threadbare seats have been replaced, the technical facilities have been updated, and a new acoustical shell has been built. The walls have been modified to better reflect the sound, dressing rooms have been expanded, and the grungy lobby has been cleaned up and modernized.
The Inaugural Week schedule suggests the tenor of Mr. LoSchiavo's programming. Besides tonight's gala, there is the opening, on Tuesday, of a chamber-music series with a new work by a woman composer on each program. The Caribbean Dance Company is to perform on Wednesday, followed by the American Tap Dance Orchestra on Thursday. A recital by Martina Arroyo is to be held on Friday, with an orchestral concert by Michael Tilson Thomas and the New World Symphony on Sunday.
"I don't think our program is typical of what you will find in New York under one roof," said Mr. LoSchiavo, who was a freelance opera director and the chief librarian at Fordham University before coming to Hunter. "But this first year is by no means as diverse as I would like our schedule to be in the future. My hope is to present the best in the performing arts of a wide variety of cultures."
"I don't perceive competition," he added. "I don't want to be Lincoln Center on the East Side. That would be a pointless intent. And I don't want to be either a clone of the 92d Street Y or a threat to them. Our programming overlaps slightly. Hunter has such a long history in music that it was expected that we would present a certain amount. But the Y doesn't offer the dance and theater programs we have, and we are not yet doing the literary programs that the Y has."
 
The 'Not Yet' Factor
 Mr. LoSchiavo's noncompetitive pronouncement notwithstanding, his "not yet" suggests designs on an area in which the Y has an edge. And indeed, the significance of Hunter's re-entry into the presentation world has not been lost on Mr. Hirshbein.
Mr. Hirshbein, actually, had his own designs on Hunter's performance facilities. For the last few years, he has explored the possibility of presenting some of the Y's concerts at Hunter. In 1990 he took an experimental step in that direction by presenting a Schubert opera -- part of the 92d Street Y's Schubertiade -- in the Assembly Hall. But with the establishment of Hunter's own presentation department, Mr. Hirshbein's plans have been shelved.
"Cooperation can definitely happen," Mr. LoSchiavo tentatively offered. "Omus and I have discussed it in general terms. But I think we need to see how we can develop on our own before we seriously explore that." And in the spirit of friendly competition, the Y allowed Mr. LoSchiavo and his team to examine, measure and copy the Y's acoustical shell.
The Y has a bigger budget, but the figures are not directly comparable. The Y's $4 million presentation budget includes musical and literary series, as well as educational outreach programs. But the Y produces its events, meaning that it pays the bill for them. At Hunter, the operating budget of $1.2 million includes some production money. But many of the events, particularly the dance and theater offerings, are rentals: the companies pay Hunter for the use of the facilities. Mr. LoSchiavo said rental fees are crucial to his budget. The budget itself, though, is a touchy issue.
"Being in the middle of a city institution that has very real financial problems, it's important that people understand that this $1.2 million is not a sum that is given to me," Mr. LoSchiavo said. "There are no tax levy funds involved. It is not part of the City University's tax levy budget, and is not coming out of any academic programs. I have to raise every dollar of my budget myself, through a combination of box office, rental fees and fund raising."
There was, however, some city money in the restoration project. Half of the $4.8 million budget came as a matching grant from New York State. New York City provided $1 million and the school raised $1.4 million in private donations, including $1 million from the Sylvia and Danny Kaye Foundation.
Mr. LoSchiavo faces a difficult juggling act. He is at the helm of an enterprise that must be financially self-sufficient. But he must also be responsive to Hunter College's needs. Some of those needs are practical -- the hall must be available for use by student ensembles -- and some are political.
"Hunter's performance program foundered on open enrollment," Mr. Hirshbein said. "There was a concern that what was perceived as the elitist persona of the hall was contrary to the mission of the college, which was that any one with a high school diploma could attend."
Open enrollment also caused a space crunch; the concert halls were pressed into service as classrooms, and the dressing rooms became faculty offices.
Hunter's East Building, which opened in 1985, alleviated the crowding. Around the same time, the school's administration began to regard arts programming as both a cultural necessity and a magnet for alumni who might contribute money to the school. The program was re-established on the condition that its offerings reflect the increasingly multicultural makeup of the student body and the city. Complying with that requirement, while keeping an eye on both the budget and the competition, is the challenge that Mr. LoSchiavo faces.
"I would be lying if I said I'm not nervous," he admitted. "You wake up in the morning and say, 'I have to be crazy to be doing this,' and then you realize that if the other people in the world who present concerts weren't also crazy, there would be no performance world."

HEADLINE: Welfare Reform, Done Harshly

 BODY:
Wisconsin's welfare reform -- putting a two-year limit on benefits -- would seem to have come straight out of President Clinton's playbook. During the campaign, he promised to "end welfare as we know it" by making benefits temporary. No wonder then that the Administration granted its approval for Wisconsin's plan last week.
But a closer look shows that the two policies veer in starkly different directions. Mr. Clinton wants to guarantee a job for parents who reach the end of the two-year period; Wisconsin doesn't. Mr. Clinton pledges generous education and training programs before the benefits run out; Wisconsin doesn't. And Mr. Clinton's advisers recognize that for welfare reform to work, it must protect children from penalties meted out to delinquent parents; Wisconsin doesn't. 
 Wisconsin, under Gov. Tommy Thompson, a Republican, will pick two counties for the experimental reform. Welfare recipients will initially be directed into training and education, but only for at most one year. During the second year, enrollees will work off their benefits in private or public jobs. After 24 months of welfare, the guaranteed jobs disappear and cash assistance is cut off for three years. The state would continue to provide food stamps, health care and, in a small number of cases, housing vouchers.
To critics, the Wisconsin plan isn't just tough; it's vicious. What happens to parents who, for no fault of their own, can't find work? Where will they get cash to buy their children soap, clothes, bus fare -- let alone an occasional book or movie ticket? Wisconsin only promises to extend benefits beyond 24 months if the local job market is dreadful; but that would still leave many unemployed in the lurch. Nor would Wisconsin help children of delinquent parents who refuse to show up for work. If they don't work, the family loses all but health benefits and food stamps.
Though Mr. Clinton's plan won't be out until next year, his statements suggest that he will at least provide the poor an opportunity to earn cash assistance through community service. And, unlike Wisconsin, he's struggling to figure out how to insulate kids from the failure of their parents.
The underlying presumption of the Wisconsin plan is that able-bodied parents who know for certain that their benefits will end, and that no job will be automatically offered to them, will figure out how to find steady work. As proof that aggressive management can work, Wisconsin points to its enviable record driving down welfare rolls the past eight years.
The Wisconsin plan might make progress in moving some welfare recipients off the rolls and into productive work. But there are virtually certain to be some ugly outcomes. And even if the experiment works to some degree, it is unlikely to be a model for reform elsewhere in the country. The experiment is isolated to relatively few families in only two counties, yet to be picked but probably prosperous, in an economically healthy state.
That would allow Wisconsin to sidestep the problems faced by urban centers where an increasing number of poor parents cannot find or hold steady jobs. The country has engaged in rounds of experiments with jobs programs, combining different levels of carrots and sticks. At best, these reforms move a few unemployed into jobs. None are hugely successful.
Wisconsin's harsh plan doesn't match the President's inviting rhetoric. But that doesn't mean he should have rejected the application. The President has pledged to provide states the leeway to experiment with social programs. And Wisconsin's track record on welfare reform is sufficiently encouraging to warrant giving it a long leash. The danger, however, is that should the plan backfire it will tarnish Mr. Clinton's more generous approach that would strive to replace welfare with a humane, effective alternative.

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: North Korea and the Bomb;
A Deadline On Diplomacy

BYLINE: By Zalmay M. Khalilzad; Zalmay M. Khalilzad, director of strategy at the Rand Corporation, was an assistant under secretary of defense in the Bush Administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
North Korea is playing a frightening game of cat and mouse in its efforts to build nuclear weapons without risking significant reprisal from the international community. Other nations -- and particularly the United States -- should not let the North Koreans get away with it: we should threaten them with economic sanctions, and soon.
The bomb program came to international attention last winter, after the International Atomic Energy Agency detected that Pyongyang was diverting fissionable material from its civilian nuclear program. To determine how much diversion had occurred, the agency demanded to inspect two sites. The North Koreans refused and threatened to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. 
 But they did offer to discuss the issue with the United States. After two rounds of meetings last summer, they agreed to continue abiding by the treaty and to renew discussions with the atomic energy agency.
But Pyongyang is still refusing to allow inspection of the two sites. Not only that; it has also impeded the I.A.E.A.'s work at sites previously under routine inspection, and ultimately suspended talks with the agency -- whose director recently reported to the United Nations that monitoring cameras at the routine sites had run out. The implication is that the agency cannot tell whether still more diversion of nuclear materials is taking place.
After breaking off discussions with the agency, the North Koreans expressed a willingness to talk with the U.S. again. And last month we did.
The longer this game goes on, the closer the North Koreans get to building nuclear weapons. And if they succeed, the risks are grave. The chances of war between North and South Korea would increase. Seoul and Tokyo might well consider nuclear programs of their own. North Korean cooperation with Iran on missiles could expand to include nuclear weapons. And North Korean success in defying the I.A.E.A. could wreck our global nonproliferation policy.
The time has come to impose a deadline on the North Koreans. We should tell them that unless they allow inspections by the International Atomic Energy Agency -- both routine and special -- by Dec. 1, we will seek the imposition of economic sanctions by the U.N. The sanctions would ban imports of petroleum products, exports of weapons and other products from North Korea and financial transfers to North Korea.
Effective sanctions would require the cooperation of China. To get its support, we must make cooperation on the North Korean nuclear program the litmus test of our relations. This issue should be the central item on President Clinton's agenda when he meets with the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin, in Seattle next week. He might forcefully remind Mr. Jiang of the implications for Japan's nuclear posture.
For now, as we pursue sanctions, we should take two other steps. First, we should increase our own military capability in the region, and South Korea's. This would help discourage North Korean adventurism and signal Pyongyang that it is on a dangerous course. It would also enforce a blockade, if need be.
Second, we should hold out a carrot to the North Koreans, telling themthat if they cooperate on the nuclear issue we will lead an international effort to help them and will consider ways to end North Korea's international isolation.
But it's obvious that the costs of relying solely on diplomacy are unacceptably high. Recent events in Somalia and Haiti may have emboldened the North Koreans to think they can play cat and mouse forever; to change their calculations, we need to make clear that we have decided to stop playing.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 4; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: School Voucher Plans Don't Improve Education;
Benefits of Choice

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "California's Experiment on Your Schools" (Op-Ed, Oct. 30), Jonathan Schorr says there's no proof that vouchers work, so let's not try them. Yet there's ample proof that public schools are not working for many of the families who are paying taxes to have children educated by them. 
 Perhaps Mr. Schorr is relying on a recent report by the Economic Policy Institute, which asserts that school choice does not help students nor create more equity for racial minorities. This is from the same group that gave us the twisted calculation that the United States spends less on education than every other industrialized country save Sweden. This report again skews the facts.
School choice programs in nearly a dozen states are made up of large numbers of low-income, minority children in well-integrated settings. Both public and private schools in which choice is exercised demonstrate not only higher achievement in academic subjects, but also a decline in dropouts, a higher average daily attendance rate, high morale, a drop in disciplinary action or none at all and greater retention of teachers.
In every experiment where a child has transferred from a public to a private school, that child is now graded against a higher standard.
In Milwaukee, home of the first example of a publicly funded school choice plan, public schools are discouraged from holding back students who show up at least half the time and are able to muster at least a D in all subjects. Conversely, most of the private schools in the choice program in Milwaukee base grades on tests, effort and the demonstration of knowledge. It will take some time before children coming out of the public school system can show on paper what they have achieved.
There are other benefits less tangible than test scores. Many of the people in California who voted for the school choice initiative that was defeated Nov. 2 are worried about crime in the schools. They're worried that their children aren't learning enough to land a job that requires more than seventh-grade skills. They're worried about public schools with minorities segregated in bad schools away from the mainstream.
In the end vouchers will give the poorest of students the choice not only to attend quality private schools, but to benefit from an improved public school system as well because a system responsive to parents will create a dynamic for improvement in all schools.
 
JEANNE ALLEN
President, Center for Education Reform
Washington, Nov. 4, 1993

HEADLINE: Past Doesn't Repeat In Fear of Immigrants

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Fear of Immigrants Sounds an Old Theme" (letter, Oct. 28) Amy Bridges notes that New York City's foreign-born population was almost twice as high in 1855 as today, and she lauds the achievements of "that generation of immigrants." 
 But history does not repeat, and one set of newcomers is not interchangeable with others. America in the Civil War era was a developing economy with abundant natural resources and great need for workers. New York's urban complexity today, with its fragile infrastructure and congested social environment, is hardly comparable. Among the many differences are the extent of diversity, changed social values and the need for vital government services.
Back then, moreover, anti-immigrant sentiment derived largely from religious bias and snobbish natives. Today, it is to be found among working people, often newcomers themselves, in despair of access to jobs, housing, safety and decent living space.
 
JOSEPH BRANDES
Wayne, N.J., Nov. 1, 1993
 
The writer is author of "Immigrants to Freedom: Jewish Communities in Rural New Jersey since 1882."

HEADLINE: Troubled U. of Bridgeport Is Seeing a Turnaround

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 6

 BODY:
Last year 19-year-old Ricardo Perez was teaching in an institute run by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church in his native Dominican Republic. Now, he's a student at the University of Bridgeport, where he lives on campus on a full $19,000-a-year scholarship.
In many ways Mr. Perez reflects the changing student body here. After years of declining enrollment, the university is making a concerted effort to recruit students from around the globe, said Edwin G. Eigel Jr., the university's president. 
 The school says 25 percent of its 1,600 students are now from 55 countries, compared to about 10 percent of foreign students two years ago. Within a few years, Mr. Eigel said, half of the students will be from foreign countries.
The university's goal, Mr. Eigel said, is to have 1,900 students next year and 3,200 in three years. The school, which had a peak enrollment of about 9,000 in the early 1970's, had dropped to just under 1,400 last year.
The new approach at Bridgeport follows the troubled university's affiliation last year with an arm of the Unification Church, the Professors World Peace Academy, which rescued the school from financial collapse under a five-year agreement to provide $50 million in aid.
 
Deny Church Membership
 Like many students, Mr. Perez said he was not a church member. But he said he agreed with its goals and philosophy and he did not consider the church a cult. Mr. Perez said many students who were Unification Church members or attended functions would not acknowledge it.
"They are very quiet about it," he said. "It can be that there is some brainwashing, but their ultimate purpose is good. If they took over the world, that would be good because there is nothing wrong with getting people from all over the world together to study."
But Naoko Miyazawa, a 19-year-old whose parents are members of the Unification Church and sent her to the university from Gifu, Japan, said she did not trust the church and was afraid to speak against it.
"I don't like the church very much, I don't want to be in it," Ms. Miyazawa said. "But I want to study in United States and this is where parents want me."
A former student, Byung Uk Kim, a 26-year-old Korean now attending the University of New Haven, said many of his friends had been pressured unduly to attend church functions.
"I think it is happening less now because they are afraid of the bad publicity," said Mr. Kim, former president of the University of Bridgeport Korean Student Association. "But Koreans don't like to make trouble for other Koreans, so nobody wants to press any formal charges," he said.
Mr. Eigel denied that students, faculty members or administrators were being pressured by anybody associated with the Unification Church and said that if students complained that anyone was harassing them, the charges were fully investigated. "I wouldn't still be here if they were trying to influence me or anybody else in any way," Mr. Eigel said. He has been president for two years and has been on the university's staff for 14 years.
But Glenn Bassett, chairman of the management department in the school's business college, said there was clearly a church influence at the school.
"It would be kind of astonishing if there weren't, wouldn't it?" said Mr. Bassett, who has been teaching at the school for 12 years. "After all they are the people who are paying the bills. But it doesn't bother me. In my estimation there are a lot of other so-called acceptable religions that are just as cultish, if not more so, than the Unification Church."
 
Student Caliber 'the Same'
 Mr. Bassett said the overall quality of students had not diminished. "The caliber of students is the same, it's just that they are now from all over the world," he said.
Some international students said they had never heard of the Unification Church when they were recruited by the university to attend the school on full scholarship. Others said they almost did not come because of it.
"I'm worried about it and I plan to transfer out of here as soon as I can," said 21-year-old Yen Feng, a physics major from Beijing. "We all talk about it and just hope we can avoid" church members.
Missy Glenn, 18, a freshman from Chicago who came to the university to play on the women's soccer team and is on full academic scholarship, said her parents were worried at first about sending her to a school with ties to the Unification Church.
"I think the diversity here is a major plus because you get points of view from people all over the world," she said. "I really haven't seen any kind of proselytizing at all and I haven't seen any church members. If that were happening, I would leave."
The president of the senior class, Erica Roesch, said she was unaware of any students being pressured by members of the church. Ms. Roesch, who is from Stratford and has attended the school throughout its last four turbulent years, said, "I'm one of the survivors and I'm glad I'm still here. I think it would have been awful if the school had closed."
But some people, like the Coalition for Concerned Citizens, composed of clergy, elected officials, university alumni, former faculty members and city residents, think Bridgeport would have been better off if the university had closed rather than been linked to the Unification Church, which they considered to be a dangerous cult.
 
Lawsuit Filed
 The coalition, founded by City Councilman William A. Finch and Rabbi Israel Stein of Congregation Rodeph Shalom, has filed a lawsuit in Superior Court in Stamford on behalf of 14 former university donors, trustees, students and professors, who maintain the university's board of trustees entered into an illegal agreement with the Professors World Peace Academy.
The basis of the suit, according to the coalition's Bridgeport lawyer, Michael Stratton, is that the agreement allows the World Peace group to have a majority representation on the board in violation of the school's charter, which requires it to be run by an independent board.
University administrators refused to comment on the suit, and said they were busy preparing for a visit next week by an evaluation team from the New England Association of Schools and Colleges -- the commission that placed the university on probation last year -- through which more than 200 institutions in New England are regularly accredited. Concern about the school's financial situation and academic standards prompted the action. The State Department of Higher Education's board of governors issued renewed state accreditation for the university in a 7-3 vote last February, but is monitoring the school closely.
Anthony J. Guerra, associate vice president of academic affairs and a member of both the academy and the Unification Church, denied any academic involvement by the church at the university. He also said he believed the church was the target of racism.
"Many religions have been called a cult, even Christianity," said Mr. Guerra.
But Glenn Davis, a 1987 University of Bridgeport graduate who is working on his master's thesis at Wesleyan University and on a book about the decline of the University of Bridgeport, said church members control the school and just about everything that goes on there. He cautioned, however, that it is done in so subtle a way as to be barely discernible.
"They influence everything because they make the decisions and are in control of the board of trustees," said Mr. Davis. "They're using the school and will use it for their own purposes down the road. It's just bizarre that here we have a known, destructive cult running an institution of higher learning right here in our backyard. It could only happen in Bridgeport."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 9, 1993, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A photograph yesterday with an article about growing foreign student enrollment at the University of Bridgeport was published in error. The picture, at the right, showed Stacy Andriolas, a student at the university and a resident of Bridgeport, not Erica Roesch, president of the senior class.

Companies
SmithKline Beecham will give cash rebates to American consumers who buy Tagamet, an ulcer treatment, in a sharp break with pharmaceutical industry policy of not marketing prescription drugs directly to the public. The move is the latest response to pressures for lower drug prices, which have intensified with the push for national health insurance. [Page A1.] 
 Nextel will buy Motorola's "specialized mobile" radio services for $1.8 billion, expanding its plan to create a nationwide telephone system to compete with cellular by using radio frequencies once reserved for taxi and truck dispatch services. [D1.]

John Sculley made management changes at Spectrum Information, the small wireless communications company he joined after leaving Apple. The founder and two other executives resigned at Spectrum, which has been clouded by losses and lawsuits. [D1.]
Akzo of the Netherlands will buy most of Nobel of Sweden for $1.73 billion, creating the world's largest paint and coatings maker. Analysts expect other chemical industry mergers. [D4.]

International
President Clinton scrambled to gain support for Nafta among lawmakers while the White House appeared split on criticizing labor unions for opposing the pact. WHITMAN'S PLEDGE MAY MEAN SACRIFICE
If Christine Todd Whitman is going to make good on her promise to cut New Jersey income taxes, her own supporters will have to pay a part of the price, analysts say. A1. 

Mrs. Whitman's advisers point to Massachusetts and Michigan as examples of states where Republicans succeeded in reversing years of supposed Democratic profligacy. But some analysts say that the experiences of other states reveal as much about the differences with New Jersey as they do about the similarities. B6.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
ISLAMIC PHILOSOPHY BROUGHT UP AT TRIAL
A bit of Islamic moral philosophy came up in the World Trade Center trial, and so did information on why an immigration inspector at Kennedy International Airport suspected that a Palestinian was not a Swede, as the prosecution turned its attention to the movements of one of the defendants, Ahmad M. Ajaj. B3.
 
GARMENT INDUSTRY DIVIDED ON TRADE PACT
Some prominent garment manufacturers think New York City's battered economy may actually benefit if Congress approves the North American Free Trade Agreement. But other manufacturers -- and the industry's unions -- believe that the prospect of increased Mexican competition may ultimately mean their demise. D1.
 
A 50-year-old woman who had been a crossing guard at her neighborhood school for 22 years was stabbed to death in her apartment in Bushwick, Brooklyn, the police said. B3.

HEADLINE: Whitman's Budget Vow May Hurt Backers

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN

 BODY:
If Christine Todd Whitman is going to make good on her promise to cut New Jersey income taxes, her own supporters will have to pay a part of the price.
Analysts outside her circle of advisers say her task will be to persuade the suburban voters who gave her the margin of victory to sacrifice some of their most cherished government benefits, including aid to education and local governments. 
 "Is it doable? Yes. Will it be hard? Absolutely," said Michael J. Scheiring, vice president and treasurer at Thomas Edison State College in Trenton, who served as executive director of a nonpartisan commission established in 1990 by Gov. Jim Florio to review the state's budget and recommend savings.
"The real question to be asked is not whether it can be done," Mr. Scheiring added, "but just how and at what price."
 
$1.4 Billion Pledge
 In fact, Mrs. Whitman argues that other governors have already cut their budgets, notably in Michigan and Massachusetts. But others say that there are important differences in the experiences of those states that undercut the parallels. [Page B6.]
Mrs. Whitman has pledged that within three years she will find $1.4 billion to cut from a budget now running about $15.6 billion a year at a time when estimates keep climbing on just how big a gap already exists between revenue and spending.
Inevitably she will have to look at aid to municipal governments and local school districts, because they are two of the largest slices of the budget pie. They are also two areas that have powerful backers in the Legislature.
In part because of the expensive administrative duplication required by more than 600 separate school districts, New Jersey spends more per pupil on education than any other state, yet ranks below average in student achievement.
"If Christine Whitman is not willing to say no to the education establishment and take a hard stand, it is going to make it all that much harder to balance the budget," said Steven Gold, director of the Center for the Study of States in Albany.
Mrs. Whitman would also have to question a number of popular programs, like the building of even more prisons. "She would have to attack some longstanding shibboleths," Mr. Gold added. "Being 'tough on crime,' for example, is very, very expensive. The voters don't understand that. To save money, though, you would have to introduce a major reform of sentencing practices."
Other experts say that New Jersey is well behind even such traditionally generous states as New York and Massachusetts in revamping its costly Medicaid program. State spending on Medicaid has risen at an annual rate of 18 percent in recent years, from $800 million in 1989 to $2.1 billion this year.
"Introducing managed care for Medicaid, as New York is doing, will not hurt the poor and should even be to their advantage by improving primary care," said David Kehler, president of the Public Affairs Research Institute of New Jersey, a nonpartisan policy analysis organization.
Mr. Kehler said New Jersey, particularly locally, is long overdue for an in-depth review of government spending priorities. Only one-fifth of Trenton's budget goes for state operations; at least $6 billion is funneled directly to schools and municipalities.
 
Different Views in G.O.P.
 "The state has already started to tighten its belt, but you can't say the same thing has happened at the local level," he said.
Some differences have already surfaced among Republican lawmakers about how seriously to take Mrs. Whitman's plan. Donald T. DiFrancesco, the Senate President, warned immediately after the election that he may want to look at alternatives. "It's a starting point, and we're going to talk about what's doable," Mr. DiFrancesco said. "It may not be what she wants."
Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian said that he thought the cuts were realistic if the specifics were worked out through the legislative process.
Meanwhile, local political leaders are already planning their defense. They argue, as Governor Florio did, that any reduction in state aid will simply force them to increase property taxes, already among the nation's highest.
"We will cooperate with the new Governor, but we will work as hard as we can to make sure the municipal aid that we currently receive will remain intact and continue to increase," said Donald L. Fauerbach, executive director of the New Jersey Conference of Mayors. "The major urban centers are desperately in need."
 
Warning About Polarizing
 Indeed, Mayor Sharpe James of Newark said Mrs. Whitman could succeed only if she was willing to challenge her strongest supporters on their home turf. He said he feared that her election would ignite an explosive conflict between cities and suburbs over the allocation of state money.
"I would hope that the new Governor can rise to the occasion and prevent a polarizing of the state," Mr. James said. "She was elected by suburban voters and I'm worried that the cities will bear the brunt of the cuts."
During the campaign, Mrs. Whitman deliberately avoided specifying where she would find the budget savings to pay for the tax cut. She cited only a few minor examples of what she called widespread waste, like the Governor's $7 million helicopter. The rest was to be achieved through broad, but generally unspecified, budget initiatives.
Claiming as much as $500 million in savings, Mrs. Whitman listed half a dozen ideas proposed earlier by former Gov. Thomas H. Kean and by Governor Florio but never carried out. She vowed to use the governor's line-item veto to cancel $250 million in spending from this year's budget, which runs through June 1994. And she insisted she could hold the growth in state spending down to the rate of inflation, arguing that that would save $460 million.
 
Immediate Budget Crisis
 The total potential budget savings, she said in a four-page document outlining what turned out to be the keystone of her campaign, was $1.2 billion. Even without questioning whether Mrs. Whitman is counting some of the same spending cuts twice, she still fell short of the projected $1.4 billion cost of her tax-cut plan. In addition to the $1.1 billion income-tax cut, it also includes eliminating the state tax on telephone use, cutting diesel-fuel taxes and rolling back the corporate tax surcharge.
Worse, just as Governor Florio faced an unexpectedly wide budget gap when he entered office in 1990, Mrs. Whitman will be confronted by an immediate budget crisis created by Mr. Florio himself, when he used several one-time revenue gains and optimistic forecasts of tax receipts to balance this year's budget.
"Both candidates did not level with the voters about how big the budget problem is in New Jersey," said Richard C. Leone, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and former budget director for Gov. Brendan T. Byrne. "And what makes being governor so politically precarious is that the problem cannot be solved in a way that pleases the people who vote for you."
By official figures, New Jersey's shortfall totals at least $1 billion in next year's budget. The gap is probably closer to $1.7 billion, said Michael Brooks, a government bond analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, a New York investment house.
 
Spending Cuts Urged First
 "She's got a lot bigger hole than she thinks she's got," Mr. Brooks said. "Before she can even think about cutting taxes, she will have to make really substantial cuts in spending."
But Mrs. Whitman's campaign advisers argue that approving a tax cut to be phased in over three years is the best way to give her political leverage to force a major retrenchment in state spending. And, unlike the theorists around former President Ronald Reagan who argued that steep tax cuts would pay for themselves through faster economic growth, Mrs. Whitman says she intends to reduce spending dollar for dollar with tax cuts.
"Basically, what you see is what you are going to get," said Lawrence Kudlow, who devised the plan with a small team of other experts. Mr. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns, was a ranking adviser to David Stockman, Federal budget director during Mr. Reagan's first term. "She intends to do exactly what she told the voters she would do. And that means whatever it takes."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Turn Up for Treasury Issues

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Treasury market ended a sharp weeklong decline as prices advanced yesterday in advance of the Government's sale of new notes and new reports on inflation.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond gained 3/32 of a point. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 6.19 percent, from 6.20 percent on Friday. 
 Shorter-term maturities posted bigger price gains.
 
 
Positive Economic Reports
 This was the market's first broad advance since Oct. 28. Last week, a string of positive economic reports sent Treasury prices plunging and yields on the long bond soaring by nearly a quarter of a percentage point.
Analysts tied most of yesterday's price gains to strategies by investors trying to unwind speculative trading strategies.
Before last week's price plunge, many traders who expected bond prices to drop borrowed bonds and sold them short. Yesterday, these traders bought bonds at the cheaper prices, paid off their loans and pocketed the price difference in a process called short selling.
Traders do not want to be in risky trading strategies amid the uncertainty of the Treasury's auction of three-year notes today and 10-year notes tomorrow, analysts said.
In addition, the Labor Department is releasing its producer price inflation statistics today and its consumer price inflation data on Wednesday.
"Everything is sort of the anticipation of upcoming reports," said Robert Brusca, chief economist and senior vice president at Nikko Securities International.
Economists hope the reports provide more insight into whether the economy is entering a period of faster growth that could aggravate inflation pressures.
If the reports show higher-than-expected inflation, the bond market could tumble. Inflation reduces the value of fixed-income securities like bonds.
 
 
Fear of Rate Increases
 In addition, investors are concerned that the Federal Reserve may lean toward encouraging higher interest rates as a way to keep inflation from picking up. Higher rates on new securities can reduce the value of existing bonds.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, added 3.92, to 1,310.45.
In its weekly bill auction, the Treasury sold $13.8 billion of three-month bills at an average discount rate of 3.11 percent and a yield of 3.18 percent.
Another $13.9 billion of six-month bills was sold at an average discount rate of 3.28 percent and a yield of 3.38 percent.
In secondary trading, the discount rate on three-month Treasury bills held at 3.04 percent. The discount rate on six-month bills fell 2 basis points, or two-hundredths of a percentage point, to 3.22 percent. And the discount rate on one-year bills fell 5 basis points, to 3.36 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10121/32 , up 2/32 from late Friday. The average yield to maturity was unchanged at 5.65 percent. Following are the results of the Treasury's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: With Foreign Policies Under Fire, Top State Dept. Deputy Is Ousted

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration moved today to stanch the relentless criticism of its foreign policy performance by compelling the second-highest official in the State Department to resign.
Deputy Secretary of State Clifton R. Wharton Jr., the highest-ranking black official in State Department history, submitted his resignation, effective immediately, in letters to President Clinton and Secretary of State Warren Christopher, senior White House and State Department officials said. 
 Mr. Clinton and Mr. Christopher have not decided on Dr. Wharton's replacement, but they are focusing on a foreign service veteran modeled on Lawrence S. Eagleburger, who was both a Secretary of State and the deputy in the Bush Administration, senior Administration officials said.
 
Background in Education
 Mr. Christopher is said to have long complained about what he considered Dr. Wharton's lackluster performance and reportedly told Mr. Clinton several days ago that he wanted a career diplomat in the job. Dr. Wharton is a former president of Michigan State University and was chancellor of the State University of New York system.
Rumors of Dr. Wharton's resignation have circulated in Washington for weeks as the Clinton Administration has come under fire for foreign policy failures in Bosnia, Somalia and Haiti.
But Dr. Wharton, the most prominent official to be dismissed in the Administration's 10 months in office, was not directly involved in the formulation of the policies that have run into trouble. Rather, his portfolio included the reorganization of the State Department, the foreign aid budget and the restructuring of the Agency for International Development.
It is Peter Tarnoff, the State Department's third-ranking official, who holds the title of Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, who has been Mr. Christopher's representative at White House meetings of the so-called deputies committee, where initial foreign-policy formulations are made. Ultimately, of course, foreign policy is set by the President with the Secretary of State.
Senior White House and State Department officials insisted that Dr. Wharton was not being blamed for policy setbacks and that his resignation is not the beginning of a purge of other officials.
"Dr. Wharton's reasons for leaving had nothing to do with hot spots around the world, but had everything to do with his view of the job and the Secretary's view of the job," said Michael McCurry, the State Department spokesman, in a telephone interview. "Mr. Christopher offered him the opportunity to stay in Government -- perhaps as an ambassador -- but Dr. Wharton preferred to depart."
When Mr. Christopher introduced Dr. Wharton to State Department employees on Jan. 25, he praised him as "a great human being, a great American," who "can succeed in almost anything."
But Dr. Wharton resented being pigeonholed as an administrator, telling reporters shortly after he took the office that he saw himself as Mr. Christopher's "alter ego" who would make policy in his absence, not as simply a bureaucrat.
 
'Weak Member of the Lineup'
 But that did not transpire. Mr. Christopher is said to have been disappointed with Dr. Wharton's performance for several months, and returned from vacation after Labor Day determined to replace him, senior State Department officials said.
"It became apparent that he was the weak member of the lineup," said one senior State Department official. "He is leaving in order to add a heavy hitter, preferably someone with deep experience in foreign policymaking."
Another senior Administration official said, "The sense of many in the White House and the sense of Christopher himself was that they needed a deputy to take a much broader range of things in the conduct of foreign policy."
At the White House, however, senior officials said the decision to replace Dr. Wharton was made exclusively by the State Department.
State Department officials close to Mr. Christopher said Dr. Wharton never mastered the bureaucratic intricacies of the department and was slow in making decisions, such as producing a plan to revamp the Agency for International Development.
Mr. Christopher told Mr. Clinton of his intention to replace Dr. Wharton during a meeting at the White House on Oct. 19, and Mr. Clinton concurred, senior officials said.
The plan was to have Dr. Wharton stay on for a while, perhaps to the beginning of next year, after his resignation was announced, which would have given Mr. Clinton and Mr. Christopher enough time to find a suitable replacement -- and perhaps another post for Dr. Wharton.
But after Newsweek reported in October that Dr. Wharton would resign, he met twice with Mr. Christopher who told him bluntly that he was not working out, senior officials said.
 
Meeting With Christopher
 After a second article about an impending resignation appeared in The Washington Times last week, Dr. Wharton forced the issue in a meeting with Mr. Christopher on Saturday and said he wanted to leave immediately.
"He said that he had resisted the idea of coming into Government and that he had been proven right," said one senior State Department official. "He said he felt victimized by a campaign of leaks."
In a statement laced with bitterness, Dr. Wharton praised what he called his "significant contributions" to the State Department, but added, "In the past two weeks, it became unmistakably clear that I was being subjected to the classic Washington practice of sustained anonymous leaks to the media. Therefore, I decided to resign, rather than permit my effectiveness to be further eroded. I am confident that those who know me well would never accuse me of quitting in the face of adversity."
 
Eagleburger Seen as Model
 Alhthough Mr. Clinton and Mr. Christopher have not decided on Dr. Wharton's replacement, senior officials said that among those under consideration are Thomas R. Pickering, the Ambassador to Russia; Michael H. Armacost, a former Ambassador to Japan and a former Under Secretary of State; Donald F. McHenry, a former chief representative to the United Nations; Rozanne L. Ridgway, a former Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs; and Morton I. Abramowitz, a former Assistant Secretary of State for intelligence matters and now the president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
 
Other Possibilities for Job
 Less likely because they are already functioning in important Administration positions, but also under consideration, are Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, and Strobe Talbott, the Ambassador at Large for the former Soviet Union.
Of the contenders, only Mr. McHenry, a professor at Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service, is black. Mr. McHenry, who has turned down an offer to become Ambassador to Brazil, said in an interview today that the Administration had not asked him whether he is interested in Dr. Wharton's job.
White House and State Department officials insisted that Dr. Wharton's resignation was not a setback for Mr. Clinton in his drive to make his Government look as diverse as America.
"The President started out wanting a Cabinet and Government that looked like America and he remains committed to that," said Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary. "There will certainly be other African-Americans serving at the highest levels of this Administration, and the President doesn't see this as a setback in terms of diversity."
Dr. Wharton was in his office at the State Department today, but did not return phone calls.
Before he became a university administrator, Dr. Wharton was the first black leader of a Fortune 500 company as chairman and chief executive of the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association-College Retirement Equities Fund in New York, one of the world's largest pension funds, with more than $100 billion in assets.

HEADLINE: Herman Nolen, 92, Chairman Emeritus Of Drug Corporation

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Herman Christian Nolen, chairman emeritus of the McKesson Corporation, the San Francisco-based manufacturer and distributor of drugs and health and beauty care products, died on Sunday at Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 92 and lived in Delray Beach.
He suffered a brief illness after a stroke, his family said. 
 Mr. Nolen led the company, now 160 years old, during a period of strong growth and diversification. He raised eyebrows in the pharmaceutical industry when he took what was then McKesson & Robbins into the distribution of generic drugs manufactured under its control in Mexico, Colombia and the Sudan. McKesson's annual sales now top $10 billion.
Mr. Nolen, who was born and reared in Muskegon, Mich., received a bachelor's degree from the University of Wisconsin, a master's degree from the University of North Carolina and a Ph.D. from Ohio State University.
 
Wrote Book on Chain Stores
 He began his career as a professor of marketing at Ohio State, where he wrote several books, including "The Chain Store Problem," an analysis of the comparative efficiency of independent stores and chains. The 1938 volume, written with Theodore N. Beckman, was reissued in 1976 by Ayer Company Publications and remains in print.
In World War II he helped the War Production Board establish an economics section for the Allied Military Government of Occupied Territories, and served in the occupation of Sicily and Italy. In 1943, Mr. Nolen, by then a colonel, joined the Allied supreme command in England to plan the military government's program for the civilian economy of occupied Germany.
He is survived by his wife, Julia Bird Nolen; two sons, Wilson Nolen of Manhattan and Chapin Nolen of Bedford, N.Y.; a stepdaughter, Jane Stearns of West Springfield, Mass.; a sister, Helen Peterman of Muskegon, six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Panel Urges Loosening of Bonds on Business

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 8

 BODY:
In its first effort to reduce the Government's power over Japan's minutely regulated economy, a commission appointed by Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa called today for the elimination or easing of 475 regulations governing the nation's legal and economic systems.
The proposals, which were in an interim report hastily prepared so that Mr. Hosokawa can present it to President Clinton this month at a planned meeting in Seattle, were ambitious but conspicuous in their lack of details. 
 The commission proposed everything from making it simpler to open large department stores and liquor shops to encouraging housing construction and easing quotas on fish imports. It called for creation of Japan's first product liability law and something that would mark a minor revolution in a country that permits dozens of cartels -- strict application of the anti-monopoly laws.
The report offered a vision of an economy making a historic turn toward freer markets, saying at one point, "Economic activity should be founded on the basic idea of freedom from regulations in principle, with regulated areas the exception."
 
'No Sacred Cows'
 Gaishi Hiraiwa, head of a powerful business organization and chairman of the commission, said at a news conference, "Our position is there are no sacred cows."
But several experts said there was little reason to believe that the plan would achieve any more success than several previous ones aimed at reducing the country's huge trade surpluses and presenting Japan as an unthreatening citizen of the world.
In addition, an appendix to the report merely listed 475 laws by name, without specifying in most instances what should be done about them.
Japan's trading partners have long pressed Tokyo to ease its regulations to increase competition, reduce prices and make it easier for foreign companies to sell their goods. But some Japanese economists say the deregulation of Japan's markets will not necessarily lead to an increase in imports to Japan.
"In terms of Japan's surpluses, deregulation basically means nothing," said Yukio Noguchi, a leading economist and a professor at Hitotsubashi University. "This isn't the solution."
 
Rice Policy Defended
 The Government also seemed to be backpedaling on some sensitive issues already. For instance, the commission suggested that Japan should remove barriers on its rice market, a politically loaded issue. But Masayoshi Takemura, the chief cabinet secretary, quickly announced that the Government had no intention of altering its rice policy.
"As you can expect, the hard part is yet to come," Toyoo Gyohten, chairman of the Bank of Tokyo and a commission member, said in an interview.
The Advisory Group for Economic Restructuring, as it is known, was appointed several months ago by the new Prime Minister as a step toward fulfilling campaign promises to tame the government bureaucracy, reduce astronomical prices and improve the quality of life of Japanese consumers.
Many businessmen have argued that the measures, if enacted, would make it easier for entrepreneurs to innovate and help multinational companies compete in markets that are growing tougher all the time.
"In a certain sense the report grew out of the fear that the Japanese economy cannot survive in the 21st century in its present form," Mr. Gyohten said.
 
Friction With U.S.
 Not least, it was also widely hoped that the commission's recommendations would begin to whittle down Japan's surpluses and thus remove a considerable source of friction with the United States. The goal is to expand demand and revitalize domestic markets. Thus, Japan would import more, and companies here would be able to grow by servicing their home market rather than exporting.
But for the most part, the report is aimed at the domestic economy and is intended to address a silent but growing anger over the fact that the Japanese consumer has been given little of the benefit of the enormous economic might amassed here. Mr. Hosokawa is getting record approval ratings in polls in part because of a perception that he is committed to helping consumers.
"What we sensed was a very conspicuous sense of frustration, particularly from the private sector," Mr. Gyohten said. "They are simply fed up."
While economists in the West have tended to look at all capitalist economies as being basically similar because of the supremacy of the markets, the Japanese have long clung to the view that state support is essential in nurturing certain businesses and making industries competitive internationally.
 
Reducing Government Intrusion
 The fundamental policy underlying the commission's report, however, is that the time has come to reduce government intrusion in the economy. It speaks repeatedly of "the principles of self-responsibility," which means businesses have to get used to fending for themselves.
In addition, the report suggests that Japan should become a nation of laws rather than of bureaucratic fiat. Currently, bureaucrats can influence businesses using what is known as "administrative guidance," meaning dictates that are often not even written down.
The commission sought to improve prospects for the enactment of its proposals by recommending the creation of two new bodies with oversight responsibility. It suggested that the Prime Minister head one council to push for scrapping unnecessary rules and prepare a five-year deregulation program.
In addition, the commission proposed the creation of an independent body to monitor deregulation.
"This is not a panacea," Mr. Gyohten said. "It's not a bonanza for the society as a whole. Deregulation means in the first stage some loss of jobs. So we have to suffer in that sense. People have to know it's not all rosy, at least at first."

HEADLINE: Other States' Cuts, Cited by Whitman, Were Less Severe Than Her Proposals

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN

 BODY:
When Christine Todd Whitman was challenged over her plan to slash state taxes and spending in New Jersey, she often replied that if other governors could do so, so could she.
Her advisers frequently point to Massachusetts and Michigan, along with Arizona, as examples of states where Republicans succeeded in reversing years of supposed Democratic profligacy after entering office. 
 "We drew very heavily from the Michigan experience," said Lawrence Kudlow, a Wall Street economist who was instrumental in drawing up Mrs. Whitman's tax proposal. "We also looked at Massachusetts, Wisconsin and Arizona as examples of what is possible. And we looked at California, where Pete Wilson came in and accepted a large tax increase without solving the financial deficit, as how not to do it."
But others say that the experiences of other states reveal as much about the differences with New Jersey as they do about the similarities.
"In Michigan, Massachusetts and Arizona, there was very little parallel between those states and what Christine Whitman is proposing," argues Steven Gold, director of the Center for the Study of States. "They may have prevented taxes from rising, but none of them went as far as she is proposing in cutting revenues."
Michigan and Massachusetts, both major industrial states with similarly sized budgets to New Jersey, elected Republicans in 1990, following eight years under a Democratic governor.
In Massachusetts, Gov. William F. Weld managed to sharply hold down spending and instituted several smaller tax cuts despite facing a legislature controlled by Democrats. And his personal popularity remains high in a state dominated by Democratic voters.
"It certainly seems like he will be re-elected," said Gerry Chervinsky, director of a public opinion research firm who serves as the poll taker for The Boston Globe. "This is largely a middle-class, high-tax state and the cuts have been popular. He did exactly the opposite of Jim Florio in New Jersey and absolutely refused to raise taxes."
 
Conflict in Michigan
 In Michigan, Gov. John Engler has had a somewhat different experience. He is embroiled in a major political fight with a deeply divided legislature, which has approved a plan to eliminate property taxes next year as a financing source for schools. But there is no agreement between the Governor and lawmakers over how to replace the lost revenue.
According to Patty Woodworth, Michigan's budget director, Mr. Engler faced a $1.8 billion deficit when he entered office, comparable with the gap that is likely to greet Mrs. Whitman. The Michigan Governor, while managing to restore fiscal balance, has not pushed through any major tax cuts. The sharp reduction in local property taxes, worth about $6.5 billion, is destined to be almost entirely offset by other tax increases.
"Our goal is not so much to reduce the overall tax burden sharply as to redistribute it," said Ms. Woodworth, a veteran, like Mr. Kudlow, of the Federal Office of Management and Budget.
"There's no question that our property taxes will be much lower, while our sales taxes, which are low by national standards at 4 percent, will certainly rise," she said. "To attract business and individuals, we want to put ourselves more in the middle of the pack."
 
Looking to Massachusetts
 Despite some differences, the closest parallel to Mrs. Whitman's situation is probably that of Governor Weld of Massachusetts, a Republican who took office in 1991 after Michael S. Dukakis left after his failed Democratic bid for the Presidency in 1988.
Dominick Slowey, Massachusetts' assistant secretary for administration and finance, said that when Mr. Weld took over, the state faced a $2.6 billion budget gap.
The task was certainly not painless. Mr. Weld forced state workers to take unpaid furloughs as long as three weeks, denied all supplemental requests for spending and so sharply reined in the budget that spending actually fell for the first time in 31 years -- from $13.6 billion in the 1991 fiscal year to $13.4 billion in 1992.
Like Michigan, Massachusetts closed several mental hospitals, farmed out some government services to private firms, and forced thousands of people off the rolls of a special supplemental welfare program.
The state introduced managed care for Medicaid, sharply cutting the growth of health-care spending. Within 18 months, the state had a $200 million surplus. Massachusetts is now spending about $15.5 billion, almost the same as the spending in New Jersey's budget.
In addition, Mr. Weld pushed through a repeal of a sales-tax increase adopted by the previous legislature, maintained a $225 million rollback of income taxes, and achieved several additional tax cuts worth more than $250 million a year.
Mr. Weld, however, retreated from his campaign advocacy of much more extensive tax reduction after voters rejected a separate initiative on the plan. "As Governor, he cut taxes far less deeply than Christine Whitman suggests, with far greater consequences than she projects," says James Braude, director of the Tax Equity Alliance for Massachusetts, which opposed the state tax cut initiative.
Still, under Governor Weld, Massachusetts has managed to curb government spending and has started to witness a modest upswing in the state economy.
"The bureaucracy is not going to volunteer to cut itself down," Mr. Slowey said. "The only way to force the state to rein in its appetite is to take the money off the table up front."
