HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Complexities of the Middle of the Road

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
There is a certain grandeur to President Clinton's proposed Health Security Act, to the sheer reach of the thing, from Title I, Subtitle B, Section 1114, g(2A), authorizing Pap tests every two years for women aged 50 to 65, to Title X, Subtitle C, Section 10201(a), creating a 15-member Commission on the Integration of Health Benefits.
There is a certain pride in the White House over the sweep and intricacy of the 1,342 pages, which roll like the work of a bureaucratic Tolstoy from the procedures on the posterior teeth of children under the age of 13 to the borrowing authority for regional alliances to cover cash shortages. 
 "The President, in bringing his Health Security Plan to Congress, demonstrates a level of detail and comprehensiveness that is not only not seen in other plans, but is also quite unique in health care in general," said Marla Romash, a spokeswoman for the White House on health.
On benefits, premium costs, deductibles and organization matters large and small, Ms. Romash said, "the President spells it out."
But the very complexity of the plan has also emerged as one of its principal political vulnerabilities. "Having trouble understanding the Clinton health plan?" asked the conservative Heritage Foundation, reprinting a mind-numbing organizational chart for the proposed system.
Democratic and Republican lawmakers are asking about the duties, powers, interrelationships and budgets of the proposed National Health Board and the regional alliances, a new form of government -- or quasigovernment -- through which millions would buy their insurance.
 
Spelling It All Out
 Republicans warn darkly of "another Big Government bureaucratic nightmare," as Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana put it in his party's response to Mr. Clinton's recent radio address. Advocates of Government-financed systems like Canada's or Medicare writ large argue that at least people can understand how their systems would work.
Much of that is the predictable partisan and ideological positioning that would occur with any effort to overhaul the health system. Moreover, as Ms. Romash suggests, some of the initial shock of detail stems from the Administration decision to spell out in legislation what would, eventually, have to be dealt with through rules and regulations under any major plan.
For all that, the structural complexity of the Clinton plan worries some analysts, including James Q. Wilson, a professor of management and public policy at the University of California at Los Angeles. In an op-ed piece for The Wall Street Journal and in an interview, Mr. Wilson argued that Mr. Clinton's plan, with its emphasis on regulating and centralizing decisions now made by millions of people in one-seventh of the economy, was at odds with his promise to reinvent a leaner government.
 
'Managing the Complexity'
 Some critics fear that the public, already fed up with the demands of the present health system, is looking for simplicity that the Clinton plan will not deliver. Other figures in public-policy circles are beginning to wonder just how well the plan would be carried out and administered, where the expertise would come from to manage the alliances and how to retain that expertise.
"It isn't the complexity of the thing, it's managing the complexity," said Harvey Sapolsky, a professor of public policy and organization at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
The alliances, after all, do not now exist, at least not on anything like the scale envisioned by the President. But they would in a few years be created to cover virtually every American except those working for large corporations that set up their own plans.
The alliances would have numerous responsibilities like negotiating with health plans, compiling and distributing performance "report cards" and responding to complaints. They would collect premiums from employers, manage the web of subsidies for low-income employees and small businesses in their regions, negotiate fees with doctors who chose to stay outside health maintenance organizations and practice fee-for-service medicine and engage in a host of other tasks.
 
Fears of Politicization
 As the details filter out, there are more than a few jitters on Capitol Hill. A senator who sympathizes with the Clinton Administration and insisted on anonymity said he worried that the system of alliances would lead to "a huge politicization of medicine."
The cost controls are also complex. The Canadian system admired by many liberals in Congress negotiates with doctors and sets rates while setting budgets for hospitals each year. The Clinton plan seeks a more politically palatable indirect approach, through a premium cap beginning with a "national per capita baseline premium target" set by the National Health Board, adjusted for each alliance by a regional inflation factor and other variables in a formula spelled out in the bill.
The question behind the debate, of course, is whether the plan had to be so complicated. Administration officials argue that it did, simply because the system is now so intricate and fragmented, and the Administration was committed to building on that rather than scrapping it and creating something entirely new.
But the Administration also made basic decisions that pushed it toward complexity. Early on, the Administration ruled out both confining itsplan to modest changes for the industry and, at the other extreme, moving to a "single-payer," or Canadian-style system, which it considered politically unfeasible. Instead, the Administration embraced what its officials saw as a Clintonian third way, the philosophy of managed competition, a blend of market and regulatory forces.
Paradoxically, several analysts said, the effort to strengthen the market involves considerable regulation. The alliances are presented as a means of giving consumers power and encouraging competition among health plans while protecting the quality of care. But the alliances also constitute a new layer of bureaucracy and regulation.
 
'Yes, It Was Inevitable'
 The Administration also chose not to rely on competition alone to hold down costs, but decided to impose a form of budget to control costs, in the end, settling on a premium cap. That also required a more intricate administrative structure.
"Once the President made the decision that he wouldn't go all the way in either direction, either regulatory or free market, yes, it was inevitable that this would be complicated, an attempt to meld two very different visions of the way the health-care system should work," said Drew Altman, head of the Kaiser Family Foundation.
The Administration also sought a middle ground on financing, deciding against a broad-based tax and a payroll tax in particular. That led to the system of premiums with subsidies to cushion smaller low-wage businesses.
"Clearly, they made a political judgment that taxes and a more straightforward way of financing this were not going to fly in Congress," said John Rother, legislative director of the American Association of Retired Persons. "So a lot of the complexity here is an end run around the T word."
 
Rebutting an Issue
 Administration officials dismiss the notion that theirs is a Big Government solution. The shift to a single-payer system would be far more radical, they say. They also argue that their plan would replace a more complicated, and less equitable, status quo. And the President's political advisers suggest that the complexity factor is a manufactured issue.
"The insiders are wrapped up in what the organizational chart looks like," said Stan Greenberg, the President's pollster. "People don't care about that. They care about what their insurance will cover, what it will cost."
Still, there are concerns that the basics could be lost. "The tremendous complexity of the legislation and the difficulty the public has in understanding it," Mr. Altman said, "really makes them vulnerable to the spin controllers and the organized interests."

HEADLINE: Stocks Edge Upward as Dow Gains 4.47

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Apparently winded after a week of agitated trading, investors nudged stocks forward yesterday, warily holding some of their orders while waiting for the Government to release reports on inflation today and tomorrow.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 234.3 million shares, one of the lowest totals in months and about 30 million shares less than the session average for the year. Volume on the American Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq also sagged. 
 But with the bond market steady and anxiety over rising interest rates ebbing, at least for now, most of the major indicators edged up and all three markets showed breadth for the first time in a week. On the Big Board, advancing issues led declining issues by about 4 to 3.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which careered through last week, rose 4.47 points, to 3,647.90, led by Caterpillar, up 1 3/8, to 91 3/8; Procter & Gamble, up 1, to 54 3/8, and Eastman Kodak, up 7/8, to 62.
Analysts said many investors appeared cautious after the frenzy of last week, when the Dow hit two record highs before it plummeted in extremely heavy trading. The markets staged a mild recovery on Friday.
Investors are also pausing before the Government's inflation reports for October are issued, analysts said. The Producer Price Index is to be released today and the Consumer Price Index is to be released tomorrow.
Economists say they generally expect a two-tenths of 1 percent rise in producer prices and a four-tenths of 1 percent gain in consumer prices. But they caution that the indexes will be influenced by the new 4.3 cent Federal gasoline tax.
If the numbers jump sharply, the bond market may drop, forcing up yields. That will probably drag down the stock market because investors may switch from equities to fixed-rate securities. The stock market has prospered this year on a surge of money from people seeking higher returns.
"It's a relatively lackluster stock market, with a mild degree of nervousness," said Alan R. Ackerman, executive vice president at Reich & Company. "If there is a sense that inflation is not a problem, then the market is likely to do better later in the week. But it's a market that is stop and go and continues to be volatile."
Underscoring that hesitancy was the Dow Jones utilities average, which many analysts consider an important indicator of the market's direction because its components are sensitive to interest rates. The index, which hit a 10-month low last week, closed down 0.13 point yesterday, to 227.13.
The utilities index was one of the only major indicators to drop. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.64 point, to 460.21. The American Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.27 points, to 476.60. And the Nasdaq composite index rose 3.22 points, to 766.21.
High-technology, life insurance, bank, health care and automobile stocks did well yesterday, while tobacco, oil and telecommunications issues suffered.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines as Traders Profit From Recent Advance

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar fell against other leading currencies yesterday, as traders took profits from its recent rise.
"The dollar's going through a consolidation," John Nelson, vice president at Barclays, said. 
 The dollar remained weak for most of the day after dropping in early trading against both the German mark and the Japanese yen. In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 107.80 yen, down from 108.40 yen on Friday. It also fell to 1.6843 marks, from 1.6930 marks.
Gold, meanwhile, also lost ground. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery fell $2.30, to $375.50 an ounce.
"Japanese economic problems are plaguing the yen and people expect the dollar to move higher," Paul Yarden of the Bank of Montreal said. "But there's still hesitancy to buy the dollar against the yen as trade balance issues are still not resolved."
 
 
Bentsen Concerned Over Japan
 In the past, a weaker dollar has been used to battle Japan's huge trade surplus with the United States. But lately the dollar has been rising because of the severely weak Japanese economy.
The Treasury Secretary, Lloyd Bentsen, urged Tokyo yesterday to stimulate consumer spending and expressed concern that Japan's economy seemed to be slowing. He also said he was comfortable with current exchange rates.
Later yesterday, a senior United States Treasury official said Japan looked unlikely to put forward a plan to stimulate its economy before Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa meets President Clinton in Seattle later this month.
Despite yesterday's setback to the dollar, dealers noted that overall market sentiment remained bullish. A recent advance in American interest rates has made dollars more attractive, since rates in Europe, Japan and Canada are falling.
The British pound, meanwhile, closed in New York at $1.4810, down from $1.4840 late Friday. Other late dollar rates, compared with Friday's quotes, included: 1.4845 Swiss francs, down from 1.4933; 5.8665 French francs, down from 5.8850; 1,643 Italian lire, down from 1,646, and $1.2960 (Canadian), up from $1.2914 (Canadian).

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chief of CVS Unit Promoted To President's Job at Melville

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Melville Corporation said yesterday that Harvey Rosenthal, president and chief executive of its CVS drugstore unit, would become its president and chief operating officer in January.
Mr. Rosenthal, who is 50, has headed CVS, which is Melville's largest subsidiary, since 1984. He joined CVS in 1969 after earning an M.B.A. from the Harvard Business School. 
 Mr. Rosenthal succeeds Stanley P. Goldstein, Melville's 59-year-old chairman and chief executive, as president. Mr. Goldstein will retain his other posts. The chief operating officer's post is newly created.
Melville said Thomas M. Ryan, 41, would succeed Mr. Rosenthal at CVS. He is currently the subsidiary's executive vice president of operations.
When he was a CVS executive, Mr. Goldstein had a hand in hiring Mr. Rosenthal, and the two men have worked together ever since.
"Over the years Harvey Rosenthal and Stanley Goldstein have had a very, very close relationship," said Robert Roth, a securities analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company.
 
Promotion Based on Perfromance
 But Mr. Roth said Mr. Rosenthal's promotion was based on performance, not on friendship. During his tenure at CVS, sales have risen to around $4 billion, roughly 40 percent of Melville's annual revenues.
And in a telephone interview, Mr. Goldstein indicated the appointment does not represent Mr. Rosenthal's appointment as his successor.
"Clearly, Harvey is a strong candidate," Mr. Goldstein said. "But I am 59 years old and plan to be here for quite a while."
Mr. Rosenthal will join Mr. Goldstein and Robert D. Huth, Melville's 47-year old executive vice president and chief financial officer, at the top of Melville's management.
With Mr. Rosenthal's background in sales and marketing, Mr. Roth said, the executive's primary task will be to put some bounce in Melville's earnings, which he said had been "fairly sluggish, even compared with other retailers." Melville is one of the country's largerst speciality retailers. Based in Rye, N.Y., the company owns Marshalls, Medisco, Key-Bee toy stores and other stores.
In a separate interview, Mr. Rosenthal said consumers, who have been extremely cautious for several years, are beginning to show some signs of life.
"In recent years retailing has been impacted by the economy and the recession, particularly on the East and West coasts, where many of Melville's stores are located," he said. "But little by little we think we are seeing improvement, and we are optimistic about 1994."
Mr. Goldstein said Mr. Rosenthal "comes at things through the customer's eyes and mind and has proven he has been able to adjust to the changes that have taken place in an extremely competitve, deflationary environment."
In addition to his M.B.A., Mr. Rosenthal also received an A.B. from Harvard. He and his family will relocate to the New York area from Woonsocket, R.I., where CVS is based.

HEADLINE: In Los Angeles, a Museum on a Roller Coaster

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The earth didn't actually quake. But to those at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, the effects of the last 18 traumatic months may make it feel as if the Big One had hit.
The museum was still enjoying tremendous growth when its director, Earl A. Powell 3d, resigned in April 1992 to head the National Gallery in Washington, one of the most prestigious jobs in the arts in America. From a fledgling institution in 1965, it had become the most comprehensive art museum west of Chicago. More than $80 million of private money had been raised during Mr. Powell's 12-year regime to put up new buildings to house the growing collection and the blockbuster exhibitions that regularly stopped there. Annual operating costs had topped a whopping $30 million, but the museum felt secure that about half of that would be picked up by the County of Los Angeles under a contractual commitment any museum could envy. 
 Now this museum finds itself digging out from the rubble of the last year and a half. The most wrenching and visible sign of crisis was the shockingly brief tenure of Mr. Powell's replacement, Michael E. Shapiro, who struggled in vain to deal with problems for which he himself admits he was not prepared.
The museum boomed in the 80's, when Los Angeles did. So when the city slumped in the 90's, the museum was perhaps bound to suffer, too. The riots didn't make it easier in straitened economic times for an art institution and its new white male director to compete for dwindling public money.
Mr. Shapiro found himself in a financial quagmire. Amid Southern California's deep recession, millions of dollars of supposedly immutable county support for the museum disappeared. So did a substantial chunk of the museum's membership. The loss of income forced dozens of staff cutbacks, helped spur resignations and compelled the museum to shut its doors two days a week instead of one.
On top of it all, disgruntled staff members and major donors entangled the museum in litigation. This added to a bitter atmosphere in which trustees wrangled among themselves about how to overcome the turmoil they had failed to anticipate, even as they remained fixed on further expansion.
In some ways, the story of the Los Angeles County Museum is emblematic of problems that cultural institutions across the country face. During the flush years of the 80's, museums organized one lavish loan show after another, and constructed one new wing after another in which to hold them. Bigger was often simply assumed to be better. Socking away endowment money as security seemed unglamorously and unduly bearish in bullish times. Now some of these organizations find themselves burdened with operations they can't support.
At the same time, as the 10-month tenure of Mr. Shapiro illustrates, museum directors who can successfully grapple with the new and complex jumble of financial and artistic challenges are as rare as Michelangelos, if not rarer.
In an atmosphere of shrinking resources and increasing competition, major museums from the Museum of Modern Art in New York to the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston to the Seattle Art Museum are all looking for directors who combine the talents of Lee Iacocca and Bernard Berenson. The problem is: who can fit that bill?
Mr. Shapiro was a neophyte, a curator at the St. Louis Art Museum with no directorial experience when, to the surprise of many museum professionals, he won the job here. Mr. Powell had also been a youthful curator when he became director, and the trustees remembered that. They were persuaded, too, by Mr. Shapiro's innovative ideas about education and community involvement, as well as by his artistic expertise. What trustees describe as his eloquent talk about making the museum more accessible and relevant to the diverse population of Los Angeles identified him, they felt, as the ideal man for the 90's.
To ask the trustees what went wrong at the museum is to hear a rehearsed chorus. "We were blindsided," said Julian Ganz Jr., the chairman of the trustees' executive committee. "No one could have seen it coming." He was referring to the county's decision to make severe cuts in funds to the museum shortly after Mr. Powell's resignation and before Mr. Shapiro's arrival. "We have a contract with the county," Mr. Ganz added, "and it is not living up to the terms of that contract. The county was like a $350 million endowment."
Yet even before Mr. Powell left there had been signs that the recession would have an effect on the museum; for one thing, memberships started to drop. Roughly half the cost of running the place comes from the county, but the other half comes from private contributions, like membership, admission fees, gifts and endowment, so that even if the county had not cut back subsidies from $16.9 million to what is now $13.4 million a year, the museum would have had a money crunch.
Having raised tens of millions to build new galleries bearing the names of their donors, the trustees had never seen the need to put together an endowment to cover operating costs, banking on the county and on steady membership to pay the bills. The museum's endowment of around $22 million is minuscule for a large urban museum.
Robert F. Maguire 3d, the current board president, concedes the point: "We were hit by two things. One was the county cuts. Should we have anticipated them? Maybe. Second, on the private side, the giving went down about the same amount. Should we have had additional private endowment? Sure."
About whether the museum, like others around the country, had imprudently emphasized growth during the 80's under Mr. Powell, setting the stage for trouble, Daniel Belin, the chairman of the museum, insists the answer is no. "The museum has to present itself as the vehicle through which great art can be shown to the public," he said. "Otherwise the collector and donor won't respond. That's why it was essential to build the new buildings."
 
 
Galleries
Space Is Available: What to Put in It?
 The Robert O. Anderson building, a wing of the museum opened in 1986, was built not only to add exhibition and gallery space but also to entice collectors of 20th-century art in a city that has some especially large and distinguished modern art collections.
No such collectors, however, have pledged what they own to the museum since Anderson opened, and now the rival Museum of Contemporary Art is stiffening the competition. "The 20th-century collections have expanded, but we have not attracted large collections," Mr. Belin acknowledges. "It's on a picture-by-picture, sculpture-by-sculpture basis."
More than one architecture critic has said that the hodgepodge of buildings the museum has constructed, beginning with the trio of dull modernist boxes that the firm of William L. Pereira & Associates designed in 1965, turned it into a kind of world's fairgrounds. Individual patrons focused on their own pavilions, but there was no coherent overall scheme.
Anderson had, in fact, been advertised as a structure that would unify the group of buildings, but it failed to do so, as Mr. Maguire, a developer known for the high architectural quality of his own projects, admits. "We have an amalgam of buildings that have to be pulled together architecturally," he says. "We have to come up with a rational, functional plan."
The same is true for the wide-ranging collection. Everyone at the museum points proudly to sheer breathtaking growth under Mr. Powell's directorship, but Mr. Maguire and his fellow trustees are hard pressed to come up with areas of it that are highly distinguished on a national level. The strengths of the museum's holdings make for an oddly disjointed list: the Robert Gore Rifkind Center for German Expressionist Studies, the Arthur Gilbert collection of decorative arts. The museum conspicuously failed to win, among other great Southern California collections, Walter Annenberg's Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings. Asian art, which includes some of the museum's strongest material, has always been treated as a stepchild, as it is in many American art museums.
Furthermore, when the institution opened beside the La Brea tar pits on Wilshire Boulevard 28 years ago, there was little competition in the Los Angeles area. Now there is not only the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art but also the J. Paul Getty Museum and the Norton Simon Museum, which owns the world's finest collection of European paintings put together after World War II.
 
 
Leadership
Lawsuits, Grousing And Other Troubles
 Mr. Maguire says that "all of the museums in the area could profit from working closely together in terms of programming." And before a new director is picked, he adds, the board must finally deal substantively with the museum's mission, a mission that he believes should take more into account the interests of the area's growing Asian and Hispanic populations. "Where is the public we are trying to serve?" he asked.
That is a question Mr. Shapiro also asked. But before he could answer it he was out the door. Almost everyone at the museum praises him for his good ideas and intelligence, and points out that not even an experienced director could have dealt easily with the crisis of the county cutbacks and the layoffs that followed.
But Mr. Shapiro revealed his inexperience in removing Maurice Tuchman, a longtime senior curator of 20th-century art, from his job, which prompted a lawsuit by Mr. Tuchman. Even those at the museum who privately say that after more than 25 years Mr. Tuchman had been in his job long enough feel that Mr. Shapiro's attempt to move him into a new post as head of 20th-century drawings was botched: the director failed to understand the intricacies of county employee rights, they point out, and tried to argue that the removal was based on minor job infractions. At the beginning of November, the museum announced that the suit had been resolved out of court and that Mr. Tuchman was to be returned to his post.
A number of trustees also complained that Mr. Shapiro lacked managerial and personal skills. Joe D. Price, a one-time trustee who gave the museum his major collection of Japanese screens and paid for the idiosyncratic building designed by Bruce Goff to house it, became increasingly disgruntled during Mr. Shapiro's tenure. Eventually he, too, filed suit against the museum, contending that the terms of his donation had not been honored and that some screens he had lent the museum should be returned.
Mr. Shapiro also annoyed officials at other museums when he said he wanted to back out of a traveling retrospective they were organizing of the work of the contemporary painter R. B. Kitaj because he was not an enthusiast of the artist. (The show is now back on the schedule.)
Finally, some senior curators, while appreciating Mr. Shapiro's attempts to involve them more in decision-making, stewed over why one of their own from a smaller museum had been chosen as their superior, and moreover why they had not even been consulted by the trustees before his appointment. "There was no honeymoon period," Mr. Shapiro says, who since leaving in August has moved back to St. Louis.
He concedes he made some mistakes out of inexperience, the first and most critical of which was his failure to get a clear picture of the museum's finances before he took the job. "No question about it," he said. "I'll be so careful next time that they'll think Price-Waterhouse is coming at them."
The chastened trustees -- although not unanimous on this point -- may do things differently themselves next time calling for advice from staff members and outsiders as "sounding boards," said Mr. Maguire, who in the meanwhile has put Stephanie Barron, a longtime and respected curator of 20th-century art, in charge of curatorial affairs. Ronald B. Bratton, the chief deputy director, oversees administrative and financial matters.
 
 
The Future
The Positive Spin: Others Worse Off
 If some officials of the Los Angeles County Museum privately express anxiety about the future of the institution, everyone knows how bad news can deter potential donors, employees and loans for exhibitions. So publicly the museum is united in trying to put the same positive spin on the current situation: it is nothing like the one at the Detroit Institute of Arts, they point out, where cutbacks in public money combined with an inadequate endowment have forced the museum to the brink of shutdown.
The museum here, staff members and trustees insist, went through a rough period but has come out of it debt-free and wiser. Some county cutbacks have already been recouped. Lawsuits, like the ones involving Mr. Tuchman and Mr. Price, are being resolved. And both trustees and the county understand the symbolic and practical importance of returning the museum quickly to a normal six-day schedule. Some younger, enthusiastic trustees are bringing a fresh perspective to the notoriously fractious board, and while important curators have left, and positions remain unfilled, Mr. Shapiro added J. Patrice Marandel as head of European paintings and sculpture to a staff that is still good. There is also a full slate of important exhibitions, some organized by the museum, like "Expressionist Utopias" and the forthcoming "Picasso and the Weeping Women."
"We're here, we're active, we're engaged," says Ms. Barron.
The museum is even on the verge of further expansion, contemplating the construction of a roughly $5 million sculpture garden, as well as the acquisition, for somewhere between $15 million and $20 million, of more than eight acres near the museum, a site occupied by the landmark May Company department store. Finally, a joint lawsuit by the museum and Stanford University against the Church of Christ, Scientist, over the complicated disposition of the estates of two wealthy Christian Scientists is nearing a settlement, to be heard by the courts on Dec. 14. It could provide a windfall of nearly $24 million to the museum, more than doubling the meager endowment.
But whether all that means the museum is fully on track is another matter. Without a clear sense of the shape and scope of the institution on which they can all agree, the trustees have yet to prove they have overcome the strategic confusion that led to Mr. Shapiro's tenure.
They are agreed on one issue: Before any successor is even considered, a firm contract concerning the county's support, this time with a specific dollar amount, must be worked out. Moreover, Mr. Maguire adds, "It's going to be important for the board to commit to specific amounts of endowment for acquisitions and operating costs."
He did not say where the millions upon millions of dollars for an endowment adequate to help safeguard the biggest museum in Los Angeles will come from.

HEADLINE: Old Tablet From Turkish Site Shows Early Spread of Culture

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
NEW discoveries in Turkey and northern Syria, two buried cities and intriguing clay tablets with cuneiform writing, are expanding the known horizons of early urban civilization and literacy well beyond the Sumerian city-states of southern Mesopotamia.
Archeologists say the discoveries are among the most exciting in Mesopotamian studies in recent decades. They are confident that further excavations at the sites will provide answers to one of the most important questions in archeology: how and when did the phenomena of urban living and the first writing spread from their place of origin more than 5,000 years ago in the lower valley of the Tigris and Euphrates rivers far into adjacent regions? 
 Working in the Balikh River valley of southern Turkey, near the Syrian border, a team of American and Turkish archeologists found traces of a large city that apparently flourished in 2600 B.C. A single tablet with cuneiform inscriptions, the earliest known writing system, was found lying on the surface, prompting hopeful speculation that other, more revealing tablets would eventually be uncovered.
Dr. Patricia Wattenmaker, an archeologist at the University of Virginia and director of the excavations, said the discovery should overturn conventional thinking that confined the development of large urban centers of the period to southern Mesopotamia and dismissed the cultures to the north and west as mere backwaters. Further research, she said, could extend the known range of early literacy.
Preliminary excavations indicate that the site, known as Kazane Hoyuk, holds the remains of a city that spread over at least 250 acres, large for its time and place. One tentative hypothesis is that these are the ruins of Urshu, a northern city mentioned in some Sumerian texts.
"Kazane's a huge place," said Dr. Glenn Schwartz, an archeologist at Johns Hopkins University who is familiar with the discovery, "and has to have been one of the most important political and economic centers of its region."
The other discovery that has excited archeologists is the buried ruins of a smaller city of the third millennium B.C. at Tell Beidar in northern Syria. There European and Syrian archeologists have found a well-preserved temple, administrative buildings and a collection of as many as 70 clay tablets with Sumerian writing and Semitic names, as well as many other tablet fragments. And they have only begun to dig.
"It's the most spectacular find this year in Syria," said Dr. Marc Lebeau, the leader of the discovery team, who is president of the European Center for Upper Mesopotamian Studies in Brussels.
 
Dating of Tablets
 Preliminary analysis places the time of the tablets and other artifacts at about 2400 B.C., during the Sumerian ascendancy in southern Mesopotamia and just before the rise of the Akkadian empire under Sargon the Great. The tablets that have been deciphered appear to be bureaucratic records of a robust economy, including lists of donkeys, oxen and sheep and the names of towns and villages.
Dr. Harvey Weiss, a Yale University archeologist, recently visited Tell Beidar and said that it and Kazane Hoyuk "prove everything we've been saying about northern Mesopotamia for many years," namely that the cuneiform archive discovered in 1974 at Ebla, also in Syria, was not an anomaly but strong evidence of the widespread expansion of Sumerian urban civilization, beginning as early as 2600 B.C.
If Ebla, near the city of Aleppo, revealed the civilization's western progression, excavations by Dr. Weiss at Tell Leilan, begun in 1979, produced the first strong evidence of its northern reach. Tell Leilan, identified as the ancient walled city of Shubat Enlil that experienced sudden growth in 2500, lies on the fertile plains of Syria near the borders of Turkey and Iraq. Nearby is the European dig site of Tell Beidar. Farther north is Kazane Hoyuk, at least twice as large as Tell Beidar and the same size as Tell Leilan or larger.
Other scholars had previously failed to recognize this expansion phenomenon mainly because the most thorough excavations had until recently been confined to the Sumerian heartland in the lower Tigris and Euphrates valley.
 
New View of Mesopotamia
 "People used to think of ancient Mesopotamia as small and restricted, but not any longer," said Dr. Elizabeth Stone, an archeologist at the State University of New York at Stony Brook.
The two discoveries were made over the last two summers, but the results have only now become known by word of mouth (and computer mail) to many other archeologists. The details and their implications were discussed in interviews last week.
Dr. Wattenmaker was driving on the road south of the modern Turkish city of Urfa when she saw a prominent mound in the fields near an irrigation canal. In her initial survey last year, pottery shards were found scattered over the ground. Some were as much as 7,000 years old. Others were at least 4,500 years old and in the Sumerian style.
This and other evidence gathered this year indicated that the site had been occupied almost continuously since 5000 B.C., and so should provide evidence of the transition from a simple farming society to an urban culture. It grew to be a large city about 2600 B.C. and was abandoned for an unknown reason around 1800 B.C.
A worker found the baked clay tablet lying on the surface. It is 22 inches by 22, and encrusted in dirt. Cleaning away some of the dirt, archeologists saw the wedge-shaped cuneiform inscriptions typical of early writing, which was first developed by Mesopotamians about 5,000 years ago.
Scholars are especially cautious in their assessment of the tablet because it was a "stray find." It was picked up on the ground, out of context with archeological ruins and in an area that had been disturbed by construction of the canal. Still, they said it appeared to be genuine and from the third millennium B.C.
"It's a tease," said Dr. Piotr Michalowski, a specialist in Sumerian and Babylonian languages at the University of Michigan, who is examining photographs of the tablet inscriptions. "It doesn't tell you much. It is not a connected narrative of any sort, just signs and not very good ones. Somebody might have been practicing writing, and wasn't good at it."
 
Speculation of Literacy
 Since early writing was associated with official record-keeping related to the collection and distribution of grain and goods and since Kazane Hoyuk was a city on known trade routes, Dr. Michalowski said: "I will stick my neck out and say it had to be a literate society. Other tablets may be found there. I've always thought Ebla was only a symptom of a much more widespread literacy in this period."
Although archeologists said they could not yet determine the ancient name of this city, Dr. Michalowski said there was a "good degree of probability" that it was Urshu, which Sumerian inscriptions of 2100 B.C. refer to as a city in the highlands of Ebla; that would put it at some distance to the northwest. The site of Urshu has never been identified. But confirmation of this surmise will have to await the discovery of more and better tablets.
Dr. Wattenmaker plans more excavations, looking for tablets and other evidence regarding the nature of economic and social forces that contributed to the rise of centralized government and urban society. Her research team included archeologists from the Universities of Chicago and Virginia, Istanbul University and the Urfa Museum.
Preliminary study of the tablets at Tell Beidar, Dr. Lebeau said, showed that they are approximately the same age as the Ebla archive, probably a century or two later than the Kazane Hoyuk fluorescence, and that they provide a clear link between this ancient city, Ebla in the west and southern Mesopotamia.
These are the first tablets of this period to be found in northern Syria, and archeologists expect to find more as they dig deeper at the site. The discovery team included archeologists from Belgium, France, Germany, the Netherlands, Spain and Syria.
The new discoveries, Dr. Weiss said, were further evidence for the sudden rise beginning around 2600 B. C. of cities in nearly all directions beyond the bounds of southern Mesopotamia and may help account for this expansion. Was this the consequence of trade among independent people or incipient colonialism and imperialism? If these burning questions in Mesopotamian archeology can be answered, scholars will still be left to ponder the bigger question of how state societies and urban civilization happened to begin then and there in the first place.

HEADLINE: MARATHON;
Lebow's Mettle Earns French Medal

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr.

 BODY:
Countdown week for next Sunday's New York City Marathon got under way at Tavern on the Green in Central Park yesterday with the usual tokens of hype and of hoopla, from the over-sized athletic shoe behind the podium at the morning news conference to the presentation of the official medal of the French City of Caen to Fred Lebow.
You know Fred Lebow. According to Caen's deputy mayor, Paul Dubourget, everybody in France does. And what's more, the French are so taken with Lebow's sheer, shining human will in overcoming brain cancer and completing his 69th marathon last year that they plan to honor him from here to France. 
 Among other things, Lebow, who is reverting from runner to race director this year, will receive the French Order of Merit. He will also run in a 14-kilometer race that is a satellite to the annual Liberty Marathon, run along the invasion beaches of Normandy to the World War II Memorial museum in Caen.
The 1994 races, on June 12, will be special, partly because they will be held in connection with the celebration of the 50th anniversary of the Normandy invasion on June 6, and partly because the shorter race, formerly known as the Pegasus, after the bridge at its starting point that was the first French territory to be liberated on D-Day (by British glider troops at 16 minutes past midnight) will be renamed the Fred Lebow Challenge.
"I've run in more than 1,000 races," Lebow said, "but never in one named for me."
 
 
Hot or Cold?
 The fact that the Nov. 14 race date is the latest in the New York City Marathon's history has stirred a debate between Lebow and Allan Steinfeld, the technical director. Because this past Sunday was very cold, Lebow expects frigid weather. For the very same reason, Steinfeld expects a warm day. The National Weather Service, citing a southeastern storm that was knocking all the models out of whack, said yesterday that it was a coin flip. For the record, the normal high for the date is 55 degrees, the low is 42, and if you want to prepare for the worst, the records were 71 in 1980 and 20 in 1905. There were also 2.23 inches of rain in 1972 and one inch of snow in 1911. Mush.
 
Helping Hands, and Feet
 He's said it before, but this time Fred Lebow means it. Really. The number of starters, which has been growing alarmingly, to a course-choking 28,656 last year, will be held down to 26,000 or so.
The runners will also be held back to prevent the premature starts that have marred a couple of previous races. For one thing, because construction at the Pulaski Bridge has required routing the course over longer lanes, the three starting lines will be moved up a compensating 40 yards or so, which means the main blue men's starting line will be narrowed considerably, making crowd control easier.
To make it easier still, the volunteer monitors who were required to move out of the way of the impatient, surging throng a minute or so before the starting canon will be replaced by 200 runners from the police and fire departments. As official competitors, they will be able to keep their front-row positions until the start. They will be given special hats, but will have to supply their own billy clubs.
 
More Sponsors Than Miles
 As befitting an enterprise that has an estimated $80 million impact on the local economy, Marathon Inc. is big business. The front pocket of the 116-page press manual's loose-leaf binder is stuffed with individual releases from seven major and 11 "sporting" sponsors. (The 10 "associate" sponsors get only listings.)
You probably knew that Mercedes is the official marathon car, that Ronzoni is the official marathon pasta, and maybe even that the Rudins are the official marathon family. But did you know that Blimpie is the official marathon sandwich, that Arnoff is the official marathon mover and that Browning-Ferris is the official marathon recycler -- primarily of the 2 million or so cups and 150,000 plastic bottles expected to be discarded by runners using Vermont Pure Natural Spring Water, the official marathon water, and Gatorade, the official marathon sports water.
 
Better Than the Stanley Cup!
 With a roster of such former runners as Bobby Murcer, Jean-Claude Killy, Ingemar Johansson and Floyd Patterson, the New York City Marathon has long attracted cross-over celebrity athletes.
This year's entries include Lynn Swann, the 41-year-old former Steeler receiver, who will make his marathon debut, and Bobby Nystrom, the 41-year-old former Islander forward, who will be making his second run, after finishing in 3 hours 40 minutes in 1991.
Whatever his time this year, Nystrom would seem fairly sold on the marathon. Or, as the man who helped the Islanders win four Stanley Cups, and scored the overtime goal which won the first one, put it yesterday, "Finishing the marathon was probably the most thrilling experience of my life."

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook: Nationalist China or Nationalist Taiwan?;
Democracy Raises An Inconvenient Issue

BYLINE: By DAVID C. UNGER

 BODY:
Americans who still think of Taiwan as "Nationalist China" are in for a shock. The most conspicuous nationalism to be encountered on the island these days is not Chinese but Taiwanese.
It's based on the idea that the immigrants who arrived from the Chinese mainland centuries ago created a new and distinctive society, just as the English colonists who settled America or Australia did. Taiwanese nationalists point out that for only four years this century has their island been under mainland rule. 
 Taiwanese nationalists distinguish themselves from "mainlanders" -- the families of those who fled mainland China with Chiang Kai-shek after he lost the civil war there in 1949. Using that definition, about 85 percent of the island's present inhabitants are Taiwanese. But even most of today's "mainlanders" are Taiwan-born children of mainland parents.
Taiwanese nationalism isn't just a cultural curiosity. In the five years since President Lee Teng-hui, himself a Taiwanese, began dismantling Chiang Kai-shek's police state, Taiwanese politics has increasingly come to reflect public opinion. Taiwanese nationalism now finds powerful political expression in the call to abandon also Chiang's claim to be the lawful government of China, and to declare, instead, an independent Republic of Taiwan.
Independence is the official rallying cry of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party. And it even has some sympathizers within the ruling Chinese Nationalist Party, or Kuomintang. Already, Taipei has begun to press for its own United Nations seat.
There's a real chance, then, that a pro-independence government could take power in Taipei this decade. If saner heads prevail on both sides of the Taiwan Straits, this needn't necessarily lead to crisis. But because Beijing openly threatens to greet any moves toward Taiwan independence with military force, the issue could bring on a large-scale regional confrontation.
Most Asian Pacific nations, the U.S. included, would prefer not even to think about such a dangerous possibility. Understandably, they give priority to their relations with mainland China, a country with many more people, regional military power and an expanding marketplace.
Taiwan is no superpower. But its 22 million people, dynamic capital-exporting economy and increasingly vibrant democracy make it impossible for Americans or Asians to be indifferent to its fate.
The sensible course is to begin diplomatic efforts now to pre-empt any future military confrontation. That involves working out broadly acceptable formulas to reinforce Taiwan's present political and economic autonomy and to include Taiwan in the regional economic and security organizations now taking shape.
For Washington, it always seems to be the wrong moment to raise new contentions into an already troubled relationship with Beijing. But waiting for the right moment poses even more serious risks.
At President Clinton's invitation, Taiwan and Beijing will both be represented at this month's Asia Pacific economic summit meetings in Seattle. That makes it a fitting occasion to begin thinking and talking with regional leaders about an issue that isn't going to go away. DAVID C. UNGER

HEADLINE: The 'Great Debate' Over Nafta

 BODY:
Were it not for the fact that truly serious issues are involved, the caterwauling over the North American Free Trade Agreement would be almost comic.
On one side we have a populist President frantically wooing the Republican establishment to round up the 30 or so votes he needs to get Nafta through the House. Standing the usual political coalitions on their heads, Mr. Clinton has courted familiar G.O.P. luminaries like Henry Kissinger, James Baker and even Senator Bob Dole, while accusing his erstwhile allies in the labor movement of using "naked pressure" and "muscle-bound tactics" to defeat the agreement. 
 On the other side we have Ross Perot, warning that Nafta is a giant plot against the American worker and delighting in the chance to tweak the big boys and rebuild his slightly tattered reputation as the People's Tribune.
To top it all off, Nafta, a complex issue of no small consequence to millions of Americans, Canadians and Mexicans, will be "debated" tonight on the Larry King show, a forum better suited to the sound-bite demagoguery of which Mr. Perot is an acknowledged master than to the deadpan analysis preferred by his opponent, Vice President Al Gore.
Nafta deserves better. The laboriously constructed agreement to phase out trade barriers among the U.S., Mexico and Canada, which this page has strongly supported, is likely to have a positive, though small, impact on U.S. living standards and provide a modest boost to the Mexican economy. Some American jobs would be lost to cheaper Mexican labor, other jobs would be gained because American exports would increase as Mexico's high tariffs gradually disappeared.
Economics aside, Nafta's defeat would suggest that the U.S. had abandoned its historical commitment to free trade and would thus discourage other Latin and South American countries that (as Washington has long suggested) have moved toward more market-oriented economies in the expectation of freer world trade.
Mr. Perot dismisses the foreign policy implications while manhandling the economic data. In a nine-month anti-Nafta crusade that has taken him to 43 states and 91 cities, he has warned that Nafta would cause American industry and agriculture to flee south with "a giant sucking sound" toward cheaper Mexican labor, costing Americans 5.9 million jobs.
This is an absurd calculation that Mr. Perot, made giddy perhaps by his resurgent notoriety, has now taken to truly stratospheric levels of exaggeration. On Sunday in Tampa, he told a cheering, stomping audience that 85 million people could lose their jobs under Nafta, which is just about everyone in the American work force. "Eighty-five million people can elect anybody -- anybody!" he cried. "Do you hear that, White House?"
There's no telling how Al Gore will handle this sort of hyperbole. Ed Rollins, a Republican consultant who worked for Mr. Perot's Presidential campaign before quitting in disgust, predicts that Mr. Perot will "chew up Al Gore and spit him out. Gore will give intellectual answers, and Perot will hit the emotional buttons and spit out sound bites."
However, this overlooks the fact that Ross Perot hasn't really debated anyone on the issue; his recent anti-Nafta campaign has consisted almost entirely of monologues with adoring audiences. And while Mr. Gore certainly cannot match the Texas bantamweight sound bite for sound bite, his grasp of dull detail may be just what the Nafta discussion needs.
Nothing will quiet Mr. Perot's incessant chatter. But a sober presentation of something resembling the truth about Nafta might persuade Larry King's audience, including Congress, to think again about Mr. Perot's distortions.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Grovel and Pander

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Ross Perot? He is a team player and yes, he might be considered for a job in Bill Clinton's cabinet.
Who said that? Al Gore, when he was running for Vice President. 
 Ross Perot? He is a man of such standing and dignity and so full of ideas that a great flock of Americans lifts off simultaneously from all over the country, flying to Dallas. They crowd the platform around him, to praise him before the nation and ask for his approval.
Who did that? Why, the country's top Democrats and Republicans -- members of Congress, financiers, large thinkers. And who told them to do it? Bill Clinton, George Bush and their political handlers, a month before Election Day in 1992.
They said it, they did it, and they made embarrassments of themselves. That is their business, I suppose. But what the Democrats and Republicans also accomplished in the great grovel of 1992 is the business of the country. They accomplished the empowerment of Ross Perot.
Instead of fighting him, telling Americans what they really thought of him, that he was a demagogue, a political hustler, a chronic quitter, making suckers of voters in the snake-oil school of American politics, whacko but not funny, they just groveled, pandered and simpered.
The motive was to win over some Perot followers, maybe even get a pat on the head from the leader. The result was they helped him parlay his wealth into 19 percent of the national vote, plus four years front and center to try for more percentage points, a whole White House more.
Now Mr. Clinton, less than a year into his first term, finds that Ross as Boss already endangers Nafta, a keystone endeavor of his Administration. And look -- he is likely to endanger other cherished goals in the three years to come, including a second term.
We will not say we told you so, will we? No, we will just count our few little blessings and give thanks that win or lose, Nafta is paying off in the decision to confront Mr. Perot.
Supporters of Nafta should hope that Mr. Gore is better than Mr. Clinton in spelling out what he is for and against. The Vice President will be for, I assume, a treaty that he thinks can bring a better economic day to the United States, Mexico and Canada. He is against H. Ross Perot, and has come to the conclusion that he is not a team player after all.
But I hope he does not turn his support for Nafta into a blunderbuss attack on Americans who exercise their constitutional right to be afraid for their jobs, correctly or not, and have the nerve to say so.
On "Meet the Press" Mr. Clinton decided that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. was behaving "real roughshod" for doing what all big lobbies do -- lobby, real roughshod.
I do not like unions threatening to defeat Representative Nancy Pelosi because she supports Nafta. She is a Democrat who is one of the best reasons for moving to San Francisco despite the weather. But I like even less the threats of other lobbies -- like the gun lobby campaigning against Congressional dissidents. Guns kill, not union cards.
The Administration has failed to convince labor after it had a full chance to do so. Denouncing American labor now will simply help Mr. Perot -- one more time.
In any case, facing Mr. Perot instead of groveling is good for the posture and the soul. So far Republican leadership seems still in careful crouch. Senator Robert Dole thinks confronting Mr. Perot in a Nafta debate could build him up more. Quite possible; there is no free pander.
The Dole argument was raised whenever politicians talked of standing straight before Mr. Perot and talking straight -- and always will be.
Will the new upright position last right through the 1996 campaign, even if Mr. Perot looks strong as primary, convention and voting time get sweatily near? Will Democrats and Republicans keep telling the American people that a demagogue is a demagogue -- and a danger to American political life?
Let's not be cynics, no. But the year of grovel, pander and simper did leave, say, certain shadows about the courage and wisdom of both major political parties.
Yet certainly it can be said that the Clinton decision to send Mr. Gore against Mr. Perot should make it hard to pick up the great grovel where it left off. Can't that be said?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: What Other Industry Suits Washington?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "Tax Fairness for D.C." (editorial, Oct. 30), you are right to criticize Congressional meddling with the budget of the District of Columbia. The residents of the District should have the real self-government that cannot exist without fiscal autonomy, including the right to make foolish decisions. 
 But you are dead wrong in asserting that "the Government presence costs the District $2 billion a year in lost tax revenues."
If that statement means anything at all, it must mean that if the Federal capital were moved from Washington, the Government uses of the land that it now occupies in the District would be replaced by private business activities and fully taxpaying housing.
That is a fantasy: in a few years, Washington would be a lot worse off than Detroit is, with its economic reason for being -- its role as the Federal capital -- gone. What would replace that? Steel mills? Oil wells? Theme parks? Shopping malls?
Washington is a city of stable, largely middle-class jobs because it is the capital. There is no earthly reason why the rest of us should pay higher Federal taxes in the form of "rent" on land and buildings we own and have paid for in the past so that District residents can pay lower local taxes.
 
DICK NETZER
Professor of Economics and
Public Administration, New York U.
New York, Nov. 1, 1993

HEADLINE: Small Businesses Also Deserve a Few Breaks From City Hall

 BODY:

To the Editor:
New York City is giving Kidder, Peabody & Company $31 million in incentives to stay in New York City (news article, Oct. 30). The city has been giving large corporations billions for decades to retain jobs. 
 But such incentives are not available to companies like mine, which have decided to stick it out though most of our competitors have abandoned this city. Indeed, by not making demands on City Hall, we pay higher taxes to subsidize those who have the leverage to hold the city hostage. Yet small companies are collectively the major employers in the city.
It costs us about double to operate in Brooklyn what it would in New Jersey. However, we are not compensated proportionately to make up the difference. Much of our work is with government. But many agencies in government limit the overhead rate a participating company can charge to about 60 percent of what it costs us to operate in Brooklyn.
We own the building in which we have three floors of offices. But we are not permitted to include in our overhead the market rate for the space that we use for offices, only the cost of depreciating and maintaining the building, which is less than one-third of the rent that we could charge others for the same space.
Kidder, Peabody claims the $31 million in incentives will enable it "to operate in Manhattan on a cost-competitive basis." What about companies like ours? Many "New York" companies face this issue with most of their work force outside the city.
Small-business owners get involved in their communities. Each year my company provides hundreds of thousands of dollars in pro-bono technical services. We plan to continue to do so as long as we live and work in New York City.
City Hall must protect the small-business people who contribute to the city's coffers and its welfare as much as those that are more politically visible.
 
CAROLYN S. KONHEIM
Brooklyn, Nov. 1, 1993
 
The writer is president of Konheim & Ketcham, environmental consultants.

HEADLINE: Theater in Review

BYLINE: By WILBORN HAMPTON

 BODY:

Trophies
Cherry Lane Theater
38 Commerce Street
Greenwich Village
 
By John J. Wooten; directed by John Gulley; set by Mark Cheney; costumes by Missy West; lighting by Mark F. O'Connor; sound by Scott Stauffer; music by David Brunetti; production stage manager, Geoffrey F. Morris. Presented by Yabadoo Productions.
WITH: Janet Nell Catt, John Henry Cox, R. Ward Duffy, Mark Irish and Christen Tassin. 
 As the lights come up on "Trophies," John J. Wooten's gripping new play at the Cherry Lane Theater, a television is on in an empty den that is a shrine to the modern American family. Appropriately, the show no one is watching is "Family Feud."
But the cozy fireplace, wingback chair, bay window and trophy case that make up this vision of homey contentment is merely a facade behind which the repressed anger and thwarted aspirations of the American dream roil. Mr. Wooten has attempted nothing less than an All-American family tragedy, a play about ordinary people in ordinary conflict that ends as a poignant lament for the lost familial values we like to think once held our society together.
The play evolves around an Easter visit home from college by David, the eldest of three children in the Stone family. It is clear from the start that if David's decision to major in acting has made him a prodigal, his return is not awaited with open arms. His father is coolly polite, his mother uneasy, and Laura, his kid sister, indifferent. Only his younger brother, Bobby, is eager to see him, and it is soon apparent that all is not well with Bobby.
Through flashbacks, Mr. Wooten relates how Bobby, the father's pride and joy, was a high school football star when an accident left him brain damaged. As a result, the father has retreated to a Scotch bottle, sliding toward alcoholism in his wingback chair, refusing to answer the phone or even watch football on television. Laura spends as much time away from home as allowed, Bobby stays mostly in his room, and Mrs. Stone fights a losing battle at maintaining equilibrium.
David's infrequent visits shatter whatever balance keeps the family afloat. His very presence seems antagonistic to his father, and while their arguments may turn on such subjects as David's choice of career, each knows their antipathy springs from a deeper source. To see "Trophies" as a play about football vs. acting would be like describing "Death of a Salesman" as a play about unemployment.
Father and son cling to rage and resentment, while the mother shuttles between the two trying to arrange a cease-fire that will at least hold through the weekend. Mr. Wooten offers no solutions or remedies, only the hope of a kind of liberation that comes through honesty, however painful. There are moments that brush close to sentimentality, and some of the early scenes tend to portray David and Mr. Stone in black and white. But those images blur as father and son move toward acceptance of their failure toward each other.
The director, John Gulley, has assembled a fine cast that keeps the action taut and the tension high, even in the humor. R. Ward Duffy is excellent as David, a resilient and ebullient young man who ultimately comes to realize his own selfishness. John Henry Cox delivers a tightly reined performance as the father, clutching his glass of whisky for dear life while coming to acknowledge his own truth. Janet Nell Catt is touching as Mrs. Stone and Mark Irish is credible and sympathetic as Bobby. Mark Cheney's set could have come from an Ethan Allen showroom. WILBORN HAMPTON

HEADLINE: In Central Asia, New Alliances Shift the Balance;
Turkey Looks to West

 BODY:

To the Editor:
William Safire's "Ally for Sale" (column, Oct. 28) lacks understanding of Turkey's deep commitment to the Western alliance, of which Turkey is an integral part. Since World War II, Turkey has promoted and strengthened its alliance with the West out of respect for shared ideals of freedom, democracy, human rights and economic liberalization. 
 Turkey stood by the United States and other coalition partners during the Persian Gulf war and its aftermath. Turkey has no intention of weakening its position over the situation in Iraq. However, the economic embargo of Iraq has cost Turkey a total of $20 billion in the last four years. This has had adverse effects especially in the southeast region of Turkey. It is difficult to understand Mr. Safire's contention that Turkey must go on suffering.
As for the Kurds, there is a distinction between the P.K.K., the Marxist-Leninist terrorist organization, and Turkish citizens of various ethnic origins. P.K.K.'s terrorism is determined to pursue its own destructive separatist aims. Turkey is determined to protect its territorial integrity and sovereignty.
Turkish citizens of Kurdish or other ethnic origins enjoy equal rights within Turkey's democratic society. Turkey has also shown concern for Iraqi Kurds. In 1988 Turkey accepted more than 60,000 Kurds running from brutality. We have recently given $13 million of humanitarian aid to the Kurds and others in northern Iraq.
Turkey's relations with the United States will grow. I quote President Clinton, who in meeting with Prime Minister Tansu Ciller remarked:
"We've all had to pay a price for enforcing the will of the international community, and Turkey in that regard has certainly done more than its share. And we are grateful for its contribution."
 
NUZHET KANDEMIR
Ambassador of Turkey
Washington, Nov. 1, 1993

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Divides New York's Garment Industry

BYLINE: By KEN BROWN

 BODY:
Behind the facades along the streets of New York's storied garment district, it would seem that few workers or managers appear as vulnerable to the potential upheaval caused by opening trade with Mexico as those in the apparel business. Over the years it has lost tens of thousands of jobs to foreign countries where lower wages and business costs seem the perfect setting for churning out competitively priced shirts, jackets, pants and blouses.
But the industry is split over the North American Free Trade Agreement. Some prominent New York manufacturers support it and are convinced that they have little to fear from Mexico's lower-wage work force. In fact, they think New York's battered economy may actually benefit if Congress approves the trade pact, which will reduce tariffs among the United States, Mexico and Canada. However, other manufacturers -- and the industry's unions -- believe that the prospect of increased Mexican competition is unfair and may ultimately mean their demise. 
 "What makes anybody think that sending my work to another country is going to help my shop?" asked Dino Bonacasa, president of Dino Clothing Company on West 19th Street in Manhattan. He said foreign competition in Asia and Mexico had already forced him to cut his work force by nearly 60 percent, to about 75 people, and he feared an influx of cheap goods from Mexico would eventually force him to shut down.
 
 
A Typical Shop
 Mr. Bonacasa's shop -- where the unionized workers speak a range of languages from Italian and Spanish to Hungarian and Romanian -- produces high-quality men's suits and sport jackets. It is typical of many companies that are too small to move and yet would face pressure from low-wage manufacturers in Mexico. The brightly lit shop extends the length of a city block, and workers, members of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textiles Workers Union, earn between $8 and $10 an hour.
"They don't pay my gas, my electricity, my labor, my insurance,"Mr. Bonacasa said of Mexican manufacturers. "How can I produce at the same price?"
Other garment makers concede that costs in Mexico would be less but they disagree that would automatically spell doom for manufacturers in New York's garment district, which runs from Chinatown in southern Manhattan to around 40th Street in midtown. They argue that clothing can be made profitably in New York even if wages here are relatively high -- mostly because New York manufacturers benefit from their proximity to fashion designers who demand fast turnaround times for making a trendy design come to life on a rack.
Those in favor of the agreement believe that the expensive suits and jackets Mr. Bonacasa's company makes will survive and that horror stories of shuttered shops could undermine the trade pact's passage. They say the accord will help the city's staggering economy, which has lost nearly 400,000 jobs since April 1989.
"Our manufacturing base is not going to be seriously affected." said Mitchell Moss, director of the New York Urban Research Center and a professor at New York University. "The ones that survived in New York have been able to adapt to the environment and find specialized niches, and find noneconomic reasons for being in New York."
"We don't make the stuff that's carried in Wal-Mart, we make the stuff that's carried in Barneys," Mr. Moss said, referring to the more intricate sewing and tailoring that is required of higher-cost suits, jackets and designer fashions made in the garment district.
Bud Konheim, the chief executive of Nicole Miller Ltd., agrees, and says New York's speed and quality cannot be matched anywhere for any price.
"We are 100 percent in favor of the Nafta agreement, and we are a union shop and we make all our clothing in New York," he said. "We have no plans to manufacture in Mexico and we never will; we were the first ones to manufacture in Hong Kong, and the first ones to leave Hong Kong."
Mr. Konheim said those who moved to Mexico for the low wages would quickly see any initial savings disappear as skilled workers demanded more money and problems that could have been solved quickly at home became intractable abroad.
"Our solution was making all our product two blocks from our office," Mr. Konheim said. "We can run down there in one minute to see if there's something wrong, and we solve it right away."
Still Mr. Konheim is in the minority. Eli Elias, the president and executive director of the New York Skirt and Sportswear Association predicted a depression for the city if the trade accord passed.
 
 
'Almighty Buck'
 "The almighty buck is the thing that is going to control people's thinking," he said, adding that garment workers who lose their jobs here would have nowhere else to go.
And Paul Lau, general manager of the Greater Blouse, Skirt and Undergarment Association, which represents 540 mainly Chinese-owned shops in the metropolitan area, agrees. "My gut feeling is there will be a significant shift of jobs, and that would clearly affect our workers," he said.
New York's garment industry has been shrinking for the last 30 years, first as companies moved to nonunion factories in the South, and then to Asia. Employment in the industry is about 83,000, making it the largest manufacturing industry in the city, even though it is the 11th-largest industry in the city over all, down from No. 2 in 1960.
Most of the companies that did leave produced on the low end of the industry -- underwear and casual clothes -- that did not require the skill and knowledge necessary for suits. But some still remain, particularly in the fast-moving area of sportswear, where styles last for days and weeks instead of months and years.
 
 
Trucker's Day Away
 Shraga Frisch, the owner of Royal Sportswear Manufacturers, said his only advantage over Asian companies had been response time -- he needs just two months lead time to produce a garment, compared with six months in Asia.
"But Mexico is just a trucker's day away," he said.
He is opposed to the North American pact. "I think the whole industry would be closed," said Mr. Frisch, himself a Brazilian immigrant. "Even the factories in the South. Historically, their lead over other manufacturers is low overhead; they're going to lose that, too."
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner for the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, said the accord must be viewed as part of the overall shift in the world economy. "It tightens the screw a notch, but the screw has been tightening without it," he said.
This point is stressed by those favoring the accord, who say that claims of job losses must be accompanied by proof that the pact is the culprit. Susan Kaufman Purcell, vice president of the Americas Society, an educational and cultural institute based in New York, said many of the jobs lost would be replaced by better jobs in industries that would benefit from the agreement.
 
 
'Life and Death Issue'
 Many of those jobs will be nonunion though, so the two garment industry unions -- the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union -- will be hurt.
"This is a life-and-death issue for the labor movement in this country and in this city," said Alan H. Howard, assistant to the president of the Ladies Garment Workers Union. Union officials say the pact will lead to lower wages in shops that do not move.
Dorcia M. Robinson, who sews sleeves for Dino's and has been in the trade for 35 years, said, "I don't mind helping anyone else, but you've got to help yourself." She reflects the prevailing attitude of the workers who sew and press the garments made in New York.
"I'm almost 65 and I can retire," she added. "I feel for the people behind me. And some people, this is all they know."
