HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: The Overview;
Gore and Perot Dual on TV Over the Trade Pact

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore suggested tonight that Ross Perot opposed the North American Free Trade Agreement to win political and financial advantage for himself.
In a sour 90-minute televised debate that turned more on personality than substance, the Vice President observed that Mr. Perot had favored the trade agreement until he began running for President, and that the Perot family had obtained special free-trade privileges for its development near a cargo airport in Fort Worth. 
 "If it's good enough for him," Mr. Gore declared, gesturing at Mr. Perot, "why not the rest of the country?"
 
For Free Trade
 Mr. Perot retorted that he was in favor of free trade generally, but not the agreement negotiated by the Bush Administration and strongly advocated by President Clinton. As for the airport development, Mr. Perot said he would never put his financial interests ahead of the country's.
The debate, broadcast on the CNN program "Larry King Live," broke no new ground on the merits and demerits of the trade pact, devolving instead into bickering and recriminations.
Indeed, Mr. Gore seemed intent on trying to attack Mr. Perot and provoke him, departing from the more polite treatment Gov. Bill Clinton and President George Bush gave the Texan in the 1992 Presidential debates.
 
Scrambling for Votes
 The House of Representatives is scheduled to vote next Wednesday on legislation to put the trade accord into effect. As matters stand now, Mr. Clinton is scrambling for enough votes to win passage of the measure. Politically, it is the most important vote facing Mr. Clinton and Congress for the rest of the year.
The White House challenged Mr. Perot to the debate in an effort to make him the embodiment of opposition to the measure. Polls show that his standing with the public has fallen markedly in the last six months.
The trade pact would gradually eliminate tariffs and trade barriers between the United States, Mexico and Canada. It has the support of many business organizations but is vigorously opposed by organized labor.
 
Sarcasm Aplenty
 From the moment the genial Mr. King introduced his guests and announced the rules, the confrontation turned sarcastic. Mr. Gore repeatedly interrupted Mr. Perot, challenging his presentation and suggesting that the Texan was more interested in promoting his political ambitions than finding the truth.
Mr. Perot, affecting a kindly schoolteacher's forbearance for the class dunce, instructed Mr. Gore to be quiet and stop interrupting him.
At the outset, Mr. Gore said of the agreement, "This is a good deal for your country."
Mr. Perot, who won 19 percent of the popular vote running as an independent in last year's Presidential election, responded: "This is not good for the people of either country," referring to the United States and Mexico.
Mr. Gore argued that every living former President, former Secretary of State, Treasury and Defense and every economist who had won the Nobel Prize favored the trade measure. Mr. Perot replied that they were the ones who had caused the country's economic problems in the first place. "Those are the guys that cut the worst trade deals in history," he said.
 
Standards of Living
 Lower tariffs in Mexico in the last five years had already led to 400,000 additional jobs in the United States in exporting industries, and the trade measure would create another 200,000 in the next few years, Mr. Gore said.
Mr. Perot disputed that. The Mexicans, he said, simply could not afford American goods. "Here it is on a more personal basis," he asserted. "Livestock in this country and animals have a better life than good, decent, hard-working Mexicans."
Mr. Gore and Mr. Perot arrived not only with charts and photographs but with set arguments. They involved much more than just the advantages and drawbacks of the trade accord.
Mr. Gore's contention that the Perot family's airport project in Fort Worth would benefit from rejection of the trade pact is a questionable one. The family has said for years that the project, run by Mr. Perot's son, Ross Jr., would benefit from free trade.
In response to the accusation tonight, Mr. Perot declared: "This is the lowest, silliest propaganda trick put out by the U.S. Government. My son's too good to be true. I will not tolerate anyone criticizing him."
Mr. Perot parried another of Mr. Gore's jabs -- the contention that he had lobbied Congress to win special tax breaks for his businesses. That was widely documented in the 1970's, but Mr. Gore did not seem to have the details. He was unable to respond when Mr. Perot called him a liar.
 
Gain or Loss on Jobs?
 The two men disagreed emphatically on the pact's effect on the job market. Mr. Gore argued that free trade would improve the economy of all North America and would create a common market larger than any other in the world. More exports would lead to more jobs in the United States, he said.
Mr. Perot maintained that hundreds of thousands of low-wage, low-skill jobs would move from the United States to Mexico as companies relocated in search of cheaper labor, less Government regulation and lax environmental rules.
Mr. Gore said that was preposterous. "If low wages were the determinant of where we locate business," he maintained, "then Haiti would be an economic powerhouse. Bangladesh would be a powerhouse."
American workers are the most productive in the world, the Vice President said, and as long as that is the case, American companies will be able to manufacture most goods here less expensively.
Mr. Gore maintained that 22 of 23 studies of the economic effect of the trade measure showed that it would lead to an increase of jobs in the United States.
Mr. Perot said Government studies were worthless. "I'm saying they basically come out with phony numbers," he said.
Mr. Gore said Mr. Perot had often been a doomsayer only to be proven wrong. The Texan had predicted, Mr. Gore said, that 40,000 American soldiers would die in the Persian Gulf war.
"You were wrong about that," Mr. Gore said. "Now, the politics of negativism and fear only go so far."
 
Spending on Lobbying
 The two men fussed time and again over who was spending how much money to lobby for and against the trade pact.
Mr. Perot said that the Government of Mexico had spent $30 million lobbying on the measure and that the full faith and credit of the United States was behind the Clinton drive to win approval of the measure.
The Vice President noted that all those expenditures were on the public record, then challenged Mr. Perot to say how much he was spending in the effort to defeat the pact. Mr. Perot hedged.
"I am paying for it," he said. "It's that simple."
 
Mexican Politics
 Mr. Perot criticized Mexico for its oligarchic, one-party rule. "Read the State Department's annual report on human rights," he said, "of journalists being killed, people in the opposing political parties being put in prison and killed and tortured. This is not a free society."
Mr. Gore held that the United States could not afford to look inward and had to reach out to other countries in order to prosper. In the case of Mexico, he said, free trade encouraged that country to move more quickly toward an open economy and a Democratic government.
Mr. Gore acknowledged that "Mexico is not yet a free democracy," and still lacked "full protection for human rights."
"But they've been making tremendous progress," he said. "And the progress has been associated with this new relationship with the United States."
During the last part of the debate, Mr. Gore and Mr. Perot took questions from callers.
An American woman calling from Mexico City said Japanese companies were waiting to move into Mexico in droves if the North American trade accord goes down.
Mr. Perot seized the opportunity to to say that in fact the trade agreement gives some special advantages to Japanese companies.
Mr. Gore said that was indeed the case. Companies like Honda and Toyota that have plants in the United States would indeed benefit, he said, creating more jobs here for Americans.
As part of his argument that Mexico did not deserve equal billing with the United States, Mr. Perot said the environment south of the border was one of the most polluted in the world. Companies can take advantage of lax environmental standards.
The Rio Grande, he said, is the most polluted river in the Western Hemisphere.
Mr. Gore responded, "If we defeat Nafta, we'll lose all leverage over the enforcement of Mexico's environmental laws."
 
Two Interpretations
 The White House and its partisans organized a quick response to the broadcast soon after it ended, arranging for former President Jimmy Carter to telephone reporters and faxing pro-accord statements around town that declared Mr. Gore the winner.
Mr. Carter said he was pleasantly surprised at the outcome.
"I was uncertain about whether it was a good idea, because I didn't know how Ross Perot and Al Gore would shape up against each other," Mr. Carter said. "Ross Perot bombed out."
But Ralph Nader, the head of Public Citizen and an ardent opponent of the proposed pact, said the broadcast had glossed over essential facts. Mr. Gore, he said, was "smooth and deliberate and misleading and disingenuous."
"It had one great asset," he said. "It greatly expanded, both in anticipation and during post-mortems, the number of Americans who now know something about Nafta and are either skeptical against it or for it."
The more Americans know, Mr. Nader said, the more they will dislike the agreement.
For his part, Mr. Perot said afterward, "This is not show business. I don't care if I looked pretty or ugly up there. I'm here for the American people."

HEADLINE: CHINA MAY ALLOW RED CROSS TO VISIT DISSIDENTS IN JAIL

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Signaling what would be a major policy shift on human rights, China said today that it would give "positive consideration" to allowing the Red Cross to visit more than 3,000 political prisoners.
Speaking with United States journalists, Foreign Minister Qian Qichen also said China viewed a meeting next week between President Clinton and the Chinese Communist Party Secretary, Jiang Zemin, as not for "picture taking," but as a discussion of "a broader and longer-term perspective" on bilateral relations. 
 The talks are to be held in Seattle during a meeting of national leaders from both sides of the Pacific.
 
'Left Over From the Cold War'
 Mr. Qian indicated that Mr. Jiang would take a hard line against Washington's policy of linking trade preferences to China's human-rights record, a policy that the United States has insisted on since the 1989 military crackdown at Tiananmen Square.
"China does not accept linking questions unrelated to trade," Mr. Qian said. "This method is a means left over from the cold-war era. It is a means to exert pressure, and therefore one cannot expect China to accept this."
Mr. Clinton said in May that "overall, significant progress" in improving China's human-rights record would be the main criterion for whether he renewed China's favorable trade status with the United States next June.
 
Skepticism From Christopher
 Just three weeks ago, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said he did not think he could recommend renewal of China's trade privileges because of China's human-rights record.
But in answer to a question about the desire by rights groups to inspect prisons, Mr. Qian said, "I believe that if the Red Cross does put forward such a request for exchanges, we would give positive consideration to that request."
[State Department officials said in Washington that the apparent decision by China to allow the Red Cross access to prisoners would be an important factor in determining whether China's favored trade status would be extended.]
Western diplomats and human-rights workers, who have been urging China to take such a step for years, applauded the move. If carried out, it would reverse four decades of refusals to allow any outside humanitarian organization access to the tens of thousands of Chinese who have been imprisoned, tortured or persecuted for their political beliefs.
Coming as it did days before Mr. Qian and Mr. Jiang leave for the United States, the statement was clearly timed to defuse the contentious atmosphere over China's record on rights.
Even though Mr. Qian rejected a link between trade and human rights, the turnabout on access to prisoners is clearly part of China's strategy to improve relations.
Access to prisoners is an explicit condition of Mr. Clinton's executive order on China's future trade relations. The order says China must make progress within one year on "insuring humane treatment of prisoners, such as by allowing access to prisoners by international humanitarian and human rights organizations."
The Asian representative for the International Committee of the Red Cross, Christophe Swinarski, said in a telephone interview from Hong Kong that the Red Cross would take Mr. Qian's statement "very seriously." He hinted that talks on prison access could begin this week when Mr. Swinarski passes through Beijing on his way to North Korea.
John T. Kamm, an American businessman who has carried on private humanitarian work in China for years, characterized Mr. Qian's statement as "a significant change in the opinion of the Chinese Government."
"To me, the immediate impact of this announcement," he said, "is that it delivers a message to every warden holding prisoners that they better clean up their act because there is a very good chance the Red Cross is coming."
Apropos the talks in Seattle, business leaders in the United States have urged the Clinton Administration and the Chinese leadership to repair their relationship, which has been dominated by Washington's reprisals and threats on trade since China's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in 1989. The crackdown has been followed by four years of harsh political repression.
Some corporate leaders fear United States companies will fall behind those in Japan and Europe in building markets in China, whose economy is growing by 13 percent this year and may continue to grow 10 percent a year for the rest of the decade.
Business leaders have also warned that if Mr. Clinton cancels China's most-favored-nation trade status, the loss of markets could further slow the growth of the United States economy.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Welcomed in Washington
 WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (Special to The New York Times) -- State Department officials said today that the apparent decision by Beijing to allow the Red Cross access to political prisoners would be an important factor in whether Secretary of State Christopher would recommend extending China's preferred trade status.
State Department officials said that since it often takes more than a year for the Red Cross to reach agreement with a government to interview prisoners, actual visits need not take place before Mr. Christopher makes his recommendations to President Clinton next year.
But the officials said China must either allow visits or engage in serious talks with the Red Cross in order to have its new position counted in its favor.
United States officials have been pressing the Chinese for some time to allow the Red Cross to meet with political prisoners. The Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, Winston Lord, raised the subject during a visit to Beijing in May, and Senator Charles S. Robb, a Virginia Democrat, did the same in August.

SECTION: Section B; Page 15; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: Right and Wrong;
Exaggerations? Yes, Particularly by Perot

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
As has been the case with much of the fight over the North American Free Trade Agreement, the debate tonight between Vice President Al Gore and Ross Perot included some misleading and exaggerated arguments on both sides.
Their disagreements ranged from the sweeping (whether the pact would result in massive layoffs across the United States) to the obscure (the pact's rules on certain labels of Tennessee bourbon). But a review of their statements on CNN's "Larry King Live" indicates that Mr. Perot tended to stray a little further from the facts than did Mr. Gore. 
 For instance, Mr. Perot complained that the networks had sold time to the pact's advocates but not to its opponents. Actually, both sides have bought advertisements of up to a minute on NBC.
What Mr. Perot was apparently referring to was the recent refusal of all three networks to displace a show in their fall schedules to make way for Mr. Perot's latest half-hour "infomercial" criticizing the pact. NBC did sell Mr. Perot a half-hour for such a program during the Memorial Day weekend when many reruns were scheduled.
By far the most heated clash today came when Mr. Gore asserted that Mr. Perot stood to gain financially if the agreement passed and also if it failed.
This exchange centered on a free-trade zone that surrounds Alliance Airport near Fort Worth. The land in the zone is owned by a company that belongs to Mr. Perot and his son, Ross Perot Jr. In such zones, the Commerce Department agrees to have the Customs Service delay collection of tariffs normally charged on imports and reduce some tariffs on components used to assemble goods within the zone.
Mr. Gore implied that Mr. Perot had gained a relative advantage in the trade zone that would be lost if the trade agreement passed and tariffs fell everywhere. "If it's good enough for him," Mr. Gore said, "why not the rest of the country?
On the other hand, Mr. Gore went on to argue that Mr. Perot and the trade zone which was approved early this autumn, would benefit if Congress approved the pact and trade with Mexico increased.
 
Family Documents Are Cited
 That assertion appears to be borne out by documents filed long ago by the Perot family to win the free-trade zone for its land around Alliance Airport.
In those documents, the family argued that the airport project would be helped by passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement because it would increase the volume of freight flowing through the airport area. The family business is run by Mr. Perot's son, but Mr. Perot retains a large stake.
Adding a final argument to the bevy he had arrayed around the potentially sensitive topic of the airport trade zone, Mr. Gore went on to say that if the pact was defeated, the Perot family would benefit by handling the increase in imports of goods made in Mexico by factories that would flee the United States.
All of Mr. Gore's arguments were rejected by Mr. Perot, who said that while he could make lots of money toting factories to Mexico if the agreement is passed, he was setting that potential benefit aside to argue instead in the national interest.
Mr. Perot's responses to Mr. Gore on the subject, while fervent, included few specifics. Mr. Perot initially said the airport was owned by the city of Fort Worth, then later said that he owned a minority stake in it. The facts lie somewhere in between; he owns a stake in the free-trade industrial zone around the airport.
Interestingly, the last of Mr. Gore's assertions runs counter to arguments the Administration has made in favor of the agreement. While the Vice President said today that manufacturing jobs would flow south in the absence of the pact, President Clinton and others have argued that there is little economic incentive for American factories to relocate.
 
Feint-by-Number Tactics
 During the rest of the debate, both men engaged in a variety of statistical distortions.
In the opening minutes, for example, Mr. Gore said that Mexicans bought 750,000 cars a year but that Detroit's Big 3 sold only 1,000 of them. The Vice President was referring only to the number of cars Detroit ships to Mexico from factories in the United States each year.
In fact, United States auto makers' increasingly efficient factories in Mexico dominate the market there. One of the biggest fears of American labor unions is that the Big 3 will use these factories to supply the United States market once the free-trade agreement eliminates the United States' current taxes on vehicles built in Mexico: 2.5 percent on cars and 25 percent on light trucks.
Mr. Gore came closer to the truth than Mr. Perot on another of the most hotly contested issues in the debate -- the extent to which American exports to Mexico actually stay there. Mr. Perot asserted that two-fifths of these southbound shipments consisted of "phony exports" -- parts assembled into products that were in turn shipped to the United States. Another two-fifths of the exports, he said, consisted of machinery used to build products mainly for the American market.
Mr. Gore more accurately addressed the first issue -- parts that come back to the United States in Mexican products. He said that 80 or 90 percent of American exports physically stay in Mexico. A recent study by the International Trade Commission, a bipartisan Federal agency that analyzes the effects of trade agreements and is independent of the Administration and Congress, found that the figure was 78 percent last year, up from 68 percent in 1987.
 
Exports of Machinery

Commerce Department figures indicate that the figures Mr. Perot cited about machinery exports were also exaggerated. Machinery accounted for 33 percent of American exports to Mexico last year, but this included everything from hospital imaging equipment to construction cranes, in addition to factory equipment. The United States is most competitive internationally in machinery, which accounted for 39 percent of all American exports to the rest of the world last year.
Sounding one of his central political themes, Mr. Perot said the free trade agreement was laced with special deals for influential companies. In making the charge, he accurately cited the inclusion of a $17 million break for Honda. The agreement would retroactively cancel an assessment on Honda Motors that was levied by the Customs Service after agents determined that Hondas imported from Canada had not been meeting the North American content levels required to avoid paying duties.
But Mr. Perot did not mention that the original assessment on Honda had been made in a politically charged process in which the Customs Service used an arcane method to measure the percentage of American parts used in Honda's cars. The North American pact would simplify these arcane rules in a way that would help Honda retroactively but would hurt Honda and other Japanese auto companies in the long run by requiring them to use more and more American parts that Detroit automakers already use.
In another attack, Mr. Perot maintained that three dozen business executives owned 54 percent of the Mexican economy and were recently asked by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari for campaign contributions of $25 million apiece. While the $25 million figure was right, the description of the potential donors was inaccurate. Some of the executives were representatives of broad trade associations composed of many companies, and some of the campaign contributions might have come from companies not owned by the executives.
President Salinas abandoned the plan after its public disclosure, and the ruling party did not end up with the money.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Promotes a Charter That Is Very Much His

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 9

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin went on national television tonight to open his campaign for a new constitution that he promised would help restore "law and order" to a country that has seen little of either in the last two years.
"We need order, but not the horrible repressive order of the Stalinist camps," Mr. Yeltsin said. "Russia needs a steady, law-based order badly," he added, not an "iron hand" but a "democratic state that will insure progress toward a normal and worthy life for citizens, toward prosperity for a single, integral Russia." 
 Russians are to vote on the draft constitution and elect a new parliament on Dec. 12.
After two years of numbing political quarrels that ended last month in the horrifying spectacle of Russians killing Russians in the streets of Moscow, most citizens seem to agree the country needs clear rules -- for themselves, but mostly for their leaders.
"We need a constitution in order not to dash from one extreme to another, in order to calm down, in order to make fewer mistakes," Mr. Yeltsin said in a rare admission that he, too, sometimes needs to be brought back into line.
 
What's in It for the People
 Under the draft constitution, which Mr. Yeltsin approved on Monday, citizens are guaranteed freedom of speech, of religion, of assembly and of travel. Rights to private property, including the right to own land, which was taboo under the Soviet constitution, are explicitly protected.
Some of these clauses were in the Soviet Constitution; others had been added over the last few years as the Congress of People's Deputies, which the President has disbanded, worked its will through myriad, often contradicting amendments. Other clauses, like the right to own land, are new.
Unlike the United States Constitution, which lays out broad principles, the draft Russian constitution sets out legislative specifics, with guarantees of free medical care, free education, a sound environment, protection against unemployment and affordable housing.
But experience taught Soviet citizens to be wary of promises, and there is still reason for Russians to be skeptical. For instance, both the old and the new constitutions promise "freedom of movement, freedom to choose a place to live and to stay." But Moscow and other major cities continue to vigorously enforce the Soviet system of residence permits.
 
What's in It for Yeltsin
 Nor is it lost on Russians that the draft is essentially a political document. As the editor of the newspaper Nezavisimaya Gazeta wrote today in an editorial, "It will be a constitution for presidents in general, and for President Yeltsin in particular."
Based loosely on the French Constitution, which also blends a strong executive and a parliament, the draft Russian constitution gives the president extraordinary latitude.
The lower house, or Duma, has control over the budget. And the President needs its consent to name (but not to dismiss) a Prime Minister. But if the Duma refuses the president's choice three times in a row, then it too can be disbanded -- just as Mr. Yeltsin disbanded the last Parliament in September, in defiance of the Constitution.
The new document removes other obstacles that had blocked Mr. Yeltsin's use of power: there will be no vice president, eliminating the chance of any more dangerous power plays by erstwhile running mates, and the head of the central bank will be answerable only to the president.
 
Who Will Implement It
 In his speech tonight, Mr. Yeltsin took pains to tell voters that this was no hastily patched together document but the product of a three-year process. And yet, in its final stages, the pretense of a broad-based consensus gave away to the sheer force of presidential will.
Over the protests of some regional leaders, Mr. Yeltsin's team emerged last weekend with a document that clearly reasserted central control aimed at halting the centrifugal forces that have been tugging at the edges of the Russian Federation.
For candidates running for the 450 seats in the Duma, there were also surprises. Until last week, they thought they were running for four-year terms; under the draft constitution, their terms have been cut to two years.
Nor is the anomaly of a single election for a new constitution and a new legislature lost on Russia's crisis-hardened students of politics.
 
Who Is Really in Charge
 Describing the new constitution and the new legislature, Aleksandr Minkin wrote today in Moskovsky Komsomolets: "Since they are born at the same time (and both of them from Zeus's head), they are brother and sister. The new constitution will never be the mother of the parliament. We are presented with some kind of almost out-of-wedlock parliament."
Mr. Yeltsin's statement over the weekend that he no longer intends to hold early presidential elections next year was regarded by many as further proof that for the moment anyway, Russia's future will be determined by a leader who will preside over two parliamentary elections before his term runs out in 1996.
"Such tactics appear to be very dangerous," a journalist said in the newspaper Izvestia. "By playing down the role of the future Parliament, the measures contradict both the interest of most parties who have decided to take part in the election and the very spirit of the election campaign."
Already several people, including Sergei Stankevich, a top Yeltsin adviser, are predicting that the constitution is bound to be a temporary one, a bridge to carry Russia through its next turbulent decade.
As one regional leader told reporters last week, "Life does not end with this Constitution."

HEADLINE: Stoked by Ethnic Conflict, Refugee Numbers Swell

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The spread of ethnic conflict since the end of the cold war has pushed the number of refugees to 44 million people, or more than one in every 130 inhabitants of the globe, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees reported today.
The number of people qualifying as refugees because they have been driven across an international frontier has climbed steadily from 2.5 million in 1970 to 19.7 million today, taking into account the recent mass exodus from the tiny African state of Burundi. In addition, roughly 24 million people have been forced into exile within their own countries. 
 The figures were presented by the High Commissioner, Sadako Ogata, in a report titled "The State of the World's Refugees -- the Challenge of Protection."
 
Intervention for Prevention
 The increase occurred despite the return of some 2.4 million refugees to their countries of origin during 1992.
"The massive number of people on the move has weakened international solidarity and endangered the time honored tradition of granting asylum to those in genuine need of protection," the report says. "The traditional system of protecting refugees has come dangerously close to breakdown."
The crisis is forcing the refugee agency to expand its mandate to help not just refugees forced across frontiers but also internally displaced people to prevent their becoming refugees.
While insisting on refugees' right to asylum in foreign countries, Mrs. Ogata said that preventing people from becoming refugees lies in the "realms of peaceful resolution of conflict, respect for human rights, economic development, stable participatory government, a fair and independent judiciary and tolerance for diversity."
But the agency, which expects to spend $1.3 billion on the care and protection of refugees this year, says that political solutions cannot substitute for helping those who need assistance.
 
Iran Tops List
 In particular, Mrs. Ogata warned that Security Council trade sanctions against such countries as Iraq and parts of the former Yugoslavia are exacerbating the plight of the people.
Asia still has the largest number of refugees with some 7.2 million last year, although that figure is down from 8.6 million in 1991. Africa follows with 5.4 million refugees, while Europe is now in third place with 3.6 million, largely a result of the fighting in the Balkans. The number of refugees in Latin America, mainly the result of the civil wars in Central America, has dropped below 1 million.
Iran is currently granting asylum to the largest number of refugees in the world, a total of 4.1 million, including 2.9 million Afghans and 1.2 million dissident Iraqi Kurds and Shiite Muslims. It is followed by Pakistan with 1.6 million Afghans and Malawi, with about 1 million refugees fleeing the civil war in neighboring Mozambique.
The report highlights the growing reluctance of industrialized countries to accept refugees, listing Austria, Canada, Germany, the United States and Britain among countries that are tightening asylum laws.
 
Germany Feels Effects
 In 1983, only 100,000 people asked for asylum in Western Europe, North America, Australia and Japan. But by 1992 the number had risen to 800,000. Over the same period the number of asylum-seekers arriving in Western Europe climbed from 30,000 a year to over 680,000. Germany has been the most seriously affected, with the number of asylum seekers rising from 121,000 in 1989 to 438,000 in 1992. Although Bonn is tightening its asylum laws, Germany remains the industrial country with the most refugees, providing asylum to 827,000 at the end of 1992. So far the numbers of refugees to Western Europe from the East have been lower than expected.
 In the United States the total number of refugees declined slightly, falling from 482,000 in 1991 to 473,000 last year.
The report says that the majority of asylum seekers are refused refugee status, though most manage to stay on illegally or under special dispensations. Only 20 percent of asylum-seekers were accepted by European Community countries in 1991, but about 80 percent remained in those states.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: MEDIA WATCH;
Personalities and Pictures: A Made-for-TV Debate

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Sometimes there is a political event so transcendentally weird, so Silly Putty, to use one of tonight's Perot-isms, that it almost defies description.
Tonight's big Nafta debate on "Larry King Live" on CNN was not exactly Webster and Clay. More like Punch and Judy -- with charts instead of bats. 
 Mr. Perot showed up for the 9 P.M. show with so many charts and pictures that the CNN producers had to provide a small table for him to stack them. Then, when the Gore contingent showed up and discovered the imbalance of chart power, they demanded their own little table.
"It's chart wars," replied a White House official, who was asked midway through the debate how it was going. Promising that the Vice President would not run out of graphics, he added, "The night is still young."
Despite the astonishing proliferation of visual aids, the debate certainly was not a primer on the pros and cons of the complicated trade agreement with Mexico and Canada. It was a confusing blizzard of facts and figures, almost all of them contradicting each other. And whatever facts might have come through to the average viewer were overwhelmed by the nasty tone of the encounter.
The television contest, once again, raised the question of whether forums usually used by addiction-confessing movie stars and book-hawking authors can work well for substantive political discourse. On the other hand, this was the spot where Mr. Perot suddenly announced the Presidential bid that won him 19 percent of the vote.
 
Camera Tactics
 For 90 minutes, Vice President Al Gore and Ross Perot mostly bickered about who was interrupting whom, who was avoiding answering whom and who was lying about whom. Mr. Perot tried not to look at Mr. Gore, preferring to talk directly into the camera and complained when the Vice President addressed questions directly to him. For his part, the Vice President, whose main tactic was to make Mr. Perot look kooky, spent most of his time smiling at his opponent rather patronizingly.
A typical exchange:
Mr. Gore: "How do you stop it without Nafta?"
Mr. Perot: "Give me your whole mind."
Mr. Gore: "Yeah, I'm listening. I haven't heard the answer, but go ahead."
Mr. Perot: "That's because you haven't quit talking. Are you going to listen? Work on it."
Or this:
Mr. Gore: "I mean, humor me, if you would, and ----"
Mr. Perot: "No, won't. I don't think I can."
Or this from Mr. Perot, who seemed particularly keen on policing the interruptions: "Please, let's have an unnatural event and try not to interrupt me."
Although the television debate was ostensibly a chance to talk about the issues involved in opening an era of free trade with Canada and Mexico, the hottest question in Washington, the White House had acknowledged in advance that its main goal was to turn Mr. Perot into the face of the opposition to the agreement and to discredit that face.
From the start, that was clearly Mr. Gore's main purpose.
The Vice President's staff felt he got off to a fast tactical start when he won the noon coin toss, calling tails, and got to choose his seat. He chose the middle seat, with the more flattering camera angle, leaving the outside seat for Mr. Perot, which offered viewers a close-up of his Texas-sized ears, floating right above the CNN logo. But to even out the staging, they had adjustable chairs so that when seated, Mr. Perot could appear as tall as Mr. Gore.
Mr. Gore tried to undercut Mr. Perot's credibility by accusing him of seeking to benefit financially and politically from a defeat of the trade pact. He accused Mr. Perot of covering up how much money he had spent on the anti-agreement lobbying campaign. And at one point he went into an attack intended to make Mr. Perot look like a wacky Chicken Little. The Vice President said that before the Persian Gulf war, the businessman had gone on "Larry King Live" and predicted that the fighting would "lead to the death of 40,000 American troops."
 
Failed Predictions
 He also said Mr. Perot had predicted that 100 American banks would fail on the day after Mr. Clinton's inauguration.
Although Mr. Gore was never able to push Mr. Perot into one of his renowned tantrums, the Texan did seem hard pressed at times to stay calm. Mr. Perot was the one who initiated most of the squabbling about the protocol of the debate.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, was exultant afterwards.
"We showed Mr. Perot for what he is tonight," Mr. Kantor told reporters at the CNN studio in Northeast Washington. "He's for fear. You don't even need to spin tonight."
While Mr. Gore was busy trying to scare America with Mr. Perot, Mr. Perot was busy trying to scare Americans with Mexico (and trying to paint Mr. Gore as a rude young fellow who wanted to ask him questions when Mr. Perot had already said several times that only Larry King was allowed to do that).
Mr. Perot began his part of the fight with a series of poignant photographs, which he described as hovels in Mexico that workers in a big American plant built next to the factory. He said that people were building homes out of cardboard and that they were worse off than American livestock. The point, which Mr. Perot never really explained, apparently was that if trade barriers were lifted, American companies would move their plants to Mexico where they could hire workers who would be paid next to nothing.
 
Pictures of a Shack
 Showing a picture of a man hammering together his cardboard shack, Mr. Perot said: "Do you know what his dream is? To someday have an outhouse."
Taking up another popular anti-pact argument, Mr. Perot said Mexico's environmental standards were too lax. Talking about a different factory in Mexico, he said, "A disproportionate number of the babies born in the shanty town around that plant are born without a brain. Now, I don't care if you're poor or rich, if your baby is born without a brain because a U.S. company is willing to take advantage of workers to that extent, that's wrong."
At first, Mr. Gore tried to out-folksy Mr. Perot, by drawing forth his Tennessee drawl and talking about a friend from Elmwood, Tenn., who make tires, which he pronounced "tars."
But that effort by the Vice President, who grew up mostly in a fancy hotel suite in Washington as the son of a Senator, may have fallen a bit flat when he tried to counter Mr. Perot's stark photographs of poor Mexicans by presenting his rival with a black and white photograph of two members of Congress who looked like undertakers: Reed Smoot and Willis C. Hawley, who introduced a famous protectionist tariff in 1930 that damaged the economy.
Mr. Perot disdainfully took the gift, which the Vice President said he had had specially framed, and slammed it face down onto the desk in front of him.
The two men, realizing that the audience of the show itself is relatively small, were mostly aiming their comments at lawmakers and others in the know. For the rest of the country, they knew that it was important to get something snazzy played back on the news tonight or tomorrow. So they devoted a fair amount of time to coming up with the best sound bite.
Mr. Perot's best line may have been the one about the outhouse, but Mr. Gore got in the last word, saying of Mr. Perot: "He started as the head of United We Stand America, and I'm afraid he'll end up as the head of Divided We Fall."
As Mr. Perot came out of the studio, a well-dressed wife of a union executive, who seemed to be a friend of his, welled up with tears and told him what a good job he had done.
"Oh," he said, laughing and throwing up his hands, "you're just a public citizen."

SECTION: Section B; Page 16; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD;
Excerpts From the Free Trade Debate Between Gore and Perot

GRAPHIC: Following are excerpts from the debate last night between Vice President Al Gore and Ross Perot over the North American Free Trade Agreement, as broadcast by CNN and recorded by The New York Times. The debate was moderated by Larry King in his television studio in Washington.
 
 
For and Against
 KING When President Bush signed this in San Antonio, he was on our show, and then a few nights later, I was with you and the then-President -- Governor, now President-elect Clinton, asked about this, Nafta, and the President said, to the best of my memory: "Well, I'm basically for it. I want to see the side agreements, I want to hear what the unions object to and then I'll come back and sort of let you know." But it was not a definitive "Yes." What changed?
 GORE Well, we negotiated two side agreements that protect labor and protect the environment and not until the two side agreements were completed did we agree to support Nafta. Now this is a good deal for our country, Larry, and let me explain why.
KING But you were hedging early?
GORE Well, we said from the very beginning that we wanted to improve the basic arrangement, which we did with the side agreements, and the reason why this is so important can be illustrated by the story of a good friend of mine that I grew up with named Gordon Thompson who lives in Elmwood, Tenn., with his wife, Sue, and his son Randy. He makes tires for a living. He is a member of the United Rubber Workers and he is for this because he has taken the time to look at how it affects his job and his family.
We make the best tires in the world. But we have a hard time selling them in Mexico because they have a 20 percent tax collected at the border on all of the tires that we try to sell. Now when they make tires and sell them into the United States, the tax at the border is zero. So it's, it's a one-way street. Nafta changes that. It makes it even-steven.
KING So he'll make more tires.
GORE Well, his job will be more secure. They'll make more tires. They'll be able to sell more tires. His son will have a better chance of going into that line of work, if that's what he should decide he wants to do.
And remember this, I mean, people think, well, they don't buy tires. Mexico bought 750,000 new cars last year. The Big 3 sold them only 1,000 because they have the same barriers against our cars. Those barriers will be eliminated by Nafta. We'll sell 60,000, not 1,000, in the first year after Nafta. Every one of those cars has four new tires and one spare. We'll create more jobs with Nafta.
KING Weren't you a free-trader always, Ross?
PEROT I am a free-trader now.
KING Do you favor some sort of Nafta?
PEROT Absolutely.
KING Then what's your rub?
PEROT The problem is this is not good for the people of either country.
KING Either country?
PEROT Yes. I think the important thing for everybody watching this show tonight to remember: This is not an athletic contest, this is not a question of who wins -- whether I win or the Vice President wins -- this is a question of do the people of the United States and the people of Mexico win. Now that's the important issue, and I'm sure we're in agreement on that. My concern is very simple.
I look at many years experience in the maquiladoras program and ----
KING These are the ----
PEROT Here is what I see. This -- we have a lot of experience in Mexico. I've been accused of looking in the rear-view mirror. That's right. I'm looking back at reality. And here is what I see after many years: Mexican workers' life, standard of living and pay has gone down, not up. After many years of having U.S. companies in Mexico, this is the way Mexican workers live all around big, new U.S. plants.
Now, just think if you owned a big U.S. company and you went down to see your new plant and you found slums all around it, your first reaction would be, "Why did you build this plant in the middle of slums?" And your plant manager would say, "Well, there were no slums here when we built the plant." And you say, "Well, why are they here now?" He says, "This is where the workers work ----

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Wages in for Mexicans
 PEROT All I'm saying is ----
KING ---- what would you ----
PEROT ---- is if after 10 active years -- this has been in effect since the 60's, but let's say 10 active years -- you would think the standard of living of the Mexican worker would begin to come up. Instead, it continues to go down by design. Thirty-six families own over half the country; 85 million people work for them in poverty. U.S. companies, because it is so difficult to do business in this country, can't wait to get out of this country and go somewhere else and, if possible, get labor that costs one-seventh of what it costs in the United States.
GORE How would you change it? How would you change it?
PEROT Very simply. I would go back and study. First, we look at this. It doesn't work. If ----
GORE Well, what specific changes would you make in it?
PEROT I can't, unless you let me finish, I can't answer your question. Now, you asked me, and I'm trying to tell you.
GORE Right, well, you brought your charts tonight, so I want to know what specific changes ----

 	 	 		.. .	 	
 
Previous Accords
 GORE I've heard Mr. Perot say in the past that, as the carpenters says, measure twice and cut once. We've measured twice on this. We have had a test of our theory and we've had a test of his theory. Over the last five years, Mexico's tariffs have begun to come down because they've made a unilateral decision to bring them down some, and as a result there has been a surge of exports from the United States into Mexico, creating an additional 400,000 jobs, and we can create hundreds of thousands of more if we continue this trend.
We know this works. If it doesn't work, you know, we give six months notice and we're out of it. But we've also had a test of his theory.
PEROT When?
GORE In 1930, when the proposal by Mr. Smoot and Mr. Hawley was to raise tariffs across the board to protect our workers. And I brought some pictures, too.
KING You're saying Ross is a protectionist?
GORE This is, this is a picture of Mr. Smoot and Mr. Hawley. They look like pretty good fellows. They sounded reasonable at the time; a lot of people believed them. The Congress passed the Smoot-Hawley Protection Bill. He wants to raise tariffs on Mexico. They raised tariffs, and it was one of the principal causes, many economists say the principal cause, of the Great Depression in this country and around the world.
Now, I framed this so you can put it on your wall if you want to.
PEROT Thank you, thank you, thank you.
KING Would raising tariffs produce another ----
PEROT We're talking to two totally different, unrelated situations. Now, you do need to measure twice and cut once, but then if you have a program that is failing, you should not institutionalize it.
See, the Mexican program has failed. It's failed the people of Mexico. It's failed the people of the United States. These numbers they give of exports from the United States are not realistic numbers. For example, they count in the Government figures automobile parts going into Mexico to be put into cars made by U.S. car companies in Mexico and shipped back to the United States to be sold as if Mexican consumers bought those parts. That didn't happen.
Then, if you take a ---- let's just say you have a piece of glass crystal that you spend $100 making it in this country, you're going to send it to Mexico to have $10 of additional work done to it, they count it as a $100 export, then they count it as $100 to come into Mexico from the U.S., then they count it as a $110 import back to the United States.
Now then, when you look at how they count, the real export figures to Mexican consumers are tiny. The used factory equipment coming from U.S. factories going into Mexico -- new factories going to Mexico ----
GORE Are not more?
PEROT No, no, no. It's equipment from the U.S. into Mexico. That's used equipment. Then, we count that as if Mexican consumers bought it. Nobody bought anything. Old equipment must come to Mexico.
GORE Let me respond to that if I can because, unfortunately, there's a grain of truth to that, but it's so tiny that ---- I mean it's not a half-truth. It doesn't quite rise to that level. There are a few things in that category, but the vast majority, 80 to 90 percent, are exports that stay in Mexico and are bought there.
Here's what's happened to our trade surplus. And these figures are net figures. It takes into account everything that he's talking about in that small category. In 1987, before Mexico started lowering its taxes at the border, its tariffs, we had a $5.7 billion trade deficit with Mexico. After five years, our, the goods we make and sell into Mexico, the volume has been growing twice as fast as the goods they make and sell in the United States.
So last year we had a $5.4 billion trade surplus. Now if that trend continued for another two years -- and Nafta will by removing those barriers greatly accelerate it -- we will have a larger trade surplus with Mexico than with any country in the entire world.
KING Why are trade unions so opposed to it, then?
GORE Well, some of them ----
KING If your friend, who makes the tire, and he is a union member, is going to benefit from this, why is the unions aligned with Ross Perot? Why do we have this alignment of Ross Perot, unions, Jesse Jackson, Pat Buchanan and Ralph Nader?
GORE Because some of them make the same mistake that, with all due respect, Mr. Perot makes. They confuse the bad trade deals in the past with this one, which is the first time we've been able to get one that's even-steven, with zero on -- zero taxes on both sides. You know, I told you about my friend Gordon Thompson? The international president of his union opposes Nafta; Gordon Thompson has taken the time to look at the facts, and he supports Nafta.
Let me tell you who else has taken the time: Every living former President of the United States in both parties, the two-termers and the one-termers. Every former Secretary of State, every former Secretary of Defense, Secretary of Treasury. Every living Nobel Prize winner in economics -- conservatives, liberals, everyone in between. They've never agreed on anything ----
PEROT That fact ----
GORE Let me just finish this one point ---- and distinguished Americans from Colin Powell to Tip O'Neill to Rush Limbaugh, Ross Perot Jr., the head of his business, Mort Myerson, Orson Swindle, the head of United We Stand last time; and Ross Perot Sr. supported it until he started running for President and attempting to bring out the politics of fear.
KING Ross.
PEROT Will I be able to speak for a second or two from time to time?
KING You may. You're on.
PEROT Because there's a lot of inaccuracies here. Let's go to the big picture, then skip the personal stuff.
People who don't make anything can't buy anything. Let's start with that. We're 85 percent of the market. Canada is 11 percent of the buying power.
KING Of the total free market.
PEROT And Mexico is only 4 percent. People who don't make anything cannot buy anything. Never forget that.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Accusations Over Airport
 GORE There has been unfair competition from foreign countries that don't let our products in, even though we buy their products. This will help to stop that.
Some people want to stay with the status quo, just keep things the way they are.
We want to open up these barriers. And let me give you a specific example. Valmont Electric Company in Danville, Ill., less than a year ago was trying to sell products into Mexico. They've got a 13 percent tax at the border. We have a zero tax coming the other way. They closed down in Danville. Four hundred jobs lost. They opened up in Mexico with 100 jobs down there, and now they ship their products duty-free back into the United States through the Alliance Airport, which is the free trade zone that Mr. Perot's company has set up for. It's kind of a private free trade zone ----
KING Are you saying Mr. Perot's ----
GORE Outside of Dallas. And they take Valmont Electric's products and distribute them through the United States duty free.
Now, if we pass Nafta, that 13 percent tax that they have at their border would be gone and companies like Valmont could stay here in the United States, sell their products in Mexico and not have to go down there to get over the barrier.
KING Are you saying that Mr. Perot is personally benefiting by attacking Nafta?
GORE I think he has set it up so that he will benefit financially either way. But if Nafta passes, I mean if Nafta is defeated, this family business that has a free-trade zone outside of Dallas will continue to distribute products coming from Mexico into the rest of the United States.
What is the deal with Alliance?
PEROT I think what you meant ---- I'll explain it. What we see here tonight is why our country is $4 trillion in debt, going a billion dollars in debt every working day. Nobody ever focuses on the real problems.
Now, I'm going to try to say this as simply as I can. Alliance Airport is in Fort Worth, Tex., not in Mexico. Alliance Airport is owned by the City of Fort Worth, not my son.
Can you shake your head on that?
GORE No, the ----
PEROT Alliance Airport, check the F.A.A., is owned by ----
GORE You don't ----
PEROT ---- the City of Fort Worth.
GORE You don't, you don't have ----
PEROT The airport ----
GORE ---- ownership of --
PEROT The airport.
GORE ---- of the Alliance Carter Incorporated?
PEROT Please.
KING All right, let him finish.
PEROT Let's have an unnatural event and try not to interrupt me.
KING O.K.
PEROT Now, my son owns land adjoining the airport. Now, the purpose of that land is to build factories and warehouses to be, so that industrial goods can be moved by rail and by air.
KING From the airport?
PEROT Just now. Watch my lips: The jobs will be created in Texas; Texas is in the United States, the workers will be United States citizens. They will be paid U.S. wages. It is a job creator in the United States of America.
And all of this other Silly Putty they throw up. For example, the free-trade zone concept goes back to the 1930's. It is nothing new about the free trade zone concept. You have to apply to the U.S. Government to get it, and if it didn't make sense, I guess they wouldn't have given it to him. But it is not aimed at doing business with Mexico.
GORE You're not involved in it?
PEROT Mexico will be a tiny, little part of this whole operation. O.K. I am putting my country's interest far ahead of my business interest.
KING You would do better with Nafta?
PEROT I would. No, it ---- When I'm in a room with corporate America, the first thing they say is, "Perot, why don't you keep your mouth shut. You could, with your resources, make more money than anybody else."
KING If Nafta ----
PEROT Here is the Nafta gain. Buy U.S. manufacturing companies cheap right after Nafta passes that are labor-intensive that make good products that have marginal profits. Close the factories in the U.S., move the factories to Mexico, take advantage of the cheap labor, run your profits through the roof, sell the company stock at a profit. Go get another one.
GORE That's what they do now.
PEROT You ----
GORE That's what they're doing right now.
KING Are they doing that now?
GORE And they're using Alliance Carter Inc. in part to do it.
PEROT Oh, come on, come on. You're talking about something like a trickle of water coming over Niagara Falls as opposed to the gusher. You know it.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Issue of Japan

CALLER The subject has come up about the possibility of Japanese taking over if Nafta doesn't go through. I'm American. I've been living in Mexico City for many years. There are thousands of Japanese here. They are waiting. They are lurking. What are you people doing? Why ----
GORE Let me answer that.
KING Hold on. What's the finish of it ma'am. All right, I didn't hear the end of it.
GORE Yes, she said, "What are you doing? Why don't you wake up?"
KING Okay. Well, I think the question was ----
PEROT It'll only take a minute to kill this snake, go ahead.
KING Go ahead, kill it.
GORE You're talking about the question, not me, right?
GORE You're talking about the question not me, right?
PEROT No, this question, absolutely.
KING Go ahead, it's for you.
PEROT Just this basic. There's a constant in the Clinton Administration. Any time they get cornered, they go into the what I call the sky is falling routine, the presidency is at stake. The Japanese are coming.
KING The question was she says there are Japanese ----
PEROT Next spring we'll have the British are coming, you know, the ghosts are coming. Look, the Japanese cannot just wander into Mexico, do anything they want to do, dump across our border unless we're stupid enough to let them. Now, if our foreign lobbyists say wired in the way they are now, we'll probably say, ooh, this is wonderful. I can tell you about Japanese deals that have been cut through our foreign lobbyists. I can tell you a deal that's buried in this agreement that gives a $17 million benefit to Honda. It's buried, I can show it to you in print. It's there big time. I can show you a deal --
KING Benefits a single company?
PEROT You bet. I can show you a deal on Tennessee whiskey that will make you just wonder what the heck is going on. The sky is not falling, the Japanese are our friends. They're not a threat. They're not a threat.
GORE Let me respond. Both automobile manufacturers, including Honda in Marysville, Ohio, Nissan in Tennessee, Saturn in Tennessee, all of the companies in Detroit, they benefit because that Mexican tariff is brought down to zero. Every other American from Tennessee, whiskey benefits, every American business potentially benefits if they want to sell in Mexico. Hold on, hold on, because I want to respond to her question. This is extremely important. President Salinas has a trade mission to Japan the month after the vote on Nafta. If we don't take this deal you can bet that Japan will try to take this deal. They'll be in there in a New York minute. Europe will try to get this deal. They are concerned about us taking this deal.
Listen, Larry, we ought to thank our lucky stars that the Mexican people have had the vision and courage to strike out on the American path toward the ideas of Thomas Jefferson, toward democracy, toward free markets and now they just want to know can we take yes for an answer.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Producer prices declined two-tenths of 1 percent in October, surprisingly strong reassurance that a pickup in the economy is not reviving inflation. Except for a modest rise in September, wholesale prices have fallen or been unchanged since April. [Page D1.] 
 A broad definition of sexual harassment in the workplace was announced by the Supreme Court, which will enable women to win suits without having to prove psychological damage. [A1.]
Few economists share the views of lawmakers that the proposed $32 billion merger of Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications will be anti-competitive. Economic Analysis. [D1.]
The failure of an Arkansas savings and loan owned by a former business partner of President Clinton will be investigated. [D2.]
 
International
Nafta has not received support from any New York, New Jersey or Connecticut House Democrat, evidence of the steep hill President Clinton must climb to win approval for the pact. [A1.]
The Bush Administration urged business to take advantage of low wages in the Caribbean, according to Government files that labor unions plan to use to fight Nafta. [B14.]
Russia has a bull market in vouchers issued to citizens for buying shares in state-owned enterprises being privatized. [D1.]
Japanese stocks went into a tailspin, pushed lower by gloomy economic news and losses in shares of East Japan Railway. [D2.]
Volkswagen and General Motors will negotiate a settlement of a dispute over the defection of G.M. managers to VW. [D4.]
 
Business Technology
Nextel announced a $1.8 billion deal to buy mobile-radio licenses from Motorola, adding to the company's nationwide telephone network that seeks to rival cellular technology. [D1.]
A talk show used a videophone to let a celebrity at a remote site interact with the hostess, guests and the audience. [D5.]
Banking and other services using telephones with calculator-like screens will be offered by Citicorp and Ameritech. [D5.]
The "new" Prodigy on-line service looks much the same as it did before a publicity campaign announcing changes. [D5.]
 
Companies
RJR Nabisco is raising most wholesale cigarette prices 4 cents a pack. The move reflects a change in strategy under the new chairman, Charles M. Harper, and may end a price war. [D4.]
AST Research will eliminate 1,050 jobs in consolidating the acquisition of Tandy's computer manufacturing business. [D2.]
I.B.M. unveiled a replacement for its antiquated mainframe line, but deliveries will not be made before late 1994. [D2.]
Price Waterhouse will receive an estimated $36 million fee in the auction of Macmillan for advising its parent. [D18.]
Ziff Communications' chairman William B. Ziff Jr. retired. He will be succeeded by Eric Hippeau, chairman of Ziff-Davis. [D18.]
 
Markets
The stock market reacted with indifference to good news on inflation. The Dow industrials fell 7.83 points, to 3,640.07. [D6.]
The Treasury struggled to sell new securities in the first leg of its quarterly auctions despite positive inflation data. [D16.]
The dollar rose against most currencies. [D15.] Corn futures are expected to jump after estimates of a smaller crop. [D15.]
 
Today's Columns
Boston Chicken shares soared in an initial public offering, helped by an unusual transaction in which officers actually bought stock in a companion offering. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
Ads on the Comedy Central cable channel rebut the contention that there is too much violence on television. Advertising. [D18.]

SECTION: Section D; Page 6; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 578 words

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 7.83 Points After a Run-Up Fizzles

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
The stock market has been yearning for more good news on the economy, but when the Government issued a surprisingly reassuring report on inflation yesterday, many investors seemed to evince only one reaction: ho-hum.
To be sure, the Dow Jones industrial average did jump more than 20 points in the first hour of the session, apparently because of the announcement that wholesale prices had declined two-tenths of 1 percent in October. Many private economists had predicted a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent. 
 But the Dow then journeyed downward, ending the day off 7.83 points, at 3,640.07. Other indicators also rose early before falling back to nearly unchanged levels, as if investors remained so guarded and worn-out after the grueling trading of the last few weeks that they refused to take many chances.
"No one wants to be a hero right now," said Edward E. Collins 3d, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities. "The long-term investors are sitting on the sidelines."
Mr. Collins said some investors may have discounted the bond market's rally yesterday, preferring to wait for more data on the economy in today's report on the Consumer Price Index for October. And the stock market may have been hesitant because of the cloudy fate of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which Vice President Al Gore and Ross Perot debated last night, after the market's close.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 276.4 million shares, slightly better than average and up from Monday's total of 234.3 million shares. Advancing issues led declining issues yesterday by about 4 to 3.
The Dow Jones utilities average, which many analysts consider a harbinger of the market's performance because its components are sensitive to interest rates, hit another 10-month low, falling 2.04 points, to 225.09.
 
Nasdaq Rises 3.63 Points
 Among the broad indicators, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks edged up 0.12 point, to 460.33. The American Stock Exchange composite index dropped 0.58 point, to 476.02. And the Nasdaq Composite index increased 3.63 points, to 769.84.
Tobacco stocks, which have been heavily traded in recent weeks, were among the most active issues because RJR Nabisco is raising prices on most of its brands, including Camel and Winston. RJR, the Big Board's most active issue yesterday, rose 3/8, to 6 3/4, while Philip Morris jumped 1, to 55 3/4, and American Brands was up 1/8, to 33 1/4.
Telefonos de Mexico was the third most active issue on the Big Board, its American depository receipts rising 1/8, to 50 1/2, amid concern over the free-trade accord.
Among other heavily traded stocks, Wal-Mart Stores was up 3/8, to 28 5/8, after reporting that its quarterly earnings and revenues were record highs. Dun & Bradstreet jumped 1 1/2, to 67 1/2. The company linked the active trading of its stock to its repurchase plan.
 
Motorola and Nextel Rise
 Motorola rose 1, to 99 3/4, after it sold a large group of mobile-radio licenses to Nextel Communications. Nextel's stock was up 1 1/4, to 47 1/4, in Nasdaq trading.
Bank, financial service and life insurance companies did well in response to the news of low inflation. Bankers Trust rose 1 to 76 1/4; First Chicago was up 3/4, to 44 3/4; American Express increased 1 1/4, to 31 7/8, and Wells Fargo jumped 2 1/8, to 112 3/4.
On the Nasdaq, Intuit shot up 5 3/4, to 43 1/2, after the company posted higher quarterly earnings than analysts had predicted.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Maxwell Advisers Seen As Winners in Breakup

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
Regardless of the outcome of today's auction of Macmillan Inc., some clear winners in the deal will be the advisers to Maxwell Communication, the parent company of Macmillan.
The biggest prize will go to Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm that is acting as the administrator in the liquidation sale of Maxwell's assets. According to court documents, Price Waterhouse will earn a fee of an estimated $36 million. That appears to be even more than what J. P. Morgan & Company will receive. The investment bank had already earned more than $6.5 million in fees, the documents show, and could earn several million more. The law firm of Milbank Tweed could earn $6.2 million. The total fees were estimated at $60 million. 
 Bidders in the auction for Macmillan, the crown jewel of the empire of the late Robert Maxwell, waited anxiously last night to learn who would win the venerable publishing house.
 
Decision Expected This Morning
 Administrators, lawyers and investment bankers representing Maxwell Communication were scheduled to meet with the Maxwell Creditors Committee at 8:15 this morning to approve a buyer. The meeting was expected to last two hours.
Maxwell Communication had been operating under the supervision of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan and administrators in London since shortly after the mysterious 1991 death of Mr. Maxwell. Price Waterhouse had been administering both the British and the United States bankruptcy proceeding of Maxwell Communication. J. P. Morgan is the banker handling the sale.
The four bidders are believed to be Paramount Communications, Harcourt General, Pearson P.L.C., and the K-III Communications Corporation. Though bidders had agreed not to divulge their offering prices, the publishing company was expected to bring as much as $500 million.
The deal has created some new relationships in the incestuous and intricate network of media companies, investment bankers and their lawyers at a time when Paramount is not only bidding for Macmillan, but is itself the subject of a bidding war betweem Viacom Inc. and QVC Network Inc.
While Lazard Freres was serving as Paramount's investment banker in the sale to Viacom, it is representing Pearson, a rival bidder to Paramount, in the Macmillan deal.
When Martin S. Davis, the chairman of Paramount, first considered bidding for Macmillan, he could not hire Lazard because it was representing Maxwell Communication, according to one banker with knowledge of the discussions.
So Paramount hired Rothschild Inc. to represent it. Later, when Lazard was no longer working for Maxwell, Paramount had already hired a banker. Lazard then found itself a client in Pearson, which is 50 percent owner of Lazard's British unit.
 
Melding Operations
 Paramount could justify paying a higher price for Macmillan than could some of its competitors, several industry experts noted, because melding the two companies would invite some economies of scale.
Although K-III, a publishing company run by former Macmillan executives, does not own book publishing businesses that would have the same cost controls, its management was eager to regain control over a company it once ran and was expected to be an aggressive bidder, according to several executives close to the negotiations.
While Paramount's college publishing business is the largest in the world, and Macmillan's is the seventh largest, a possible merger was not expected to raise antitrust issues because the college textbook market is fragmented, with professors selecting the reading for their classes. In contrast, school districts or state agencies select the reading material for an entire elementary or high school system.
Macmillan represents the last major asset sale of the Maxwell empire. When it is all over, according to documents filed earlier this year with the British and American bankruptcy courts, Price Waterhouse, the two law firms involved in the deal -- Norton Rose is the other -- and the United States bankruptcy examiner and advisers are projected to collect a total of about $60 million in fees.
According to the documents, J. P. Morgan had already earned at least $6.5 million, after the sale of Official Airline Guides and and some other assets. Today's sale of Macmillan is expected to provide a fee of several million dollars more, the documents indicated.
One Maxwell creditor with expertise in bankruptcy investing said yesterday that the fees in this case had been on the high side. Price Waterhouse and Milbank Tweed executives could not be reached for comment yesterday evening. J. P. Morgan declined to comment.
 
Viacom Amends Lawsuit
 Separately, Viacom Inc. amended its antitrust lawsuit against QVC yesterday to include Comcast Corporation, which is supporting QVC in its hostile bid for Paramount Communications.
Viacom had previously filed an antitrust suit against QVC and two companies controlled by John C. Malone, the powerful cable executive, whose Liberty Media Corporation is the largest shareholder in QVC.
The suit charged that a series of practices were anticompetitive and had hurt Viacom. Yesterday's suit contended that other actions were also anticompetitive, including conduct that forced Viacom to raise its offer for Paramount Communications by $2 billion. Viacom had raised its bid twice since the initial merger plan was signed on Sept. 11.
