HEADLINE: At Haiti-Dominican Border: Barrier or Loophole?

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANICA, Dominican Republic, Nov. 4

 BODY:
More a creek than a river, the Rio Artibonito forms the border between Haiti and the Dominican Republic, and for as long as the two countries have existed people on both sides have often just waded across at points like this whenever they wanted to trade with each other.
But with Western ships off the Haitian coast, the success of an oil and arms embargo against Haiti may ultimately depend on enforcement of the sanctions along the country's 241-mile border with the Dominican Republic. 
 So it was no surprise when the Dominican President, Joaquin Balaguer, visited this market town today and proclaimed that there had been no violations of the sanctions.
"Since the embargo began, this country has not sent a single drop of oil to Haiti," Mr. Balaguer said. He said his country would continue to abide by the embargo imposed by the United Nations and the Organization of American States, "so long as they do not condemn the Haitian people to hunger."
 
Embargo Is Reimposed
 The United Nations reimposed the embargo last month after the Haitian military began to renege on an agreement to restore the country's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to power.
Mr. Balaguer has since been under growing international pressure to insure that no oil or arms cross the border. But diplomats say his Government is ambivalent at best about complying with its obligations.
With a presidential election only six months away, Mr. Balaguer, who is running for re-election, wants to avoid a situation in which thousands of desperate and hungry Haitians flee across the border and are settled in refugee camps run by the United Nations.
The 87-year-old President's distaste for Haitians is no secret, having been documented in two books he wrote, and he has told foreign diplomats that he thinks the embargo is a mistake. Diplomats and other political experts say Mr. Balaguer had an amiable relationship with Haiti's former Duvalier family dictatorship and has privately expressed dislike for Father Aristide, a leftist priest.
"Balaguer will do everything he can not to respect the embargo," Wilfredo Lozano, director of the Dominican branch of the Latin American Faculty of Social Sciences and an expert on Dominican-Haitian relations, said in an interview in Santo Domingo, the capital. "But he is a practical man, smart enough to know that could lead to confrontation and isolation, so he will observe the forms of the blockade while hoping that holes will open in it."
A diplomat in Santo Domingo said that given the porous nature of the border, "it is accepted that there is going to be some slippage" in the embargo. The countries that want to see Father Aristide return to power are willing to accept some small-scale profiteering, he said, so long as they are certain that Haitian military or Government officials are not running the operation.
"Juan Valdez may be running across the border with 20 one-gallon milk containers full of gasoline strapped to his back," the diplomat said. "But that's not a major violation. It's the 20-truck convoys being waved through the checkpoints that we're worried about, and so far we haven't seen any of that."
Any continuous large-scale truck traffic across the border can take place only through the three main crossings, at Jimani, Dajabon and Elias Pina. The Haitian military is rushing to complete a two-lane road that would allow traffic to flow smoothly from Jimani to the Haitian capital, Port-au-Prince, and this has caused international concern about Dominican compliance with the embargo.
In late October, a foreign reporter on the Haitian side of the Jimani crossing saw six heavy trucks pass through in the 15 minutes soldiers allowed him to linger. One of the trucks appeared to be carrying oil, though the nature of its cargo could not be confirmed.
 
Steady Flow of Trucks
 During a five-hour drive on the main highway from Santo Domingo to Jimani recently, only one truck with Haitian license plates was observed. The truck, which was loaded with metal drums of the type used to transport oil, sped away, seemingly when its driver sensed that he was being trailed.
Dominican officials acknowledge there is a steady flow of truck traffic through Jimani into Haiti. But they maintain that all of the goods being exported there or sold openly to Haitians at markets in towns like Banica, often at prices that are triple those of just a few weeks ago, consist of food, medicine and other items specifically exempted from the embargo.
"It is not true that the Dominican Republic does not support the blockade," Deputy Foreign Minister Fabio Herrera Cabral told reporters. "The list of articles being sent is limited to humanitarian articles."
Among the goods crossing from the Dominican Republic into Haiti, Mr. Herrera acknowledged, are rice, sugar, cooking oil and "items for personal cooking," like propane gas. "We are only sending what is permitted, and within that is propane gas, which is for cooking food," he said.
The United Nations has threatened to widen the embargo to cover all goods except vital food and medicine if the Haitian military does not back down. But Western governments are still somewhat reluctant to stiffen the sanctions at this point. Already the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere, Haiti is suffering more each week because the fuel cutoff has slowed delivery of supplies.
 
All Oil Is Imported
 The Dominican Republic produces no oil itself, importing it from Venezuela and Mexico under an agreement negotiated in the 1980's. Latin American diplomats in Santo Domingo said Venezuela, one of four countries underwriting the July agreement intended to restore Father Aristide to power, was determined not to let the Dominican Republic flout the embargo.
"A sudden surge in oil imports would not go unnoticed here or in Caracas," one said. "That has not happened yet, but if there are signs of an increase in oil purchases, I am sure that question will be promptly addressed."
The commander of Haiti's armed forces, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, and the Port-au-Prince police chief, Col. Joseph Michel Francois, have relatives in the Dominican Republic who have come under scrutiny, Haitian exiles in Santo Domingo say. The exiles, who insisted on anonymity, said that a brother of General Cedras had been involved in a small air-charter business in Santo Domingo but that the company's planes were too small to haul large amounts of gasoline.
In recent weeks there has been a noticeable buildup of military and police forces on the Dominican side of the border. Residents of the region say the Dominican troops have been focusing not so much on enforcing the embargo as preventing Haitians from crossing the border and deporting those who have already reached Dominican territory.
At the many checkpoints along the border, armed soldiers stop every car and truck headed toward Haiti, but do not search the vehicles for weapons or other contraband. Instead, they briefly question drivers and passengers in Spanish, hoping to detect Creole-speaking Haitians by their accents.
Dominican press reports say that as many as 600 Haitians have been arrested on Dominican soil and forcibly returned to Haiti and that many of them pay bribes of about $4 a head to Haitian soldiers to stay out of jail.
Mr. Balaguer formally ordered the repatriation campaign halted late last month, saying the armed forces "did not understand my instructions well."

GRAPHIC: At the Jimani main border crossing, one of three between Haiti and the Dominican Republic, a Haitian youth ran carrying a gasoline container. Many Haitians are getting fuel from the Dominican Republic despite its President's claim that his country has not violated U.N. sanctions. (Fuminori Sato/Impact for The New York Times)
 
Map shows the border between the Dominican Republic and Haiti.

HEADLINE: Paris Journal;
France's Homeless Get Help! Read All About It!

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 9

 BODY:
After a chilly night huddled in blankets outside the Musee d'Orsay, Georges was up with the sun and ready for a morning's work selling Macadam Journal at an open-air market near the Seine in Paris's elegant 16th arrondissement. By noon, he had earned enough for a good lunch.
"It has made a big difference for me," he said, nodding toward the tabloid newspaper "for the homeless" that he was holding out to passers-by. "I can stay in a small hotel one night out of three, but at least I'm well fed now. And I have saved a bit of money." 
 A hundred yards away, past stalls weighed down with the best meat, fish, vegetables, pates and cheeses that France can offer, Raymond, a slightly unshaven man in his mid-30's, called out softly, "Macadam Journal, the paper of the S.D.F." -- the French initials for "Sans Domicile Fixe," or "No Fixed Address."
"I lost my job last year because of the economic crisis, then things fell apart in my life," he said unapologetically. "But for the past three months I have been doing this and things are looking up. Someone I met selling the paper even offered me a free room."
When Macadam Journal appeared in May, the founders made no claim to originality. Street News in New York and The Big Issue in London both served as inspirations for the new monthly.
 
A Growing Phenomenon
 But the appearance of a street people's newspaper here -- it takes its name from the word used to describe the surface of a road -- is itself confirmation that Paris is beginning to experience social problems long familiar to New York and London. Paris may have always had wine-swilling "clochards" living under its bridges, but the notion of homeless is relatively new here.
The dimensions of the problem are hard to measure. Private associations supporting the homeless estimate that half a million people live in inadequate housing in France, while Government officials put the number of people without a permanent home at about 200,000. What no one disputes is that the phenomenon is growing and that, in Paris at least, the sight of homeless people sleeping in doorways no longer causes surprise.
As winter approaches, both Government and charitable organizations are hurriedly preparing centers that offer a bed and a meal for the homeless. Transportation officials have also set up relief programs to prevent train stations, the subway and airports from becoming improvised shelters from the cold.
But with unemployment now standing at 3.2 million, or 11.8 percent of the work force, and still rising, the underlying causes of the problem remain. Men -- and some women -- lose their jobs, their unemployment benefits run out, they can no longer afford to pay rents and they end up on the streets.
More than for the tramps, drug addicts and the new influx of Romanian Gypsies who try to survive by begging and often upset the public with their fierce panhandling approach, Macadam Journal is intended mainly for those homeless people who are victims of temporary misfortune but who still hope to resume normal lives.
 
Falling on Hard Times
 "We don't deal with clochards," Leila Khallouki, the paper's communications director, said. "We're looking for the new S.D.F. We have some 600 vendors, and 90 percent of them have suffered some accident -- in their lives, families, health or jobs -- that has put them on the streets."
Gerard -- a 36-year-old former businessman who, like others, asked that his full name not be used -- said he lost all his savings when 11 cars that he had exported to Poland were seized in a dispute over customs payments. "I had to leave my apartment and move into a hotel that I pay for daily," he said.
Since July, though, he has been selling Macadam Journal, and he boasts that he was able to save enough to take two children from a broken marriage to Eurodisney. "They don't know what I do because I always appear in jacket and tie," he said.
The newspaper sells on the street for 10 francs, or $1.69, of which the vendor keeps 6 francs, or $1.02. Olivier, who arrived at the monthly's depot in Aubervilliers outside Paris with his 18-month-old girl, Marianne, asserted that he sold 200 copies one Saturday, probably a record. Olivier admitted sheepishly that sales were better when he carried Marianne.
But even with one vendor's daily sales averaging, say, 50 copies, they can still earn around $400 a week, enough to pay for a small hotel and simple meals. "It gives us a chance," Gerard said. "My aim is to come here one day and say, thank you, Martine, I'm not going to sell Macadam Journal anymore."
 
An Extraordinary Success
 Martine Vanden Driessche is editor of the paper, but it is the brainchild of Jacques Chamut, a Belgian businessman who decided that there was a need for a French-language version of The Big Issue, for sale not only in Paris and Brussels but also in other French and Belgian cities where homeless are now appearing.
Written by professional journalists, the 24-page monthly tackles broad social issues for the general reader. And whether people buy it out of sympathy for the vendors or out of interest in its contents, its success has been extraordinary. Its first issue sold 100,000 copies, its fourth 400,000.
Indeed, its example is already being followed. One of its former vendors, Georges Mathis, has founded La Reverbere, which is written by homeless people and is backed by several neighborhood associations. A bimonthly glossy, La Rue, is now also sold by homeless.
For the homeless vendors, who are required to dress as well as possible and are urged to avoid "aggressive" sales tactics, what matters most is that they have recovered some dignity. And at least Macadam Journal has now become a symbol of respectability that seems to reassure the general public.
"What I most like is that people come up to chat," Georges said as he awaited a sale beside a vegetable stall in the 16th arrondissement market. "They want to help people who want to help themselves. If I'm not seen for a few days, they ask, What happened? Are you all right? In the past, they would look the other way."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "It has made a big difference for me," Georges, left, said about Macadam Journal, France's first newspaper to be sold by the homeless. "I can stay in a small hotel one night out of three, but at least I'm well fed now. And I have saved a bit of money." He sold the tabloid in Paris's 16th arrondissement. (Alan Riding/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Haven for Hopeless Causes;
Devotions to St. Jude Are Growing, Manhattan Church Says

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Clutching rosaries or wrinkled prayer cards, thousands of urban pilgrims filed through the sanctuary of St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church over the course of a recent week, seeking answers to the impossible -- chronic illnesses, broken marriages, lost jobs -- or just a glimpse of happiness. Laborers and executives, blacks and whites, young and old sat together during prayers, lining up afterward for a blessing from a relic of St. Jude, the patron saint of impossible causes.
Attendance at the devotions has doubled at the Manhattan church in the last six years, just one sign of the popularity of this dedication of prayers to a saint who, despite having been one of Christ's 12 Apostles, had been obscure until a priest in Chicago erected a shrine to St. Jude. It has become one of the most durable American devotions, with numerous prayer services that attract even non-Catholics. There are also countless tiny newspaper ads by worshipers that read "Thank you, St. Jude, " and there is even a St. Jude chain letter. 
 Every era spawns its own reasons for interest in the saint -- the Depression and World War II saw the devotion become so popular that some priests broadcast them on the radio. Recently, the Persian Gulf War, a stale economy and the AIDS scourge have attracted new followers in quest of miraculous solutions.
 
Peace and Solidarity
 But there is also a desire to satisfy a more fundamental need.
"People need a place to go to pray, a sense of peace and they need the opportunity to express their sorrows," said the Rev. Eric Carpine, who leads the devotions at St. Francis of Assisi, on West 31st Street between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue. "They can look around and see others suffering. There is some solidarity that comes from that, and a great deal of strength."
Saints are seen by the faithful as people who led exemplary lives and have the ability to intercede with God.
"It's easier to approach a human person than it is to approach God directly," said the Rev. George Concordia, a Dominican friar in charge of the St. Jude shrine at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan. "You have more empathy with a St. Jude. You identify with a human being."
Virginia, who would give only her first name, credited her prayers to St. Jude for her son's rapid recovery from an accident that had left him unconscious four years ago. She has attended the weekly prayer sessions at St. Francis ever since. "You've got to have faith; otherwise you couldn't go through it," she said. "People do have faith that things do get better. Even if it doesn't look that way."
The American Catholic tradition of devotion to St. Jude is relatively recent for a martyr who was both a relative and disciple of Jesus Christ. It began in 1929 when the Rev. James Tort, a member of the Claretian order, founded a shrine in honor of the saint at a Chicago church that attracted people who were struggling through unbearable economic times.
Robert Orsi, a professor of religious studies at Indiana University and the author of an upcoming book on American women's devotion to the saint, said it was then common to finance church buildings through devotions to a particular saint. In Chicago, the devotions helped to pay off a church debt and assisted in the financing of a seminary.
St. Jude had been somewhat obscure in this country partly because his identity was confused with that of Judas Iscariot, the disciple whom the New Testament said betrayed Christ. As an indication of the saint's marginal status, Mr. Orsi noted, in Chile Jude was considered the patron saint of prostitutes.
By choosing the relatively unheralded saint, Mr. Orsi said, Father Tort faced no competition from other religious orders with established devotions. Since then, other shrines have sprung up across the country, and smaller versions where a statue is placed in a church niche.
The devotion's American origins may be one reason for its enduring popularity, especially among the children of immigrants and non-Catholics, Mr. Orsi said. Unlike other saints, like Poland's Black Madonna or Mexico's Virgin of Guadalupe, St. Jude is not firmly identified with the religious experiences of any particular ethnic group. "Jude is attractive because he is not an ethnic saint," said Mr. Orsi. "Jude is really an Americanized saint."
St. Jude's association with impossible or lost causes has been somewhat harder to determine. Several priests whose parishes have shrines to the saint said that peoples' belief in St. Jude's ability to help them through extraordinarily difficult times stemmed partly from the very obscurity that had dogged St. Jude. His guilt by association, because his name was similar to that of Christ's betrayer, allowed people to relate their burdens to St. Jude's.
"It seems they believed that some of the worst needs were relegated to him because of his relationship to Christ," said the Rev. John Lemrise, the novena director at the Chicago shrine. "We are convinced that the grass roots discovered a quality they attributed to St. Jude."
 
Testimonies of Faithful
 The shrine's newsletter features testimonies from the faithful, who said their prayers had been responsible for recoveries from aneurysms and comas, for finding jobs and even for selling a house in a slow market.
Toni C., a songwriter and a recovering addict, offered her prayers at St. Francis for other addicts and their families. She said her devotion to St. Jude dated to her childhood, when her younger sister's paralysis from spinal meningitis was inexplicably relieved after her family prayed.
"Having a patron saint is like having a sponsor who looks out for you," she said.
Roy Davidson, who helps at services at St. Francis, said it was important to remember that prayers to the saints are asking for their intercession with God.
"It's good and healthy as long as they approach the devotion in the right frame of mind," said Mr. Davidson, who said he prayed to the saint a few years ago for the strength to cope with his companion's death. "It's like approaching a friend to ask a favor. I wouldn't approach him as I would approach God."
 
Long-Term Relationships
 Mr. Orsi said that the devotion has endured despite what he saw as a disdain among theologians and liturgists. "These guys think that relating to the sacred is awesome and unreachable except through the official teachings of the church," he said. "But lots of people found access to what they considered the holy through the saints. To enter into a relationship with Jude, in a desperate time, that is to enter a relationship that often lasts for decades."
Danny Thomas, the late entertainer, often said St. Jude had answered his prayers when his early career was sputtering. In thanks, Mr. Thomas was the moving force in establishing the St. Jude Children's Research Hospital in Memphis.
The classified ads thanking the saint are viewed with mixed emotions by priests. While the ads spread knowledge of the saint and encourage others to pray to him, some priests feel the money spent on the ads could be better used on donations to soup kitchens or homeless shelters.
Some priests worry that the ads are part of an improvised religious tradition that in some extreme cases are more akin to superstition and send the wrong message about the devotion.
Indeed, some practices surrounding the devotion have been criticized as superstitious and as preying on people's fears, including the proliferation of a chain letter. It promises solutions to any problem in return for saying a prayer to St. Jude and other prayers over a nine-day period. It also asks the worshiper to leave nine copies of the letter inside a church each day.
Such practices reduce the devotion to an acquisitive exercise where a rote incantation to a saint possesses some magical power, said the Rev. James Gill, a psychiatrist and Jesuit.
 
'An Intermediary'
 "A solid piety knows it is God who does the deed and answers their prayers and the saint is only an intermediary," he said. "Those who are more superstitious will direct a plea to St. Jude, get what they want at times and not think beyond that. They don't attribute it so much to God but to the pull a saint has."
He added that even within the accepted forms of the devotion, people had to be careful in interpreting an answered prayer as a miracle. In strict terms, miracles are occurrences that transcend the laws of nature, not the marketplace. An unexpected cure from a terminal illness might qualify, happening upon a rent-controlled apartment would not.
Dr. Gill and other priests emphasized that prayers had to be not just for help with needs, but also for praise and thanksgiving, adding that without a deeper, well-rounded faith, the devotions would be empty.
Dennis O'Donnell has faith in the young people he works with as the head basketball coach at St. Thomas Aquinas College in Rockland County. He makes a regular "pilgrimage" to the city to offer his prayers to St. Jude on their behalf.
"I suppose the hardest thing in the world is for a young person to grow up and be good," he said. "It's just so easy for kids to get messed up."
Of course, some people think he's really praying for victory, although he insists that's not the reason. But he wouldn't mind that, either.
"We have been winning the past couple of years," he said, smiling. "I guess there's been some spillover."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
A Wireless Upstart Gets Bigger

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

 BODY:
The revolution in wireless communications took a new turn yesterday as an upstart company acquired the capstone for a nationwide network that could give cellular phone companies and giants like A.T.& T. a run for their money.
Capping a steady and often stealthy six-year buying binge, Nextel Communications Inc., of Rutherford, N.J., announced it would buy a huge collection of mobile-radio licenses from Motorola Inc. for $1.8 billion in stock. When combined with licenses that Nextel had already acquired, the company now has the potential -- theoretically at least -- to serve 180 million people across 21 states. 
 That is roughly three times the number of people covered by McCaw Cellular Communications, the nation's biggest cellular operator, which American Telephone and Telegraph is buying for $12.6 billion.
"We admit it, we are the skunk at the wireless picnic," said Morgan E. O'Brien, chairman of Nextel. "No one invited us."
Using digital technology to update old-fashioned taxicab radio services, Nextel officials say they hope to offer a sophisticated rival to cellular networks within three years. Besides carrying ordinary voice conversations, as cellular does, the new Nextel networks would offer built-in paging and data communications -- features not available with most current cellular service.
The company has already begun operating such a network in Los Angeles and expects to cover almost all of California by spring. In the metropolitan New York area, Nextel's service should be running by next summer.
Nextel officials also announced yesterday that Nippon Telegraph and Telephone , the Japanese telephone giant, would invest $75 million in the company and would design a nationwide signaling system to enable Nextel to link all its local systems into a single network within three years.
Despite Nextel's potential, made possible by a more than fourfold increase in the company's stock in the last year, the challenges ahead are enormous. For one thing, the existing cellular industry has a huge head start with roughly 12 million customers nationwide. Nextel would not be fully operational until at least 1996.
Moreover Nextel, despite having raised more than $1 billion in working capital during the last two years, will also need a lot of additional financing. Brian D. McAuley, Nextel's president, estimated that Nextel's initial construction costs would total $1.2 billion.
Beyond that, the company will need hundreds of millions of dollars to cover marketing and operations. Industry analysts estimate that cellular companies incur marketing costs of $500 to sign up each customer, and some predict Nextel will have to spend $650 a customer because its equipment and service is not as familiar.
Currently, Nextel has about $400 million in cash from recent stock and junk-bond offerings, and $520 million in credit from Motorola, which supplies Nextel's network equipment. Mr. McAuley has made it clear the company will be raising extra money, either from the public markets or from investment partners.
But Nextel is well positioned to raise money on the strength of its stock, which has soared from a low of $9 last year to the mid-40's recently. Nasdaq trading in Nextel's stock was temporarily halted yesterday morning after the company made its announcement. When trading resumed, the shares soared $5 to more than $51 each, a record, before easing back to close at $47.25, up $1.25 for the day.
Money could come from some of its current partners, like the Comcast Corporation, a Philadelphia-based company with extensive holdings in cable television, cellular and other communications services. Comcast has already invested $300 million, and it holds options to buy shares at $16. Exercising those options would bring Nextel $400 million, Mr. McAuley said.
But the company faces obstacles besides money. Nextel telephones are currently bulkier and more expensive than comparable cellular phones. And company officials acknowledge that they cannot yet economically compete for low-budget consumers who spend only $50 a month on cellular service. At least initially, the company plans to focus on business customers who want both cellular service and more traditional fleet-radio services.
 
A Credible Player
 Nevertheless, Nextel has clearly emerged as a credible player in the wireless wars. Its biggest advantage is that it and the other big "radio dispatch" carriers like Cencall Communications of Denver and Dialpage Inc. of Greenville, S.C., will all use the same digital technology developed by Motorola. That should make it much easier for these companies' subscribers to use the same telephone when they travel to different cities, and for the carriers to serve one another's traveling customers.
By contrast, the cellular industry is now divided among at least three different technologies. One is the traditional analog system in which sounds are transmitted in the form of waves. The other two are dueling digital technologies, each of which can greatly increase the capacity of a cellular network and is expected to improve sound quality. The cellular industry is split over which of the two digital technologies is better, while many smaller companies are reluctant to spend the money to move beyond the older analog systems,
Nextel, meanwhile, may be able to get a jump on companies developing "personal communication services," or P.C.S., a broad family of new wireless services that will use a huge block of the airwaves that the Federal Communications Commission opened up last month.
Most of these new services will not be up and running for at least three years, because the F.C.C. will not even begin handing out licenses until it starts auctioning them off next June. Many industry experts say the F.C.C. has also doomed the fledgling P.C.S. industry to fragmentation by electing not to offer any nationwide licenses, deciding instead to offer more than 2,500 regional licenses.
Nextel may benefit directly from the P.C.S. rules. The F.C.C. placed strict limits on the ability of cellular telephone companies to bid for the new licenses, because it was afraid cellular companies would stifle new rivals. But it placed no limit on companies like Nextel, which can now bid on P.C.S. licenses to fill out any remaining blank spots in their holdings.
Many analysts had been expecting a deal like the one announced today, in which Motorola is selling Nextel hundreds of licenses in 21 states. Nextel had recently been on a frenzied acquisition campaign, expanding its portfolio of properties. And it had cemented agreements with other big operators of mobile-radio services to help create a national market by using the same technology as Nextel.
Motorola, which has been the nation's largest operator of these so-called "specialized mobile radio" services, had already sold off a big chunk of its holdings to two other companies similar to Nextel, Cencall and Dialpage.
Motorola, the world's largest maker of cellular and paging equipment, developed the technology being used by Nextel.

HEADLINE: A Satisfactory Marriage;
Many Economists See Boon to Competition In Merger of Cable and Phone Companies

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
The proposed $32 billion merger of Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications may turn out to be not only the biggest deal yet, but also one of the most scrutinized.
The Justice Department, the Federal Communications Commission and a host of Congressional committees are all expected to weigh in. Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, the Ohio Democrat whose Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust policy held hearings last month on the merger of the giant regional phone company and the nation's largest cable television conglomerate, has attacked the deal as a "double whammy for consumers," a mega-monster that will raise both phone and cable prices. 
 Many economists, by contrast, seem almost sanguine about the proposed combination. While they acknowledge that a merger of this magnitude in so important an industry merits a close look, few share Senator Metzenbaum's concerns. "If they spin off T.C.I.'s cable companies in Bell Atlantic's own phone territory, I just don't see any anticompetitive aspects," said Robert Crandall of the Brookings Institution.
Peter Pitsch, a former adviser to the F.C.C., thinks the merger could actually stimulate competition. "The new company," he predicts, "could give local telephone monopolies a run for their money in wireless voice communications."
Economists generally expect free markets to discipline themselves; if one producer charges excessively, it will attract other sellers and drive down prices. But because it was assumed there was really only the need (or room) for one set of telephone lines, communications policy has long been aimed at letting a local phone company operate as a protected franchise and then closely regulating its prices and performance.
The catch is that even under the best circumstances, regulation can only approximate the outcome of competitive markets. And as technology has made it possible to carry voice or video in many different ways -- on different kinds of wire or even beamed without wire -- the neat market boundaries have evaporated, making it ever more problematic that the waste associated with unchecked private market power would exceed the waste linked to less than omniscient regulation. For many economists, in fact, the far greater worry today is that Government control will retard technological change or distort it to favor entrenched interests.
It is still easy to see why the alarm bells are ringing in Washington. the Bell Atlantic Corporation alone provides a dial tone for 18 million phones and operates cellular systems with 800,000 customers. Tele-Communications Inc. serves 13 million cable subscribers and has a big stake in video programming, owning chunks of the Turner Broadcasting System, the Discovery Channel and the Liberty Media Corporation. What is more, Tele-Communications' chief executive, John C. Malone, has never been shy about exploiting a new opportunity.
But Alfred E. Kahn, the last chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board and a father of the deregulation movement, points out that sheer size and aggressiveness are poor yardsticks of a corporation's market power. What counts is the capacity to manipulate the price of services bought and sold at the expense of customers, suppliers or competitors. How one views this merger, he suggests, should depend on how one expects the market for telecommunications services to evolve.
 
The Competitive Shootout
 The seven unregulated parent companies of the regulated local telephone carriers have campaigned for years for the right to offer cable video services to their phone customers -- a right denied them under the 1982 judicial decree breaking up A.T.& T. The idea, which seemed reasonable at the time, was that the sale of unregulated services would generate insurmountable conflicts of interest for local phone monopolies.
By the same token, cable companies have been itching to compete in the portion of the telephone market now dominated by the local Bells. And while some can and do provide specialized data communications to businesses, they have yet to obtain permission from state regulators or make the investment in switching equipment needed to operate a local telephone network.
Many analysts had expected that if the regulatory obstacles were removed, the two forms of communications networks would eventually engage in a bitter battle to sell an array of advanced services ranging from picture phones to catalogue shopping to movies on demand.
At first glance then, a merger of a big cable company and a big phone company seems to upset the prospects for a competitive shootout in which consumers are guaranteed to be the winners. But hardly anything is so simple in the rapidly changing, technologically driven market for telecommunications.
One complication, argues Leland Johnson, an economist who recently retired from the Rand Corporation, is that the two kinds of communications networks are not really competitive equals. The coaxial cable used by cable television gives the cable companies an enormous advantage now because it has far more capacity to carry information than the pair of copper wires currently used to link most phones.
In fact, coaxial cable may be sufficient to provide the first generation of interactive video services, leaving potential competitors from the telephone side of the market with the difficult choice of leap-frogging the cable operators by investing in super-expensive fiber-optic links to homes or leaving the field of battle.
 
A New Class of Competition
 Mr. Pitsch, the former F.C.C. adviser, notes that another complication is that it is far from clear that the primary challenge to cable's video services will come from competing wire networks, like the phone companies, or that challenges to local phone companies' voice and data transmission will come from cable. There may well be yet more competition from companies that transmit signals with no wires at all; satellites, for example, could be used to broadcast video direct to homes and wireless phones may go head to head with the wired networks.
In fact, direct broadcast service with the potential for more than 100 interference-free channels is scheduled to begin next year. To make such a service interactive, however, users would have to send messages back to the broadcaster by ordinary phone lines.
Moreover, the cable networks may never go into the wired phone business because their main competitive chance lies elsewhere. Mr. Pitsch points out that tiny, wireless phones may have significant cost advantages over conventional wired networks. And he says existing cable systems may prove the perfect match for the new technology, accommodating the thousands of transmission "nodes" a personal communications system would need to operate within a single large city.
In any case, Bell Atlantic is not about to concede that the merger would reduce competition, even if one discounts the prospects for a new generation of wireless video and phone services. Jim Smith, a spokesman for the company, points out that a combined Bell Atlantic-Tele-Communications would sell off all its local cable systems in the states where Bell Atlantic now operates wired phone networks. "How can it be anticompetitive," Mr. Smith asks, for Bell Atlantic to provide the cash and technical expertise to speed the enhancement of T.C.I.'s plain-vanilla video cable systems.
This is not quite the last word in the debate, however. By being first, it is at least plausible that Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications could discourage local phone companies from going into the interactive video business themselves.
That assumes, of course, that the regional Bells would otherwise be able to surmount the technological and financial hurdles of converting existing phone networks into information superhighways. Rapid enhancement of Tele-Communications' cable systems might also lock up millions of customers for the expensive new video services, deterring investment in direct-broadcast satellites.
But Mr. Pitsch is not impressed by such scenarios. Telecommunications are changing so rapidly and the difficulty of predicting winning and losing technologies is so great, he argues, that Washington would be foolish to second-guess those willing to take big risks in search of big profits. "I'm glad it's Bell Atlantic's money, not mine," he says.
What does worry many economists is a less-noticed potential bottleneck to competition: the cost of producing programming is so great today and the audience so fragmented, says David Waterman, an economist at the University of Indiana, that new cable channels need access to every home they can get. Thus a big cable system -- notably Tele-Communications Inc., which already has a hammerlock on the cables serving one home in four -- can extract the best possible terms from program producers.
The issue gets even stickier if -- as is the case with Tele-Communications Inc. -- the cable system already has a substantial investment in the programming business. How, for example, should one expect Tele-Communications to respond to the formation of another all-news network when it owns a chunk of CNN through its investment in Turner Broadcasting?
But Tele-Communications' share of the total cable market is smaller than the maximum 30 percent permitted by the F.C.C. If that share were deemed anticompetitive, the commission (or Congress) could always reduce it. In any case, Mr. Waterman allows, this potential for discriminating against programmers would not be increased by union with Bell Atlantic.
"The merger probably won't make telecommunications less competitive," Mr. Johnson cautiously concludes. "And it may make it more competitive."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Economic Analysis

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Supreme Court Ruling on Sexual Harassment in Workplace

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's ruling today on sexual harassment in the workplace. The Court ruled unamimously that workers suing their employers for sexual harassment need not show that they suffered psychological injury. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote the opinion, Harris v. Forklift systems. While joining the opinion, Justices Antonin Scalia and Ruth Bader Ginsburg also filed separate concurring opinions.
 
BY JUSTICE O'CONNOR,
For the Court
 In this case we consider the definition of a discriminatorily "abusive work environment" (also known as a "hostile work environment") under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. 
 Teresa Harris worked as a manager at Forklift Systems, Inc., an equipment rental company, from April 1985 until October 1987. Charles Hardy was Forklift's president.
The magistrate found that, throughout Harris's time at Forklift, Hardy often insulted her because of her gender and often made her the target of unwanted sexual innuendos. Hardy told Harris on several occasions, in the presence of other employees, "You're a woman, what do you know" and, "We need a man as the rental manager;" at least once, he told her she was "a dumb ass woman." Again in front of others, he suggested that the two of them "go to the Holiday Inn to negotiate (Harris's) raise." Hardy occasionally asked Harris and other female employees to get coins from his front pants pocket. He threw objects on the ground in front of Harris and other women, and asked them to pick the objects up. He made sexual innuendos about Harris's and other women's clothing.
In mid-August 1987, Harris complained to Hardy about his conduct. Hardy said he was surprised that Harris was offended, claimed he was only joking, and apologized. He also promised he would stop, and based on this assurance Harris stayed on the job. But in early September, Hardy began anew: While Harris was arranging a deal with one of Forklift's customers, he asked her, again in front of other employees, "What did you do, promise the guy . . . some (sex) Saturday night?" On Oct. 1, Harris collected her paycheck and quit.
Harris then sued Forklift, claiming that Hardy's conduct had created an abusive work environment for her because of her gender. The United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee, adopting the report and recommendation of the magistrate, found this to be "a close case," but held that Hardy's conduct did not create an abusive environment. The court found that some of Hardy's comments "offended (Harris), and would offend the reasonable woman," but that they were not "so severe as to be expected to seriously affect (Harris's) psychological well-being. A reasonable woman manager under like circumstances would have been offended by Hardy, but his conduct would not have risen to the level of interfering with that person's work performance.
"Neither do I believe that (Harris) was subjectively so offended that she suffered injury . . . . Although Hardy may at times have genuinely offended (Harris), I do not believe that he created a working environment so poisoned as to be intimidating or abusive to (Harris)."
 
Conflict Among Circuits
 In focusing on the employee's psychological well-being, the District Court was following Circuit precedent. See Rabidue v. Osceola Refining Co. (CA6 1986). The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit affirmed in a brief unpublished decision.
We granted certiorari, to resolve a conflict among the circuits on whether conduct, to be actionable as "abusive work environment" harassment (no quid pro quo harassment issue is present here), must "seriously affect (an employee's) psychological well-being" or lead the plaintiff to "suffe(r) injury." . . .
Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 makes it "an unlawful employment practice for an employer . . . to discriminate against any individual with respect to his compensation, terms, conditions, or privileges of employment, because of such individual's race, color, religion, sex, or national origin." As we made clear in Meritor Savings Bank v. Vinson, (1986), this language "is not limited to 'economic' or 'tangible' discrimination. The phrase 'terms, conditions, or privileges of employment' evinces a Congressional intent 'to strike at the entire spectrum of disparate treatment of men and women' in employment," which includes requiring people to work in a discriminatorily hostile or abusive environment. When the workplace is permeated with "discriminatory intimidation, ridicule, and insult," that is "sufficiently severe or pervasive to alter the conditions of the victim's employment and create an abusive working environment," Title VII is violated.
This standard, which we reaffirm today, takes a middle path between making actionable any conduct that is merely offensive and requiring the conduct to cause a tangible psychological injury. As we pointed out in Meritor, "mere utterance of an . . . epithet which engenders offensive feelings in a employee," does not sufficiently affect the conditions of employment to implicate Title VII. Conduct that is not severe or pervasive enough to create an objectively hostile or abusive work environment, an environment that a reasonable person would find hostile or abusive, is beyond Title VII's purview. Likewise, if the victim does not subjectively perceive the environment to be abusive, the conduct has not actually altered the conditions of the victim's employment, and there is no Title VII violation.
 
Effects on Performance
 But Title VII comes into play before the harassing conduct leads to a nervous breakdown. A discriminatorily abusive work environment, even one that does not seriously affect employees' psychological well-being, can and often will detract from employees' job performance, discourage employees from remaining on the job, or keep them from advancing in their careers. Moreover, even without regard to these tangible effects, the very fact that the discriminatory conduct was so severe or pervasive that it created a work environment abusive to employees because of their race, gender, religion, or national origin offends Title VII's broad rule of workplace equality. The appalling conduct alleged in Meritor, and the reference in that case to environments " 'so heavily polluted with discrimination as to destroy completely the emotional and psychological stability of minority group workers,' " merely present some especially egregious examples of harassment. They do not mark the boundary of what is actionable.
We therefore believe the District Court erred in relying on whether the conduct "seriously affect(ed) plaintiff's psychological well-being" or led her to "suffe(r) injury." Such an inquiry may needlessly focus the factfinder's attention on concrete psychological harm, an element Title VII does not require. Certainly Title VII bars conduct that would seriously affect a reasonable person's psychological well-being, but the statute is not limited to such conduct. So long as the environment would reasonably be perceived, and is perceived, as hostile or abusive, there is no need for it also to be psychologically injurious.
This is not, and by its nature cannot be, a mathematically precise test. We need not answer today all the potential questions it raises, nor specifically address the E.E.O.C.'s new regulations on this subject. But we can say that whether an environment is "hostile" or "abusive" can be determined only by looking at all the circumstances. These may include the frequency of the discriminatory conduct; its severity; whether it is physically threatening or humiliating, or a mere offensive utterance; and whether it unreasonably interferes with an employee's work performance. The effect on the employee's psychological well-being is, of course, relevant to determining whether the plaintiff actually found the environment abusive. But while psychological harm, like any other relevant factor, may be taken into account, no single factor is required.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
BY JUSTICE SCALIA,
 Concurring
 Meritor Savings Bank v. Vinson, held that Title VII prohibits sexual harassment that takes the form of a hostile work environment. The Court stated that sexual harassment is actionable if it is "sufficiently severe or pervasive 'to alter the conditions of (the victim's) employment and create an abusive work environment.' " Today's opinion elaborates that the challenged conduct must be severe or pervasive enough "to create an objectively hostile or abusive work environment, an environment that a reasonable person would find hostile or abusive." Ante, at 4.
"Abusive" (or "hostile," which in this context I take to mean the same thing) does not seem to me a very clear standard and I do not think clarity is at all increased by adding the adverb "objectively" or by appealing to a "reasonable person's" notion of what the vague word means. Today's opinion does list a number of factors that contribute to abusiveness, but since it neither says how much of each is necessary (an impossible task) nor identifies any single factor as determinative, it thereby adds little certitude. As a practical matter, today's holding lets virtually unguided juries decide whether sex-related conduct engaged in (or permitted by) an employer is egregious enough to warrant an award of damages.
One might say that what constitutes "negligence" (a traditional jury question) is not much more clear and certain than what constitutes "abusiveness." Perhaps so. But the class of plaintiffs seeking to recover for negligence is limited to those who have suffered harm, whereas under this statute "abusiveness" is to be the test of whether legal harm has been suffered, opening more expansive vistas of litigation.
Be that as it may, I know of no alternative to the course the Court today has taken. . . . .
 
BY JUSTICE GINSBURG,
 Concurring
 Today the Court reaffirms the holding of Meritor Savings Bank v. Vinson, "(A) plaintiff may establish a violation of Title VII by proving that discrimination based on sex has created a hostile or abusive work environment." The critical issue, Title VII's text indicates, is whether members of one sex are exposed to disadvantageous terms or conditions of employment to which members of the other sex are not exposed. As the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission emphasized, see Brief for United States and Equal Employment Opportunity Commission as amici curiae, the adjudicator's inquiry should center, dominantly, on whether the discriminatory conduct has unreasonably interfered with the plaintiff's work performance. To show such interference, "the plaintiff need not prove that his or her tangible productivity has declined as a result of the harassment." It suffices to prove that a reasonable person subjected to the discriminatory conduct would find, as the plaintiff did, that the harassment so altered working conditions as to "ma(k)e it more difficult to do the job."
Davis concerned race-based discrimination, but that difference does not alter the analysis; except in the rare case in which a bona fide occupational qualification is shown, see Automobile Workers v. Johnson Controls, Inc., Title VII declares discriminatory practices based on race, gender, religion, or national origin equally unlawful. (Footnote 1)

 	 	 		. . .	 	Footnote 1. Indeed, even under the Court's equal protection jurisprudence, which requires an exceedingly persuasive justification for a gender-based classification, Kirchberg v. Feenstra (1981), it remains an open question whether classifications based upon gender are inherently suspect. See Mississippi Univ. for Women v. Hogan, (1982).

HEADLINE: Fears on Nafta Lower Peso

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The Mexican currency fell sharply today as foreign investors pulled out money amid jitters over the prospects for approval in the United States of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The new peso declined 15 centavos against the dollar, to trade at 3.30 pesos in early dealings before firming later in the day to close at 3.27, down about 4 percent. 
 The funds have reportedly been withdrawing as much as $1 billion a day since last week, and this prompted Mexico's central bank to raise interest rates to stem the tide.
However, a senior Mexican official, who was not identified by name, said there was nothing to worry about and scotched any idea of a devaluation. "Has there been a devaluation?" the official said. "Absolutely false. There's nothing to it. This is all within the normal range."
Some investors fear that the trade agreement, widely known as Nafta, will be defeated by the United States House of Representatives in its vote next Wednesday. This, they fear, would dash hopes for a quick economic stimulus in Mexico and for a time depress Mexican stock and bond prices. Analysts and traders said $4 billion to $5 billion have poured out of Mexico since the weekend as investors tried to limit their exposure in pesos.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Refunding Wavers a Bit

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Treasury struggled a bit in the first leg of its quarterly refunding auctions yesterday, even though the latest report on inflation was unexpectedly good.
Bidding for the $17 billion worth of new three-year notes sold yesterday was somewhat ragged, traders said, and the securities sold at an average yield of 4.44 percent. It is the lowest yield on a three-year note since the May 11 auction, when the average yield was 4.27 percent. 
 In addition to the three-year notes, the Treasury also sold $14 billion worth of 66-day cash management bills at an average yield of 3.16 percent.
 
Three-Year Note Auction
 Before the three-year note auction, yields on the new securities dipped as low as 4.41 percent, as traders reacted to the Government report showing that wholesale prices fell by two-tenths of a percent last month.
The report on the Producer Price Index took the market by surprise, and the yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond fell to 6.14 percent, from 6.19 percent on Monday. Treasury yields have been rising in recent weeks on signs that the economy is strengthening, which could reignite inflation.
October's decline in producer prices was partly a result of a steep 3.9 percent drop in automobile prices. Many analysts had expected the Producer Price Index to rise by two-tenths to three-tenths of a percent.
Despite the steep drop in the automobile component, the overall decline "wasn't totally illusory," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at BA Securities Inc. in San Francisco.
"A substantial proportion came from the car sector, but there was weakness elsewhere in the report," he said. "Producers have been having difficult times putting through any price increases for the last couple of years, and they still are."
The three-year auction will be followed today by the sale of $12 billion worth of new 10-year notes. That auction will close out the autumn refunding, which is unusual this year because the Treasury does not intend to sell new 30-year bonds.
The change reflects the shift in the Treasury's approach to debt management announced in May, one that places more emphasis on shorter-term securities and less on longer-term issues. The Treasury will not sell any new 30-year bonds until its winter refunding in February.
This is the first time that the Government has voluntarily held refunding without bond in slightly more than two decades.
Unless a report due this morning on consumer prices is much worse than current expectations, traders said they expect the auction of 10-year notes will go well.
"Since the Treasury changed the supply schedule, and since the Fed isn't about to ease monetary policy, there is no real reason, either technically or fundamentally, to buy the short end," one trader said.
"But the long end is an entirely different story. Inflation is low, the yield curve is steep, and there is no supply as you go out the curve. After the 10-year auction, I would expect the long sector will outperform the world."
In when-issued trading late yesterday, the new 10-year notes were offered at a price to yield 5.63 percent.
Because the increase in Federal gasoline taxes went into effect in October, most analysts are forecasting that the Consumer Price Index to be released this morning will be up by about four-tenths of 1 percent. Excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, however, the closely watched index is expected to post a more modest rise of around one-tenth of 1 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, bonds benefited most from the good news on producer prices. By late in the day, the 6 1/4 percent bonds of 2023 were offered at a price of 101 17/32 , up 25/32 from late Monday, to yield 6.14 percent. In hectic trading following the producer price report, bond prices jumped by more than a point.
Reaction among shorter-term securities was much more muted. Prices of the Treasury's 4 3/4 percent five-year notes rose by just 3/32 , to a late offered price of 98 30/32 , to yield 4.99 percent. And prices of the 3 7/8 percent two-year notes were unchanged, at 99 19/32 , to yield 4.09 percent.
In other developments, an offering of $823 million worth of securities from the New York City Municipal Water Finance Authority highlighted activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market.
Term bonds maturing in 2019 represented the biggest part of the multi-part issue. These 5.50 percent securities were priced to yield 5.73 percent.
Investment bankers at Smith Barney Shearson, lead managers on the underwriting, said the issue, which was increased in size from $750 million, was selling well. By late yesterday, they said about $100 million worth of securities remained unsold.
The issue is rated A by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Corporate Bond Market
 In the corporate bond market, U S West Communications priced $250 million worth of debentures with a final maturity in 50 years. The maturity is a bit misleading, because the issue can be called in 20 years.
The 7 1/8 percent securities were priced at $99.269, to yield 7.179 percent, 85 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/8 percent 30-year bonds maturing in February, 2023.
Merrill Lynch & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The issue is rated AA-3 by Moody's and AA- by Standard & Poor's.
Following are the results of yesterday's auctions of three-year Treasury notes and 66-day cash management bills:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Broad Gains While Gold Also Advances

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most currencies yesterday, despite a two-tenths of 1 percent drop in October producer prices that pointed to lower interest rates and inflation.
"It was a surprising day in some respects," said Bruce English, head of institutional sales for ABN/AMRO N.V. "I would've expected the dollar to fall on the P.P.I., but bulls maintain inflation is still a problem no matter what the short-term indexes say." 
 The dollar normally loses value as United States interest rates decline, because dollar deposits earn less money as rates fall. But some dealers said the currency rose as the market reassessed the data to view low inflation as positive for the dollar longer term.
"If rates were to go higher in response to inflation, the dollar would go higher because it would attract money from overseas," said Michael Martin, vice president at the Sinclair Group, "But a long-term inflationary picture hurts the buying power of the dollar," he said.
Mr. English noted some dollar buying was related to concerns about the passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, ahead of a televised debate last night between Vice President Al Gore and Ross Perot.
"If Nafta is not passed, it will have a slight inflationary impact on the U.S.," he said.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.6925 German marks, from 1.6843 marks on Monday. It also edged up to 107.95 Japanese yen from 107.80 yen.
Meanwhile, gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery gained $1.10, to $376.60 an ounce.
The dollar traded in a narrow range against the yen, caught between Japanese exporter sell orders at 108.30 yen and good buying beneath the market at 107.50 to 107.80 yen.
Nagging concerns about Japan's huge trade gap with the United States continued to brake the dollar's gains, dealers said.
Trading remained cautious ahead of the release of more inflation data today, when the Government reports the Consumer Price Index for October.
Many economists are maintaining their forecasts for October consumer prices despite the drop in producer prices. On average, economists forecast the Consumer Price Index to rise four-tenths of 1 percent, while the so-called core rate is seen up two-tenths of 1 percent.
The British pound slipped to $1.4685 in New York trading, from $1.4810 on Monday.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Fell In October

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Prices received by American producers declined two-tenths of 1 percent in October, surprisingly strong reassurance that a pickup in the economy is not reviving inflation, Labor Department figures showed today.
Except for a modest rise in September, prices for finished goods have fallen or been unchanged every month since April and "core" inflation -- with energy and food excluded -- has all but disappeared over the last 12 months. 
 "This report underscores the fact that inflation still looks like it's declining," commented William C. Dudley, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. He said it probably "cinches the argument" that the Federal Reserve would avoid even positioning itself to tighten credit when its main policy-making arm meets next week.
 
 
Bond Prices Jump
 Bond prices surged on news of lower producer prices, driving down interest rates. [Page D16.] Most economists had expected a small increase in prices, mainly reflecting what turned out to be the biggest jump for energy since February.
But food prices declined five-tenths of a point and the finished-goods index benefited greatly from a 3.9 percent drop in the price of new cars. As part of its process of adjustment for recurring seasonal variations, the department calculated that quality improvements averaged $310.96 a car, or 46.5 percent of the $668.80 yearly increase that car makers received.
The retail equivalent of these changes averaged $363.63, about half for air bags and the rest involving powertrains, corrosion protection, emissions, side-impact standards and changes in amounts of standard or optional equipment.
Before seasonal adjustment, passenger car prices climbed 5 percent for the month.
 
 
'Lot of Excess Capacity'
 Inflation was also well contained at the intermediate stage of production, where prices edged down one-tenth of 1 percent last month. Crude goods posted a 1.4 percent increase but would have declined without the surge in oil prices, which has now been reversed.
"Inflation should be well behaved" for a considerable period, said Patrick J. Corcoran, economist for the Prudential Insurance Company. "We've got lots of excess capacity in the United States economy."
Laurence H. Meyer, a St. Louis consultant, concurred. He noted that the Producer Price Index rose just one-tenth of 1 percent without the benefit of the restraining automobile component and said today's report "should calm inflationary fears which have been brewing on a host of strong economic reports" over the last two weeks.
So far this year, prices for finished goods -- those ready for sale to the consumer or final business user -- have advanced at a rate of just four-tenths of 1 percent, the best performance since the Producer Price Index posted a rare decline in 1986 with the collapse in oil prices.
The Producer Price Index, however, does not include imported goods, most services or taxes. The Consumer Price Index, which does cover these items, is expected to show a modest increase when it is published Wednesday, perhaps half the rise resulting from the 4.3-cent Federal gasoline tax that took effect Oct. 1.
Prices for the core Producer Price Index last month fell five-tenths of 1 percent after showing no change in September, today's survey also found, meaning that most companies are finding it nearly impossible to impose price increases.
 
 
'Competed Away'
 The cost reductions obtained through restructurings are being "competed away" in a ferocious market, declared Mr. Dudley of Goldman, Sachs.
At Greer Industries in Morgantown, W. Va., Thomas Buck, the controller, said the company had managed only "very, very slight" price increases for its sand, gravel and concrete over the last six months.
Today's report showed a 1.3 percent rise in energy that resulted from jumps of 6.3 percent for gasoline and 5.5 percent for home heating oil, partly offset by a 2.3 percent decline for residential natural gas. But finished foods reversed a September rise to decline five-tenths of 1 percent on lower prices for beef and veal and fresh fruits and vegetables.
Capital equipment eased four-tenths of 1 percent as computer prices and motor vehicles fell in price while civilian aircraft rose sharply.
Among intermediate goods, metals and other durables for manufacturing fell four-tenths of 1 percent while factory nondurables, such as chemicals, fell six-tenths of 1 percent. In both cases the declines exceeded September's.
Construction materials, however, rose five-tenths of 1 percent following a September advance of seven-tenths of 1 percent.
The Producer Price Index for total domestic manufacturing, which includes petroleum refining, climbed eight-tenths of 1 percent in October, the report also showed. This was the first increase since May.

HEADLINE: Gorky Stars as Auctions Resume

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL

 BODY:
The market for contemporary art at auction is facing its own sort of Catch-22. The audience is there and eager to buy; the only problem is finding good material to sell. At a tepid auction at Christie's last night, art sold at every price level, even relatively insignificant art. Of the 62 works offered, 50 found buyers. The evening's sale totaled $15.9 million, just above Christie's low estimate of $15.3 million.
"I was mightily relieved and pleased that there was so much activity," said Christopher Burge, president of Christie's in New York. "We saw more bidding on less valuable works than we have in the past." 
 Eli Broad, a Los Angeles collector, said after the sale: "This was not an exciting sale. If they had first-rate material, they'd have more buyers."
The sale reflected more conservative offerings than Christie's has had in recent seasons, with works mostly from before 1980 and a strong emphasis on classical Abstract Expressionist work. There were also few pricey paintings; only three pictures were expected to bring $1 million or more.
Final prices for works bought before 1993 reflect the buyer's commission, which was then 10 percent and is now 15 percent of the first $50,000 and 10 percent of the rest. The estimates do not include commissions.
 
Gorky Sells;, Twombly Doesn't
 By far, the star work was Gorky's "Year After Year" (1947), sold by Gifford Phillips, a New York collector who is a trustee of the Museum of Modern Art. The lush, beautifully colored abstract painting was estimated at $3 million to $4 million. It sold to an unidentified American collector for $3.8 million, a record for the artist.
Another big-ticket painting's failure to sell became the evening's surprise. Cy Twombly's "Untitled (New York City)," from 1969, a blackboard painting with spiraling scrawls in chalk on a gray background, had been expected to fetch $1.8 million to $2.2 million, but bidding stopped at $1.5 million.
The third high-price work, Jackson Pollock's "No. 26, 1951," a black-and-white abstract painting, was estimated at $800,000 to $1 million. It was sold to Larry Gagosian, the New York dealer, for $827,500.
Francis Bacon's "Study for Portrait of Lucien Freud" (1964), estimated at $700,000 to $900,000 had many would-be takers. After a lengthy bidding war, it was sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for $1.7 million.
Throughout this fall auction season, many works that were up for sale just a year or two ago have reappeared, but with far lower estimates. Frank Stella's "Kingsbury Run" (first version), from 1961, was last up for sale at Christie's in November 1991, with an estimate of $2 million to $2.5 million, but bidding never went higher than $1.1 million. Last night, it was for sale again, this time with an estimate of $550,000 to $750,000. The painting was sold to an unidentifed bidder for $662,500, right in the middle of its estimate.
Calder, is one artist whose work has seemed almost recession-proof in the last few rough years, and last night was no exception. In fact, two of the three Calders for sale last night were among the auction's top 10 sellers.
The most important Calder, "Fish," a mobile circa 1942, was expected to bring $300,000 to $400,000. Seven years ago, it was up for sale, also at Christie's in New York, with an estimated of $65,000 to $85,000. Then it sold for $187,000; last night it brought $376,500. Another Calder, "Mobile with Eight Elements" (1948), estimated at $105,000, was sold to David Nahmed, a New York dealer, for $118,000. An untitled 1948 Calder with an estimate of $250,000 to $300,000 was sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for $277,500.
Another artist who fared well was Morris Louis. His "No. 25" (1962), estimated at $120,000 and $180,000, was sold to an unidentified bidder for $255,500. The artist's "Beta Tau" (1961) also sold to a telephone bidder for more than its high estimate of $300,000, bringing $354,500. "Pretty and decorative things sold, especially Color Field artists," said Lorinda Ash of the Gagosian Gallery. "There seemed to be new bidders, a different group than in the past."
The auction house confirmed that it had seen many new buyers, but there were many familiar faces in the audience as well. Stefan Edlis, a Chicago collector, bought Claes Oldenburg's "Stockinged Thighs Framed by Skirt" (1961), estimated at $150,000 to $200,000. Mr. Edlis paid $167,500. Several dealers were also buying, among them Laura Carpenter from Santa Fe, N.M., and Paula Cooper, the SoHo dealer.
Two artists who are currently having major retrospectives, Robert Ryman and Roy Lichtenstein, were represented last night. Mr. Ryman's "Marker" (1988), estimated at $120,000 to $180,000, brought $134,500. Several determined phone bidders fought over Mr. Lichtenstein's "Still Life With Coffee Pot" (1976), estimated at $200,000 to $250,000. After two bidders slowly climbed by $5,000 increments, it finally sold for $211,500. A Lichtenstein "Portrait" (1986), estimated at $140,000 to $180,000, sold above its high estimate, bringing $200,500.
One of the evening's tensest moments came when bidding began for Robert Artschwager's "Train Wreck" (1967). The work, estimated at $60,000 to $80,000, brought out a host of collectors in the salesroom who bid and bid hard. The painting finally sold for $222,500, almost three times its estimate.
But the Artschwager was an exception. For the most part, works sold within their estimates. "We've been at this level long enough," said Diane Upright, the head of contemporary art at Christie's, referring to the fact that prices are now where they were in early 1988. "It seemed both buyers and sellers were accepting the price levels."

HEADLINE: NEW YORK CITY MARATHON;
After 9,319-Mile Run, 26.2 Should Be a Mere Stroll

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN

 BODY:
As Japan's Demon Drummers sprinted the final yards in Central Park yesterday, completing a three-year, 9,319-mile run around the perimeter of the United States, Sunday's New York City Marathon promised to be less a torturous race than a stroll down the driveway for the morning paper.
"After this, only 26 miles will seem like dessert," said Marco Lienhard, 31, a Swiss-born member of the drum troupe, known in Japan as Ondekoza, which will play Carnegie Hall on Dec. 3. "A treat." 
 The nine arriving runners had been through 28 states, 125 pairs of shoes, countless knee strains, untold cartons of aspirin and analgesic rub, running an average of 20 miles a day and as many as 40, arriving at the finish line of their odyssey only to prepare for another run. The idea made the two-time New York winner, Tom Fleming, wince, as if he had pulled a muscle.
 
'A Serious Disease'
 "It's a serious disease," Fleming said with a laugh yesterday. "There should be medicine for that."
Takayasu Den, 62 years old, who founded the drum troupe in 1969, smiled and admitted through a translator that, yes, running the perimeter of the United States was "abnormal." After all, he was wearing socks and comfortable thongs on his feet, not a pair of running shoes that had been on tour longer than the Grateful Dead.
But, Den added, what better way to collect a mental scrapbook of the United States than to run the country instead of traversing it in the steel tube of an airplane or the five-speed isolation of a car?
"Many people have run across the United States," Den said. "But no one has run around it."
 
'Fulfilling My Dream'
 The idea was to see American cities, big and small, spreading the tradition of Ondekoza music with its throbbing 700-pound barrel drums and whispering bamboo flutes. In return, the drummers would learn something about the United States and themselves. Den had experienced America through its movies -- "I was born in 1931, same as James Dean" -- yet the country had seemed like a mannequin, draped out in finery but artificial on the flat screen. Now, it would come to full life in person.
"I wanted to run, but I couldn't," Den said. "These young people are fulfilling my dream."
Thirteen runners, age 15 to 29, set out from New York on Nov. 15, 1990, and ran down the East Coast to Miami, across the Deep South and Texas to Phoenix and Los Angeles, up the West Coast to Seattle, across the Great Plains toward Minneapolis, Chicago, Cleveland and finally, back to New York, skipping only an excursion to Boston in order to be here for Sunday's marathon.
They ran on small highways, avoiding the interstates except when it was impossible in Yuma, Ariz., and parts of Southern California. The drummers stayed on a ranch in Sulphur Springs, Mont., bunked in a church in Roundup, Mont., and otherwise bivouacked in schools, tents, a trailer, economy hotel rooms or the homes of people drawn to their pulsing music and the inspired lunacy of their running.
"America is a welcoming country," said 29-year-old Shigeru Yamamoto. "People we didn't know a few hours earlier, we ended up staying at their houses."
Ondekoza gave 300 performances during the run, many planned, some impromptu. Money came from ticket and T-shirt sales, donations, corporate largesse. The people of Crowley, La., made the drummers honorary citizens. The artist's colony of Hillsboro, N.M., made them feel as if they had ended up in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade.
"There are only about 173 people in the town, and 98 showed up for our performance," Lienhard said. "It was a small town, but a big push."
 
Not Without Complications
 The running was not without complications. One runner was hit by something dropped from a truck in Japan and lost a leg before the trip began. Two months after leaving New York, the group had its trailer crunched by an 18-wheeler on the North Carolina-South Carolina border. In Virginia, several runners were picked up by the police as they tried to negotiate a five-mile bridge span that was off limits to pedestrians.
"We had made up our minds to run the whole way, so we came back and did it at night," Lienhard said.
And, of course, somebody was bound to get lost on one of the maddening Los Angeles cloverleafs.
"The guy had a beeper, so he called Japan, and they called New York and New York finally called my pager," Lienhard said. "We were supposed to be on the Pacific Coast Highway. We found him on Interstate 405, heading for San Diego."
In the desert from Phoenix to Los Angeles, the temperature hit 110 degrees. When shoes blew out, strips of tires along the road made for spare soles. Four runners eventually dropped out at different points for health reasons. Most everyone had to walk for stretches to nurse a sore knee or a balky muscle. Ryohei Inoue limped across Montana, needing as long as 14 hours to cover 35 miles in a day. His twin brother, Kohei, had earlier experienced a gimpy knee in Florida.
"We were only doing 20 miles a day then, so he was lucky," Ryohei Inoue said.
All nine runners are fit for Sunday's marathon. After completing the run in Central Park, they will head for Brooklyn and a concert at the Grand Army Plaza. On Dec. 3, it's off to Carnegie Hall. After that, there is talk of more running.
Around Europe.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A member of Japanese drum troupe, Ondekoza, performing in Central Park after completing a three-year run around the United States perimeter. (Alan Zale for The New York Times)
