HEADLINE: Small Ranchers Can't Pay More for Arid Lands

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Bruce Babbitt's Landscape, at Risk" (editorial, Oct. 31) captures the attitude of the Clinton Administration (and your newspaper) that the Secretary of the Interior and the Federal Government can lord it over citizens of the West and arrogantly impose upon them a new system of grazing regulations.
This tired old command-and-control approach is deemed by Mr. Babbitt to be in the best interests of Westerners, despite the historical, social, economic and, yes, even democratic arguments to the contrary. 
 Mr. Babbitt and you conveniently forget one important point when endorsing the grazing scheme offered by Senator Harry Reid. Simply put, people have a right to due process.
In Congress that means a right to be heard before legislation is passed. But this backroom Reid-Babbitt deal is being foisted upon Westerners without such basic fairness. Not one hour was spent in Congressional committees of jurisdiction before this deal was cut by a handful of Congressmen and tacked onto Mr. Babbitt's spending bill for quick passage into law -- even though the proposals would dramatically change public policy affecting 270 million acres of the United States.
Remember, Western ranchers, who on average make only $28,000 a year, didn't ask to be neighbors with Federal lands. It simply came to pass in the days of America's westward settlement that no settlers wanted to homestead these unfarmable, arid, desolate lands that eventually devolved to Government control.
It was understood, however, that settlers (and their descendants ranching today) would combine these Federal acres with their private land to provide enough grass to feed livestock and squeeze out a living.
These inhospitable lands deterred homesteaders for the same reasons that today justify the difference in public and private grazing fees. There is no magic, no trickery here. It is the same economic reality that accounts for a different rental charge for an unfurnished sixth-floor efficiency apertment and a furnished penthouse in Manhattan. Both provide shelter, but no one would expect to pay the same rent for both.
Your naked assertion that no ranchers will lose their homes and livelihoods from an 85 percent increase in rent charged by landlord Babbitt is a surprisingly casual and callous disregard for human suffering and of numerous studies by university economists to the contrary. You and your readers would benefit from the facts.
It is clear that the Secretary of the Interior has no interest in resolving the impasse, apparently in the belief that he can steamroller his agenda through the Senate. Our advice, then, is for his boss. President Clinton, the time has now come to get involved. Americans in the West deserve fair play.
 
WILLIAM G. MYERS 3D
Exec. Director, Public Lands Council
Washington, Nov. 2, 1993

HEADLINE: Theater in Review

BYLINE: By D. J. R. BRUCKNER

 BODY:

Jimmy Tingle's
Uncommon Sense American Place Theater
111 West 46th Street
Manhattan
 
Written and performed by Jimmy Tingle; directed by Larry Arrick; lighting, Christopher Boll; production stage manager, Paul A. Kochman. Presented by the American Place Theater, Wynn Handman, artistic director; Susannah Halston, executive director. 

 Jimmy Tingle has worked his way up the stand-up comedy circuit in the last decade until he stands near the top. But the fact that there is more to him than comic wit is evident in the emotional effect he has on an audience in his one-man show, "Jimmy Tingle's Uncommon Sense."
Mr. Tingle brings so much energy and personal warmth to this 90-minute nonstop performance that one comes away from it strangely uplifted. He reveals often mortifying absurdities in virtually everything that comes to his attention: politics, sex, the economy, religion, education, race, nationality, even assassination. Yet he is so cheerfully intelligent that he makes his audience optimistic in the face of appalling reality.
Having developed his act mostly in comedy clubs, Mr. Tingle lacks some of the artfulness he needs for the theater. He could use more training in a whole range of theatrical gestures that might make him less dependent on words alone.
But those are not great faults. And the man does have courage: he wraps his entire commentary in an autobiographical journey that begins with the murder of President John F. Kennedy, when Mr. Tingle was 5 years old, and he raises laughter at his reactions even to that.
None of the rest of his material is quite so dark. While politicians and various authority figures are his main targets, his most lethal jabs are aimed at consumerism and what he sees as a growing popular revolt against "the gods of the billboards." He applies the logic of cigarette advertising to sportswear with wonderful effect and ridicules the hidden hypocritical moralizing of economic analysts ("Consumer confidence is down? People don't lack confidence; they lack money").
Mr. Tingle's persistent, even philosophical effort to expose prejudices and rid us -- and himself, for he is an engaging sharer -- of them accounts for the uplift one feels at the end. It takes a serious and well-intentioned man to make one laugh to such good effect. D. J. R. BRUCKNER

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jimmy Tingle starring in "Jimmy Tingle's Uncommon Sense," at the American Place Theater. (Jonathan Slaff)

HEADLINE: Rebounding From Crises, New York Hospital Changes Its Ways

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN

 BODY:
At a time when New York Hospital, like nearly all others in the city, was facing an acute financial crisis, the mysterious death of Andy Warhol after a routine operation in 1987 added yet another jolt. But in the end, the tragedy helped shock the entire staff of the institution into accepting the need for a sharp change in direction.
New York Hospital -- which, in conjunction with Cornell Medical Center, is among the most distinguished teaching hospitals in the nation -- brought in a new president, introduced modern business practices and, perhaps most importantly, took the lead in looking for innovative ways to escape the fiscal traumas that continue to plague nearly all hospitals in the area. 
 Today, instead of continuing to struggle like most of its counterparts in the city, New York Hospital is considered by its peers to be at the forefront of a transformation of the health care industry across the nation.
Its network now consists of 15 institutions with 4,100 beds capable of serving a population of almost a million people. Within the New York region, it is the first of what is expected to become a host of large, all-embracing providers of managed care, which is the underlying goal of President Clinton's health care overhaul plan.
Not only did New York Hospital undertake measures to improve its bottom line, it also has focused even greater attention on insuring a high level of patient care. In a survey conducted by the Federal Health Care Financing Authority, the overall mortality rate for Medicare patients treated at New York Hospital has been significantly lower than most other hospitals. In the nationwide survey, it stands in the top 1 percent of all hospitals, despite treating patients with unusually severe illnesses.
"The impact of the bashing we were taking was very negative on the staff here and people were very demoralized," recalls Dr. David B. Skinner, who took over as president and chief executive officer of New York Hospital in late 1987. "We were losing $1 million a week, the building was crumbling from age, and there was no question we couldn't go on as before."
 
A Major Expansion
 So Dr. Skinner took a new tack. While engineering a turnaround that took the hospital from a loss of $57.2 million in 1988 to a surplus of $2 million in 1991, he began exploring uncharted waters. Even as other local hospitals were trying just to stay afloat, New York Hospital expanded its reach.
Through a complex corporate arrangement requiring almost no cash on either side, it formed a network of allied hospitals, clinics and nursing homes extending through the city and, most recently, into Westchester County. In May the hospital began a long-delayed $880 million rebuilding project to replace its sprawling 60-year-old Upper East Side monolith with one of the most modern acute-care centers in the nation.
New York City and, to a lesser extent, the state and surrounding region have been well behind the curve in exploring this trend. "In health care, New York has generally been an island apart from the rest of the nation," said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association. "We've been out of sync."
By contrast, New York Hospital has tried to anticipate the changing marketplace for health care. More than four years ago, the hospital's trustees agreed with Dr. Skinner's idea to form the New York Hospital Care Network, effectively a friendly takeover of smaller institutions. A common board oversees the network.
 
A Family of Institutions
 So far, the network includes, in Manhattan, the Amsterdam Nursing Home, Gracie Square Hospital, the Hospital for Special Surgery, New York Downtown Hospital, the Stanley Isaacs Healthcare Center for Senior Citizens and the Rogosin Institute.
Elsewhere it includes Community Hospital, the Methodist Hospital and its Family Health Center, all in Brooklyn, and in Queens, the New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens (formerly Booth Memorial Medical Center), the Women's and Children's Health Center of Western Queens, the Rogosin Institute Queens Dialysis Center, and Silvercrest Extended Care Facility. Last month, it reached into Westchester for the United Hospital Medical Center in Port Chester.
"The corporate relationship has been a blessing," says Mark Mundy, president of the Methodist Hospital. "What distinguishes our network from others is that we are all part of a family. Since there is no possibility of divorce, we all have to work together on the marriage."
In different ways, several other groups of hospitals are racing to catch up. Mount Sinai Medical Center recently established ties with the Queens Hospital Center, the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in Manhattan and Phelps Memorial Hospital in Westchester. Beth Israel Medical Center just purchased a chain of six doctors' offices in Westchester.
Meanwhile, many of the same institutions have formed looser links to create their own "preferred provider" networks. One of them, Premier Preferred Care, offers its patients access to a network of doctors and hospitals in New York and New Jersey at discount prices.
 
Savings in Consolidation
 Whatever happens to Mr. Clinton's proposal in Congress, the introduction of competition into the practice of medicine means that such integrated networks are almost certain to be the key institutions in any revamped health care system.
Under the concept of managed care, patients receive all their medical services from a group of providers, from simpler primary care at doctors' offices and routine operations at outpatient clinics to emergency care and intensive, so-called tertiary care at sophisticated medical centers. Savings are achieved by using advanced computers and pooling services to reduce overhead. Even more important is the ability to funnel a steady, more predictable supply of patients through the network.
"We realized," Dr. Skinner said, "that health care delivery had to change from the very decentralized, Mom-and-Pop approach to streamlined systems that use modern technology and link together the various systems from primary care, community hospitals, to tertiary and emergency care to nursing homes into a seamless web. As in any other industry, there are substantial savings to be found."
Indeed, the cushy world of nonprofit hospitals is being transformed into the cutthroat business of providing medical services to what insiders call "covered lives." And Dr. Skinner is the very embodiment of the doctor who has become a hard-nosed, up-to-date, computer-literate executive to preside over such a transition.
"See, I still put on my white coat," said Dr. Skinner, somewhat defensively, as he concludes an interview to take a reporter on a brief tour of the hospital.
"I don't think I'll ever entirely lose the physician mind-set," he added. "Doctors have to be part of the solution, not just part of the problem. I've taken on this business role because I believe that if we weren't involved, it would just get worse."
Dr. Skinner's methods have not gone down easily. Coming to New York Hospital from Chicago with a reputation as a tough bargainer, he insisted on full authority, gaining considerably more administrative power than his predecessor. He replaced several of the hospital's senior department heads. Amid tensions over real estate the dean of the affiliated Cornell medical center resigned in 1991 to return to his native Texas.
But his approach also got results. In a recent speech, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said that Dr. Skinner has demonstrated that "he's not only a skilled physician, but also a master business manager."
The Governor said: "He's establishing a network for managed care with the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center serving as the hub. That network will serve as the perfect complement of a new national health-care plan." For his work, Dr. Skinner, 58, received salary and benefits worth $809,000 last year.
For Dr. Skinner, as for many other health care providers, the ultimate target of his ambition is now coming into view. He would like hospitals to take over the job that insurance companies now perform and thereby capture the money for his own institution.
 
'Extracting Premium Dollars'
 "There is a fairly strong sense on our board -- and it's spreading elsewhere, too, I might add -- that insurance companies don't bring added value to the health care industry," he said. "To the extent administrative costs are high, including a profit to their shareholders, they are extracting premium dollars away that could be captured by a provider-sponsored service and used to provide better health care."
New York Hospital is actively exploring the creation of its own health maintenance organization to offer its network of services directly to employers and their employees. For all the temptations, however, the venture would be fraught with risks. The greatest danger is retaliation by insurance companies that now direct patients to the hospitals within the network.
"New York Hospital would absolutely lose our membership if they formed an H.M.O.," David Alpeter, senior vice president at Aetna Health Plans of New York, recently told Crain's New York Business.
Dr. Skinner seems prepared to take the plunge within the next few years. "We won't go into that until we have a large enough network," he said. "But we are approaching the point where we feel confident we could rapidly acquire a sufficient panel of patients on our own."
Much is at stake for major hospitals. Once national health care is adopted, "My greatest long-run fear is that health care will be dominated by large insurance companies," says Mr. Raske of the hospital association, which represents 152 hospitals and nursing homes in the New York area. "Instead of local control, power would shift to Hartford," where many of the largest insurance companies are headquartered.
For now at least, the insurance industry professes to be unworried about being squeezed out of a very lucrative business.
"If groups of providers want to take on the risks of health insurance, they are going to have to come up with considerably greater resources to satisfy state requirements of financial soundness," says Kylanne Green, director of managed care at the Health Insurance Association . of America in Washington. "In general, their pockets aren't very deep."
 
Thinnest of Margins
 That's true, particularly in New York, where hospitals have been heavily regulated and operate on the thinnest of margins. Even New York Hospital, healthier than most of its counterparts, is going deeply into debt to finance its new building, which will stretch across Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive between 68th and 70th Streets.
But help could be on the way. White House officials, upset at the health insurers' opposition to Mr. Clinton's plan, are suggesting that Washington might side with the hospital industry in its looming battle with the insurance business. Ira C. Magaziner, the White House's senior adviser for health policy, recently proposed that the Federal government offer financing to hospital-run networks willing to assume all the risks of full coverage.
Whatever happens, Dr. Skinner thinks New York Hospital is ready. "Nobody really knows what the health care delivery system is going to look like in the future," he said. "But I think our network structure provides us with the flexibility to offer top-quality care no matter what."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 1, 1993, Wednesday

A picture caption on Nov. 10 about the New York Hospital Care Network described the Amsterdam Nursing Home incorrectly. Although it is a member of the network, it has not been taken over by New York Hospital. It remains a separate corporate entity with an independent board.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD;
Mexicans Seethe With Anger At Perot's Depiction of Them

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 10

 BODY:
After weeks in which Mexicans seemed to hold their anger at criticism of their country by opponents of the North American Free Trade Agreement in the United States, they fairly exploded today at Ross Perot's depiction of Mexico the night before.
"Last night, Mexico was the object of a long series of calumnies and lies," the Government-owned newspaper El Nacional said in an editorial on Mr. Perot's comments on the trade agreement in his debate with Vice President Al Gore. And the accusation was echoed by many others. 
 "He's never set foot here!" said Luis Estrada, a 50-year-old lawyer in a gray business suit who put down his sandwich at a downtown restaurant. "How is it possible that he can say everyone lives in poverty here? Before he opens his mouth, he ought to come down here and take a look."
 
Words of Rage
 Cristina Cueto, a graphic designer in the upscale neighborhood of Polanco, offered a series of off-color terms for Mr. Perot before settling on a mild epithet.
Relatively few Mexicans watched or heard the debate on Tuesday night between Mr. Perot and Mr. Gore, but angry newspaper editorials, outraged politicians and word-of-mouth seemed to carry what regular Mexican television programming had not.
And after weeks in which other American opponents of the trade pact have been assailing Mexico as polluted, corrupt, destitute and undemocratic, there was some new evidence for the warnings of officials here that a backlash of anti-American feelings could ensue if the accord is rejected by the United States Congress in a vote scheduled for next Wednesday.
What rankled Mexicans was that in the course of the 90-minute debate on CNN's "Larry King Live," Mr. Perot described Mexico as a destitute, authoritarian and unjust place where "36 families own over half the country," virtually everyone else lives in poverty, and factory workers dream of having outhouses and running water.
"People who don't make anything cannot buy anything," said Mr. Perot, who held up photographs of what he described as hovels surrounding an American plant in Mexico. He said some Mexican workers were building homes of cardboard, implying that this was what to expect if the trade accord was approved.
Some of his assertions were seen here as merely exaggerated, while others were denounced as patently untrue.
While poverty in Mexico is widespread, for instance, most studies indicate that less than half, about 40 percent, of the population lives below the poverty line. The figure in the United States is about 14 percent. Similarly, according to the latest Mexican Government statistics, the richest tenth of Mexican households takes in 37.9 percent of the country's total household income. And whatever they might earn, Mexicans as a whole are the third largest customer for exports from the United States.
Not all Mexicans seemed to wince at the country's rough-handed treatment. Some critics of the accord have viewed Washington's debate as an opportunity to voice their complaints about the policies of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. At least some seemed to appreciate that Mr. Perot had gone so far in countering what they see as Mexican Government propaganda.
Mexico's Trade Secretary, Jaime Serra Puche, sought to emphasize the positive. He called the debate a "fortunate" departure from the unanswered criticism with which Mexico and the trade agreement have sometimes been showered in the past.
 
'Distortions and Inventions'
 "For the first time, the distortions and inventions of the opposing group, headed by Mr. Perot, were given correct and specific answers of fact," Mr. Serra said. "It seems to me that in that sense it was particularly positive."
There was also a good deal of rejoicing today at the Mexico City stock exchange. The elation was based on a perception that Mr. Gore had knocked his opponent around and improved the prospects for the agreement.
Yet there was no shortage of prickly reactions to Mr. Perot's remarks.
"His words were totally offensive to the Mexican people," said Evararido Rodriguez, a computer programmer at the Bolsa who read of Mr. Perot's comments in a newspaper. "They don't have anything to do with reality."
At the announcement this afternoon of $1.5 billion worth of new real estate investments in Mexico City, Javier Beristain was having similar trouble with Mr. Perot's imagery. "I imagine that Mr. Perot is not very well informed," said Mr. Beristain, the city's courtly planning secretary. "He obviously has not undertaken a complete analysis of the new Mexico."
Political analysts here differ on how directly the continuing criticism of Mexico in the United States might lead to a resurgence of anti-American sentiment in Mexico if the pact is defeated.
Mexican officials and their opponents expected that the Salinas administration's policies would be discussed in the American debate, including its efforts to perpetuate the 64-year control of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party. But as with recent moves to toughen efforts to stop illegal immigrants on the United States' southern border, some Mexicans said they were surprised that American officials could overlook their country's sensitivity to criticism, even as a historic partnership is in the balance.
Sergio Aguayo, a political scientist who has studied the evolution of Mexico's image in the United States, argued that even Mr. Gore spoke in the debate in what many Mexicans would consider "interventionist" terms. "More than racism, there was a kind of cultural disdain coming from both of them," he said. "There was a kind of 'us and them' attitude. And I think both of them expressed the view that Mexico's future depends on the United States."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Enforcement Problems May Help Cable Systems Sidestep Rate Rules

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Thousands of cable television systems across the country may escape new Federal price regulations because many cities and towns are afraid that enforcing the rules will create more problems than it solves.
Alarmed by the possibility that cable operators in many cities might be free to raise prices as high as they want, the Federal Communications Commission decided today to extend a temporary revenue freeze on cable companies for three months to give cities more time to study the new regulations. 
 The problem is the latest of several recent signs that the new cable law is not delivering the consumer benefits that Congress envisioned in October 1992 when it passed the legislation over the veto of President George Bush. Last month, for example, a preliminary study by the F.C.C. found that about a third of cable subscribers have seen their rates increase since the new pricing regulations went into place.
 
Local Responsibility
 Under the Federal law that took effect last spring, local governments were given the primary responsibility for regulating cable prices under guidelines established by the F.C.C. Cities and towns must first apply for certification from the F.C.C., which entails filling out a one-page form.
Yet so far, agency officials say only about half the 11,000 communities have sought certification. The problem is most widespread among small towns and cities, many experts said, because many fear the potential complexity and administrative burden will overwhelm their resources. But other experts say the reluctance stems primarily from the cable companies, which have waged a concerted effort in many cities to persuade local officials against becoming regulators.
"Many of them are scared," said Barry Orton, a professor of telecommunications at the University of Wisconsin and a consultant to local cable authorities in that state. "Some fear it's going to cost them money. Some are against it on principle. And some have been talked out of it by cable companies."
As a group, officials from medium and large cities were among the staunchest advocates of the new law as it progressed through Congress. And most big cities, including New York, have been quick to seek the F.C.C. authority to regulate cable prices.
But local officials in some smaller municipalities apparently find the Federal rules too burdensome. "Once you get tied up with the Feds, you can end up running the cable system yourself," said Marvin Thompson, the president of the City Council in Rice Lake, Wis., a town of 8,000 people. The Council decided not to seek F.C.C. certification for regulating cable. "We just decided we didn't know enough to make a decision," he said.
 
Government Reluctance
 The reluctance of local governments marks the latest strange twist to the saga of cable rate regulation. In overriding President Bush's veto, Congress passed what was seen as a tough law designed to address the consumer outcry over soaring cable prices, which were deregulated in 1987. Since that year, cable rates have risen at more than twice the rate of inflation, in part because all but a handful of cable systems face no head-to-head competition.
But the new regulations have generated continuing controversy as the F.C.C. has tried to codify the intent of Congress. F.C.C. officials initially predicted that the regulations would lead to a $1 billion annual rate reduction nationwide. Instead, prices for at least a third of all customers have gone up rather than down, and the biggest rate reductions have gone to relatively affluent customers who buy extra cable outlets and remote control devices. People who subscribe to the most basic packages of service have often seen prices go up.
Few people dispute that the new rate regulations are complicated. The rate rules alone are more than 400 pages long, and the rules on technical and programming issues run hundreds of pages more.
The F.C.C. tried to simplify the rate rules by establishing a set of "benchmark" prices for different kinds of cable systems, a move designed to avoid the endless analyses used in telephone rate regulation to determine a company's costs and allow a reasonable profit. But a city must still wade through a long list of calculations, juggling the number of channels and the prices for installations, extra outlets and remote control devices.
Beyond that, a cable company is allowed to appeal the benchmark prices by asking for a separate proceeding to explain its costs. While the F.C.C. and the courts ultimately must decide such appeals, the city is responsible for seeing the case through the process.
"You've got to think about this in the context that there are a lot of very small towns and counties with limited resources who have always been very suspicious of the Federal Government," said William F. Squadron, the Commissioner of Telecommunications and Energy for New York City. Mr. Squadron, who is also the president of a national association of telecommunications administrators, added that many cable companies had worked hard to foster those concerns among local officials.
For example, Marcus Cable, which is based in Dallas, in July wrote to the local officials in small cities in Wisconsin where it has cable systems, warning that the Federal rules would create a nightmare. "This hodge-podge of rules, requirements, edicts and dictates is, in a word, ludicrous," wrote Jeffrey Marcus, the president of the company. "The losers are the cable customers, the municipalities, and the cable companies."
 
'Step Up to the Plate'
 Despite such pressures, some consumer advocates said municipalities bore a good measure of responsibility for delaying the implementation of the new cable rules. "They've really got to step up to the plate and do something," said Brad Stillman, legislative counsel for the Consumer Federation of America, which pushed hard for the cable law last year. "I guess I'm surprised. The cities had been pretty gung-ho on enabling this legislation. This is somewhat troublesome."

LENGTH: 1029 words

HEADLINE: New Home Option: Surviving Flames

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WEBB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Watching the television images of brush fires engulfing the canyons of Southern California, most viewers probably had mixed emotions: awe at the scale of destruction, and relief that they were safe from risk.
But natural fires can occur almost anywhere, especially in forested areas and during droughts. In 1992, there were 439,000 reported brush and grass fires, according to the National Fire Protection Association. 
 Richard Bukowski, senior research engineer with the Building and Fire Research Laboratory at the National Institute of Standards and Technology in Gaithersburg, Md., cited current risks in Texas and in the Southeast, where pine forests have been devastated by beetles. "If I were living in a wooded area, even in the Northeast, and it were time to replace a shingled roof, I would look for one that was highly fire-resistant," he said.
But the degree of risk varies greatly. "California is the only state with an insurance designation for brush-fire zones," said Chris Guidette of the Insurance Services Office, an organization in New York that prepares statistics for property insurers."
Fire is part of the ecology in the arid West, nature's way of clearing old growth and regenerating the landscape. But well-protected houses in high-risk areas can survive the flames. Creative architects and builders have developed fire-resistant alternatives to the rustic cottages and wooden chalets that have regularly succumbed to conflagrations.
To Bui-Bender, a Vietnam-born civil engineer and builder, anticipated the need for protection when he constructed his family house in Laguna Beach with stucco walls, a concrete-tiled roof and double-glazed windows. For four hours before the fire reached the house on Wednesday, he hosed down the stucco and surrounding vegetation. Later that evening, he appeared on television beside his house, which had survived amid the devastation of the neighborhood.
But most people are not as sensible as Mr. Bui-Bender.
"Very few of my clients put a premium on fire protection, even when they get involved in every other aspect of the design," said Ron Goldman, an architect in Malibu. "People who live close to nature want to build in natural materials -- wood stands for comfort and tradition."
Another Malibu architect, David Lawrence Gray, built a wood-shingle house for himself when he arrived in Los Angeles from the Northwest, via the University of California at Berkeley. "As soon as I saw my first fire, I realized that was a dumb thing to do," he confessed, "and for the last five years, I've used only steel and concrete. If you must use wood as a facing, you should back it with a fire-resistant 5/8-inch drywall."
Fire officials and building experts agree that the first priority, wherever you live, is to cut back dried vegetation from around the house and create a green belt of fire-resistant grasses, ice plants, salvias or whatever varieties a nursery recommends for the climate and site. Citrus trees make an effective fire block; eucalyptus and pine are highly flammable. When renewing scorched slopes, they recommend planting deep-rooted plants to check erosion.
Chief John Montenero of the Santa Monica Fire Department, said he becomes frustrated and angry when he sees homeowners neglecting their responsibilities. "I've even heard careless people say, 'That's what I carry insurance for,' " he said.
To be safe, he added, you should set the house back 100 feet from dry vegetation on an average slope, and up to 500 feet on sheer slopes, which can accelerate updrafts. "And you need a pump that will put out 250 gallons a minute through a one-and-a-half-inch hose from your pool or a water tank," he continued. "You don't have a chance in a Santa Ana with a garden hose."
Even with such clearings and plantings and abundant water, a house can be ignited by radiant heat or flying embers. Dick Davis of Factory Mutual Engineers in Boston, an expert on building materials, recommends brick, stucco or concrete for walls, and clay or concrete tiles for the roof. The eaves should be sealed to exclude wind-borne sparks.
Buzz Yudell, an architect, and his wife, Tina Beebe, a color consultant, incorporated these lessons in the house they built in Malibu. A tin roof fits snugly atop the stucco walls, with no overhang. The house is set well back from vegetation on every side, and the interiors have sprinklers.
As an economy, they chose not to use double-glazed windows, which retard the transfer of radiant heat and are less likely to break. "Someone should market the painted metal shutters or roll-up metal blinds that are common in France and Italy," he said.
Often, people neglect the simplest precautions. Mr. Gray noted that a neighbor's roof has been piled high with driftwood and an old boat for more than three years. And Mr. Goldman pointed out that houses are built of the same materials used centuries ago. He said he hoped that the rising cost of wood would encourage the use of innovative industrial products. In a house he designed for himself on the Malibu beach, Mr. Goldman used translucent fiberglass for a large skylight, and last week it survived a flurry of burning embers.
Expense is a factor. Ceramic glass will withstand a high level of radiant heat without cracking, but its high cost -- four to eight times that of conventional glass -- restricts its use.
Steven Ehrlich, a Santa Monica architect whose outlook was shaped by his Peace Corps experience in Africa, says he sees a need to live in harmony with nature.
"A house in Malibu should not be like one in New England," he said. "What we need here are porous fortresses -- to withstand human and natural assaults, and to open up to the benign climate."
He recalled the thick-walled courtyard houses he explored in the Sahara and the Sahel, simple shelters that stayed cool for most of the day. "Here, you can use poured concrete or concrete block for the walls, open up courtyards on one side to the ocean or a view, and protect the wide openings with sliding steel doors."
These safeguards can be considered the price of living -- perhaps of surviving -- in an earthly paradise.

HEADLINE: Emotion Rules TV Debate on Puerto Rican Vote

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R., Nov. 10

 BODY:
With Puerto Ricans set to vote on Sunday on whether they want statehood, independence or a continuation of commonwealth status, leaders of the island's three main political parties resorted to emotional appeals in a crucial televised debate on Tuesday night, their last chance to address uncommitted voters en masse.
Unless Puerto Rico becomes the 51st state, said Gov. Pedro J. Rossello, head of the pro-statehood New Progressive Party, Congress could deprive the island's 3.7 million residents of their American citizenship. 
 Mr. Rossello's chief rival, Senator Miguel Hernandez Agosto of the Popular Democratic Party, which favors an "enhanced" commonwealth status, countered that Puerto Ricans might be forced to give up "our language, our anthem and our sports teams" to enter the union.
Senator Ruben Berrios Martinez, leader of the Puerto Rican Independence Party, on the other hand, urged what he called "this country on its knees" to forge a new identity through a complete break with the United States. "There is only one colony left in the world with a population of more than a million people," he said, "and that is Puerto Rico."
 
Dead Heat in Poll
 The two-hour debate, conducted in Spanish and broadcast by the Telemundo network, was characterized by angry accusations and heated language, with both Governor Rossello and Mr. Hernandez Agosto saying the other had run "a campaign based on fear and lies." Mr. Berrios in turn said both statehood and commonwealth offered only "a vision of dependence, lack of functions and handouts."
A poll published today in a San Juan newspaper, El Nuevo Dia, shows statehood and commonwealth running virtually even, at about 40 percent each, and independence trailing at 5 percent. That survey of 1,000 people, conducted door to door from last Wednesday to Monday, also indicated that most of the 15 percent of voters still undecided seemed to be leaning in favor of statehood. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Sunday's plebiscite, in which about two-thirds of Puerto Rico's two million registered voters are expected to participate, has been endorsed by the White House as a welcome exercise in self-determination, but the result is not binding. No matter which wins, any change in Puerto Rico's status would require approval of Congress, which in the past has been extremely reluctant to deal with the issue.
Some Republicans fear that a Puerto Rican state would send an overwhelmingly Democratic delegation to Congress. Democrats and Republicans alike question the expense of a state in which most of the population would qualify for welfare benefits, and some fear that Puerto Rican statehood would give momentum to a campaign to grant statehood to the District of Columbia.
 
Question of Citizenship
 It was exactly the dependence on the good will of Congress that Governor Rossello, a pediatric surgeon elected last year in his first campaign for office, advanced as a principal reason to seek statehood. Echoing a recent television advertisement, he referred several times on Tuesday to a study by the Congressional Research Service, an arm of the Library of Congress, that concludes that Congress has "the power to sever the United States' relationship with the island" unilaterally as long as Puerto Rico remains a commonwealth.
Mr. Hernandez Agosto dismissed the issue as a scare tactic that in practical political terms is meaningless. Congress also has the power to declare war on the Vatican, he noted, "but that doesn't mean it will." Citing Supreme Court decisions, he also argued that "Congress cannot take away the citizenship of any American citizen without his consent."
Mr. Hernandez Agosto also questioned the patriotism of Mr. Rossello and other advocates of statehood, implying they were willing to sacrifice Puerto Rico's interests and cultural identity in their eagerness to join the union.
"One does not negotiate the nation," he said. "One does not sell the nation."
 
Question of Costs
 Mr. Rossello repeatedly attacked what he called the "impotence" of the commonwealth model, noting that soldiers from Puerto Rico had repeatedly been sent off to war without the island's having a voice in the decision and that the island's economic model was largely imposed by Washington. More than 40 years of commonwealth, he argued, have failed to "breach the income gap" between Puerto Rico and the United States mainland.
"Those of you who have gone to the United States, who have relatives living there, know that the standard of living is higher there," Mr. Rossello said, addressing voters directly. Puerto Rico's per capita income is about $6,200 a year, the highest in Latin America but less than half that of the United States as a whole.
With statehood, Mr. Rossello predicted, Puerto Rico would automatically receive an annual injection of more than $3 billion in new Federal money, like Medicare payments and Aid to Families With Dependent Children, which would spur growth. In addition, he said in response to a journalist's question, Congress would have to allocate even more money to the island, "no doubt about it," because Puerto Rico would need "extraordinary aid" to rise to the levels of the 50 other states.
"Congress has to assume its responsibility to a new state," he said.
Answering the same question, Mr. Hernandez Agosto said enhanced commonwealth status would also "cost Congress some money." His party said it would seek extension of some Social Security benefits, protection for Puerto Rican agriculture and restoration of some tax exemptions that Congress reduced this year.
But he argued that the benefits of commonwealth included exemptions from Federal income taxes, and he said statehood would be costly. Not only would some Puerto Ricans have to pay Federal income tax, he said, but Mr. Rossello's party would also have to institute a sales tax and raise property and gasoline levies to make up for revenues like some business taxes that were possible only with commonwealth status.
Mr. Berrios was also critical of commonwealth status, complaining of "the indolence promoted by the government and colonial status." But he said statehood would "convert Puerto Rico more and more into the ghetto it already is." He urged voters to be courageous, saying, "To be afraid of an independent republic is to be afraid of oneself."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Three Choices for Puerto Rico's Future"
 
POLITICAL STRUCTURE
 Commonwealth: Residents vote in Presidential primaries, but not in other Federal elections. The island sends a single nonvoting delegate to Congress. The local government is headed by an elected Governor, and there is an elected bicameral legislature.
 Statehood: Puerto Rico's congressional delegation would consist of two senators and at least six representatives, with full voting powers. Residents would enjoy the same constitutional rights and benefits as all other citizens, including the 2.6 million Puerto Ricans living on the mainland.
 Independence: Puerto Rico would become a fully sovereign republic, with its own diplomatic representation and membership in international organizations. The only formal tie to the United States would be a treaty of friendship and cooperation, to be negotiated during a 10 year transition to independence.
 
TAXES AND BENEFITS
 Commonwealth: Residents of the island are exempted from Federal income taxes, though Puerto Ricans living on the mainland are taxed like all other citizens. In order to generate jobs, American companies operating in Puerto Rico also get an exemption on local profits. Puerto Rico does receive large amounts of Federal aid, though payments are capped at levels far below that of any state.
 Statehood: Special tax exemptions for industry would disappear, and Puerto Ricans would have to begin filing income tax returns like all other Americans. Because income levels are less than half those on the mainland, many Puerto Ricans would not have to pay Federal taxes and would be eligible for an "earned income credit" of up to $2,000 a year.
 Independence: Military veterans and retired people would continue to receive their pensions, but other Federal payments to Puerto Rico would eventually cease. Instead, a new system of local taxation and tariffs would be implemented. Independence advocates say they would also press the United States to pay for having occupied the island since 1898.
 
LANGUAGE AND CULTURE
 Commonwealth: Both Spanish and English have been official languages since early this year, reversing previous legislation that granted that status only to Spanish. Because of its uniquely ambiguous relationship with the United States, Puerto Rico has its own Olympic team and participates in other major international competitions and events as if it were independent.
 Statehood: Advocates say Puerto Rico would continue to be a bilingual entity, though commonwealth backers dispute that, arguing that Congress has required some states to adopt an "English only" policy as a condition of entry into the Union. Like all other states, Puerto Rico would have its own flag and anthem, but would probably be forced to give up its Olympic team.
 Independence: Spanish would become the sole official language, and schools would give more emphasis to Puerto Rican culture and history, phasing out a "colonial" curriculum.
 
CITIZENSHIP
 Commonwealth: Backers of commonwealth status insist that American citizenship is irrevocable, but statehood forces argue that is only true of Puerto Ricans born on the American mainland. Puerto Ricans are eligible for military service, whether born on the island or in one of the 50 states, and thousands have served with distinction.
 Statehood: Full American citizenship, with all the rights and responsibilities it confers, to all Puerto Ricans, regardless of their birthplace.
 Independence: Those who wish to maintain their American citizenship would be allowed to do so, through a system of dual nationality, but that right would not be extended to those born after independence. Puerto Ricans would become a nationality separate from that of the United States and would travel with their own passports.

HEADLINE: Clinton Pushing Business With Asia

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Seeking to capitalize on the world's fastest-growing economies, the Clinton Administration is pushing to topple trade barriers in East Asia, increase export subsidies and persuade United States companies to overcome their traditional reluctance to expand in the region.
While trade with Mexico and Canada dominates national debate, the Administration is orchestrating the push out of concern that businesses are not taking advantage of the huge opportunities in a region whose boom the World Bank calls the East Asian miracle. 
 Some officials have suggested creating a zone free of barriers to trade and investment on both sides of the Pacific, invoking the same philosophy that underlies the North American Free Trade Agreement: more trade means more jobs.
"The fact is this is the most dynamic region in the world," said Winston Lord, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs. "If we are interested in more exports and jobs, the most lucrative direction is the Asia-Pacific region."
 
Waking Up Businesses
 Corporate America has been slow to expand in East Asia. The Administration's plans are also presented as a way to prod businesses to wake up to the opportunities, though some critics may question whether the Administration's push is more show than substance.
A central part of the plan is to transform a weak, 15-nation association -- the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Forum -- into a powerful group that might, for instance, establish uniform rules for trans-Pacific trade and investment. The forum includes the United States, Canada, and 13 nations in Asia.
In parallel actions to increase the United States economic presence in Asia, the Administration is pressing Japan to open its market more to manufactured goods. The Administration's efforts have yet to produce concrete changes in Japanese practices, however.
The Treasury Department has also stepped up a campaign to put pressure on Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and other nations to remove barriers to American banks and insurers.
And the Trade Representative's office is pushing China to remove quotas on goods like cars, chemicals and computers.
 
Clinton to Meet Pacific Leaders
 As part of the Administration's efforts, President Clinton will meet in Seattle on Nov. 19 and 20 with the leaders of the other 14 nations. Some officials fear that the President's position could be undercut, however, if Congress defeats the North American Free Trade Agreement in a vote scheduled two days before the summit meeting.
Several officials described the push as a strategic repositioning, redirecting economic ties from slow-growing, inward-looking Europe toward a more dynamic, outward-looking Asia.
"If you look at our problems in that region, a lot has to do with the lassitude and ignorance of American business," said Paula Stern, a Washington-based trade consultant. "There needs to be a sense of urgency on the part of U.S. interests because we are slipping, relatively speaking, in that area."
American companies have been slow to expand in East Asia for various reasons, including cultural differences, trade barriers, a lack of capital, a widespread perception that much of the region remains backward and opportunities in other regions, like Latin America and Eastern Europe.
Governments in Japan, Thailand and other nations also maintain that Washington has simply been too complacent, allowing Japanese investors to fill the vacuum. They are also concerned that the recent withdrawal of United States military forces from the Philippines and, in part, from Japan and South Korea signifies a diminishing interest in Asia.
Still another problem is that Asia represents a wide range of countries, from rich to poor, with different concerns about protecting their industries with trade and investment barriers.
Many trade experts question how soon the Administration's Pacific overtures will translate into more exports and investments. Officials acknowledge that it may take years for these efforts to bear fruit.
If the United States increases its $129billion in annual exports to Asia by just 10 percent, that will mean 240,000 new American jobs, experts say.
 
Demand for Goods Seen
 In another decade, the World Bank predicts, the combined economies of China, Taiwan and Hong Kong will grow larger than the United States economy. In the same period, officials say, China, Indonesia, Taiwan and other countries will be shopping for hundreds of billions of dollars in goods and services in which American companies are world leaders.
These include computers, aircraft, telecommunications equipment, hospital equipment, airport construction, power generators and financial services like insurance. Wall Street's investment banking giants might also benefit from East Asia's huge need for billions of dollars in capital to finance factories and infrastructure, officials say.
The Administration is eager to use its Asian efforts to show that post-cold-war foreign policy can indeed translate into more jobs and higher living standards for Americans.
"Improved economic cooperation with Asia is naturally a major component of a foreign policy directed at promoting prosperity at home," said Lawrence H. Summers, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs. "Asia, which already represents a trillion-dollar-a-year import market, will account for nearly half the world's economic growth over the next decade."
 
Details of the Boom
 In the view of Administration officials, most Americans fail to recognize how fast Asia's economy has grown, how trade with Asia is booming and how rich many Asians have become. Per-capita income in Singapore is $15,000 a year, higher than in many Western European countries.
Indonesia's economy has more than doubled since 1985, and while most of its 190 million people remain poor, it has developed a sizable middle class able to afford American goods.
Thanks to moves toward a free market, China's economy has been growing by a phenomenal 12 percent a year. Since 1988, United States exports to Indonesia, Thailand and Malaysia have more than doubled. In 1980 the nation's trans-Atlantic trade was the same size as its trans-Pacific trade, but now the Pacific trade is 50 percent larger.
"Asia is likely to be the most dynamic part of the world in the decades to come," said Robert E. Rubin, director of the National Economic Council. "The idea is to have the freest possible trade with Asia."
The Administration is convinced that it can play a major role in expanding exports by improving political relations, reaffirming security ties and promoting economic cooperation, for instance, by pushing to reduce customs paperwork or harmonizing product standards. If the United States and a dozen Pacific nations develop common standards for mobile phones or satellite channels, that will increase United States exports.
 
Malaysian Boycotting Summit
 Some Asian officials complain that the Seattle summit meeting shows that Washington is arrogantly assuming a leadership role in East Asia. For this reason Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, plans to boycott the talks.
But other Asian officials have quite a different fear: that the meeting will mainly be a photo opportunity with little follow-up. Leaders of some nations are eager for Washington to play a larger role, partly to serve as a counterweight to Japan and China.
"They certainly want us to stay on in security and economic terms," said Mr. Lord, of the State Department. "They find that we provide stability. Each one has concerns over the longer term about one or more of its neighbors. They see us as a friendly balancing nation."

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD;
Perot Stake Under Pact Is Not Clear

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
A business owned by Ross Perot that became a central point of contention in his debate with Vice President Gore on Tuesday night told the Commerce Department earlier this year that it intended to take advantage of the surge in trading that would follow passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Questions about the venture, Alliance Corridor Inc., a 9,700-acre distribution center near Fort Worth that uses Federal tariff breaks to attract business, led to a series of testy exchanges, as Mr. Gore suggested that Mr. Perot stood to gain personally from his campaign against the pact. 
 Mr. Gore went on to say that Mr. Perot "has set it up so that he will benefit financially" whether the trade agreement passes or fails.
A review of documents filed by Alliance and interviews with Commerce Department and trade officials as well as Perot aides indicates that the Alliance has much more to gain from passage of agreement than its defeat.
Barry P. Bosworth, a Brookings Institution economist, dismissed Mr. Gore's suggestion that Mr. Perot would benefit from the pact's defeat. "I don't find the logic of that at all," he said. "That project is a good idea only on the basis of trade with Latin America."
 
Room for Confusion
 Both in Mr. Gore's assertions and in Mr. Perot's responses about Alliance, there was plenty of room for confusion.
The Perot family is developing the center for the distribution of goods in the United States and Mexico. The family is building vast warehouses for lease to other businesses, while the Santa Fe Railroad is building the largest freight-handling operation in the Southwest there. Mr. Perot is the principal investor in the venture.
According to a 1991 filing by Alliance with the Commerce Department, the project intends to take advantage of the higher volumes of freight that the trade pact would produce. "As the goods begin to flow, the Alliance Corridor will act as a hub for free trade," the filing said.
The filing was part of a petition for the Commerce Department to designate the project as a foreign trade zone, a status that allows businesses to delay payment of import taxes and sometimes pay lower rates. The petition was approved on Aug. 31.
Mr. Gore mainly emphasized the contradiction between Mr. Perot's public opposition to the trade pact and the Alliance project's advocacy of it. But he also suggested that Mr. Perot would benefit more from the foreign-trade zone if the pact failed, when the actual benefit would be very small or nonexistent, managers of other foreign trade zones in Texas said today.
 
Contradictory Motives
 "I think he has set it up so that he will benefit financially either way," Mr. Gore said. And at another point he suggested that Mr. Perot might be opposing the agreement to hold on to the relative advantages a foreign trade zone designation conveys. "If it's good enough for him," Mr. Gore declared, gesturing at Mr. Perot, "why not the rest of the country?"
Mr. Bosworth described the foreign trade zone's benefits as trivial compared with the trade pact's benefits for Alliance.
A Commerce Department official who insisted on anonymity noted that the use of a foreign trade zone does not eliminate the need to pay duties even for imports that are taxed. The main advantage of a foreign trade zone like Alliance is that it allows the importer to postpone the payment of duties, earning interest on the money in the meanwhile, the official said.
Manufacturers with factories in foreign trade zones are able to reduce the tax rate that they pay on some imported components for assembly, by choosing to pay the lower of the tax rate on the components or the tax rate on the finished product. But this requires separate approval by the Commerce Department, and the Alliance project has never applied for such approval, the department official said.
Mr. Gore also referred to the Alliance foreign trade zone incorrectly four times as a free trade zone. A free trade zone is a group of countries that do not collect tariffs on each other's goods.
Alliance officials expressed irritation today about the confusion, which Mr. Perot perpetuated during the debate by using the free trade zone term twice after Mr. Gore began using it. "Free trade zone has a connotation or perceived definition, that is different from a foreign trade zone -- it was most misleading," said Timothy D. Ward, the president of the Alliance Trade Authority, which operates the foreign trade zone.
Mr. Gore also suggested during the debate that the foreign trade zone had allowed an American company, Valmont Electric Inc., to shut down its factory in Illinois, move to Mexico and ship its products back to the United States without paying duties. "They closed down in Danville, 400 jobs lost, they opened up in Mexico with 100 jobs down there, and now they ship their products duty free back into the United States through the Alliance Airport," Mr. Gore said.
But no duties apply to the product, regardless of whether it comes through a trade zone, Federal officials said. Mr. Ward said the foreign trade zone status had never been activated for Valmont's warehouse. "They located to Alliance because of its distribution capability," he said.
Valmont executives were traveling today and did not return telephone calls for comment.
Mr. Gore first mentioned Valmont Electric to raise the issue of Alliance. But Jay Ziegler, a spokesman for Mr. Gore's office, said that the Vice President had not explicitly linked the duty-free status to the foreign trade zone. "It makes it sound that way, but that's not explicitly what the Vice President said," Mr. Ziegler said.
Mr. Ziegler said that Mr. Gore meant to say that the foreign trade zone gives Mr. Perot an advantage if the agreement fails. But the Commerce Department official said there were 25 other free trade zones in Texas, including three others near Fort Worth.
Terry Parent, the director of marketing for the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport, which also has a foreign trade zone designation, said that the designation would become more important if the trade pact is approved. The trade zone would still help for imports from countries outside North America, and these imports from outside the continent will likely increase if the agreement is adopted, he said.
The Alliance project is not the only one in which Mr. Perot appears likely to benefit financially from Congressional approval of the pact. He also owns a stake in the Perot Systems Corporation, a computer services company that is trying to do more business in Mexico.
Morton Meyerson, the chairman and chief executive of Perot Systems, was quoted on Oct. 20 by a Mexican newspaper, El Norte, as saying that, "Perot would be much better off if he favored Nafta rather than oppose it since his businesses would operate with great success in Mexico."
Mr. Meyerson was out of the country today and could not be reached for further comment. Stan Thigpen, a spokesman for Perot Systems, said that Mr. Meyerson had been accurately quoted by El Norte.


GRAPHIC: In his debate with Ross Perot, Vice President Gore raised the issue of a foreign trade zone in Fort Worth, Tex., operated by a company owned by Mr. Perot's family. Foreign trade zones are areas designated by the Commerce Department in which tariffs, which are taxes on imports, are waived to encourage business in or around the area.
Chart: "Advantages of Foreign Trade Zones"
Specifically, foreign trade zones allow American and foreign companies to save on Federal import taxes in various ways. The Perot family's foreign trade zone, which is designed to be a distribution hub for goods, has been granted permission for the first two ways. The Perot family has not asked permission to run factories in the zone, so the third method does not apply to it.
 
DELAYS SOME TAX PAYMENTS
If a company imports a widget from another country, stores it in the foreign trade zone for a month and then ships it to a store somewhere in the United States, the company does not have to pay import taxes until the widget leaves the trade zone. Without the trade zone, the company would have to pay the import taxes one month earlier, losing the use of that money.
 BENEFIT: Company earns interest on the duty for one month.
 
AVOIDS WAIT FOR TAX REFUND
If a company imports a widget from another country, stores it for a month in a foreign trade zone, and then reships it to another country, then it never pays taxes on the import. If the company stores the widget for a month outside of a foreign trade zone and then reships it, then the company must pay the tax when the widget arrives and then ask the Customs Service for a tax refund, known as a duty drawback, which can take half a year.
BENEFIT: Company earns interest on the duty for seven months.
 
LOWERS COMPONENT TAXES
If a company imports widgets, and uses them to build other gadgets inside the foreign trade zone, then the company can choose whichever tariff is lower, for widgets or gadgets.
 BENEFIT: Lower tarrifs.
 
IF THE NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE AGREEMENT PASSES, import taxes would be eliminated on goods shipped from Mexico, eliminating the advantage of foreign trade zones for such imports. But the advantages of foreign trade zones could be increased for imports from other countries.
 
(Sources: Commerce Department; Office of the United States Trade Representative)

HEADLINE: JAPANESE PREMIER FACING MAJOR TEST

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 10

 BODY:
A hundred days after taking office and promising the most sweeping political change in postwar Japan, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa still enjoys the highest approval rating in the history of Japanese polling but faces a critical test within the next few days getting the first of his biggest reform plans approved by Parliament.
Mr. Hosokawa has said that he must get a broad political reform bill approved in at least one house of Parliament before traveling to Seattle to meet President Clinton and most of the leadership of Asia at a major economic conference next week. But the obstacles standing in the way loom large. 
Mr. Hosokawa's aides and colleagues say passage of the bill must be completed before they can move on a host of other promises -- including an economic package and reforming a bureaucracy grown bloated with power. Mr. Hosokawa has said that he would resign, or force another election, if the political reform ever fails. But as the deadline nears, Tokyo is awash with predictions of another outbreak of political turmoil, the second stage of what began last summer when the Liberal Democratic Party splintered after 38 years and paved the way for Mr. Hosokawa's coalition Government to come to power.
 
New Defections Foreseen
 Many predict more defections from the Liberal Democrats over the reform plan, one that threatens to vastly weaken the power of the rural voting base that has been the party's greatest strength. But there is also strong opposition to the plan from the Socialists, the biggest party within the Hosokawa Government. The Socialists fear that the plan may work against small parties, who therefore may also defect from the Government ranks. To survive, Mr. Hosokawa's coalition would have to quickly find new members from the ranks of the Liberal Democrats.
"The next few weeks will be the most critical period in the post-war political history of Japan," Hiroshi Kumagai, the Minister of Trade and Industry and an influential member of Mr. Hosokawa's cabinet, said the other day.
So far, Mr. Hosokawa is extending the olive branch, offering to compromise on details of the plan. He may have no choice, because even before the issue is settled he will be forced to wander into a political minefield every one of his predecessors has sidestepped: Agreeing to the opening of Japan's long-closed rice market.
At the same time, in Seattle, Mr. Hosokawa will meet with President Clinton and try to convince him that the changes underway in Japan will narrow its trade imbalance with the United States.
 
Premier's Prospects Improve
 But for all his problems, the straight-talking southern governor now appears to have a better hold on power than at any time since he came to office. People who predicted a six-month premiership for Mr. Hosokawa are now measuring his potential tenure in years.
His greatest strength is the weakness of the Liberal Democrats, who seem on the verge of collapse. Unaccustomed to life in the opposition, the party's elderly leaders are constantly bickering. The elaborate system of factions they built up over the decades is falling apart. Many fear that the reapportionment of seats, and the granting of greater power to urban voters, could mark the end of their careers.
But a group of conservative, long-time leaders of the party, like former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, seem openly unrepentant. In a recent interview he argued that Mr. Hosokawa's popularity "is not really substantiated by merit, competence and capability" but rather in "some nebulous expectation that something new might emerge."
Clearly, many younger members of the Liberal Democratic party disagree. A number are openly talking about abandoning ship in the next few weeks, so that they will be seen as reformers working alongside Mr. Hosokawa rather than as proteges of a dying generation of old-style politicians.
 
Threat of New Election
 On Tuesday the man who stitched together the seven-party coalition Government, Ichiro Ozawa, taunted the Liberal Democrats with the threat that he was ready to play his strongest card: Another election. If the Liberal Democrats block the electoral reform effort in coming days, he said, "we may have to ask the will of the people" for the second time in six months.
Few think that Mr. Ozawa, a master strategist, really wants an election yet. But with Mr. Hosokawa's Cabinet drawing approval ratings of 70 percent in the polls, the Liberal Democrats cannot risk it; they would almost certainly lose many of the seats they now hold -- and more young members of the party would defect.
One of the results of the endless scandals here is that virtually everyone in the political scene has to support political reform in public. But arguments have broken out over how the seats would be divided once Japan does away with its current system, in which each district is represented by three to six members of Parliament.
Under both the Government and opposition party's proposals the country would be divided in constituencies that would have only one representative. Currently, half or more of the candidates are endorsed by the Liberal Democrats, meaning they differentiated themselves by how much cash they could give out or what favors they could perform.

HEADLINE: Mexican Stocks Soar After TV Debate in U.S.

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 10

 BODY:
After what was widely seen here as a tough and effective defense of the North American Free Trade Agreement by Vice President Al Gore in Tuesday night's debate with Ross Perot, the Mexican stock market today turned in its strongest performance of the year.
The market's index rose 81.49 points -- 4.17 percent -- to reach a new high of 2,035. 
 Currency exchange rates also stabilized after a wild fluctuation on Tuesday that saw the Mexican peso, after months of comparative stability, drop 15 centavos against the dollar, a little more than 4 percent. Currency-exchange shops along the Mexican border with the United States stopped accepting pesos on Tuesday and closed at midday. The shops reopened today.
Despite the market's rebound, analysts, economists and bankers continue to predict substantial volatility in Mexico until at least next Wednesday, when the House is scheduled to vote in Washington on Nafta, the trade agreement grouping the United States, Canada and Mexico.
 
Flight of Americans Seen
 Many foreign investors are hedging against the risks of the next week by selling short-term Mexican Government Treasury notes or by not renewing them, at least until after the vote. Erick Berry, an analyst at Vector, a Mexico City financial consulting firm, said he believed that American citizens, rather than Mexicans, were those seeking to get out of the market.
Foreign investors may have withdrawn $3 billion to $5 billion from Mexico over the last few days, analysts said. In an attempt to lure back that money, the rate on the Mexican Treasury notes, known as cetes, was set at 17.23 percent this week, up from an average of 14.94 percent last week.
 
Turbulent Week Expected
 "Many investors decided they wanted to go into dollars while they wait out the Nafta vote," said Jonathan Heath, director general of Macro Asesoria Economica, another consulting firm here.
The Mexican stock exchange, the Bolsa Mexicana de Valores, has shadowed the progress of the trade agreement all year.
Yesterday, the market may also have been responding to other positive economic signs. Inflation figures for October showed a rate of four-tenths of 1 percent, the lowest monthly rate in 25 years.
And Paul Reichmann, the Canadian real estate developer who built Olympia & York, announced here today that he was investing in three office and retail projects valued at $1.5 billion, with backing from the New York investor George Soros.
By the end of the day, the peso was selling at 3.19 to a United States dollar, about the level before the plunge yesterday. Analysts said that uncertainty over the trade accord's chances of United States approval had led investors over the last few days to convert their peso investments to dollars, leading to a tide of selling and pressure on the exchange rate, and prompting the Mexican central bank to stop defending the peso at its longstanding ceiling against the dollar.
Rogelio Ramirez de la O, an economic consultant here, said that by 11 A.M. on Tuesday, there was "a moment almost of hysteria," when it was unclear what action, if any, the central bank would take to regain control.
The bank has established a band within which it allows the exchange rate to fluctuate. The ceiling now stands at 3.309 to the dollar. But to help an economic stabilization plan of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, the central bank has in fact tried to keep the exchange rate somewhat better -- around 3.15 to the dollar -- where it has been most of the year.
On Tuesday morning, the bank decided to ignore the informal ceiling and allow the exchange rate to reflect to the real pressures of the market. That meant that if investors wanted to change pesos to dollars, they would have to turn over more of them.

HEADLINE: Its Economy Rising, Morocco Lures Investors

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RABAT, Morocco

 BODY:
For several weeks, Kerry Yeager, a project manager for the AES power corporation of Arlington, Va., has been hunkered down in a suite at the Hyatt here hammering out the terms of the biggest American investment ever in Morocco.
"We are coming here because Morocco is pro-Western, stable and has as good and sophisticated a group of people as I've ever met," Mr. Yeager said. 
 He has reason to be bullish. AES is about to ply close to $600 million into building a major thermal power plant and therefore has a keen interest in Morocco's stability. But it is not alone in taking a new look at Morocco, whose cheap labor, proximity to Europe and fast-growing population have prompted talk here of the potential similarities between Morocco's relationship to Europe and Mexico's to the United States.
After a decade of economic adjustment directed by the International Monetary Fund, Morocco has seen inflation reduced to 5.6 percent, tariffs cut and the foreign-debt burden lowered. So the argument, in essence, says Morocco is ripe for a wave of foreign investment to exploit both the growing domestic market and the potential for using the country as a low-cost base for exports to Europe.
Without that investment, Western officials here say, a demographic explosion expected to swell the population from 25 million to 40 million by early in the next century could prompt millions more Moroccans to cross the eight miles of water separating them from an increasingly xenophobic Europe.
Morocco appears to offer the best chance of an economic success story in North Africa. Its gross national product rose 4.5 percent a year from 1985 to 1991, and 3.5 percent in the last two years, when harvests were bad.
Already, foreign investment has risen fourfold in the five years to 1992, when it totaled $500 million. This year, the investment will be far higher as Spanish textile companies like Cortefiel have been moving production here because labor costs are at less than 25 percent of European levels.
Menaces lurk, however. In neighboring Algeria, the rise of militant Islamic fundamentalism has led to unrest that has claimed 3,000 lives over the last two years. While King Hassan of Morocco has kept a tight lid on similar movements in Morocco, and there is no sign of their making headway, the danger of a spillover persists.
Unemployment, about 16 percent, and illiteracy, about 55 percent, remain high. And fundamentalism has thrived on economic misery in both Egypt and Algeria. Aware of the danger, King Hassan has been trying to open the economy and pressing for closer links to the European Community.
Andre Azaulay, chief economic adviser to the King, said: "We are eight miles from Europe, and we want to be part of Europe. What we would eventually like is a full free trade zone with Europe, along the lines of the North American Free Trade Agreement."
After having initially scoffed at Morocco's interest in joining the community, Europe has sharpened interest in the country's economic and political stability because of the prospect of Algeria's turning into another Iran.
Meanwhile, Mr. Azaulay predicts fast progress on a privatization program devised in part to lessen Morocco's dependence on agriculture, which still accounts for over one fifth of its national output. The program involves the sale of 112 companies and is expected to raise about $2.2 billion.
A wide range of Moroccan businesses -- including mining, textile, paper, banks, insurance and hotels -- are on the block, and foreign investment is being encouraged.
One decisive stimulant to the economy could come if Morocco accords diplomatic recognition to Israel. There are more than 500,000 Jews of Moroccan descent in Israel, and many more in the United States and Canada. Mr. Azaulay, who is a Moroccan Jew, and other officials say they believe that these people would be ready to invest in Morocco if it recognizes Israel.
But Morocco is still a very long way from that. The King, while a persistent intermediary between Israel and Arab countries, is certain to move cautiously on Israel because he does not want to be seen to be betraying Arab claims to Jerusalem.
