HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD: Beyond a Trade Pact;
The Issue: Should the U.S. Expand Its Economic and Political Influence?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
The political debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement is not about tariffs or domestic content rules or side agreements on labor and the environment. It is not even mostly about trade with Mexico.
The debate is about matters much larger and more important. It is about whether, in the aftermath of the cold war, the United States will try to expand its economic and political influence around the world or whether it will withdraw within its borders and try to go it alone. And the debate is about the fate and frustrations of American workers, who have seen the number of good factory jobs decline and family incomes stagnate. 
 The trade agreement, in other words, is a symbol. It is more than a trade accord the way a nation's flag is more than a colored piece of cloth. It represents the enormous changes coursing through the American economy: increased competition from abroad, ever fewer blue-collar jobs, declining military industries, greater opportunities for workers with education, skills and knowledge of new technology.
These changes are extremely promising to some Americans and terrifying to others. That is why so much attention is being paid to an arcane measure that almost no one has tried to understand in detail.
 
U.S. Place in World Economy
 This is one of the first chances politicians have had to vote on a matter involving the place of the United States in the world economy since international communism ceased being the overriding threat to the nation's security.
And it is an opportunity for politicians to vent their anxiety about what is to become of workers in this country who have been mainstays of the middle class and who lack the education and perhaps the ability to master the sophisticated tools of the 21st century.
The trade agreement is bound to cost some jobs off the bat -- in the garment industry, for example. And it is sure to improve commerce around the Mexican border. So lawmakers with many garment workers will certainly vote against the measure, and those with districts along the Rio Grande will vote for it. But the greater tension is over what the agreement stands for rather than what it does.
Some politicians have been rather eloquent in addressing the symbolism.
In September, when President Clinton opened his campaign for Congressional approval of the trade pact, he declared, "This is a debate about whether we will embrace change and create the jobs of tomorrow, or try to resist those changes, hoping we can preserve the economic structure of yesterday."
 
'Seen too Many Jobs Lost'
 Last week, Representative David E. Bonior, the Michigan Democrat who is leading the drive against the trade pact, explained his position this way: "We have seen too many jobs lost. We have seen too many families uprooted. And we have seen too many communities destroyed the past 12 years."
In the television debate Tuesday night, Vice President Al Gore stacked the pact against some of the monumental judgments in American history. "Sometimes we do something right," Mr. Gore said. "The creation of NATO, the Louisiana Purchase. The purchase of Alaska. These were all extremely controversial decisions."
But Ross Perot saw the stakes differently. If the changes in the world economy are so encouraging, Mr. Perot asked: "Why is corporate America down-sizing? Why do we have the largest number of college graduates this year unable to find jobs since at any time since the '40's?
In point of fact, the trade agreement itself is of quite modest consequence in the whole scheme of the world economy and the American work force. Few Americans if any stand to strike gold or go broke depending on whether Congress votes next week to put the pact into effect.
But this is an instance in which the vote on a piece of legislation becomes disproportionately important because, coming at a turning point, the outcome could signify a change in direction or the continuation on a course.
In that respect, it is similar to the Civil Rights Act of 1957, the first civil rights law in this century. The actual provisions of that law -- creation of a Federal Civil Rights Commission, the authority for the Attorney General to seek court injunctions against obstructions of voting rights -- did little for the cause of black America. But its enactment was the first step toward the abolition of legal segregation in the United States.
Had Congress rejected this modest measure of President Dwight D. Eisenhower, it would have been crushing to the cause of civil rights.
Similarly, said Robert D. Hormats, a vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, who has been a Government economic official under Democratic and Republican Presidents, rejection of the trade accord would be a more significant loss than just the defeat of a trade measure. "It would be devastating to American foreign policy," he said.
From the opposing point of view, there are also parallels between the trade accord and the civil rights legislation. Not that those against the trade agreement would have voted against civil rights. Far from it. The Congressional Black Caucus is opposed to the agreement.
But many of the opponents of free trade with Mexico are trying desperately to hang on to a vanishing way of life, much as were the white Southerners in the 1950's. In the case of the trade pact, it is completely understandable that they should want to do so.
One of the bases of the American middle class, once the envy of the world, has been the well-paying assembly-line jobs available to (mostly) men who were not skilled craftsmen and had nothing more than a high school education.
 
Fewer Workers Producing More
 Such jobs are rapidly disappearing -- not primarily because of trade competition and not primarily because American factories are moving abroad in search of cheap labor -- but because machines are replacing people. The number of manufacturing jobs in the United States decreased to 17.7 million last month from 19.4 million in 1970. But manufacturing output has doubled during that period. Fewer workers are producing more.
It is fine for economists whose jobs are not in jeopardy to say that such improved productivity is essential to long-term economic prosperity. And many legislators who agree with the economists will vote for the trade pact.
But improved productivity is little solace to workers whose own livelihoods are at stake, and in their behalf, many lawmakers will vote to reject the agreement.
Romano L. Mazzoli, a Democrat from Kentucky, said he was leaning toward voting for the measure. But he said he was not happy about it. "There's a real palpable fear," he said, "that Nafta signifies the beginning or continuation of a profound change -- that it'll never, never be like it was before. And with it comes the frustrations that you and I, with two or three college degrees, can't understand."

HEADLINE: State Dept. Seeking Funds of Other Agencies

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Faced with the erosion of its foreign aid budget, the State Department has begun a campaign in the Administration to direct funds from other Federal agencies into foreign assistance programs.
A proposal being drawn up by top officials in the State Department will recommend to President Clinton that the Federal budget be revamped to channel funds from agencies like the Defense Department and the Drug Enforcement Agency into international programs. 
 State Department officials assert that with the demise of the Soviet Union and the threat of Communism, American foreign policy must concentrate on issues intertwined with domestic concerns, like the global environment, terrorism, narcotics trafficking and the development of markets for American goods.
In the new conditions, it makes little sense to maintain strict separation of domestic and international programs, the officials argue. In addition, they say funds earmarked for military assistance programs to foreign governments might also in future years be shifted more into foreign aid not related to defense.
Some State Department officials acknowledge, however, that the impetus for breaking down walls between domestic and international spending also stems from a realization that recent cuts in foreign aid are forcing severe cutbacks in international programs.
The State Department proposal is likely to touch off a turf battle between various Federal agencies and their protectors in Congress.
A first step toward this end is a new foreign aid bill being drafted by the State Department. The bill, which will be presented to Congress after the vote on the North American Free Trade Agreement, seeks to move away from allocating dollars on a country-by-country basis, and give the Administration flexibility to shift foreign aid dollars around to meet specific goals like building democracies or providing relief assistance.
An Administration official said that for the time being, certain foreign aid programs that are considered sacred cows, like aid to Israel, will not be affected.
 
A Trial Balloon
 The bill is a kind of trial balloon that even State Department officials call a "discussion draft" that could be modified to take into consideration objections raised by Congress and would affect only funds already controlled by the State Department.
But some officials make clear that they they envision eventually using the same kind of flexibility they hope to get from the new foreign aid bill to use funds that have been shifted from other Federal agencies into the foreign aid program.
The proposals being discussed at the State Department come at a time when levels of foreign and political support for it in Congress continue to plummet.
From a high in 1985 when foreign spending hit $18.5 billion, the amount budgeted for foreign assistance has fallen to $14.4 billion -- about one percent of total Federal spending -- in the current fiscal year.
With aid programs for Israel, Egypt and the former Soviet Union taking up about 40 percent of the foreign assistance budget, State Department planners find that other international programs, including those involving population stabilization, the environment and anti-drug programs are being squeezed.
In addition, the Administration last week told Congress that it intended to cut $458 million more in development assistance and economic support programs for foreign nations.
 
Aid Groups Alarmed
 The prospects of further deep cuts in foreign aid to help the Administration meet its deficit reduction targets has caused alarm among groups doing international relief and development work.
Last month, a letter signed by nearly 200 groups representing private relief agencies, environmentalist and religious and other charitable groups was sent to Mr. Clinton urging him to protect financing for international development programs.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Storage Divides Apaches and Neighbors

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MESCALERO, N.M.

 BODY:
The laser-guided saws at the Mescalero Apaches' lumber company turn out 16 million board-feet a year. The tribe's cattle company raises 7,000 head. Ski Apache draws 250,000 visitors annually, and the 440-room Inn of the Mountain Gods, with a convention center, golf course, Casino Apache and two artificial lakes, is humming.
What's next? A company that will store nuclear waste, if tribal elders get their way. The Governor of New Mexico, both houses of the Legislature, both Senators and all three Representatives are adamantly opposed, but because the tribe is a sovereign nation, such opposition may not stop them. There is little open opposition to the idea on the reservation, which expects enormous profits. 
 For a decade, the nuclear utilities and the Department of Energy have been looking for a few hundred acres, -- some place with not too many people but not too far from major transportation routes -- to store several thousand tons of high-level nuclear waste for a few decades, until a permanent repository is established.
The industry or the Government could pay tens of millions of dollars a year. That kind of money has attracted many inquiries, but only the Mescaleros have expressed serious interest. They see it as another way to use their 460,000-acre reservation to support the 3,400-member tribe.
 
Ancient Tribe, Modern Ills
 "We are looking for something so we can continue the tribe into perpetuity," said Fred Peso, one of eight members of the elected tribal council and the tribal official in charge of what the elders refer to as "the project." Nuclear waste storage could provide scores of jobs, many of them requiring far higher levels of professional training than the mill or the hotel demand.
The Mescaleros, descendants of Geronimo and Cochise and other Apaches who once ranged over a wide swath of Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and the Mexican states of Sonora and Chihuahua, face a variety of problems today. They have a housing shortage, a high unemployment rate despite the businesses they already operate and vandalism so bad that at one point it forced the closing of the tribal store.
Many of the tribe's neighbors say a waste site could wipe out the economic base of nearby towns. "Western tourism and nuclear storage don't mix," said E. Frank Potter, a city councilman in Ruidoso, a skiing and resort center next to the reservation.
 
'We're Still Here'
 In the high desert and fir-covered mountains, the conflict has racial overtones. The Mescaleros accuse neighboring whites of condescension when they say that Washington is trying to impose radioactive waste on the Indians. "The state has always tried to tell the tribe what to do," said Silas Cochise, one of the elders and a great-grandson of the Apache warrior.
The debate also raises questions about the nature of long-lived radioactivity. The Indians say they have a sense of continuity with future generations and a stronger respect for the land than a governor or a corporate executive can claim. "We fought the Spanish, the Mexicans, the Texans, the U.S. Army," Mr. Peso said. "Even the Confederate Army came here. We fought with five nations and we're still here."
What little opposition exists within the tribe is subdued. The tribal council is employer, landlord, local government and family circle, so misgivings are voiced quietly. Whites who have had long associations with the Mescaleros say tribal politics is not much influenced by outsiders and, like family decisions, is driven by unseen factors.
In fact, tribal officials discourage discussions with outsiders. Wendell Chino, the president of the Tribal Council for the last 30 years, complained in a three-page letter sent to all members of the tribe in January 1992, that "using the white man's influence, T.V. and papers against your own people is not the Apache way."
 
Misgivings and Ghost Bullets
 To push the idea of accepting the waste, the tribal government converted an old laundromat into a nuclear information center, complete with geiger counter and sample radioactive materials, and a dummy nuclear fuel assembly. The tribe also distributed refrigerator magnets with the information center's phone number.
To explain ionizing radiation to older members of the tribe whose primary language is not English, Mr. Chino uses a phrase in Apache that means "ghost bullets."
Many people voice misgivings, although they refuse to be identified. "I don't want to start glowing in the dark in a couple of years," said one young Mescalero woman who works at a job off the reservation.
An older woman said she was torn. On one hand she was drawn to the allure of a long-lasting industry that would provide jobs to keep young people on the reservation and support traditional ceremonies and crafts. On the other, she was bothered by the uncertain meaning of "interim storage." The Department of Energy hopes to open a permanent repository at Yucca Mountain, in the desert near Las Vegas, early in the next century. But Nevada is fighting hard to stop it, and the site may prove unsuitable. "Yucca Mountain is holding back, and they may never find a place for it," she said.
 
Voters Reject Dissidents
 Mr. Chino's opponent in the tribe's most recent election, Rufina Marie Laws, said there were religious objections to the project: "We were given this land by the Great Spirit. The ground we walk on is the same ground as our forefathers walked upon."
Ms. Laws said relatives had pleaded with her not to campaign against the waste site, fearing reprisals against the family. She said she had gone forward because she had had a dream in which a stream of iridescent water came down off the mountain and killed everything in its path.
In tribal elections on Nov. 3, Mr. Chino defeated Ms. Laws 391 to 176. Mr. Peso was elected vice president, defeating Donalyn Torres, another opponent of the plan, 333 to 211.
Tribal elders and outside engineers -- some from the nuclear industry and some who are industry critics -- say the installation the Mescaleros are considering would entail very little risk, if any.
 
Question of Appearances
 Used, highly radioactive nuclear fuel would arrive in sealed steel containers. But it would be in solid form, no longer generating enough heat to require water cooling, so there would be no liquid to leak and no pumps or valves or other mechanical systems to fail.
But that may not be the point. "Whether or not it is safe is not as big a question as the appearance," said H. John Underwood, the city attorney of Ruidoso and the area's state representative.
Last winter a group in Ruidoso gathered signatures on a petition to oppose the storage site. They planned to march to the reservation to deliver it, but Mr. Chino, the tribal president, threatened to close the ski area if they did. The opponents gave up the march.
In August, the Mescaleros applied for a final grant of $2.8 million from the Department of Energy to study whether the tribe should volunteer for the job. Over the years, 29 tribes and counties, including the Mescaleros, have applied for grants of $100,000 or $200,000, but most have dropped out. The Mescaleros were the first to seek the final grant.
The grants are available under a Federal law that invites states, counties and Indian tribes to negotiate with the Government for a temporary or permanent site. According to the Department of Energy, a sovereign Indian tribe would not need state permission, but Congress and the President would have to approve.
 
State Circles Its Wagons
 The Governor and New Mexico's Congressional delegation were horrified. Senator Jeff Bingaman led the successful push for an amendment to the Energy and Water Development Appropriations Act that eliminated financing for the grant for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1.
But the Indians are not deterred. The tribe is studying two areas on the slopes of the Sierra Blanca. When the light is right, the tops of the ski area's chairlifts are visible from the sites, 40 miles north of Alamogordo, N.M., where the first atomic bomb was tested in July 1945.
Nationally and in New Mexico, some environmentalists say they will fight the idea because it means putting more nuclear waste on the roads and rails than is absolutely necessary. But advocates of interim storage argue that the only alternative to one location with casks full of spent fuel is scores of such locations around the country, some in places far more populous or environmentally fragile than this area.
The Mescaleros say they may not need Congressional approval at all. If the Government does not build a repository, they say, they may strike a deal with a consortium of investor-owned utilities. Experts in the nuclear industry say that Commonwealth Edison in Illinois, and Northern States Power in Minnesota are likely candidates.
Whatever the claims of opponents, Mr. Chino explains his outlook this way: "The Navajos make rugs. The Pueblos make pottery. And the Mescaleros make money."

HEADLINE: House G.O.P. Proposes 'Tough Love' Welfare Requiring Recipients to Work

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
House Republicans struck first today in what promises to be a divisive debate over welfare, unveiling a plan they called "tough love" to make welfare recipients spend 35 hours a week working off their benefits.
With the White House drafting its own welfare proposals, the Republicans staked out a position that portrayed the nation's five million welfare families as an indolent lot in need of a moral tonic. 
 "You can't maintain civilization with 12-year-olds having babies and 15-year-olds killing each other and 17-year-olds dying of AIDS," said Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the minority whip.
The Republicans called the work proposal a compassionate idea that would give the downtrodden the incentive to change. But they also recognized that change would not come cheaply and they proposed spending up to $6 billion a year.
They proposed raising the money by cutting food programs and barring immigrants from welfare assistance, provisions almost certain to be opposed by the Democrats.
The plan offered a preview of the volatile politics likely to surround next year's debate, as advocacy groups leapt to denounce the plan's emphasis on personal morality rather than the weak state of the national economy.
 
Accusation of Racism
 "It's racist," said Sonia Perez, a policy analyst at the National Council of La Raza, a Hispanic advocacy group. She said the plan unfairly made immigrants targets and blamed minorities for high rates of single motherhood.
The Administration reacted cautiously, issuing a statement pledging to work with Congress on a bipartisan basis. But Representative Harold E. Ford, Democrat of Tennessee, who heads a Ways and Means subcommittee with jurisdiction over the plan, dismissed it as "negative and punitive."
President Clinton's pledge to impose a strict, two-year limit on welfare benefits was one of his most popular campaign themes and a large part of his claim to represent new Democratic thinking. But he has yet to specify what he has in mind.
An Administration plan being written for release next winter is likely to be shorter on penalties and longer on the expansions of social services, like job training and child care.
Distributing a series of Clinton campaign pledges on welfare, the Republicans warned they would attack any Democratic plan they found to be too permissive as backsliding.
"I hope the President means what he says," said Representative Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania.
The handouts accompanying the Republican plan said the two fundamental causes of welfare were the high rates of out-of-wedlock births and the failure of welfare recipients to seek jobs. Many scholars say the shortage of remunerative jobs for people with few skills is a third factor.
 
Two-Year Deadline
 Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., Republican of Florida, acknowledged that some regions had high unemployment but argued that even then "it doesn't mean that you don't have jobs."
The Republican plan, endorsed by party leaders, would give welfare recipients up to two years to take advantage of the education and training programs that already exist.
At the end of the two years, however, the mothers would have to work 35 hours a week to continue benefits.
The plan envisions two kinds of work programs: community service at a public or nonprofit agency, or a job at a private business that receives a Government subsidy. But they would pay no wage other than the continuation of welfare benefits.
States could end all benefits if recipients still had not found real jobs after three years on the work program.
Parents who failed to comply would have their aid reduced, with three infractions resulting in the cessation of all cash assistance.
The plan also seeks to increase child support collections and deny any cash assistance to a mother who fails to identify a father.
Mr. Santorum and the bill's other sponsors argued that the work experience would enable welfare recipients to develop skills and resumes that would make them more appealing to potential employers. But research in the area is at best inconclusive.
A recent report by the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, a nonprofit group, looked at past community work experiments and found "there is little evidence that unpaid work experience leads to consistent employment" or higher earnings.
The Republicans tried to portray their bill as an expansion of opportunity to needy people. But they also portrayed welfare recipients in almost uniformly negative terms.
"Some women on welfare are more consumed with the feeding of their drug habit than the gut instinct to feed their children," said Representative Nancy Johnson of Connecticut.
Gary Franks, Republican of Connecticut, who said he had relatives on welfare, talked of "taxpayer dollars going into the hands of drug dealers."

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD;
Cuomo Says He Won't Support Trade Pact

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 10

 BODY:
After refusing for months to take a firm position on the North American Free Trade Agreement, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York said today that he could not support the proposed treaty in its current form.
Mr. Cuomo's announcement came at an impromptu news conference a week before the House of Representatives is to vote on the trade agreement. Almost all 31 members of the House from New York had already taken a stand on the issue. 
 Twenty-one oppose the agreement, while four favor it and six are undecided. More than 40 governors support the agreement.
In recent appearances, Mr. Cuomo has praised the concept of a free trade agreement, even calling the one under discussion "a terrific idea" in a speech to the American Bankers Association in San Diego on Saturday. But he has also asked, as he did on the "Charlie Rose" program on PBS on Tuesday, "Is this the best deal, and is this moment the time to make it?"
 
Request for Analysis
 Mr. Cuomo said in that interview with Mr. Rose that he would not take a stand until he received an analysis of the agreement's potential effect on jobs in New York from the state's Department of Economic Development. But today, after being criticized in news reports for the ambiguity of his position, he announced his opposition before receiving that analysis.
"At this moment, I don't see how I can support it because there is not evidence for me to support it now," Mr. Cuomo said. "It will be good for business. But there is no evidence that it produces jobs for us. And there is some evidence that it will cost us jobs."
Mr. Cuomo said the trade agreement might be good for New York in the long run. But, he said, "I govern in the short term as well," adding that the greatest short-term need in New York was for jobs.
Mr. Cuomo said New York had been hurt disproportionately by several recent Federal decisions, including Medicare cuts and tax increases in this year's budget and military base closings in the state. He suggested implicitly that he could not support President Clinton, a fellow Democrat, on the trade accord unless the state received financial help in other areas.
"I'm for some kind of free trade agreement because you have to compete with the European Community, you have to compete with the East," Mr. Cuomo said. "But does it have to be at this moment, because I have all these impacts? Are you offering us something?"

HEADLINE: Louis Banks, 77, Dies; An Editor for Time Inc.

 BODY:
Louis Banks, a former managing editor of Fortune magazine and former editorial director of Time Inc., died on Sunday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 77.
The cause was congestive heart failure, Fortune said in a statement issued yesterday. 
 Mr. Banks started at Time in 1945 as a correspondent in the Los Angeles bureau. He was chief editor of Fortune from 1965 to 1970 and, as editorial director from 1970 to 1973, he held the second highest editorial position at Time Inc.
He helped launch a number of new ventures, most notably Money magazine. He retired as a member of the corporate board in 1987 when he reached the age of 70.
Mr. Banks was born in Pittsburgh and raised in Southern California, where he graduated in economics from U.C.L.A. During World War II, he served as a Navy pilot in the Pacific with the rank of lieutenant.
In 1969 he took a sabbatical to study at Harvard University as a Nieman Research Fellow. He returned to Time Inc. when he was offered the editorial director's post along with a seat on the company's board.
In 1973 he became a visiting professor at Harvard's Graduate School of Business Administration.
Mr. Banks is survived by his wife, Mary Campbell Banks; four sons, Robert L., William C. and Theodore R.; a daughter, Margaret Banks Czekaj, and eight grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices, Reflecting New Gasoline Tax, Rise 0.4%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Reflecting a higher gasoline tax and other special factors, consumer prices climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in October, the biggest advance in six months, the Labor Department reported today.
The rise in the Consumer Price Index, which followed an unchanged reading for September, was widely regarded as a statistical anomaly and not a sign that the recent pickup in economic activity was heating up inflation. 
 "The tax increase had a one-time effect," said Brian S. Wesbury, an economist at Griffin, Kubik, Stephens & Thompson, a Chicago investment house. "Over all, the numbers confirm that inflation remains moderate."
In another report, the department found that first-time claims for unemployment insurance rose a surprising 14,000 last week, to 354,000, the highest level in more than three months. The four-week moving average, which is considered a more reliable indicator of labor-market conditions, moved up 2,500, to 348,250.
While today's inflation report was not as unexpectedly favorable as Tuesday's survey of prices at the producer level, which declined two-tenths of 1 percent in October, it showed that underlying, or core, inflation eased to 3 percent in the latest 12 months. This is the best year-over-year performance since the early 1970's, when the Nixon Administration imposed price controls.
Nonetheless, bond prices fell and long-term interest rates rose in the credit markets. Traders said that the surprisingly favorable producer price figures released on Tuesday had raised expectations in the market that consumer prices would also show weakness.
The underlying inflation rate, which rose three-tenths of 1 percent in October, does not include food and energy, which bounce around from month to month, often because of extreme weather.
Indeed, food prices in grocery stores spurted eight-tenths of 1 percent last month, the biggest rise since August 1992. The advance was concentrated in fresh fruit prices, which rose 18.1 percent in the last four months.
The effect of higher energy prices was felt mainly in the transportation sector, where prices rose 1 percent last month, the most in three years.
Gasoline prices, which had fallen for seven straight months, jumped 4.5 percent as the 4.3-cent increase in the Federal gasoline tax took effect on Oct. 1. Demand was apparently strong enough to allow service stations to pass most of the extra tax on to customers.
New cars, which fell 3.9 percent at the producer level, rose four-tenths of 1 percent at retail, with about 30 percent of the sample consisting of 1994 models. Used cars climbed six-tenths of 1 percent to a level 8.3 percent above that of October 1992.
Medical costs rose five-tenths of 1 percent, the biggest increase since May, bringing the 12-month gain to 5.7 percent, the report showed.
Among the five big metropolitan areas for which October figures were published today, prices rose the least in New York, edging up just one-tenth of 1 percent. Prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent for Chicago and San Francisco, five-tenths of 1 percent for Los Angeles and seven-tenths of 1 percent for Philadelphia.
For the first 10 months of the year, the C.P.I. for urban consumers has advanced at a 2.8 percent pace, about the same as for all of 1992.
"We have modest inflation, and I think the downtrend is going to remain intact," said Carl J. Palash, economist at MCM Money Watch, a New York advisory firm. He predicted that the year-over-year rate would fall to less than 3 percent, to perhaps 2.5 percent, in the first half of 1994.
Still another report, one partly derived from the price data, showed today that real average weekly earnings rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month, recovering part of the September decline of eight-tenths of 1 percent.
Hourly earnings rose five-tenths of 1 percent and hours worked rose three-tenths of 1 percent. But inflation -- as measured by an alternate C.P.I. -- reduced buying power by five-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Fight for Green Point's Pot of Gold

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
In the 125 years since it was founded, Green Point Savings Bank of Flushing, Queens, has accumulated a giant pot of gold -- retained earnings of $758 million.
Under the arcane rules governing mutual savings banks like Green Point, the pot of gold is nominally owned by depositors, but in reality owned by no one. The pot of gold is why Green Point is in the middle of a takeover battle with Republic New York Corporation of Manhattan. 
 Claiming that pot of gold was one reason behind Green Point managers' announcement in July that the bank would convert to a shareholder-owned corporation in an initial public offering worth $600 million to $800 million, the largest such conversion to date.
Their deal would give insiders 30 percent of the company and would make all top management and trustees millionaires. For example, Thomas Johnson, Green Point's chairman, would get about $2 million in stock outright and options on $4 million more. A former president of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, he was hired in August.
Last Friday, however, Republic upended Green Point's plans. It proposed to acquire Green Point, paying nothing for it directly, but offering a $100 million special interest payment to depositors. Republic has acquired the Manhattan Savings Bank and the Williamsburg Savings Bank on similar terms.
The nasty war of words that has ensued represents the fervor of people fighting over the keys to a treasure chest.
"They are looking for a loophole to get something for nothing," Mr. Johnson said about Republic.
Jeffrey C. Keil, Republic's president, in turn, criticized the large awards of stock and options that would go to Green Point management and trustees: "The whole thing is a scheme to enrich insiders," he said.
To be fair, these compensation programs are similar to other conversions of mutual savings banks, although the dollar amounts are higher, since Green Point is the largest such conversion. Moreover, these awards vest over five to ten years.
As for getting something for nothing, the two proposals offer the same windfall to the eventual acquirer: an institution with a book value of at least $1.2 billion for a contribution of equity of about $700 million.
Who should get this windfall? The relevant law was not written to deal with this situation. Essentially, it is up to the bank's board of trustees to decide, although the standard they should apply is far from clear.
On this point, the regulators obfuscate. The state Banking Department approved the Green Point plan last week, but in response to a query by Republic, Elizabeth Tibbals, the department's deputy superintendent and counsel, wrote to both banks that the trustees were obligated to act "in a manner that is consistent with their roles as fiduciaries, although the Banking Department will not attempt to describe or define the scope of such fiduciary duties."
The Green Point trustees' main objective is to preserve Green Point's independence, Mr. Johnson said: "It is our absolute conviction that this bank should be preserved and not incorporated within some other bank that would change it and hurt it."
Mr. Keil, Republic's president, responds that because Republic is bigger, it can offer Green Point customers a broader range of services.
The other difference between the two plans is how they affect the depositors. Under the management plan, each depositor would have the right to buy up to $1.75 million in stock in the offering, stock that would be otherwise hard to find. Republic would offer its stock to depositors at the market price, which is no real benefit, but give them a share of the $100 million special interest payment, about 2 percent of deposits.
Unlike proxy battles for public companies, Green Point's depositors are largely left on the sidelines. They must vote whether to approve management's plan, but Republic is not allowed to submit an alternative to them. A lawsuit has been filed on behalf of depositors, with Republic's assistance, seeking to get the trustees to consider Republic's bid.
All of this begs the question of whether Green Point needs to convert to stock ownership at all. As a public company, it can issue more stock to raise capital or make acquisitions. On the other hand, the bank is overcapitalized now and would be much more so after the Green Point offering. Ronald S. Riggins, who conducted the appraisal for the offering, says the bank's return on equity would fall to a meager 6.8 percent.
After converting from mutual status in public offerings, many savings banks, in fact, have started buying back their stock with their extra capital. This, not so coincidentally, increases the share of the company's stock held by insiders.
For this and other reasons, depositors thinking of investing should exercise caution. Green Point has essentially one business: It attracted deposits with above-average interest rates and lent them as home mortgages, to borrowers who offered little or no documentation of their income.
But as the New York area fell into recession and still struggles out of it, Green Point's delinquent loans and loan losses have increased sharply.
The numbers do not necessarily paint a disaster in the making, but Green Point's record of steadily increasing earnings in recent years could well be broken by a spike in loan losses.

 COMPENSATION FOR INSIDERS. Executives and trustees would all keep their jobs and get compensation comparable to what they would get in the public offering.
 MORE REPUBLIC STOCK ISSUED. Republic would sell about $700 in its stock and add the proceeds to Green Point's capital.

HEADLINE: Goal: Integration by Consensus;
Weak Gesture or Trojan Horse? Connecticut Is Divided

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
Connecticut is about to call on its 169 towns and cities to do what no state has ever asked: to cooperate in creating, from the local level up, a statewide plan for integrating public schools.
To some parents and politicians, the planning exercise, mandated by a law enacted in the spring, is a Trojan horse being hammered together to force racial quotas and busing on their communities. To others, it is a weak gesture at bridging the racial and economic gaps that divide the state's poor cities from their wealthy suburbs. 
 All Jack Hasegawa has to do is bring everyone together to discuss, very publicly, one of the most sensitive issues in American life, and make the process work.
Mr. Hasegawa, until last month the director of Dwight Hall, a community-service center for students at Yale University, is the sole full-time employee hired by the state to set in motion the law, "An Act Improving Educational Quality and Diversity."
Looking at his new surroundings, an isolated cubicle in the State Department of Education with little more than a desk and a telephone, he sees perhaps the best answer to fears that the law's language conceals a plan to impose school desegregation. There is no one to do that.
"The legislature really meant it, for once, when it said we're going to do this as a locally directed process," Mr. Hasegawa said in an interview. "As far as I can tell, this may be the only time that a state has said, we have to do a basic education reform and we're going to do it by going out to the citizens and asking them to do it."
The law lays out a firm timetable for every community to take part in an unfamiliar process, defined by code words ("quality," "barriers to opportunity," "student diversity") that can mean different things to different people.
Republicans, who opposed the law in the General Assembly, intend to make it a central issue in next year's legislative elections, and are already distributing materials that sharply dispute its intent.
In the end, whether any community takes part in magnet schools, or exchanges of students or teachers across district lines, or any other plan, remains up to each city or town, not the state.
So Mr. Hasegawa's role is in many ways like that of a guide leading a large and prickly contingent of strangers through new territory. There is a deadline, there is a need for order, but the destination is uncertain and not his to decide. He can only point out features of the land that might help people decide where they want to end up.
Mr. Hasegawa, 49, has made his own journey through a diverse world. He grew up in a Japanese-American farm community in California, took part in civil-rights protests in the South, was inspired by black church leaders to attend divinity school, worked with street gangs in Boston, and eventually spent several years working and teaching in Japan, where as a fourth-generation American he learned the language of his great-grandfather.
Having worked with Yale students of all backgrounds meeting people unlike themselves for the first time, hearing his 11-year-old son tell of unpleasant encounters in his suburban school in Woodbridge, Mr. Hasegawa says, "It's unnatural in Connecticut for us to have children in class with kids who are fundamentally different in color or ethnicity."
 
'A Common Interest'
 He says the essence of his new job is "the ability to create community, the ability to help people see that they have a common interest in this question of quality and diversity."
"There are a lot of people who don't trust that the law means what it says," Mr. Hasegawa said, "who believe that somehow down the road their kids will have to be bused."
"But the Commissioner of Education has said over and over, if busing comes, it will be the result of a local plan, or because people feel there is a better opportunity at the end of the bus ride, or because a court orders it. It will not come out of the department's planning process."
A court order is a possibility because of a lawsuit known as Sheff v. O'Neill, which seeks to integrate Hartford's schools with those of 21 suburbs. Long-delayed final arguments are set for Dec. 16, and a decision by Superior Court Judge Harry Hammer is expected in the spring.
 
Asking Local Boards
 The law calls on local school boards to appoint advisory committees and then propose what their communities could contribute to regional plans to improve and integrate public schools. Almost 80 percent of the students in Connecticut's cities are black or Hispanic, while most suburban districts are 90 percent to 95 percent white.
Eleven regional forums will draft the plans, which the Commissioner of Education can comment on, but not reject. Approval is up to the school boards and governing bodies in the communities. Even then, towns can refuse to participate.
The process officially begins in January, when the Institute for Public Service at the University of Connecticut will convene the forums. Mr. Hasegawa and the institute staff, however, are already deeply into their planning, knowing that the success of the process will depend greatly on how they start it off.
"Every region will be free to do its own thing, but we'll have some suggestions on how to proceed," said the institute's director, Howard Rifkin. "We're going through this constant debate on how much guidance is too much and will be perceived as trying to force certain solutions."
"I've been to a lot of meetings where people are trying to set up the us-against-them mentality," he said. "I tell them, this is about you. It's not about the institute or the Department of Education defining anything."
 
Italicized Options
 To build consensus, Mr. Hasegawa and Mr. Rifkin have consulted with several statewide groups on how to organize the process. In suggesting ways to proceed, or options for meeting a goal, Mr. Hasegawa said, "We find ourselves using things like italics, to say, "one possible way.' "
In this month's school-board elections, the law did not appear to be an issue, said Terry P. Cassidy, executive director of the Connecticut Association of Boards of Education, which has conducted several meetings on the law for its members.
"I haven't heard anyone say, 'We will not do this.' I haven't heard anyone say it's a bad idea. I've heard them all recognizing that we have to give every child a chance."
What does concern school boards, Mr. Cassidy said, is how they will build support for the regional plans in their communities, and the unanswered question of whether the state will help pay for new schools, new programs or transportation that the plans propose.
The Republican Party has already sent its legislators material for letters warning constituents that the law portends mandatory busing, regional tax districts and desegregation plans forced on towns.
"It's not something that's of great concern to people at this moment, but I think this is the major issue for next year," said State Representative Daniel F. Caruso, a Republican from Fairfield who sent a mailing on the law to his district.
Mr. Hasegawa's advice to those concerned about the law is to take part in the process. There will be advisory groups. All meetings will be open. There will be public hearings.
"The fear is, isn't there a hidden agenda?" he said. "The right question should be, how can I be involved?"

(Steve Miller for The New York Times) (pg. B9)

HEADLINE: Cyclicals Set the Pace, With Dow Up by 23.48

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Surmounting its gnawing fear of rising interest rates, the stock market yesterday cobbled together its first major rally in more than a week.
The Dow Jones industrial average rode a wave of buying in stocks of the cyclicals, companies whose earnings are sensitive to changes in the economy. The index rose 23.48 points, to 3,663.55, its biggest increase since late October. Technology issues were also strong, propelled by an encouraging report from a trade group on semiconductor sales. 
 Yesterday's gains came despite a slump in the bond market that was apparently touched off by the Government's report that consumer prices climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in October, the biggest advance in six months.
A faltering bond market -- and a resulting jump in bond yields -- has repeatedly pulled down the stock market in recent weeks because some investors fear that people seeking better returns on their investments will switch from equities to fixed-rate securities, analysts said.
But yesterday, stock investors seemed to home in on parts of the Government's inflation report indicating that the economy was expanding without creating major price increases. Many economists noted that the four-tenths of 1 percent rise was an anomaly influenced by the new Federal gas tax of 4.3 cents.
"The report hinted that some pricing power is being restored, and that's good for stocks," said Hugh Johnson, the chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation. "Because of some strengthening in the economy, corporations are recovering their ability to raise prices."
Mr. Johnson said the market was also buoyed by Vice President Al Gore's performance against Ross Perot during the debate on the North American Free Trade Agreement on Tuesday night.
 
Market Seems to Favor Nafta
 The market seems to favor the accord because many companies believe they will benefit from it. Mr. Gore's apparent success also helped American depository receipts of Mexican companies in yesterday's trading. Telefonos de Mexico was the second-most-active stock on the Big Board, rising 1 7/8, to 52 3/8.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was better than average at 283.45 million shares, up from 276.4 million shares on Tuesday. Advancing issues led declining issues by about 4 to 3.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 3.39 points, to 463.72. The American Stock Exchange composite index was up 0.68 point, to 476.70. And the Nasdaq composite index jumped 6.66 points, to 776.50.
The cyclicals led yesterday's gains, particularly the auto, mining, paper and chemical issues.
General Motors rose 2 1/2, to 51 1/8; Ford was up 7/8, to 61 3/4, and Chrysler edged up 3/8, to 55 1/4.
Besides G.M., the other cyclicals that contributed to the rise in the Dow Jones industrials were Alcoa, up 1 3/8, to 69 3/4; Bethlehem Steel, up 1 1/4, to 17 5/8; International Paper, up 1 1/8 to 62 5/8; Allied Signal, up 7/8, to 71 7/8, and Caterpiller, up 7/8 to 90 7/8.
A report from the Semiconductor Industry Association on growing semiconductor sales bolstered the stocks of technology companies. Intel was the most active issue on the Nasdaq, rising 2 1/2, to 63 1/2. Texas Instruments surged 4, to 63 1/8, and National Semiconductor jumped 1 3/4, to 17 7/8.
Among other technology stocks, I.B.M. rose 3/4, to 49 7/8, Compaq shot up 2 1/4, to 68, and Oracle Systems was up 1, to 31 1/2.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Retreat on Price Index Rise

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The bond market retreated yesterday and long-term interest rates rose after the Government reported news on inflation that disappointed traders and investors.
The rise in October consumer prices of four-tenths of a percent matched most analysts' forecasts. It was caused mostly by a big jump in gasoline prices, which surged as Federal taxes rose 4.3 cents a gallon. 
 But in the wake of Tuesday's unexpectedly good producer price figures, traders said expectations had been raised. "There was hope that the Consumer Price Index would perform better," said Steven Saslow, an executive managing director at Carroll McEntee & McGinley. "Accounts wanted to see a more favorable number to justify buying back securities they probably sold over the last month."
 
Rally on Tuesday
 On Tuesday, the unexpected drop of two-tenths of a point in the October Producer Price Index caused bond prices to rally by about 3/4 point. But those gains were completely wiped out yesterday.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 6 1/4 percent 30-year bond was offered at a price of 10025/32 , down 25/32 , to yield 6.20 percent, up from 6.14 percent late Tuesday.
"We aren't going to see a lot more declines in inflation," said Donald Ratajczak, director of the economic forecasting project at Georgia State University. "But we will see better numbers than we had for October. Basically, we are on a 3 percent inflation path."
The consumer price data also quelled demand among investors for the $12 billion worth of 10-year Treasury notes that were auctioned yesterday. The auction was the second and final leg of the Treasury's autumn refunding.
Traders said that much of the issue, which was auctioned at an average yield of 5.69 percent, was bought by speculative accounts. At the last 10-year auction on Aug. 11, the securities were sold at an average yield of 5.78 percent.
Late yesterday, the new 10-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 5.69 percent.
 
Managers Turn Cautious
 The disappointing consumer price figures were the most obvious apparent cause of the selloff yesterday. But traders and analysts said the session's results were also symptomatic of a market in which money managers, approaching the end of the year with substantial profits in their pockets, were turning cautious.
"People are defending their profits," said one Government securities trader. "The same thing happened last year, and with the economy looking stronger, people are getting very, very careful."
Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a bond market research firm in Princeton, N.J., said that weekly surveys of money managers conducted by the firm showed that since mid-October these accounts had substantially reduced their exposure to longer-term notes and bonds, which are more volatile than shorter-term securities.
"It makes sense for them to do that, because they have had a heck of a year," Mr. McCarthy said. "Right now there is very little reward for taking on more risk."
Prices of shorter-term Treasury issues also fell yesterday, but not as much as bonds.
By late yesterday, the 4 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered in late trading at a price of 9821/32 , down 1/4 point, to yield 5.06 percent. And the 3 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 1/2, down 2/32 , to yield 4.14 percent. Treasury bill rates were little changed.
 
Corporate Activity Slow
 In the corporate bond market, new-issue activity, which was heavy on Tuesday, ground to a virtual halt yesterday. The consumer price figures and the Veterans Day holiday persuaded underwriters to leave new issues on their shelves.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the day's biggest offering was a competitive sale of $310 million worth of sales tax revenue bonds for the Los Angeles Metropolitan Transit Authority. A bid from a group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company won the issue.
Serial bonds were reoffered with yields from 4.05 percent in 1997 to 5.35 percent in 2013. And term bonds maturing in 2023 were priced to yield 5.50 percent.
The issue is insured by the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, and carries an AAA rating from both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Despite Report Showing Increased Inflation

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the yen and other currencies yesterday after the American currency failed to rally on a Government report showing higher inflation.
Rumors that the Federal Reserve was buying dollars for the Bank of Japan helped the dollar recover from its worst levels, although traders said they saw no signs that the United States central bank was in the market. 
 The dollar fell to 107.20 yen in late New York trading, from 107.95 on Tuesday. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 107.88 yen from Tuesday's close of 107.97 yen.
Gold bullion rose 80 cents an ounce, to $377.40 for the December contract, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
The yen gained against most currencies on signs that Japanese buyers were liquidating foreign assets, which supported the yen.
 
 
'Good Buying'
 "There was good buying of yen across the board on talk of repatriation of offshore assets by Japanese investors," Richard Koss, director of foreign exchange sales for CIBC, said. "The Japanese also sold European assets."
The dollar ended at 1.6892 German marks in late New York trading, down from 1.6925 marks on Tuesday. Earlier, it fell to 1.6925 marks in London from the Tuesday close of 1.6957 marks.
In United States trading, the dollar declined initially after the Government said the overall Consumer Price Index rose four-tenths of 1 percent in October, and three-tenths of 1 percent for the core rate, excluding food and energy. The dollar ignored a sharp rise in credit market interest rates in response to the consumer price rise.
"The C.P.I. was more or less in the bounds of expectations and had a low level of impact," Chris Bourdain, a corporate foreign exchange trader at Credit Suisse, said.
Failure to push the dollar higher sparked selling.
"People are beginning to question how long the bullish sentiment in the dollar will survive," Mr. Koss said. "It's liable to persist, but some may start to figure the path of least resistance is lower," he said.
The Mexican peso ended firmer against the dollar, recouping some of its sharp losses of Tuesday amid growing optimism about the prospects for the North American Free Trade Agreement.

HEADLINE: China Austerity Drive Is Hurting U.S. Ventures

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHENYANG, China

 BODY:
Last summer, when thousands of regional Communist Party bankers were printing money to finance their capitalist dreams, China's leaders in Beijing clamped down with an austerity drive to rein in a runaway economy.
Bank lending stopped suddenly under orders from central authorities to recoup tens of billions of dollars in state loans made in a frenzy of unauthorized investment. 
 But China's four-month-old austerity cure may be worse than the disease, especially if it kills the investment momentum that is pouring about $1.5 billion in foreign investment into China each month.
Already, the program has undermined production at some American corporate ventures and dried up bank credits that were financing new factories for other foreign partnerships.
Here in the heart of China's northeastern industrial belt, a $100 million joint venture with the General Motors Corporation and the Jinbei Automotive Company to produce pickup trucks is at a virtual standstill because local governments that would be likely customers for the trucks do not have the money to buy them. And even if they did, Beijing has told Government agencies and state factories to stop buying new vehicles until the end of the year.
The austerity drive's aim was simple: stop the wasteful spending on golf courses when power plants and dams were begging for funds; get control of the inflationary spiral that had broken through 20 percent in urban areas and was still climbing, and, finally, slow China's growth, which was highballing at 13.9 percent in the first half of the year.
But because China's economy still largely runs by central command, the austerity drive froze the flow of money through the banking system.
Financing problems also endanger another $100 million project: Pittsburgh-based PPG Industries' plan to join Japanese and Chinese partners in producing flat glass in nearby Dalian. PPG said its Chinese partners could not get the money they needed.
And the Chinese partners of the big American pharmaceutical company Pfizer Inc. are also said to be having trouble getting money to finance a venture that began operating earlier this year at Dalian, producing antibiotics and other medical products.
Western bankers here have begun telling European and American corporations to proceed cautiously into China and to gauge how the austerity program, might affect new projects.
The lack of money for Government-owned factories, some of which are straining to meet their payrolls, and the shortage of bank financing for construction became such a crisis that in early October China's economic czar, Deputy Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, flew to Dalian to address the complaints of industrial managers and regional officials.
One result was that the Government decided about a month ago to pump $5.2 billion nationwide into high-priority projects that were going begging for working capital. But this injection may fall well short of the overall demand.
Almost $1 billion of the emergency money was designated for projects here in the northeast, where one foreigner said American joint-venture executives "have been yelling bloody murder" over arbitrary Government decisions to block access to letters of credit and other sources of guaranteed financing.
 
Tight Credit Acknowledged
 Zhou Zhengqing, deputy governor of the People's Bank of China, acknowledged that credit was tight, a situation he said was caused both by excessive construction as well as the controls clamped on by Mr. Zhu.
He said those controls "are not meant to tighten money" and that additional funds were being directed to important projects in the railway, coal, oil, power, communications and building-materials sectors.
For Mr. Zhu, who has day-to-day management control over the economy, engineering a "soft landing" for China's economy is a test of his political skill and China's credibility.
There have been persistent reports in recent weeks that President Jiang Zemin and other members of the Politburo, fearing a crash landing of the economy with Mr. Zhu at the controls, are ready to throw off the strictures of the austerity plan.
In recent days, there have been reports that China's ailing senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, has grumbled that the austerity program is stunting the full-speed growth he insists is the only course.
"It is better to make the pace faster," he was quoted by Wen Wei Po, a pro-Beijing newspaper in Hong Kong, "A slower pace of development is not correct." Then, the Communist Party released one of the old speeches by Mr. Deng to showcase his dictum that slowing growth leads to civil unrest.
 
Fear of Institutional Suffocation
 A number of officials have suggested that the austerity program will be enveloped by a new set of changes aimed at overhauling the banking and taxation systems. This plan was reviewed by the Politburo in the summer and was scheduled for consideration at a Communist Party Central Committee leadership meeting.
A new commercial banking sector could go a long way toward re-establishing credibility for joint-venture companies that are finding out that guaranteed letters of credit are not worth the paper they are written on if the People's Bank of China simply refuses to issue the funds.
"Most of the joint ventures are solving their problems at considerable cost to themselves," said one person knowledgeable about the ventures. "Either they have brought in more money, or they have sent people down to Beijing to complain until they get something done."
A spokesman for PPG Industries, John S. Ruch, said, "Our Chinese partners have not been able to obtain the funding they have been promised" for a $100 million assembly line. PPG hopes that by 1995 it will begin making 600 tons of glass a day for China and for export to Japan.
"At this point," Mr. Ruch said, the plant remains on schedule, but he added that PPG had put its Chinese partners on notice that without a favorable response on the financing by the end of the year, "the project will be affected in the near future." He declined to say whether PPG would pull out.
 
Feeling Pinched
 A Pfizer spokesman in New York, Michael W. Hodin, said the Government's decision to tighten credit had had the effect of "reducing the local funds available for companies to finance their operations."
"This limits expansion opportunities," the statement continued, "and results in an increase in the cost of doing business for both local companies and joint ventures in China."
He did not elaborate on how the tight credit would affect Pfizer's plan to begin operations this year at a 250-employee production line that would make a range of pharmaceuticals.
As for the General Motors joint venture here in Shenyang, analysts say G.M. may be a victim not only of the austerity program, but also of some basic miscalculations about China's auto market. G.M.'s share of the $100 million venture is a $30 million upgrading and expansion of an antiquated assembly line belonging to the Gold Cup state auto maker, which is affiliated with Jinbei, a major commercial vehicle maker.
 
'1920's Technology'
 The plan was to jump into the truck business here by assisting Gold Cup in producing its dowdy trucks temporarily while bringing in kits of G.M.-designed products: a light-duty S-10 pickup truck and the Jimmy and Blazer utility vehicles.
G.M.'s first problem was that in the spring, the aged Gold Cup trucks, which one executive described as "1920's technology," began to lose their market among Chinese customers. At the same time, the S-10 truck was not creating the demand that had been expected. Of the 500 kits assembled since May 1992, the venture sold only 12, one analyst said.
"This could just be a question of suitability to the market," one analyst said. "The S-10 is overengineered for the China market. It is too expensive and it has too many bells and whistles on it." G.M.'s pickup costs about $25,300 in China; competing models sell for 35 percent to 50 percent less.
But the real blow came during the summer, when Mr. Zhu announced his austerity measures and ordered state enterprises to stop buying new vehicles for the rest of this year. Now most of the activity going on at the G.M. assembly line in Shenyang is training and waiting.
 
G.M. in for Long Term
 In Hong Kong, a G.M. spokesman, David Bodkin, said, "We recognize the country had to do something to cool down an overheated economy, and regrettably, we may have to live through it." He would not say how many trucks the venture had sold. "But we did not go to China only to pull out after a year or two," he said. "We view this as a long-term project. We're definitely staying."
Putting the best face on it, Mr. Bodkin pointed out that G.M. business in China was up this year, despite the Shenyang disappointment.
[In Detroit on Monday, G.M. confirmed a report in the trade press that Robert Stramy had been replaced as president of its joint venture with Jinbei. His successor is Stanford Clemens, who took over in October. G.M. said Mr. Stramy left because his job, which was to initiate the venture, had been completed.]
G.M.'s exports to China jumped from 3,600 units in 1992 to an estimated 9,000 units this year. Mr. Bodkin said G.M. still planned to redesign the S-10 truck and hoped to build 50,000 trucks a year by 1998 with Gold Cup.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
To Let a Thousand Bull Markets Bloom

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
After watching Adam Smith's two-part series on the Chinese economy, the first impulse is to invest, to get in on the ground floor of China's booming, astonishing economy.
That is not an unreasonable impulse. On Channel 13 tonight and on Nov. 18, Mr. Smith offers a vivid glimpse of China's emerging middle class, now 200 million people and climbing rapidly. Supplying them makes China a golden market, not only for American companies with products to sell but also for Americans with money to invest in the Shanghai and Hong Kong stock markets. 
 Mr. Smith calls it the "China play," and he brings on a Western investment banker in Hong Kong who says, "I foresee a 50-year bull market developing."
We have heard this sort of message, of course. The Chinese economic miracle is a favorite and important media theme; Mr. Smith breaks no new ground. But in his simple, explanatory style, he makes the Chinese marketplace understandable to Americans only casually acquainted with China.
The two half-hour programs are a quick, viewer-friendly course in Chinese economics. They reflect Mr. Smith's surprise, on his first trip to China since 1976, at the buying power and size of the consumer population. He mentions in passing that for all its vigor, China's economy could founder, given that nation's various political and civil-rights problems, and even the possibility of regional conflicts.
He notes that the 200 million middle-class consumers represent less than 20 percent of China's population, clustered mostly in urban coastal areas, while 1 billion Chinese inland still suffer from poverty and hardship. Will this mix erupt in some unforeseen way after the death of Deng Xiaoping, China's 89-year-old leader?
While other journalists raise these downside problems in detail, the message of Mr. Smith's program is that the worst-case scenarios won't happen: China will stay on the high road, regaining the glory it enjoyed through most of history as a rich and powerful nation. So get aboard, America. Or, as J. Stapleton Roy, the American Ambassador, puts it, China is a market that cannot be ignored.
Mr. Roy makes several appearances, becoming a sort of assistant narrator, reinforcing Mr. Smith's message and providing some startling statistics. The Chinese economy, he says, is growing faster than any other nation's, and at the current pace will be the wealthiest economy in the world in 30 years. For every 100 urban households, there are 101 television sets, 77 cameras, more than 55 VCR's -- and good products, not cheap merchandise.
In the rich Guangdong Province near Hong Kong, wages and incomes are rising by 20 percent a year, on average, and bank deposits by 40 percent, Mr. Roy reports. And other experts tell us that by the end of the century, China could have more billionaires than the United States, while already 80 million people in the rising middle class make $10,000 a year.
This rich marketplace has already paid dividends for American companies, Mr. Roy explains, giving Mr. Smith's documentary just the suggestion of a sales pitch for foreign investment. A visit to the A.T. &T. operation, trying to supply China's huge demand for telephones, demonstrates the payoff now and to come for one big investor. And then Mr. Smith and his camera crew move quickly to the next scenes and interviews, never bogging down as they portray, in broad strokes, China's new wealth, its modern cities and rising, Westernized middle class.
Mr. Smith's great skill is in the insights that explain in some simple, memorable way how economics works. His visit to a Beijing family -- parents and young daughter -- does this towards the end of tonight's program. The parents, two of China's new consumers, earn $141 a month, he as a property manager and she as a bookkeeper. But they spend only half this income on necessities in a nation where the state still subsidizes rents, utilities and three daily school meals for their daughter.
That leaves half the income for consumption, a neat explanation of how China can be both a great source of low-wage labor and also middle-class consumption. Can the subsidies and the good times last? No one knows, Mr. Roy says, but Mr. Smith bets that the good times will.
 
Adam Smith
Made in China

HEADLINE: The Nafta Debate That Wasn't

 BODY:
It wasn't exactly what the Founding Fathers had in mind when they spoke of reasoned political discourse, nor was it what Al Gore and Ross Perot presumably have in mind when they tout the mediating powers of the electronic town hall. Instead, Tuesday's Big Debate over Nafta was a frightful mishmash of rhetorical false starts and logical inconsistencies. It would be nice to say that the evening was redeemed by civility, but it wasn't.
From time to time, Vice President Gore and Mr. Perot returned to the question at hand: Is the North American Free Trade Agreement a good deal? Mr. Gore said it would benefit everyone by eliminating tariffs and boosting exports. Mr. Perot, tapping into widespread anxieties in the labor force, argued that jobs would flee to Mexico as companies relocated in search of cheaper labor. 
 Mr. Gore got the better of the evening. We say this not because this page supports Nafta but because he did a better job of rising above the constant schoolyard bickering and, on matters of substance, stumbled into fewer logical blind alleys.
Early on, Mr. Perot produced a picture of a man hammering together a cardboard shack and said: "Do you know what his dream is? To someday have an outhouse." But he never explained why this man would be worse off under Nafta. When Mr. Gore asked him how he'd improve the lot of the Mexican worker, Mr. Perot replied with the odd argument that the U.S. should impose a "social" tariff that would be phased out as Mexico lifted its wages to U.S. levels. Mr. Gore wasn't quick enough to ask how forcing employers to pay higher wages would help Mexican workers who suffer double-digit unemployment rates.
Mr. Gore also embarked on unproductive digressions, devoting too much time to arguing that Mr. Perot would benefit personally from Nafta's defeat. This seemed part of a White House strategy to paint Mr. Perot as something other than a disinterested citizen who wished only to protect ordinary Americans.
Even here, though, Mr. Gore seems to have scored some useful points. A USA Today/CNN/ Gallup poll reported that 47 percent of adults who saw the show believed Mr. Perot's opposition to Nafta sprang from "personal interests." Respondents also made Mr. Gore a 59-to-32 winner.
The real target of the debate, however, was not the television audience but Congress. Mr. Gore tried his best to appeal to its conscience. Nafta, he said, represented optimism and the future; Mr. Perot represented defeatism and fear. Whether this moved lawmakers -- who seem more worried about their own jobs than any that would be lost to Mexico -- will not be known until the vote on Nov. 17.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Gore Flattens Perot

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Are you going to keep interrupting, or can I finish this column?
In a classic rendition of "Mr. Nice Guy Goes for the Jugular," Vice President Al Gore poked, prodded and needled Ross Perot into revealing himself as a bossy old billionaire bully who blows his cool when confronted in a fair fight. 
 The debate on CNN, which I saw on National Public Radio, wasn't even close. Gallup scored audience reaction as almost 2-to-1 for Gore, and two members of my own focus group showed why: "The old guy was mean to him," said one; her husband said of Perot: "He wants everybody to listen to him, but he don't listen to nobody."
Was this event an elucidation of the issue of free trade versus protectionism? Of course not; the scrap taking place in the arena of Nafta has little to do with foreign economic policy. It is the old grudge fight between the politics of hope against the politics of fear (as the free traders put it) or the cultural elite against the pee-pul (as the protectionists put it).
That's why the Clinton decision to have his Vice President take on Perot was a media masterstroke. Last year, both parties abased themselves polishing the independent's apple. This year, at little political risk (a buildup of the Perot candidacy would cut primarily into any Republican challenger's votes) the President saw how to dramatize a dull issue -- by anointing one volatile villain as spokesman for Nafta's opposition.
Perot stepped eagerly into the trap of Larry King's unstructured debate. His "are you gonna keep interrupting me?" technique works well with journalists, but backfires when used against another politician, especially one who can strike a deferential pose.
The White House strategy was to provoke Perot into blowing his cool, into getting visibly mean and verbally abusive when cornered. Gore's tool in peeling off the veneer of folksiness was an accusation of hypocrisy: since Perot personally profited from his land around a free-trade zone near Mexico, why did the billionaire oppose everybody else getting the same free-trade break?
That threw him on the defensive. In truth, Perot is not in the Nafta opposition for the money he can make; he's only in it for the power he can grab. But the charge of financial hypocrisy rattles him because it undermines his appeal to populist resentment.
When Perot launched his customary attack on lobbyists, Gore landed the counterpunch related to that conflict of interest: "I served in the Congress," said Gore, "and I don't know of any single individual who lobbied the Congress more than you did . . . to get tax breaks for your companies."
"You're lying," Perot sputtered. "You're lying, now." But the fact is that he has lobbied government at all levels all his business life for contracts and special favors, with great success. Vulnerable to this counterpunch, Perot lost control and hurled the word "lying" twice at the Vice President, the cry of the stymied debater.
When Perot expressed his usual scorn at government forecasts, Gore lowered the boom: "When the war against Iraq was about to take place, you told Larry King 'this is a terrible mistake and it'll lead to the death of 40,000 American troops.' " Same with a wild Perot prediction that 100 banks would fail after Election Day. Irrelevant to Nafta? Yes -- but right on target against "the politics of negativism and fear."
Throughout the show, Perot left the impression of a man whining about the interruptions of his interruptions: "I would like to finish a sentence just once before the program's over . . . let's have an unnatural event and try not to interrupt me. . . . Are you going to listen? Work on it. . . ."
Gore's red cape enticed Perot into insulting charges and insolent digs, which Americans recognize as a symptom of blown cool. "Would you even know the truth if you saw it? I don't believe you would. . . . Give me your whole mind. . . ." The effect of this uncontrolled contempt was heightened by the matador's studied, boy-scout respectfulness.
The depressingly sincere Vice President is not the best formal debater around; I thought Dan Quayle edged him last year. But in this performance, Gore proved that a politician armed with courage and civility can beat a bully every time.
Perot's insistent message through his exercise in self-revealing self-destruction was "Let me finish." Let's hope he has.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: SPORTS PEOPLE: GOLF;
Woods to Stanford

 BODY:
TIGER WOODS, the youngest player to compete on the PGA Tour, signed a letter of intent yesterday to attend Stanford. Woods, 17, of Cypress, Calif., is the only three-time winner of the United States Junior championship. A senior at Western High School in nearby Anaheim, the teen-age sensation chose Stanford over Nevada-Las Vega and Arizona State.
"School has always come first, and that meant Stanford," Woods said at a news conference at Western. 
 Woods, who carries a 3.70 grade-point average at Western, will major in economics at Stanford with an emphasis on accounting. The university agreed to allow him to play several PGA Tour events during the spring. (AP)
