HEADLINE: U.S. TO GIVE ISRAEL INCENTIVES TO SEEK A BROADER PEACE

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
President Clinton is planning to present Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel with a package of military and economic incentives that he hopes will both reinforce the Israeli leader's political standing at home and make him and the Israeli public more willing to deal with Syria.
Among the items Mr. Clinton plans to discuss with Mr. Rabin during their talks on Friday, American and Israeli officials said, is how to help Israel meet an estimated $250 million in costs for roads and military bases required for redeploying Israeli troops from Gaza and Jericho as part of its accord with the Palestine Liberation Organization. One idea is for the Administration to consult with Congress about allowing Israel to use some of the $10 billion in American loan guarantees extended last year for absorbing Russian Jews to pay for redeployment projects in the West Bank and Gaza. 
 Officials said the White House also seeks to address Israel's desire to import more American computer and electronic technology to help it maintain its military edge over the Arab states for another generation. At the moment, some of the most sophisticated American supercomputers and electronics components are banned for export to Israel -- as well as other countries -- because they have both civilian and military applications, particularly for use in ballistic missiles.
 
Assurances on Aid
 President Clinton also plans to offer assurances that his Administration will not cut the current aid level of $3 billion a year, despite a shrinking foreign aid budget, officials said.
Moreover, they said, the Administration wants to discuss Israel's desire to purchase its next generation of American combat aircraft -- the F-15E's -- and how the United States might help Israel defray some of the costs.
There is something very new and something very old about the package. What is old is the laundry list of items that constitute the traditional currency of the United States-Israel security relationship. What is new is that the United States now has little money available to help Israel pay for them.
So, in this era of "no-money diplomacy," the Administration will try to deliver benefits largely by loosening regulations on export controls or loan guarantees, or by offering creative financing proposals, in order to get the Israelis some strategic benefits that might have come from cash or grants in the cold war era.
The politics behind this package, say American officials, is this: Since Mr. Rabin signed the peace accord in September with Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, there has been a slight erosion in support for the treaty in Israel, as shown by the recent municipal elections in which Mr. Rabin's Labor Party took a beating from the right-wing Likud in both Jerusalem and Tel Aviv.
Administration officials say they want to do all they can to bolster Mr. Rabin's standing, by showing the Israeli public that the Prime Minister can deliver on their security concerns. At the same time, they want to make the Israeli leader more comfortable with the idea of striking a deal with Syria.
 
Balancing Two Promises
 The question of Syria will hang over all the discussions on Friday between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Rabin at the White House. Mr. Clinton is trying to balance two promises: one to Mr. Rabin not to try to foist on him an Israeli withdrawal from the Golan Heights before Mr. Rabin feels he is ready and able to sell it to the Israeli public, and the other to President Hafez el-Assad of Syria not to let the Israeli-Palestinian deal stand as a separate peace.
As American officials note, the Israeli-Palestinian deal is certainly important for peace. But American strategic interests lie even more importantly with getting a Syrian-Israeli peace accord, since this would eliminate the greatest threat to a major war in the region and help to further isolate Iran, now a Syrian ally.
The Americans fear that if Mr. Assad feels put off by Israel for too long he will invest all of his energy in trying to scuttle the Israeli-Palestinian accord, and the emerging Israeli-Jordanian deal.
But Mr. Rabin has his own domestic balance to worry about, say Israeli officials. One message he will be bringing Mr. Clinton is: don't overload the political circuits in Israel by pushing a Syrian-Israeli deal before President Assad himself demonstrates some real willingness to sign a full treaty. Mr. Rabin, Israeli officials said, will stress to President Clinton his willingness to engage in either secret or public diplomacy with the Syrian President, and that if Mr. Assad were to accept such a meeting it would dramatically recast Mr. Rabin's attitude toward him.
 
Incentives for a Syrian Deal?
 Up to now, Mr. Assad has rejected such secret or public encounters with Israeli leaders. The Syrian leader is still apparently considering whether he is ready to offer Israel the sort of full peace, open trade, and tourism that it would demand in exchange for a withdrawal from the Golan Heights.
The question some Middle East experts are asking is: Will the Clinton package provide what Mr. Rabin needs now to build a solid Israeli constituency for the agreement with the Palestinians and for a future deal with Syria?
Some analysts believe that what goes to the heart of those concerns are matters that are really in the hands of the Palestinians and the Syrians, and that Washington is largely a bystander. Unless the Palestinians can control the radicals in their own community and create their own viable political and economic structures in Gaza and Jericho, American F-15's will not necessarily allay the Israeli public's concern about the peace accord.
Israeli officials said that Mr. Rabin arrived in Washington in a not particularly upbeat mood about the readiness and ability of the Palestinians to take the reins of authority in Gaza and Jericho from the Israeli military. The highly centralized P.L.O. structure under Mr. Arafat has been slow to design solutions to the practical problems of creating a quasi-government in Gaza and Jericho.
While the P.L.O. has been procrastinating, Mr. Rabin has complained, Palestinian opponents to the agreement have been acting with ruthless efficiency, killing Israelis, Arafat loyalists and optimism.

HEADLINE: Maurice Cranston; Briton, 73, Wrote On Political Theory

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Maurice Cranston, a British professor who was a leading interpreter of the political philosophers of the 17th and 18th centuries, died last Friday in London. He was 73.
He had a heart attack while recording a television program for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation about the recently published memoirs of former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. 
 He was a professor of Political Science at the London School of Economics from 1969 to 1985. His specialty was Rousseau. But he also delved into contemporary thought, as in the study of Jean-Paul Sartre he published in 1962 and a collection called "Western Political Philosophers" he edited two years later.
He wrote two books on freedom and human rights before achieving prominence in 1957 with "John Locke: a Biography." His book about Locke, the 17th-century British doctor-philosopher, won the James Tait Black Memorial Prize in Britain. It was published the same year in the United States by Macmillan.
Professor Cranston was born in London, the son of a theatrical manager, and in his younger years was a freelance writer and film critic. He received his education at the University of London and St. Catherine's College, Oxford.
He lectured at the University of London throughout the 1950's and joined the London School of Economics as a lecturer and reader of political science, becoming a full professor 10 years later.
He lectured, in French, in France and Quebec. In the United States, he was visiting professor at the University of California in 1976 and again from 1986 until last year. He had also served as a visiting professor at Harvard University, Dartmouth College and the University of British Columbia.
He was named a foreign honorary member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1970. He was also a regular contributor of literary features to the BBC.
Professor Cranston is survived by his wife of 35 years, Baroness Maximiliana von und zu Fraunberg. They had two sons, Nicholas and Stephen.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Obituary (Obit); Biography

HEADLINE: U.N. Tightens Sanctions Against Libya

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov 11

 BODY:
After weeks of haggling and delay, the Security Council finally carried out its threat to tighten sanctions on Libya today. The Council said Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi had defied its order to surrender two Libyans accused in the destruction of a Pan American airliner over Lockerbie, Scotland. The downing of the plane, in 1988, killed 270 people.
Eleven of the Council's 15 members voted for the resolution, which is to freeze Libya's overseas assets, ban some sales of oil equipment and tighten an earlier decision to end commercial air links with Libya. China and the Council's three Islamic members, Djibouti, Pakistan and Morocco, abstained. 
 The new sanctions, which are to take effect Dec. 1, will cause Libya some inconvenience, particularly by cutting off its income from investments it has made around the world. But Libya had ample notice that the restrictions were coming and has been able to hide much of its liquid overseas assets.
Moreover the new measures stop well short of the total ban on oil exports that the Council imposed on Iraq for invading Kuwait. Many families of those who died in the destruction of Pan Am Flight 103 sought a total ban. Libya gets 98 percent of its income from oil, selling mainly to Western Europe.
 
Critics of Resolution
 In addition, French, Belgian, Italian and other foreign oil companies will also be able to maintain the lucrative oil and gas exploration and drilling contracts they have with Libya.
Representatives of the families of the victims of the bombing predicted today that nothing short of a full oil embargo is likely to persuade Colonel Qaddafi to hand over the two suspects.
"This resolution is a step in the right direction but we don't believe it's going to be enough," said Rosemary Wolfe of Washington, who is the head of the Association of the Families of Pan Am 103-Lockerbie and who lost a 20-year-old stepdaughter in the bombing. "Only an oil embargo will get Colonel Qaddafi to comply."
Nevertheless, family representatives who attended the debate broke into applause when the United States representative, Madeleine K. Albright, came to talk with them after the vote.
Clinton Administration officials have made it clear that the United States will press again for a full oil embargo if the new sanctions do not force Libya to hand over the suspects. But Western European countries have resisted a total embargo because it would hurt their economic interests.
In her address today to the Council, Ms. Albright defended the resolution as "balanced and precisely targeted," adding: "To those who say it is not enough, I say this: why did Libya try so hard to stop this resolution if the sting of its new sanctions is so mild?"
But she also told Council members that Washington was willing to go further if these sanctions did not work, noting that the United States has already imposed harsher unilateral measures on Libya. She acknowledged that in formulating the new sanctions, "we have considered and respected the views of those countries whose economic interests at stake might exceed our own."
 
British View Presented
 Sir David Hannay, the British representative, said the new sanctions sent a clear message that "terrorism is not cost-free," adding that Britain favors "gradually ratcheting up" the pressure on Colonel Qaddafi. France's representative, Jean-Bernard Merimee, said Libya's attitude showed that "all it wants to do is play for time."
During an hour-long address to the Council, Libya's representative, Ali Ahmed el-Houderi, questioned its right to require the extradition of Libyans and complained of the Council's "whims, special interests and double standards." Maintaining that polls showed that 61 percent of the British do not believe the Libyans would get a fair trial in Scotland, he repeated Libya's demand that they be tried in a third country.
Speaking on behalf of the Arab League, Sudan's representative, Ahmed Suliman, said additional sanctions would prove counterproductive.
The decision to take new measures against Libya came almost six weeks after the Oct. 1 deadline that the Council had set for Colonel Qaddafi to hand over for trial the two suspects, Abdel Baset Ali Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah.
 
French Investigators
 Libya was also supposed to cooperate with French investigators in the bombing of a French airliner over Niger in 1989 that killed 171 people. And it was supposed to renounce support for international terrorism and agree to compensate victims of the two downings if its agents were found to be responsible.
But the deadline was allowed to slip, initially because Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali wanted more time to mediate. After his efforts got nowhere, Russia for a while threatened to veto new sanctions unless the Council agreed to use frozen Libyan assets to settle an arms debt of $4 billion. In the end, Moscow settled for a paragraph stressing that Libya is still expected to pay its debts.
In addition to freezing Libyan assets, today's resolution bans the sale of oil-refining and pipeline equipment and requires members to reduce the size of Libyan diplomatic missions and close all offices of Jamahiriya Libyan Arab Airlines, the flag carrier.

GRAPHIC: Photo: After the United Nations Security Council voted to tighten sanctions on Libya, Madeleine K. Albright, lower right, the chief U.S. representative, spoke in the Visitors' Gallery with friends and relatives of victims of the 1988 jetliner bombing in Lockerbie, Scotland. Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Libya's leader, has defied orders to surrender the two Libyans accused of complicity in the crash. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Disneyland of History Next to the Real Thing

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAYMARKET, Va., Nov. 11

 BODY:
To the shock and utter exuberance of many in this thoroughly rural village 35 miles from the White House, the Walt Disney Company unwrapped plans today for a new amusement park that would relive the grand sweep of American history. Only better, of course.
On 3,000 verdant acres abutting a busy Interstate highway, Disney will split the American story into nine playlands which, planners declared, will let visitors participate in the nation's creation but without getting shot, or even dirty. 
 When and if the park opens in 1998, it will occupy only about 100 acres of the site. The rest, officials said today, will be held as open space or marked for later development with hotels, shops, houses or apartments and other ventures. The company declined to say how much all this would cost, except that the total would run into the "hundreds of millions."
Virginia and Prince William County, the park's locale, will also be asked to do their part, building a new highway interchange and other improvements. In return, Disney officials estimated that the attraction would pump about $1.5 billion in taxes into state and local treasuries over the next three decades.
 
Losses at Euro Disney
 Today's announcement came as Disney disclosed that it had lost $900 million in the first full year of operation of its Euro Disney theme park outside Paris, a figure so large that the company's executives committed themselves to eating future losses for only "a limited period" while they sought refinancing of the venture.
Disney officials here shrugged that off. They said that Euro Disney was still the Continent's biggest tourist attraction and that the losses stemmed mostly from Europe's recession. The company's other theme parks, in California, Florida and Tokyo, are still enormously profitable, they said.
As for the park being planned here, there has never been anything like it in Mickey Mouse's empire or anywhere else -- unless, of course, one counts American history itself, which saturates the piney hills and rolling pastures surrounding the park site.
Tourists not fulfilled by the Manassas National Battlefield Park, the solemn site of two of the Civil War's most poignant battles, could drive five miles up the road to Disney's America for what its designers call the Civil War "experience."
And if a glimpse of Bill Clinton's morning jog whetted their appetite, they could drive 40 minutes to a Disney building crammed with talking, moving Presidents, dead and alive.
 
Making History 'Real'
 "The goal here is to make this real," said Peter Rummel, who heads the Disney Design and Development unit that designed the park.
Disney's America will feature arecreated Indian village with a Lewis and Clark whitewater ride, and a Crossroads USA town, a recreation of a bustling town of the mid-1800's that sells 1990's souvenirs. It will sport a Civil War scene with realistic floating ironclads, a replica fort, and veritable slaves and soldiers. It will include the factory town Enterprise, in which roller-coaster riders will careen under smoky vats of ersatz molten steel, just as in the era of the steel barons.
It will boast cheek-pinching real "audioanimatronic" Presidents -- computer-driven mannequins that will spout historic speeches and debate one another. And it will have a genuine-looking Army airfield where computer animation will let 10-year-olds fly World War II bomb runs and parachute behind enemy lines.
Some preservationists and lifelong residents are expected to oppose Disney's America, with the traffic, fast-food restaurants and geegaw shops sure to follow if the park is established. But Prince William County is in the economic horse latitudes after two go-go decades, and the park's 3,000 jobs seemed as thrilling to local residents as the prospect of something new to do.
 
Good Things Predicted
 "I think it'll do the area a world of good," said John Evans, who moved to America 18 years ago as a British diplomat and now runs an antique shop here with his wife. "It's not a rich town. There are a lot of people out of jobs."
Sarah M. Turner, the head of the Haymarket Historical Commission and chief chronicler of events in this town of 500 people, said that as far as she was concerned Disney could not come soon enough.
"I think it will be fine," she said. "I think almost anything out here would be an improvement, because it's so dull."
Manassas National Battlefield, where 4,200 Union and Confederate soldiers died in July 1861 and August 1862 -- both Confederate victories -- is a local shrine. But "there's not much exciting there for a child," Mrs. Turner said.
True again. Over at the national park, there is a brief movie and booklets about the Civil War, and there is a walking tour. But there is no Circle Vision 360, which Disney's designers said would transport visitors into simulated combat.
 
Battlefield Visitors
 About 130,000 people a year visit the battlefield. Disney is reported to anticipate that many tourists in about four days of business.
In fact, Faith Swettle, of nearby Warrenton, had planned to take her four children to today's Disney announcement until, as often happens with children, they all got out late. So she took them to the Manassas battlefield, with its somber hills and statues and authentic stone houses, instead.
"You come here, it's quiet, very moving," she said. "You can almost feel what they went through."
But as she read the Disney brochure, she concluded that the park would be a great addition. "Good for the economy," she said. "I think it'll be neat."
The visitor's log at the Manassas battlefield, where tourists leave parting comments, echoed that.
"Cool place. Neat."
"Good show."
"Sell T-shirts."
"Very moving."
Wrote Keli Wright, of Oakton, Va., "Get a snack bar, or at least a vending machine."
Replied Warren W. Walls, of St. Louis, "Leave it as it is."

HEADLINE: U.S. and China Try to End Bar to High-Tech Trade

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
The United States and China are negotiating to eliminate American trade sanctions on high-technology exports to China, senior Administration officials said today.
But the Administration has so far failed to persuade China to formally agree to an international accord controlling the export of missile technology. And President Clinton's senior national security advisers agreed at a White House meeting on Wednesday to keep the sanctions in place unless China agrees.
 
Talks Next Week
 The Administration had hoped to strike a deal with China on lifting the sanctions before Mr. Clinton meets China's President, Jiang Zemin, in Seattle on Nov. 19, the first top-level meeting since before the June 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre in Beijing. Unless Mr. Clinton overrules his advisers, he will not be able to announce the end of sanctions. 
 "Our conditions for waiving the sanctions haven't changed," a senior Administration official said. "We have been urging the Chinese to talk about those conditions, but so far they've refused."
The Administration imposed sanctions on an estimated $1 billion in high-technology trade with China in August, as required under law, after intelligence agencies reported that China had shipped technology and components for M-11 missiles to Pakistan in violation of the Missile Technology Control Regime. The sanctions affect the planned launches of seven commercial satellites on Chinese rockets.
But as part of the Administration's larger strategy to win over China rather than isolate it, the White House is looking for a legal way to ease the sanctions.
In an effort to persuade the Chinese to begin talks on the sanctions, and in a major concession to United States business, the White House is pressing for a broad legal interpretation of the law requiring sanctions so some sales can proceed. The goal is to have Mr. Clinton accept the broad interpretation so that he can approve the export of one or two of the satellites by the time he goes to Seattle, senior Administration officials said.
White House lawyers argue that satellites that do not include components on the State Department's munitions list are not covered by the sanctions law and should be allowed for export.
"The National Security Council genuinely believes that the legal arguments are not clear cut and that there is some discretion on how to apply the law," an Administration expert said. "It's in part a matter of good business and in part that Seattle is coming up."
But it is far from certain whether satellites manufactured by Hughes Aircraft and Martin Marietta, the companies whose exports are pending, will be allowed to ship them.
Mr. Clinton intends to use next week's meetings with East Asian heads of state to point to his foreign policy successes, particularly efforts to increase trade with Asia. In his meeting with Mr. Jiang, the President will cite a series of high-level exchanges in the last several weeks between the United States and China, officials said.
 
Contact With Chinese Army
 As a result of one such visit, the Administation recently announced the resumption of long-suspended contacts between the Pentagon and the Chinese Army. The next high-level visit will be a trip to Beijing this winter by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen.
Senior Administration officials added that Mr. Clinton would bring a negative message to Seattle as well: that China must make urgent progress on human rights, trade and non-proliferation of nuclear arms.
Senior officials said he would not be able to escape the conclusion voiced by Secretary of State Warren Christopher and other senior officials: that the relationship with Beijing has deteriorated in recent months and that unless there is significant improvement, particularly in China's human rights record, Washington will be unable to renew trade benefits for China when they come up for review in June.
These benefits, which allow China to export goods to the United States under the same low tariffs that apply to most other countries, form the foundation of the two nations' economic links.
There is other worrisome behavior as well. China experts in the Administration have concluded that China's underground nuclear test in early October was not a gesture of defiance aimed at the United States but an important military decision to improve strategic nuclear forces.
And Administration officials are convinced that American intelligence reports indicating that China intended to ship ingredients for chemical weapons to Iran were accurate, despite the fact that an inspection of a merchant ship turned up no evidence.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
BellSouth will invest $1.5 billion in QVC's bid for Paramount Communications. But the F.T.C. told QVC to cut its ties with Liberty Media, its largest shareholder, if it wants antitrust clearance to buy Paramount. [Page D1.] MCA's president expressed irritation that Matsushita, MCA's parent, had talked with John Malone of Tele-Communications about acquiring 50 percent of MCA. [D5.]
Pacific Telesis announced a $16 billion plan to build a high-speed video and data superhighway in California by itself, failing to team up with a big cable television operator or programmer. [D1.] 
 United Airlines' unions submitted a proposal to gain majority control of the carrier and are said to have chosen Gerald Greenwald, Chrysler's former vice chairman, to run the airline. [D1.]
Disney announced plans for a new amusement park based on American historical themes for a site in rural Virgina. [A14.]

The Economy
A casino in downtown Detroit that backers say will revive a city that once boomed with the auto trade attracted thousands of job applicants. But it has little chance of being approved. [A1.]
A proposal to stop political contributions from bond dealers to state and local officials was modified. [D6.]
Large commercial trucks would be prohibited from carrying radar detectors under a Federal recommendation. [A18.]
 
Markets
Stocks slipped in quite trading because of the Veterans Day holiday. [D6.] The credit market was subdued. [D14.]

HEADLINE: Even Brazil Is Shocked: State Is One Family's Fief

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MACEIO, Brazil

 BODY:
With her gold earrings glinting and high heels sinking in the mud, Denilma Bulhoes roams her domain, bringing what she calls a message of hope to the peasants and shantytown dwellers in Brazil's impoverished northeast corner.
Underscoring the mixed message, her husband, Geraldo, the Governor of Alagoas State, appears before photographers in dark glasses and releases a white dove. 
 With a few superficially modern touches, the Bulhoes family offers a portrait of a Latin American institution that is certain to endure into the 21st century: the provincial oligarchy.
From Mexico to Argentina, powerful political clans still hold sway in much of rural Latin America. In Brazil they flourish particularly in the most disadvantaged states, in the Amazon and the Northeast, where wealthy families feud among themselves for control of city hall or the state governor's palace.
 
Cholera and Leprosy
 In Alagoas, where the Bulhoes family has presided over the state machinery since 1991, the people suffer from the highest infant mortality rate in the region, its lowest child vaccination rate, its lowest rate of prenatal care and one of its lowest rates of schooling -- 1.8 years per adult.
In this seaside capital of 600,000, slum dwellers are plagued by cholera and leprosy; by contrast, the local elite looks forward to the day in January when cellular telephone service will be inaugurated.
The state Governor's wife chartered an executive jet three times this year to fly to Sao Paulo and back, with the state treasury picking up the $24,000 bill for each trip. At the same time, the state's public schools were closed for seven months because teachers were protesting salaries of $80 a month. Taking a hard line with the teachers was the state Secretary of Education, Isnaldo Bulhoes, a brother of the Governor.
Partial to French suits and Italian shoes, Mrs. Bulhoes shops for clothes in Miami, Paris and New York. Swinging through Alagoas, she says, "Poor people have just the same right to see me pretty as people in society."
An untiring campaigner who hopscotches across the region in her helicopter and claims to be more popular than her husband, Mrs. Bulhoes plans to run in 1995 for the Mayor's seat here in Maceio.
 
High Ratings in the Polls
 "In this panorama of absolute poverty, where people are dying of hunger, if you arrive out of the blue with some food, people think you are God," said Pedro Collor, a local newspaper owner, trying to explain the political couple's consistently high ratings in polls conducted in the state of 2.5 million.
A central tenet of a Latin American political oligarchy is a blurring of lines between public and private.
In Brazil's northeastern states, political families pass power from father to son: the Magalhaes in Bahia, the Maias in Rio Grande do Norte, the Arcoverdes in Piaui, and the Tavoras, the Bezerras and the Cals in Ceara.
In Alagoas, the blurring of public and private developed into a virtual art form with the inauguration in 1991 of Geraldo Bulhoes, a three-term Congressman who had risen from rural roots.
At the Governor's palace, Enaldo Bulhoes, a brother of the Governor and a staff member, helps route state cars to a garage partly owned by one of the Governor's sons, Geraldo Henrique, for servicing. The state's printing needs are met by a shop owned by another son, Gustavo, and state travel arrangements are handled by an agency owned by the Governor's daughter, Ana.
 
No Fear of Inquiries
 But the family has no fear of inquiries by the state Attorney General; the post is occupied by Heraldo Bulhoes, another brother of the Governor.
"Corruption has become institutionalized in Alagoas," said Luiz Barbosa Carnauba, an independent state prosecutor who is conducting criminal investigations of the extended family. Mr. Carnauba says he has received death threats.
The Governor's eldest son, Geraldo Henrique, is under investigation on charges that he takes kickbacks for reducing tax obligations and in awarding contracts for road repair and school contruction.
After winning election in 1990, Mr. Bulhoes built the state-controlled military police into a major political base. In two years, the police payroll doubled, from 8,000 to 16,000, including a newly formed "Denilma Bulhoes Battalion" of women who served as officers.
 
Police Notorious for Violence
 Statistics show that crime actually increased, partly as a result of a free rein given to police officers. The Bulhoes rehired about 120 policemen who had been dismissed for corruption or for excessive violence. Whenever police brutality cases came to trial, military police units surrounded the courthouse, forcing witnesses to walk through a corridor of armed and hostile men.
Police violence became so notorious here that a Brazilian congressional investigation concluded in June that the military police were involved in 80 percent of the 600 murders committed in Alagoas during the first two years of the Bulhoes government.
Sometimes violence erupts within the Bulhoes clan itself.
Last June, when Geraldo Henrique asked his younger brother Gustavo to account for the print shop's expenses, Gustavo stormed out of the palace here and sprayed his brother's car with automatic rifle fire before guards disarmed him. Geraldo Henrique met his brother in the parking lot, pulled out a pistol, and aimed it at his brother's head. Then he lowered the pistol and shot his brother in the left foot.
 
President Intervenes
 Last spring there was a national outcry when dissident police officers charged that the police commander, a protege of the family, was skimming $400,000 a month in illegal deductions from the police payroll. One of the dissident officers, a police colonel, was detained in May in a police hospital, where police doctors were reported to have injected him with tranquilizers.
The scandal grew so great that Brazil's President, Itamar Franco, intervened in July by appointing an army colonel as the police commander for Alagoas.
But in a state where 27 families own 60 percent of the fertile land, the Bulhoes still seem to enjoy a kind of impunity.
Blood feuds are common among the handful of political clans that jockey for power in each of Brazil's 10 northeastern states.
On Nov. 5 in Paraiba, the state Governor recently walked into a restaurant and shot his predecessor twice, leaving him critically wounded.
After spending a few hours in jail, the Governor was released on the ground that he did not have a criminal record. Angry over corruption accusations made by his predecessor, the Governor announced that he would argue in court that he was defending his honor.
Here in Alagoas, the string of abuses began in February, when the youngest of the couple's four children, Guilherme, shot his girlfriend in the hand in a motel. In May, Gustavo Bulhoes urinated in front of a beachfront tourist bar, taunting the police to try to arrest a son of the Governor. Two policemen detained him, and they were later dismissed from the force.
Then in August, Gustavo ran over an 17-year-old girl waiting at a bus stop here. After pausing to pull the critically injured girl off his car hood, he raced off without bothering to call an ambulance on his police radio. But in his haste to escape the accident scene, he plowed into three other cars.
The Bulhoes family managed to keep Gustavo's name out police reports, but not out of the newspapers.
The Governor declined to be interviewed here. Mrs. Bulhoes was out of town, on a two-week shopping trip in New York.
 
A 'Shocking Picture'
 Even in Brazil, where excesses of the wealthy are often excused, the Bulhoes oligarchy is seen as an embarrassment, especially in the country's developed south. It is not lost on the public that Mr. Bulhoes's predecessor as Governor was Fernando Collor de Mello, an Alagoas native who resigned last year as Brazil's President after lawmakers impeached him on charges of benefiting from a multimillion-dollar influence-peddling ring.
"This is the shocking picture of the type of regional oligarchy that unfortunately has not yet disappeared from our political scene," a recent editorial in the Rio newspaper Globo said of the Bulhoes family.
In another Rio newspaper, Jornal do Brasil, a journalist named Rosemarie Muraro wrote scathingly of Mrs. Bulhoes, "Evita Peron was only possible when Argentina was a big Alagoas."

HEADLINE: Mindful of Trade Fight, Clinton Warns of Isolationism

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
President Clinton used the 75th anniversary today of the armistice ending World War I to warn against a return to the economic isolationism that he said once again poses a threat to American security.
Mr. Clinton referred only obliquely to the North American Free Trade Agreement in his Veterans Day remarks. But his words added gravity to an Administration attempt to elevate its fight for passage of the accord to one seen as representing a momentous choice in the nation's history. 
 "Once again, history is about to take the measure of our wisdom," Mr. Clinton declared in an address to hundreds of veterans in an amphitheater adjoining the Tomb of the Unknowns at Arlington National Cemetery. He said Americans would choose "whether we will swell the global tide of freedom by promoting democracy and open world markets or neglect the duty of our leadership, and in the process and in the withdrawal diminish hope and prosperity not only for our own people, but for billions of others throughout the world."
Mr. Clinton, who was born 28 years after the First World War ended, offered the predominantly older veterans a history-book style reprisal of an American descent after 1918 into isolation, protectionism and more war. As Vice President Al Gore did on Tuesday night in his televised debate with Ross Perot, he held up the high tariffs of the 1930's as the dangerous alternative to the controversial slashing of tariffs with Mexico and Canada that he has proposed.
 
'Siren Song of Protectionism'
 "We neglected during a careless peace what had been so dearly won in a relentless war," the President said. "We turned our backs on the rest of the world. We ignored new signs of danger. We let our troops and arms fall out of readiness. We neglected opportunities for collective security in our own national interests. We succumbed to the siren song of protectionism and erected walls against peaceful commerce with other nations. Soon, we had a Great Depression and soon that depression led to aggression and then to another world war, one that would claim a half-million American lives."
He added, "Let us today resolve we will not shrink from the responsibilities necessary to keep our nation secure and our people prosperous."
Mr. Clinton's appearance was not marked by the kind of hostility he has sometimes encountered from military groups disdainful of his decision to evade military service during the Vietnam War. But on his first Veterans Day since taking office, Mr. Clinton went out of his way to praise Army Rangers for their valor in the Oct. 3 battle in Somalia. They suffered heavy casualties in the incident, which forced a reappraisal of American policy there.
By inviting 17 of the Rangers and Delta Force soldiers involved in that firefight to visit him in the Oval Office and join him at the ceremony, aides said, Mr. Clinton hoped to send a message that their conduct had been heroic and not the fiasco that some published accounts have described.
 
Mending Military's Image
 In a larger sense, the gesture served as a first step by the President to repair the damage to the military's image from the Somalia mission, which has contributed to the isolationist impulses he was warning against.
"We owe it to them and to their colleagues to insure that our forces remain the best trained, the best equipped, the best prepared in the world," Mr. Clinton said. He said the aftermath to victory in the cold war was testing once again "whether we will preserve freedom's gains and learn freedom's lessons."
The President arrived hatless and coatless at the cemetery on a bright but chilly autumn day, and he moved with a touch of awkwardness as he laid a wreath at the unknown soldiers' tomb and was honored with a 21-gun salute. Military leaders and veterans of battlefields from France to Mogadishu greeted him with polite applause.
In a week in which the House of Representatives only grudgingly approved his request to keep American troops in Somalia until March 31, Mr. Clinton seemed determined to drive home his message that the United States must remain engaged with the rest of the world. He began the day by congratulating the American Legion for its support of the trade agreement, and he met privately with the Rangers so that he could recount "the real story" of their ordeal.
Although 18 Americans died and more than 70 were wounded in that fight, Mr. Clinton noted that most of the casualties were suffered because the elite unit chose to stay behind to protect the body of a fallen comrade. He said the Rangers exacted a "terrible toll" on their adversaries. "I want you to let them know that they did their mission well and that we are proud of them," he said.
Later in the day, the President traveled to Martinsburg, W.Va., where he toured a Veterans Administration hospital, awarded medals to four World War I veterans and made a brief pitch for the universal health coverage program that he has proposed.
"I'm very proud of the fact that the health care reform plan proposed by our Administration is the only one that embraces the V.A. as a real resource for high quality, affordable health care for our people," he said.

HEADLINE: Dr. Nicholas A. Rango, 49, Dies; Built New York's AIDS Program

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Dr. Nicholas A. Rango, who built New York State's AIDS Institute into the nation's largest state AIDS program while struggling with the illness himself, died on Wednesday at home. He was 49 and lived in Manhattan.
The cause was AIDS, the State Health Department said. 
 Dr. Rango publicly acknowledged his illness and his homosexuality. He ran the agency from his sickbed during medical relapses. In June he said, "When you're aware the clock is ticking, it focuses your attention."
Through his work in New York, he exerted national influence on AIDS issues. He also organized his counterparts from other states into a coalition to lobby for Federal money and policy changes.
 
Recruited in 1987
 Dr. Rango was recruited to his post as director of the AIDS Institute in 1987 as the epidemic worsened in New York, which has the most AIDS cases in the country. His mission was to plan treatment and prevention and to get services delivered.
During his tenure, the AIDS Institute quadrupled its budget to $120 million and expanded into a wide array of programs.
Dr. Rango broadened services to people other than gay men who were increasingly afflicted by AIDS, including heterosexuals, women and babies. New programs were begun for teen-agers, minorities, prisoners and addicts.
Advocates for AIDS programs, even while complaining about the state's shortcomings, considered him a friend behind the scenes. Once, when the group Act Up disrupted a State Public Health Council meeting by blowing deafening horns, Dr. Rango confided to a bystander that he was glad the protesters kept the pressure on.
"We are moving too slow," he said in 1989, repeating a frequent theme. "We have done a lot, but we have not done enough." Sometimes acerbic, he said at a 1990 seminar on lobbying: "On the issue of AIDS, the New York Congressional delegation is somewhere between stage three and four of a coma."
 
The First Long-Range Plan
 Dr. Rango assembled the state's first long-range plan on AIDS. It called for action by 18 agencies, including those dealing with human rights, the courts, schools, mental health, youths, parolees, addicts and welfare recipients.
He initiated AIDS medical care standards, a wider definition of AIDS entitling more patients to receive care, special nursing homes and residences, higher reimbursements to encourage doctors and clinics to treat AIDS patients, housing aid, prison health programs, home care, tuberculosis programs, care for the uninsured, research to prevent accidental exposures like needle sticks and special training for doctors and nurses.
Dr. Rango advocated giving clean needles to drug users to curb infection, a measure resisted by many state and local officials. He also expanded preventive education, voluntary testing, confidentiality protection, subsidized medications for 7,300 patients and a network of AIDS treatment centers in 23 hospitals across the state.
Nationally, he led the opposition to mandatory testing of health care workers and to the barring of infected people from doing invasive medical procedures.
In New York he worked with State Health Commissioners David Axelrod and Mark Chassin and with the State AIDS Advisory Council and its chairman, David Rogers. With Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, they forged the administration's AIDS programs and sought support from the Legislature.
Getting money for the agency was a constant struggle, and Dr. Rango was quick to defend its semi-independent status within the Health Department.
He did not win every battle. He failed in an attempt to require Roman Catholic-run AIDS nursing homes to give preventive education on safe sex and the use of condoms. When the recession hit, AIDS funds and staffing did not rise so quickly as the epidemic, which by June 30 reached 61,082 cases with 42,567 deaths.
Trained in gerontology and sociology, Dr. Rango was the director of the Village Nursing Home in Manhattan before joining the AIDS agency. In AIDS work he faced many of the same terminal-care issues but in much younger patients, he said.
 
An Ohio Native
 Dr. Rango was born in Youngstown, Ohio. He graduated from St. Louis University in Missouri and earned his medical degree at Northwestern University. At Cook County Hospital in Chicago, he was president of the Residents and Interns Association, a union with more than 500 members.
He earned a doctorate in sociology at Columbia and for nine years taught health at Barnard College, where he developed a health policy and medical ethics program for premedical students.
Dr. Rango won awards for his work, published research in medical journals and assisted on the federally sponsored National Hospice Study and the Hasting Center's project on Termination of Treatment and Care of the Dying.
His survivors include his mother, Doris, of Manhattan; a brother, Arthur, of Manhattan, and a sister, Ann Ursula Watkins of Warren, Ohio.
A Mass will be held at 12:45 P.M. on Wednesday at the Church of St. Francis Xavier at 30 West 16th Street in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: The High Price of Protectionism

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Ross Perot and other critics of the North American Free Trade Agreement have hammered away at how many American jobs will be lost if the United States lets down barriers to Mexican imports.
What has gotten much less attention is the cost of keeping those barriers: how much Americans pay in higher prices when tariffs and other barriers are used to protect jobs, and how effective such protection is in shielding workers from job losses. 
 Almost all economists agree that the price of protecting jobs with trade barriers is high. First, there is the cost of the tariffs, themselves, which amount to billions of dollars a year. Then there are other less visible costs as well, including greater inefficiency and bigger profits for foreign and domestic producers, which are harder to measure, but also very large.
 Economists have pondered the price of protection since Adam Smith's 1776 treatise, "The Wealth of Nations," which detailed the costs of mercantilism. And economists of nearly every political stripe since then, from conservatives like Milton Friedman to liberals like Paul Samuelson, have dismissed protection as a job-saving strategy.
Dozens of studies in recent years have estimated the costs, reaching remarkably similar conclusions. One such study that is receiving attention now, in the middle of the debate over the North American pact, is work by Gary Hufbauer and Kim Elliott, two pro-Nafta trade experts at the Institute for International Economics.
They estimate that Americans effectively spend about $32 billion more each year on purchases of goods and services than they would if there were no barriers to goods entering this country. Their figures, drawn from surveys of 21 industries with sales of $1 billion or more that the United States protects most heavily, suggests that the price of protection amounts to $170,000 a year per job saved. The authors note that that is many times the pay in the jobs being protected -- as well as many times what it would cost to send a worker back to school to learn a new trade.
 The estimates by the two economists are not hard and fast numbers, and depend on assumptions about how consumers and companies would react to changes in import prices if existing tariffs were abolished overnight.
Some advocates of protection for key industries argue that the calculations include only the costs, but not the benefits, of protection. Jeff Faux, president of the Economic Policy Institute, a union-backed research organization, is one who calls the Hufbauer-Elliott figures "way overblown."
A non-economist who has provided some of the intellectual fodder for Nafta foes, Mr. Faux argues the researchers ignored the savings from avoiding worker dislocation, the added investment that protected companies may undertake and the likelihood that producers, not consumers, would capture gains from lower tariffs.
But many trade experts consider the calculations conservative. And economists who have seen the work say they find the methodology reasonable.
"Most economists would agree with the estimates, both with the techniques and the actual numbers," said Dominick Salvatore, an international economist at Fordham University and editor of "Protectionism and World Welfare" who supports freer trade with Mexico and other nations.
Furthermore, Mr. Hufbauer says that trimming the estimates would not puncture the point that protection is a very costly strategy for retaining low-wage manufacturing jobs.
"We not going to defend these numbers to the last digit," Mr. Hufbauer said. "But even if we're off by a factor of 10, the policy is bonkers.
"If protection were a boon to low-skilled workers, how is it that we have extremely bad working conditions and low pay in sugar plantations in Florida and Louisiana? Basically, if protection helps anybody, it's the owners. It doesn't trickle down."
 
 
Smoot-Hawley Days
 Only about 5 percent of United States manufacturing -- about 1 in 10 factory workers -- gets significant protection from imports, and many of the protective tariffs date back to the Smoot-Hawley days of 1930. Smoot-Hawley tariffs still exist on products ranging from luggage to shoes, and range from 6.5 percent to 21 percent. The North American trade pact, if adopted, would squeeze most tariffs on Mexican imports to zero by 2000.
What is equally surprising is that although these 21 protected industries employ nearly two million workers, the two trade experts calculate that tariffs and quotas effectively shield only about 200,000 workers. That would amount to $160,000 per job being saved, several times as much as the average worker in those industries takes home in pay.
The luggage-making industry shows how much tariffs can cost consumers. It is a small industry, with relatively high tariffs, but one in which relatively few jobs are thought to have been saved. An industry that turns out about $1 billion in luggage annually and employs about 7,500 workers -- the number has been shrinking by about 2 percent a year -- it has been helped by tariffs that raise the price of virtually every piece of luggage imported from other countries. Consumers who buy a suitcase made in China or the Dominican Republic, for example, pay a 16.5 percent duty on it, or a total of $169 million a year.
 
 
Damping Competition
 But the two economists say that while those costs are sizable, they do not fully capture the price Americans pay for such protection. By making imports less competitive with American-made suitcases, tariffs let domestic manufacturers charge more than they might otherwise because they do not need to compete with the very low prices on imports. And by damping competition even a little, tariffs remove an incentive for the domestic industry to be as efficient as it could be.
Mr. Hufbauer and Ms. Elliott conclude that when these factors are added up, American consumers pay $211 million more every year for luggage than they would otherwise have to, to save about 200 jobs. The effective cost per domestic job saved, the two economists calculate, amounts to almost $1 million a year.
Nor is the luggage industry an isolated example. The two economists conducted similar calculations for other large, heavily protected industries -- from clothing to ceramic tiles to sugar -- and concluded that protection for these industries carried similar heavy costs.
Despite the high cost, the protection is not very effective in saving jobs. According to Mr. Hufbauer and Ms. Elliott, employment in most protected industries is shrinking anyway, just as it is in many other manufacturing industries that are eliminating lower-skilled jobs to become more efficient.
 
 
Losing a Job to Another Region
 What is more, the workers who are supposed to be shielded from dislocation often do not avoid it. High apparel and textile barriers never kept New England textile mills and garment factories from shutting down, and for a worker, or a region, losing a job to Florida can be just as devastating as losing it to the Far East.
Take the experience of Frank de Sousa, a 25-year employee of an American Tourister plant in Warren, R.I., who clocked in for the last time several weeks ago. After years of downsizing, consolidations and pay concessions, during which three plants were closed, American Tourister this year moved its last operations to Jacksonville, Fla., leaving behind 350 Rhode Island workers, many of them Portuguese immigrants who speak little English and have few job options.
"I worked in the plant for almost 25 years," Mr. de Sousa said. "Nobody got a pension. I'll pick up part-time jobs sometime, wait until summertime, cut some grass or something like that."
Luggage is the most extreme case the researchers studied, and economically, not the most important. But, according to Mr. Hufbauer's and Ms. Elliott's estimates, the hidden tax on consumers for each job saved by high tariffs -- or in some cases quotas -- on 21 products ranging from suitcases to sugar to sweaters, exceeds $150,000 per job.
 
 
Worker Retraining Programs
 Even after taking into account that the Government makes money by collecting the tariffs and American companies earn extra profits, the net cost to the nation is still $54,000 per job -- several times what workers in the protected industries earn.
That kind of arithmetic makes may many economic experts, including Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, suggest that substituting worker retraining programs -- at a cost of no more than $15,000 a year per worker -- for tariffs would be a real bargain for the country.
Still, there is no rush in this direction. "First of all, in an age of economic anxiety, a good job in danger of being lost is more potent than a better job not yet visible," Secretary Reich said, calling it "a bird in the hand phenomenon."

HEADLINE: Cautious Optimism as Fall Art Auctions End

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL

 BODY:
As the two most important weeks of the fall art auctions in New York ended on Wednesday night, it wasn't high prices but a new infusion of energy that stunned the art world. Not since the heady years of the 1980's had there been so much enthusiasm and so many determined bidders. But these buyers weren't going crazy and paying ridiculously high prices. Indeed, the last two weeks have been less about conspicuous consumption and more about a sense of renewed confidence.
"It's fashionable to buy art again," said Diana D. Brooks, who heads Sotheby's auctions worldwide. "We've turned an important corner this fall. After a difficult few years when people were scared away, they now feel good about buying art again." She cited lower interest rates and strength on Wall Street as having helped make the difference. 
 Christopher Burge, the president of Christie's in New York, said: "There's new money out there, and it's pretty visible. New buyers were from all the major industries. Everyone from entertainers to financial advisers is coming into the market."
 
Back to Middle Ground
 Both Sotheby's and Christie's worked hard this season to keep estimates low, helping to fuel sales. Savvy collectors recognized that this season's sales offered an opportunity to buy at realistic prices. The lure of a bargain, after all, is irresistible.
Unlike last season, when "quality sells" was the tired mantra of the auction experts, this fall art of all levels and quality sold, including less expensive works the experts call the middle market, which often went unsold last season.
Still, the dollar totals from the last two weeks of sales were not impressive. Christie's sales of Impressionist and modern art brought in $64.1 million and Sotheby's brought $93.4 million, including the Stanley J. Seeger collection of Picassos. Contemporary art, as always, fetched far less. Christie's contemporary-art sales totaled $22.6 million; Sotheby's totaled $21.7 million. (Final prices reflect the buyer's commission, which was 10 percent before 1993 and is now 15 percent on the first $50,000 and 10 percent on the rest. The estimates do not include commissions.)
 
Picasso's Night
 The auction that was by far the biggest risk and in the end turned out to be the biggest success was Sotheby's sale of 88 Picassos from the Seeger collection on Nov. 4. The works spanned the artist's entire career, from 1899 to 1972, and every medium.
Every work sold, with many bringing double their estimates. While there were no blockbusters, there were paintings that carried estimates of several million dollars and a host of drawings offered for as little as $8,000 each.
Mr. Seeger, a reclusive American who lives in Switzerland, began buying Picasso's work in 1980, acquiring almost all of his collection at auctions in London and New York. The sale became a telling barometer of the art market's last 13 years. Works for which Mr. Seeger paid high prices in the 1980's were offered with significantly lower estimates, while those he bought longer ago carried price tags that reflected their significant inflation.
The star work, "Women and Children at the Seashore" (1932), was sold to an unidentified American collector for $4.4 million, well above Sotheby's estimate of $2.5 million to $3.5 million. Mr. Seeger had bought the painting at a sale at Christie's in New York in 1983 for $990,000. Another important painting, "Glass, Bouquet, Guitar, Bottle" (1919) sold for $2.3 million, just under Sotheby's estimate of $2.5 million to $3.5 million.
But Mr. Seeger didn't always sell at a profit. "Setting Sun," a painting from 1956, sold for only $398,500, below Sotheby's $500,000 to $700,000 estimate. Mr. Seeger bought it at Christie's in London in 1989 for $1.8 million.
Drawings, which have recently become particularly popular, often soared way beyond expectations. "Portrait of Angel Fernandez de Soto" (1899-90) brought a surprising $530,500, more than five times its estimate of $80,000 to $100,000. Mr. Seeger had bought it at Christie's in London in 1988 for $154,500. After the sale, David Nash, the director of Sotheby's department of Impressionist and modern art, noted that many bidders were people he never thought would be interested in Picasso.
 
Hits and a Big Miss
 New buyers were active at the sales of Impressionist and modern art, too. Both sales had similar results, with some works bringing prices that far exceeded their estimates. At Sotheby's, the star work was a Matisse cutout, "The Wine Press" (1951), which sold for $13.7 million, nicely above Sotheby's estimate of $10 million. But Christie's top painting, Renoir's "Motherhood or a Woman Nursing Her Son" (1886), failed to sell. It was expected to bring $8 million, but bidding never rose above $4.8 million. No one seemed surprised, however, since the work had been at auction fairly recently; it had previously sold for $8 million at Sotheby's in New York in 1988. But just as the Renoir fell flat, Degas's "Dancers Taking a Bow (The Ballerinas)," from 1885, sold for $7 million. The pastel, which showed dancers taking a curtain call, doubled its low estimate of $3.5 million.
Many works at the contemporary sales also fetched far more than their estimates, but people who attended all the sales of the last two weeks couldn't help noticing the difference between the two areas. "Two different things happened in the two different markets," Mr. Burge said. "In the Impressionist and modern field, the turnaround came 18 months ago, and what we saw last week was a continued steadying." The contemporary-art market, on the other hand, has been far weaker for the last three years, and this week it made a big leap forward.
Buyers of contemporary art follow trends more closely and trade more furiously. This has traditionally been a more volatile segment of the market. Contemporary art had the greatest inflation in the boom years, the most dramatic crash three years ago and the slowest recovery. This fall, while the offerings at both houses were slim, the results were significant. At each auction, about 80 percent of the contemporary works offered were sold. Christie's sale totaled $15.9 million, just above the low estimate of $15.3 million, and Sotheby's totaled nearly $14 million, right in the middle of Sotheby's estimate of $11.3 million to $15.5 million.
 
Seven Records in One Night
 Sotheby's sale was livelier and set records for seven artists. While only one painting at Sotheby's was expected to sell for more than $1 million, in the end four works brought seven figures. The star work in the sale was Alexander Calder's 14-foot, 6-inch standing mobile "Constellation" (1960). Sotheby's estimated it would bring $500,000 to $700,000, but it sold to an unidentified collector bidding by phone for $1.8 million.
At both Sotheby's and Christie's many works were up for sale that had been at auction not long ago. But this season, prices were dramatically lower and the results were astonishing. An untitled Cy Twombly painting from 1969, which failed to sell two years ago at Sotheby's (the highest bid was $75,000), sold for $162,000 on Wednesday night, well above its $55,000 to $65,000 estimate. "The person who bought it and the underbidder were both at the sale in 1991," said Lucy Mitchell-Innes, director of Sotheby's department of contemporary art. "It shows a new level of confidence."
Despite all the good news, both auction houses worry that the market is still shaky. "We have to continue to be careful about keeping estimates down," Mrs. Brooks said. "If we aren't, this recovery could easily come to a dead halt."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Female Genital Torture

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
On Oct. 7, H.R. 3247 was introduced, almost unnoticed, in the House of Representatives. It is the first Congressional bill to deal with the most widespread existing violation of human rights in the world.
The bill forbids operations to mutilate female genitalia, a torture committed against millions of women abroad. Some have already taken place in the U.S. 
 With expanding emigration from the 30-odd countries, mostly African, where these ritual mutilations are practiced, the likelihood grows of more occurring in the U.S. Unlike many European countries, the U.S. has no laws prohibiting them.
The bill was introduced by Patricia Schroeder of Colorado and Barbara Rose Collins of Michigan. A few days later, Representative Schroeder mentioned female genital mutilation to a colleague. He did not know what she was talking about.
That conversation, it seems to me, is the issue.
The bill is needed. But it cannot prevent the millions of mutilations committed every year against small girls, leaving them in lifelong pain and sexual deprivation, and making them more vulnerable to disease, infection and early death.
Only two things can do that. One is making sure nobody can say "But I did not know." The other is to organize political and economic action.
Female mutilation is decreed by no religion. But it is passed on, generation to generation, and enforced by custom and religion. Eighty million women now alive are its victims.
The chief instrument of enforcement is not the knife or razor. It is the belief drilled into women that their genitalia and their sexual desires are inherently disgusting. For girls to be marriageable, the genitalia must be controlled -- by cutting, excision and other mutilations.
Representative Schroeder's fact list says the male equivalent would be amputation or cutting of the penis and its surrounding tissues -- a description that should get any Congressman's attention.
One form of mutilation is removal of the clitoris and labia minora. Infibulation, another form, is the removal of the external genitalia, the stitching up of the two sides of the vulva, sometimes with thorns, and the insertion of a sliver to keep only a small opening for the passage of urine and menstrual blood -- all done without anesthetic while the child is held down.
Does that clear it up for Representative Schroeder's colleague? So now he knows.
Judged against its reach and hideousness, no other existing violation of human decency has received so little government and journalistic attention. But not everybody has been silent.
U.N. commissions have passed resolutions. In the West organizations like NOW, Population Action International, the Women's International Network and others have spread information.
Hanny Lightfoot-Klein wrote the important "Prisoners of Ritual" 14 years ago. Alice Walker wrote a novel on the subject and has taken part in a new film, "Warrior Marks." On TV, Charlayne Hunter-Gault did a documentary for public television, and ABC moved ahead of the other major networks with a fine piece for "Day One." In print journalism, The Atlanta Journal and Constitution have been particularly good.
So if many people really do know, why has so little been done? The major responsibility belongs to the governments where mutilation is practiced as part of life, or death.
The former colonial governments and present independent governments either sidestepped the whole thing or accepted it as custom and ritual too dangerous to handle. A few African governments are now trying to do something, and should get help.
The rest of the world has simply failed to take obvious steps. In the U.S., all political and social groups that care could pool talents and clout to shake Washington awake.
The U.S. could bring this atrocity before the major bodies of the U.N. The goal could be to use international clout: give special help to governments fighting mutilation on their soil, cut grants and loans to governments that refuse or stall.
The lack of action in the West -- it must come from bias and disdain, not just against women and blacks by others, but also against women and blacks by themselves. Else, once knowing, they would never again look away.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Devil in the Details

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
The Israel-P.L.O. Declaration of Principles signed on Sept. 13 calls for all implementing plans to be agreed by Dec. 13 and the Palestinians then to assume authority in Gaza and Jericho. A month before that date, with Prime Minister Rabin again in the United States, the necessary agreements are far from completion.
In the declaration the two parties took the essential step of mutual recognition. But all the details of how to govern a dense urban population like Gaza's -- the size and powers of a Palestinian police force, for example -- were left to be negotiated. 
 "It was a beautiful ceremony on the White House lawn," a high Israeli official said. "But in practice the declaration said very little."
Failure to meet the Dec. 13 target date would carry serious risks. For in the view of the Rabin Government, it is only by showing that promises will be carried out on the ground that peace can be made credible to Palestinians -- and can draw in the neighboring Arab states, notably Syria.
After a lame start under the eyes of journalists, one negotiating committee of Israelis and Palestinians moved to a secret location in Cairo. There they have made progress on a ticklish question, the scope of Israel's military withdrawal from the Gaza and Jericho areas: where the troops will go, how many will remain to protect Jewish settlers and so on.
But another important negotiating committee has not started work. It will decide economic questions that greatly concern Israel. For example: Will there be an open relationship between Israel and a future Palestinian entity in the West Bank and Gaza? How will taxes be arranged? Customs duties?
The P.L.O. has been slow even to name its economic negotiators. The committee is now scheduled to meet for the first time Monday in Paris.
The tardiness of the P.L.O. on that issue reflects a fundamental problem in these talks. On one side there is a state, used to the hard business of governing. On the other there is a body, the P.L.O., that is torn by individual and ideological conflicts and that has no experience in running the life of a community.
The odds must be against meeting the Dec. 13 target. Nevertheless, I think there is reason for some optimism about the outlook for peace in the Middle East.
The Rabin Government has a great stake in the success of its agreement with the P.L.O., as hardly needs to be said. That is why Mr. Rabin has been pressing for international aid to the new Palestinian institutions -- to show Palestinians that peace can actually improve their lives.
More broadly, the handshake between Mr. Rabin and Yasir Arafat has opened possibilities for Israel in parts of the world that formerly shunned it. Though Arab states have refused to lift their economic boycott, for example, several have quietly begun talking about financial deals.
Then there is the hope of peace with Syria, which would be the great prize for Israel's security. Prime Minister Rabin has made clear that he does not look for any early breakthrough on that front. Syria will wait to see the concrete results of the P.L.O. agreement. So there again Israel has a deep interest in seeing that it comes to fruition.
Peace has also developed a tangible political momentum among Palestinians since the Sept. 13 signing. Even in Gaza, where the Islamic fundamentalist movement Hamas has been strong, support for the P.L.O. is said to have increased sharply. In Jordan, with its majority Palestinian population, fundamentalists lost ground in the election this week.
Hamas is trying to counter the momentum for peace. In the last two weeks its terrorists have killed three Israeli civilians in the occupied territories, with the obvious purpose of arousing Israelis against the agreement with the P.L.O.
Israeli settlers have rioted. But the main body of Israeli opinion has apparently not been moved -- indeed, some reports say people living in Israel proper have been troubled by the settlers' lawlessness. The general impression since Sept. 13 is that for most Israelis, after all their years of war, the palpable hope of peace has very strong attraction.
"The P.L.O. agreement created an entirely new atmosphere for Israel," the high Israeli official said, "all over the world. The problem now is not atmosphere. It is making the agreement work."

HEADLINE: Why Americans Distrust Clinton on Trade Pact

 BODY:
To the Editor:
James Carville, Bill Clinton's 1992 campaign manager, of all people, should know better than to waste his time joining Tony Snow, a George Bush speechwriter, pontificating on behalf of the North American Free Trade Agreement (Op-Ed, Nov. 2). Mr. Carville should have spent that time reminding his President of the reasons Americans fear the agreement to begin with, and telling him what to do about it. 
 For the majority of American workers, wages have declined since 1973. Meanwhile, inequality has soared, as the richest 20 percent of the population has reaped whatever gains a slow-growing economy has made. According to some studies, the overall effect of economic globalization is to exacerbate the increase in inequality in this country. Americans fear -- rightly or wrongly, but understandably -- that the trade agreement will accelerate these trends.
President Clinton should realize that he cannot expect Americans to trust him on the North American Free Trade Agreement until he reassures them he is committed to raising wages and combating inequality. In the campaign, Mr. Clinton proved that he knew the grim statistics, and he promised to fight for American workers. He downplayed deficit reduction and talked about things like investment in infrastructure, a massive national service program and requiring employers to devote a percentage of revenue to job retraining.
But in the course of the budget wars, the "investment" budget shrank to a pittance, and national service became a pilot program. The retraining requirement has been forgotten. And the Administration has shown little enthusiasm for any increase in the minimum wage.
In short, Bill Clinton has given American workers little reason to believe that he is on their side. Thus, when they are told that the North American Free Trade Agreement is a sellout to big corporations, they tend to think it's true.
The trade agreement may be merely symbolic, but the problems it symbolizes are all-important. Mr. Clinton should have spent some political capital addressing those problems before he asked Americans to swallow a trade agreement that they suspect will make the problems worse.
 
STEVEN NOVICK
Washington, Nov. 9, 1993

HEADLINE: Why Americans Distrust Clinton on Trade Pact;
Retraining's Failure

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The views expressed by Tony Snow and James Carville in "Victory Made (Sort of) Easy" (Op-Ed, Nov. 2) are loaded with pro-North American Free Trade Agreement and pro-business arguments. What happens if the rewards outlined by these two insiders aren't harvested? Maybe earning the equivalent of their Mexican counterparts would be their reward. 
 Our beleaguered economy is already encountering a pre-trade agreement employment crisis by not creating sufficient jobs with good pay for United States workers. Sears, I.B.M., Boeing, Procter & Gamble, Woolworth and General Motors have all announced employment cutbacks of some 200,000 workers in the next 28 months (not to mention cancellation of the supercollider project in Texas). The trade agreement won't restore those jobs.
The bottom line is that proponents of the North American Free Trade Agreement, including these two political observers, must prove that the trade pact will not result in lower wages for American workers. That's what the North American Free Trade Agreement is all about.
President Clinton promises to cushion the short-term jobs fall-out from the North American Free Trade Agreement with retraining dollars for "dislocated" workers. However, retraining workers is not so easy as originally thought. A Labor Department study of Government job-training programs for workers hurt by foreign trade in 1991 found that one in five retrained workers landed jobs paying at least 80 percent as much as their former jobs. This retraining program cost United States taxpayers $200 million. What waste!
The North American Free Trade Agreement is good for investors and big business only; it's bad for American workers.
 
LARRY WROBLEWSKI
Detroit, Nov. 5, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 32; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 192 words

HEADLINE: Why Americans Distrust Clinton on Trade Pact;
Past Promises Unkept

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In the heated debate over the probable economic consequences of the North American Free Trade Agreement with Mexico, surprisingly little attention has been paid to the accuracy of past predictions about development along the border.
In 1965 business leaders lobbied successfully for a border industrialization program, predicting that factories would spring up all along the United States side of the border in tandem with Mexican border development: the twin plant concept.
On the other hand, Ernesto Galarza, farmworker chronicler, was skeptical. In 1967 he requested in vain that the Border Commission include in its membership Mexican labor people from both sides of the border to work toward raising "Mexican levels of income to American standards," not "lowering American to present Mexican ones." Otherwise, he predicted, "goods will be manufactured at Mexican wages and reimported for sale at American prices."
Given past misguided business predictions, why should we rely on the assurances about the trade agreement?
 
JULIE LEININGER PYCIOR
Assistant Professor of History
Manhattan College
Bronx, Nov. 3, 1993

HEADLINE: Courts Also Must Take Battering Seriously

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Whose Shocking Crime?" (Op-Ed, Nov. 5) by Annie Gottlieb puts the case of the severing of a batterer's penis in perspective. Battering of women results in severe physical and emotional harm to millions of women in the United States. However, Ms. Gottlieb, like many others, has been misled by exaggerated reports that police studies prove that arrest does not deter batterers. 
 The National Center on Women and Family Law has completed "Must We Stop Arresting Batterers?: Analysis and Policy Implications of New Police Domestic Violence Studies," a review and analysis of those studies. The findings of lack of deterrence in those studies is limited to unemployed, socially marginal batterers. Even that conclusion is questionable because the methodology of the studies is seriously flawed.
Indeed, the studies show a strong deterrent effect overall. This is particularly impressive because domestic violence usually escalates unless society intervenes effectively.
By isolating police response from other parts of the legal system, the studies fail to consider the very real effect that court and prosecution have on the abuser. The problem with mandatory arrest may be that even when we require the police to take domestic violence seriously, the courts still don't.
 
LAURIE WOODS
Director, National Center
on Women and Family Law
New York, Nov. 8, 1993
