HEADLINE: Tapping a Rich Smoking Frontier

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
Andreas Gembler, the head of the Philip Morris International tobacco operations in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, points to a simple statistic to explain the company's decision to sink nearly $1 billion into the region after the collapse of Communism. About 700 billion cigarettes are sold there annually, making the market 40 percent larger than that of the United States.
"No industry can ignore the consumer in this part of the world," Mr. Gembler said. 
 At the Czech Ministry of Health, Dr. Jiri T. Kozak is pondering another statistic. The percentage of Czechs who are smokers, he said, has risen to 37.5 percent, from 35 percent in 1989, when the Berlin wall fell and Eastern Europe began opening in earnest to, among others, the Marlboro Man, Joe Camel and the rest of the Western tobacco industry. In the United States, an estimated 25 to 27 percent of adults smoke.
"Until the arrival of the transnational tobacco companies and the beginning of aggressive advertising, the prevalence of smoking was decreasing," said Dr. Kozak, an adviser to the ministry who is helping to prepare legislation to restrict cigarette advertising.
 
Looking for Growth
 Confronted with flat or shrinking markets in America and Western Europe, as well as a precipitous drop in profits in the United States, tobacco companies are counting on the rest of the world for growth. The trend has encompassed Latin America, Africa and Asia. But no region has captured more of the industry's money lately than the former Soviet bloc, where Philip Morris and R. J. Reynolds of the United States, B.A.T. Industries of Britain, Reemstma of Germany and other companies are forging joint ventures and making acquisitions.
Their investments, which total more than $1.5 billion, have bought them a large presence in countries extending as far east as Kazakhstan in central Asia, where Philip Morris agreed in September to pay more than $200 million to acquire control of the Government-owned cigarette factory. Still to come are privatization programs in Poland and the full-scale opening of the tobacco industry in Russia.
As they looked out on the cities and towns where billboards and alluring slogans herald capitalism ("L& M: The Way America Tastes"), tobacco executives said they were confident in their strategy.
But the tobacco companies will face formidable obstacles and some controversy. A look at the biggest deal completed so far -- Philip Morris's acquisition of a controlling stake in Tabak, the formerly state-owned tobacco company in the Czech Republic -- illustrates the potential and pitfalls for the industry.
Philip Morris, the largest tobacco company in the world and the maker of Marlboros, won a bidding war by agreeing last year to pay $400 million to acquire a controlling interest in the company and modernize its five plants -- the only tobacco factories in the Czech Republic.
Philip Morris got factories that are considered among the best in Eastern Europe, though far below Western standards. Perhaps most important, Philip Morris acquired a portfolio of local brands that were extremely strong sellers and a chance to increase the sales of Marlboro and its other Western brands.
 
A Growing Share
 Tabak controls 62.5 percent of the combined Czech and Slovak markets, according to Philip Morris, up from 60 percent before the acquisition. In the Czech market alone, the figure is probably closer to 75 percent, prompting grumbling from competitors that the Czech Government has been too slow to allow other Western cigarette companies to begin manufacturing in the country.
Mr. Gembler said that on an operating basis Tabak was already profitable. But analysts said Philip Morris might wait a long time for the investment to pay off, because profit margins in Eastern Europe were a fraction of those in the West, and the ability to raise prices was limited.
Emanuel Goldman, an analyst for Paine Webber in San Francisco, said that in the former Soviet bloc, the company made $2.29 for each 1,000 cigarettes sold last year. In the European Community, in contrast, it made $6.03. In the United States, the margin was $24.23 for 1,000 cigarettes last year, though Philip Morris's move earlier this year to slash prices has driven down margins in the United States to $15.82, he said.
 
Unit Sales Lower
 Retail prices are up sharply this year in the Czech Republic and Slovakia, but primarily because of tax increases. At the same time, the region's economic teething pains and the effects of the recession in neighboring Germany -- the biggest export market and the primary source of foreign investment -- have lowered total unit sales by more than 2 percent this year.
Much of Philip Morris's investment has gone to modernize Tabak's main plant in Kutna Hora, 40 miles from Prague. The plant's decades-old cigarette-making machines ground the tobacco unevenly, and the machines could not weigh the tobacco used in each cigarette, so each cigarette would burn differently. Packaging machines often put cellophane wrappers on unevenly.
All that has changed, said Leon Dediot, the manager of operations for Tabak. The new machinery has been put in, and the old equipment is being rebuilt.
 
Emphasizing the Familiar
 In the long run, Mr. Gembler said, Western brands like Marlboro will be the big sellers in Eastern markets. But for now, he said, Philip Morris is happy to emphasize the familiar, affordable local brands.
Of the top 10 brands in the combined Czech and Slovak market, 8 are produced by Tabak, including 4 of the top 5. The two leading brands are Tabak's Petra and Petra Lights. Marlboro, which sells for the equivalent of $1.20 a pack, 60 percent more than Petra, ranks fifth and is the best-selling international brand.
To support its products, Philip Morris has become one of the biggest advertisers in the region.
Smoking here has never had the social stigma it has acquired in America. Dr. Jaroslav Kriz, the chief hygienist for the Czech Ministry of Health, noted a study showing that 52 percent of surgeons are smokers.
But governments, with the encouragement of groups like the World Health Organization, have taken up the anti-smoking cause. With their tobacco industries now largely in foreign hands, they have become more aggressive in their attacks.
"The transnational tobacco companies exploit our countries' desperate need for immediate economic investment," public health officials from 13 former Soviet bloc nations, including the Czech Republic, said in a letter to President Clinton in September. "But in so doing they damage our health and ruin our longer-term economic well-being."
Legislators in the Czech Republic, like those in many other Eastern European countries, are debating restrictions on tobacco advertising. Poland has adopted some that will take effect in 1995. In Hungary, several companies, including Philip Morris, have been fined for violations.
So far Philip Morris, along with the advertising industry, has headed off legislation in the Czech Republic, in part by casting the issue as one of free speech, not an issue that any politician at this point in the country's history is eager to be seen opposing.
Mr. Gembler said Philip Morris did not oppose advertising restrictions, but said they should be drafted in an open legislative process and define what was permissible. Czech officials said compromise legislation was likely in a year or two.
Philip Morris already faces advertising restrictions in almost every Western market. Still, neither Philip Morris nor any other tobacco company has shown any less interest in Eastern Europe because of the issue.
Mr. Gembler said the company was pleased with the results of its strategy in countries like the Czech Republic and Hungary. And while progress in countries like Russia and the former Soviet republics will be much slower, he said, ultimately they will be very attractive markets.
"The question is, can you afford not to be there?" Mr. Gembler said.

HEADLINE: Mere Hint of Jobs Draws Crowd in Detroit

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 11

 BODY:
In this city's troubled downtown, thousands of people lined up in the cold this morning to apply for jobs that may never exist. The applicants, mostly black, were hoping to work in a casino to be run by Greek-American businessmen on behalf of an Indian tribe based in Northern Michigan.
But the casino appears to have little chance of winning approval, which means the long line probably served as little more than a gauge of the desperation of people unable to find full-time work in a city that once boomed with the auto trade. 
 The casino's sponsors say the project would help revive downtown's boarded-up department stores, office towers and stately theaters. With Detroit's unemployment at 13 percent, almost double the national rate, the prospect of jobs with benefits -- any jobs -- led hundreds of would-be workers to turn out by 7 A.M., three hours before applications were available.
 
Desperation in Motor City
 "It's pitiful," said Roosevelt Albritton, standing near the end of the line, which snaked back and forth through blocked-off streets over two blocks. "This is the auto industry town. It should never have to go through this."
For the casino to open, Federal and state officials must permit a block of downtown Detroit to be taken into trust for the Indian tribe, the Sault Ste. Marie Tribe of Chippewa Indians, to make it part of a reservation some 350 miles north of here.
With that prospect in deep doubt, Dennis Archer, the city's Mayor-elect and an opponent of the plan, said the casino job offer was cruelly raising false hopes. The casino's sponsors announced the offer in Sunday's newspapers, which warned that no one would be hired until the plan was approved.
 
'Nothing Else Happening'
 But the patiently waiting applicants said they had no alternatives. "Nobody else is saying, We've got 4,000 jobs," said Bessie Sibbaluca, who said she has been raising two children on part-time jobs and social assistance for more than three years. "There's nothing else happening but crime."
The last solicitation for a large number of jobs came from the post office, she said. It promised 300 jobs over three or four years.
Most of the auto jobs disappeared long ago; Mr. Albritton, 45, lost his in the late 1970's. While some businesses and neighborhoods still thrive in Detroit, the grim remnants of the blue-collar paradise that slipped away with the industry are everywhere: the silent, sprawling brick factories; the deserted wood-frame houses with doorways gaping; the vacant lots, where grass grows waist-deep in summer.
Now, Mr. Albritton said, "The American dream isn't here anymore."
The casino, in some ways, has the earmarks of a desperation move by businessmen in one of the city's still-vibrant pockets. The casino would be in an area called Greektown, at night an island of bustling restaurants and bright lights amid the dark streets.
Mayor-elect Archer called the offer of 4,415 jobs like dealing cards or spinning roulette wheels an effort to build political pressure. Referring to the businessmen, he said in an interview today: "They've confirmed what all of us know in the city, that we've got some outstanding people who would like the dignity of good-paying jobs. I would respectfully represent to you that if you went to any city in the United States and said, 'We have 4,000 jobs,' you would create a line."
Ted Gatzaros, one of the businessmen who would operate the casino for the Chippewas, said he had to solicit applications now to have time to train the workers for the casino's planned opening in June to coincide with the World's Cup in nearby Pontiac. Base wages of $16,000 to $18,000 would be paid for work cleaning bathrooms to dealing blackjack to spinning the roulette wheels.
In addition, he said, 11,000 jobs will open up around the casino for tour guides, jewelers, bakers, baby sitters, taxi drivers and others.
 
Governor Is Opposed
 By the end of the day, more than 10,000 people had filled out applications, and many more had picked them up, the casino's backers said. The Detroit police had no crowd estimates.
Gov. John Engler opposes Indian casino gambling in Detroit if it does not benefit all seven of Michigan's tribes and if it is not part of a larger urban revitalization plan. "The tribe has failed to meet the minimum conditions that the Governor has set down," said Michael Gadola, the Governor's deputy legal counsel.
Before the proposal reaches the Governor's desk, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt must approve taking the land into trust. He has not yet indicated how or when he will decide, a spokesman said.
Residents of Detroit have voted down casino gambling in the city four times. But if the land is taken into trust, their approval would not be necessary, a fact that enrages some city leaders.
"Something is being forced on us that we have rejected as a community," said the Rev. Jim Holley, president of the Council of Baptist Pastors of Detroit and Vicinity. "We're not looking for a war on anyone, but it's not something the Indian community would let us do to them."
 
'50 Years of Depression
 On the reservation on Michigan's Upper Peninsula, gambling has already created a boom for the tribe. "Detroit is similar to the Sault," said Bernard Bouschor, the tribal chairman, or chief. "We had 50 years of depression." About 1,500 members of the tribe live in Detroit, a city of about one million.
Throughout Michigan, the seven Indian tribes now run eight casinos, but Mr. Gadola said the operations were not legal. The state has agreed to a compact governing gambling at those casinos, but that agreement is awaiting Mr. Babbitt's approval. Meanwhile, Federal officials have not taken action against them.
Mr. Bouschor and his business partners have promised the city $20 million annually from the casino, over and above the cost of city services, and the state another $32 million.
It is unclear whether the state could accept the funds, however. Under the 1988 Indian Gaming Regulatory Act, states may recoup their costs for providing services to casinos, but may not profit from them, said Bob Walker, a spokesman for the Department of the Interior.
Unlike casinos in Atlantic City, he said, the casino proposed by the Chippewas will benefit surrounding business because it will offer few services besides gambling. "It's gaming and bathrooms," he said. "They don't want to create fortresses of greed."
Mr. Gatzaros said he saw business at his restaurants and hotel in Greektown plunge 50 percent in two years. Suburbanites, he said, have been scared off by what he called exaggerated reports of crime downtown.
 
'Have a Job for Me?'
 He also said that city leaders who pine for the return of high-wage auto jobs needed to explore alternatives. "People are desperate," he said. "They're waking up and realizing those jobs are never going to happen again."
As they waited in line, applicants said that unless the casino's critics could supply another option, they should stand aside.
"Do they have a job for me?" asked Ponchita Flowers, 45, a former executive secretary who said she had been searching for a full-time job for six years. "If they have a job for me, fine, I'll come see them tomorrow."
"Yesterday," amended Gloria Chapman, 49, who was standing in line behind Mrs. Flowers.

HEADLINE: The Future Is Coming

BYLINE: By Timothy Ferris; Timothy Ferris, professor of journalism at the University of California at Berkeley, is senior producer of the forthcoming PBS series "Future Quest."

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
Why doesn't America know where it is going? U.S. foreign and military policy is swerving like a drunken driver without a map. . . . We are undergoing the deepest rearrangement of global power since the birth of industrial civilization.
-- Alvin Toffler and Heidi Toffler, Op-Ed page, Oct. 31, 1993.
Why is American foreign policy lurching like a drunken driver without a map? To answer that vital question, we need to set aside the obsolete world map that befuddled policy makers have been consulting and turn to a new map -- specifically, the 1993 Universal World Globe. 
 We find that there are three sorts of nations -- those with muddy colors, yellow and brown, like India and China; those with cooler, "Miami Vice" hues of blue and green, like Singapore, Lithuania and the nations of the Malay Archipelago, and those that display a confetti-like array of bright colors, like the U.S., Japan, Western Europe and the Cape Verde Islands.
As the hypersonic winds of change blow us all down the corridors of future history, it becomes clear that these states have sharply differing interests. Mud-colored nations need seed bags, Archimedes' screws, insect repellent and audio cassettes recorded on only one side. The priorities of cool-tone nations lean toward bedroom air-conditioners, cigarette papers and powerful X-ray machines for checking whether shoes fit.
The confetti-colored nations are very different. They don't need food, water, and transportation, but information. They require high-speed C.P.U.'s, giant TV screens, comfy sofas and coasters. Without leaving their couches, citizens of these third-hue nations will soon be able to calculate their taxes, look up "bird" in the Grolier's Encyclopedia or watch grandmothers be shot by snipers in Sarajevo from six camera angles.
Of course, these divisions are not absolute. Even in mud-colored nations, a few people watch TV or play Gameboy. Every once in a while someone in a cool-tone region grooms a water buffalo or lights a fire to stay warm. Some among the confetti peoples upholster couches or grow potatoes. But these overlaps should not blind us to the powerful forces shaping the very nature of futurology. Confetti will fly everywhere, and policy makers who don't smell the coffee had better get their heads out of the fan.
When we take these prospects together, there emerges a vision of a new world in which traditional political boundaries count for little. Once mighty states like Italy, Germany and the Benelux nations are doomed to be replaced by such emerging centers of info-power as Orange County, Calif., and Champaign-Urbana, Ill.
With the dinosaur governments of Japan, the U.S. and Russia paralyzed by thousands of treaties and regulations thoughtlessly inked by their old-think leaders, vital decisions about whether, say, to explore Mars or dispatch a carrier wing to the Indian Ocean will be left to free-wheeling confetti states like Ifni and Nauru.
Dwarfing even this change will be the revolutionary economic transformations wrought by the coming info-age. Studies commissioned by the Home Shopping Channel show that more buying power is wielded by just one confetti-nation subgroup -- divorced fathers living in trailer parks who own a remote control TV and at least one automatic pistol -- than by the former Warsaw Pact nations combined. In the emerging world of fiber-optic networks, such economic clout will be combined with instant access to information ranging from high school basketball scores to promotion prospects for stenographers born under the sign of Libra.
Where it will all go, know few -- and most of them work in my think tank. As wave upon wave of digitized change washes across a changing world, U.S. policy will continue to swerve drunkenly across the globe until its leaders wake up and start hiring futurologists.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: A Graver Jackson's Cry: Overcome the Violence!

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Rev. Jesse Jackson's star has dimmed a bit. At 52, he is graying at the temples, and his heart seems heavier than it was in the 1970's, when he sought to sway a generation of black teen-agers to believe, and repeat, "I am somebody." When he talks with teen-agers these days, it is not about the promise of tomorrow but about the dangers of today.
"Stop the violence!" Mr. Jackson thunders. "Save the children!" 
 Until then, hope will have to wait.
Mr. Jackson says he cannot remember a time when so much of black America was in such deep danger and despair because of drugs and violence, unemployment and disease.
 
Part of Culture, He Says
 Poverty and racism still do their devil's work. But nowadays the threat to life and limb and liberty often grows up just down the street. Young black men and boys are killing one another, Mr. Jackson says, in a storm of "self-destruction." Baby sister and little brother are dying in the crossfire.
But this isn't happening in a vacuum; the violence among blacks, he says, is rooted in a national culture -- shared by people of every color in the country's rainbow -- that is drawn to the power of the gun, particularly as a means to settle disputes, big and small, in the street and in the home.
For Mr. Jackson and a growing number of prominent black clergy members, writers and community leaders, ending the violence has become a crusade. He calls it the "new frontier of the civil rights movement."
Long-term answers will have to include jobs and schools, the nuts and bolts of life, Mr. Jackson says, but in the meantime people are dying.
Mr. Jackson has been traveling the country preaching to black audiences to do-for-self, to take responsibility for ending the carnage in their streets. And lately, he has been getting a lot of attention from news organizations and even from President Clinton.
"No one else will do it for us but us," he says. It is a sentiment passed down from generation to generation, like the family Bible. For Mr. Jackson it is a self-evident truth.
"When it's black on black, there seems to be a zone of permissiveness about crime," he says. "That has got to stop."
But he says permissiveness and acceptance of killing has also seeped into the souls of too many black people, and that troubles him the most. He wants black students to be on the front lines in the war on guns, self-hate, greed and violence, much as their parents' generation was in the forefront when the enemies were Klansmen, dream-crushing laws and governors blocking the schoolhouse door.
The man who spent recent years telling students to "keep hope alive" is now telling them to stand up to the thugs among them and to break the student "code of silence" that allows Johnny to sit in class with a pocket full of dope and a 9-millimeter pistol in his waistband. Turn Johnny in, he says.
"It's not snitching," he recently insisted to a group of skeptical students at Roosevelt High School in Washington. "It's self-defense."
A senior, DeMone Perry, shook his head at what he later said was Mr. Jackson's naivete or "old age" about what it takes to survive in the streets. "You need some kind of protection," the youth said, "because nobody else is going to stop a bullet for you."
He said almost everyone he knew carried a gun or a knife to school, including some teachers. He said he would not "snitch" because the police had their own code of silence that protected crooked officers and allowed them to rob, cheat, steal and sell drugs like criminals.
"I'm sorry, sir," the youth told Mr. Jackson. "This is 1993, not 1963. I don't know where you've been."
Mr. Jackson put his hand on the student's shoulder and said, "I've been to a lot of teen-age funerals."
 
Recapturing Spotlight
 Mr. Jackson has also been to a lot of news conferences.
Adolph L. Reed Jr., a political science professor at Northwestern University who wrote "The Jesse Jackson Phenomenon," a book published in 1986 by Yale University Press, says that now, with attention on a new group of more moderate black political leaders, Mr. Jackson's talk of self-help to fight crime is one sure way to recapture the spotlight that dimmed so much for him last year during the Presidential election campaign.
"Jackson has been marginalized within the Democratic Party," Mr. Reed said. "He's been trying to figure out for some time what to do with himself and how to assert his presence on the national stage."
Not long after the Presidential campaign, he failed to recapture that spotlight when at the 11th hour he withdrew from consideration as executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Although Mr. Jackson was clearly the most well-known of the candidates, questions were raised about whether he was best suited for the post.
For others, Mr. Jackson's current campaign comes dangerously close to blame-the-victim oratory, and it lets the bigger -- and whiter -- society off the hook of responsibility.
Richard Majors, a psychologist on leave from the University of Wisconsin and a founding member of the National Council on African American Men, said Mr. Jackson and other leaders must be careful not to put too much of the burden for change solely on the weary shoulders of black America.
"We've paid a black tax in terms of our blood, sweat and tears," Mr. Majors said. "The solution may begin in looking at ourselves but it doesn't end there. Considering unemployment, poverty and racism, I think black males have done very well."
Carl Upchurch, a founder of a national effort to get street gangs to stop fighting, said, "Unless we get the larger society to live up to its responsibilities to justice and equality, then these kids aren't going to change."
"These kids aren't the problem," he said. "They are the symptom."
In another sign of how deep the crisis seems to be, people and organizations who have kept their distance for years are starting to come together to oppose violence. A few weeks ago, the Congressional Black Caucus embraced the Nation of Islam leader, Minister Louis Farrakhan, partly because he is such a hero in some of the hardest-hit and most difficult-to-reach pockets of urban America.
 
'A Sacred Mission'
 Benjamin Chavis, the executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, has been traveling from city to city, encouraging gang members to put down their guns. "This is a sacred mission," he said at a recent gang peace meeting in Chicago.
Mr. Jackson and Mr. Farrakhan addressed the same gathering.
In recent weeks, from Washington to Oakland, he has been mixing shock therapy with theology, pep talks with homicide statistics, in a series of speeches to inner-city high school students about their singular role in ending the "madness."
He asks the students to pledge that "my school and my community will no longer be a sanctuary for dope pushers, gunslingers and killers."
He has started a project called "Reclaim Our Youth," a program to counsel and to provide mentors for teen-agers that he hopes to see operating soon in 1,000 churches across the country.
"So we can get the kids before the streets do," he explained.
On the road, he bellows: Stop killing each other! Stop in the name of the grandmothers who worked two jobs to support you, and stop in the name of the college students who died in some southern swamp so all Americans could vote. In the name of God. Stop.
"You have the power to do that right now," he says. "You have the power to choose life over death and hope over dope."
The students near the stage at Roosevelt roared yes, they would sign his pledge. A group of boys in back slumped in their seats, smirking as they watched a teacher pull a girl out of the auditorium.
"She's using all sorts of vulgarities," the teacher said to another.
"So what?" the girl said. "You wouldn't understand no way."
She did not get to hear much of Mr. Jackson's message. Sam Hartwell, 19, did and said his mother would faint when he got home and told her how close he had been to Mr. Jackson.
"He's a great leader," Sam said. "So I'll listen to him. But it's easy for him to talk about giving up guns and drugs. He don't have to live with the same problems we do.
"Some people bring guns to school because their lives are in danger. He has body guards, we don't. He has money, we don't. You watch, somebody is going to get killed tonight. I'm going to do my best to make sure it ain't me."

Companies
A Federal judge cleared the way for the three big television networks to own a financial interest in all of the programs they broadcast. The decision was a blow for Hollywood studios, which had hoped to keep the networks from sharing in the profits from the programs they produce for television. [Page 39.] 
 United Airlines rejected a proposal from its pilots and machinists unions to buy a majority stake in the carrier, killing the unions' bid to take over the carrier. The move could signal the beginning of widespread layoffs and tumultuous labor strife. [39.]
QVC Network increased its hostile bid for Paramount to $90 a share in cash and stock. Armed with a fresh cash infusion from BellSouth, QVC raised the cash portion of its offer by 15 percent and appears to have the edge in the bidding with Viacom. [39.]
Novell's chief executive, Raymond J. Noorda, will retire when a successor is named. Mr. Noorda's age of 67, his dominance of Novell's management and reports of his memory lapses have raised concerns about the company's future. [39.]
Ford Motor will give salaried workers raises averaging 5 percent in 1994 and benefits will be restored to previous levels. The move is similar to one at General Motors. [41.]
Asarco expects to sell a portion of its stake in Grupo Mexico when shares of the mining company are listed in the U.S. [41.]
The Postal Service will culminate a $1 million ad campaign on today's telecast of the Florida State-Notre Dame game. [41.]
Southern New England Telephone will lay off up to 14 percent of its work force to increase efficiency in a changing market. [28.]
 
 International
Thousands of Romanians may lose their savings in a fraudulent financial scheme while the scheme's founder is said to have pocketed as much as $40 million. Western bankers said the scheme's failure could have grave social and economic consequences for a country trying to shift to capitalism. [1.]
Volkswagen of Mexico has been shaken by bitter labor strife that may weaken its ability to survive the transition that all Mexican businesses must undergo, with or without a North American Free Trade Agreement. [39.]
Several previously undecided members of Congress said they would support the free-trade pact. [10.] The pact is stirring the passions of grass-roots labor. [10.] A least $10 million will be spent in advertising by both sides in the Nafta debate. [10.]
Poverty is visible in Russia as never before, with about 37 percent of the country's 150 million people classified as poor. [3.]
 
The Economy
Retail sales rose 1.5 percent in October, the seventh straight gain and the biggest since April. The greater-than-expected advance was confirmation that the economy had gained momentum since late summer and indicated a good holiday retail season. [39.]
 
Markets
Stocks bounded ahead, propelled by another report of good economic news. The Dow climbed 22.08 points to 3,684.51. [40.]
Treasury prices rebounded from an early sell-off. The yield of the 30-year bond fell to 6.15 percent from 6.20 percent. [48.]
The dollar fell to a four-week low against the Japanese yen. Gold also dropped. [50.] Oil prices retreated. [50.]

Small investors in the volatile Latin American stock markets should plan for the long haul and avoid short-term trading. [37.]

HEADLINE: Phone Company to Cut Its Work Force by 14%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12

 BODY:
Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation said today that it would lay off up to 1,500 employees, or 14 percent of its work force, to become more competitive in a changing market.
"We have carefully considered all other possible actions and there are no realistic alternatives to layoffs," said Daniel J. Miglio, president and chief executive officer, in a videotaped message to employees. 
 In recent years, the company has moved gradually to reduce costs and shrink its work force. But with "incredible changes" transforming telecommunications, including the merging of industries, Mr. Miglio said the slow approach had to be abandoned.
 
Management Feels It Too
 Mr. Miglio said 400 to 700 of the 3,600 management employees would be laid off, along with 500 to 800 of the 7,000 union employees.
Industry analysts have been saying that SNET needs to cut up to 3,000 jobs to match the productivity of other phone companies.
Most of those who will lose their jobs are employed in the network operations of the company's largest subsidiary, Southern New England Telephone. They include telephone installers, cable splicers and clerical workers.
Layoffs will begin Jan. 12. Management employees will be notified between Jan. 5 and March 4 and union workers starting Jan. 27.
The company had earlier offered financial incentives to most of its work force to leave voluntarily, but only a small number have accepted, said Beverly Levy, a spokeswoman for the company.
"The numbers are low and really don't make a significant dent in the number of jobs we have to downsize," she said.
Ms. Levy said the company could not be more specific because "we're still working on a radical reorganization and restructuring."
Improved technologies make the job cutbacks possible, the company said.
Southern New England Telephone's revenues have been flat during the last five years as the state has endured its worst recession since the Great Depression.
Adding to the pressures on SNET, the company began facing competition this year on intrastate long-distance phone services, and has seen revenues drop as a result, Ms. Levy said. The company's new competitors include A.T.&T., MCI and Sprint.
Employees were reluctant to discuss the announcement during their lunch hour today, and those who would comment did not want to be identified.
 
Workers Saw It Coming
 A market researcher said most employees knew layoffs were coming and accepted that cutbacks were necessary.
"I guess my job is in jeopardy as well as everyone else's," the researcher said. "But if the company is going to be viable, it's going to have to make some hard decisions."
The Connecticut Union of Telephone Workers, which represents 7,000 SNET employees, did not challenge the need for the cutbacks.
"We certainly feel for those who lose their jobs," said Jim Grinberg, a union spokesman. "We're unhappy about it."
But realistically, Mr. Grinberg said, "the company is not a nonprofit organization" and had to find ways to deal with the state's lingering recession, increased competition and changing technology.
Blue-collar workers at SNET have until Nov. 30 to accept the company's buyout offer, which provides employees as much as $26,000 in a lump-sum payment based on years of service. The management buyout offer did not have a deadline. SNET said it would disclose next week how many accepted the offer.
In his 10-minute message to employees, which was shown throughout the day today and will be replayed Monday, Mr. Miglio called his action "the most gut-wrenching decision I have ever had to make in my 30-plus years at SNET."

HEADLINE: NATIONS BACK BAN ON ATOMIC DUMPING

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT

 BODY:
Capping a series of actions hailed by environmentalists as a turning point in the protection of the world's oceans, the United States and 36 other governments voted yesterday to impose a permanent, legally binding ban on the dumping of all types of radioactive waste at sea.
The vote to ban dumping of low-level radioactive wastes came at a meeting in London of 42 of the 71 nations that signed a 1972 treaty on ocean dumping. Five of the countries represented at the meeting -- Russia, Britain, France, China and Belgium -- abstained from the vote. 
 On Thursday the signers of the treaty also approved two less intensely debated measures, approving permanent prohibitions on ocean dumping of toxic industrial wastes and waste incineration at sea. The agreement's "black list" of prohibited materials already includes highly radioactive wastes.
Diplomats say the actions will transform the treaty -- known as the London Convention -- from an agreement regulating marine dumping to one aimed at preventing the practice whenever there is reasonable doubt about its ecological soundness.
 
Modest Step, Big Problem
 In terms of the overall problem of ocean pollution, the bans constitute a modest step: deliberate dumping of nuclear and toxic industrial wastes at sea constitutes only about 10 percent of the total that enters the ocean. Up to 80 percent originates from such sources as raw sewage, airborne wastes and runoff of pesticides and fertilizer.
But environmental groups believe that the governments' actions in London this week are a sign that they may eventually come to grips with the much larger problem of land-based marine pollution, which Clifton Curtis, a treaties expert with Greenpeace International, described as "far more complicated in technical, legal, political and economic terms."
"What they did here is a sign of a real commitment to view the oceans very differently than before," Mr. Curtis said in a telephone interview from London, where Greenpeace -- which began campaigning for permanent dumping bans 15 years ago -- was monitoring the conference. "It sends a very positive signal."
Any of the 71 signatories, including the 5 that abstained from yesterday's vote, have the right to refuse to comply with changes to the treaty if they file notice within 100 days. The measure approved yesterday replaces a 10-year-old nonbinding moratorium. It is to take effect in 100 days, and includes a provision for a scientific review after 25 years.
Russia, which has been dumping nuclear wastes into the ocean for decades, said it would have to resume dumping low-level radioactive garbage after 18 months unless it receives assistance from the West to build more land-based storage areas.
The plea for aid was dismissed as unconvincing by the chief American delegate, David A. Colson, who noted that Russia spends "enormous sums of money" on its nuclear fleet.
"You will not convince me, and you will not convince the American people, that if the Russian Government so chose, it could not reallocate its priorities and immediately build and quickly have in place adequate storage and processing facilities," Mr. Colson told delegates on Thursday.
Adoption of the ban comes less than a month after a Russian tanker, shadowed by a Greenpeace vessel, pumped more than 900 tons of low-level waste into a squid-fishing ground in the Sea of Japan. The episode, days after the Japanese and Russian Governments had pledged a new era of cooperation, set off a storm of protest. Soon after, on Oct. 21, Japan announced that it would support a permanent ban.
 
Clinton Shifts U.S. Policy
 On Nov. 1, a Clinton Administration official disclosed that, after nearly a year of deliberations, it had decided to reverse American policy and also support such a ban. Participants in the London meeting said the shift, championed by the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, was a decisive factor in yesterday's vote.
The decision in London follows years of controversy over the suspected -- but still largely unproven -- dangers of dumping of low-level radioactive wastes on marine ecosystems. Proponents of the ban argued that the wastes could be retransmitted to humans through the food chain. They also warned that it was risky to dump radioactive material without means to monitor and, if necessary, retrieve it.
The ban, originally proposed by Denmark, is in line with a measure approved at the so-called Earth Summit in Brazil last year, when 172 governments urged the treaty signatories to consider banning low-level dumping as a precaution.
But Britain and France, which fought an 11th-hour battle for a compromise short of a permanent ban, questioned whether low-level waste dumping posed a real danger, and complained that a permanent prohibition would complicate the problem of what to do with growing accumulations of low-level wastes, much of it from decommissioned submarines, nuclear power plants and hospitals.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD;
Clinton Extends an Unusual Offer to Republicans on the Pact

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Administration officials worked today to nail down a solid base of support for the North American Free Trade Agreement as members of Congress returned to their home districts to face constituents this weekend.
President Clinton even promised to defend any Republican incumbent against a Democratic challengers' attack if it was based on the incumbent's vote for Nafta, as the trade agreement is known. 
 Several previously undecided members of Congress, including two Democratic Representatives, Nita M. Lowey of New York and Richard Lehman of California, announced they would support the pact, and White House officials said they expected similar support to come Saturday from Representatives Harold E. Ford and Jim Cooper, both Democrats from Tennessee.
"I think we'll get what we think we have to get on the Democratic side, and I'm working with the Republicans," President Clinton said today as he embarked on another round of meetings and phone calls on the subject.
But the White House lost a potentially powerful ally today when Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, announced that he would vote against the agreement.
Mr. Waxman said he remained unhappy with what he said was a lack of health, environmental and labor protections in the agreement, and he called on the White House to withdraw the legislation and reopen negotiations.
 
'Full Court Press'
 Much of the last-minute lobbying on behalf of the pact has fallen to Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the second-ranking Republican in the House. "I feel like we're in the third overtime of a basketball game and we've been running a full court press," said Mr. Gingrich, who met with Mr. Clinton and the House Republican leader, Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, at the White House on Wednesday to count votes.
Mr. Clinton plans to hold a dinner for undecided lawmakers at the White House on Sunday.
Mr. Clinton sweetened the pot for Republicans today, offering a written promise that he would assail any Democratic challenger who ran against a Republican incumbent because of a vote in favor of the accord. "I'll give it to them in writing," he said. "I'll give it to them in public statements. I do not believe any member of Congress should be defeated for doing what is plainly in the national interest."
 
Debate is Cited
 Mr. Gingrich, like other pact supporters, said they detected momentum toward the agreement, and they attributed it to the fallout from Tuesday night's debate between Ross Perot and Vice President Al Gore, which they said was lost by Mr. Perot, who opposes the accord.
"The Perot collapse the other night took a great deal of the energy out of the opponents," Mr. Gingrich said.
Mr. Perot's lobbying against the accord is continuing. A Dallas-area telephone number for workers in his field organization carries a message that pleads for opponents of the pact to "leave nothing to chance."
"They are spending hundreds of millions of dollars in taxpayer money to buy votes," Mr. Perot says in a message taped this afternoon. "We have to make sure we don't even blink. The meetings that you are holding this weekend while the Congressmen are home will make all the difference.
"You know who the uncommitted are," Mr. Perot continues. "Let's focus on them. Just cover them up with telephone calls."
White House officials stopped short of saying that minds were changed because of the debate, but several said they were satisfied that it had eroded the credibility of the accord's opponents.
Lawmakers who oppose the agreement, which would erase trade barriers with Canada and Mexico, said, however, that they have enough votes to defeat it. The President, they said, must now wrest votes from their base of support if he is to eke out another of his trademark narrow victories on a crucial piece of legislation.
"I'm still very upbeat about this," Mr. Clinton said today. "But I think there'll be, you know, clouds around this issue right until the last."
 
Undecideds Hold the Outcome
 Part of the Administration's uneasiness appeared rooted in its concern about appearing too confident too early, but both sides concede that most of the remaining undecided members of Congress will probably side with the Administration.
"If you're undecided today, we feel pretty good about our chances to have them fall our way by Wednesday," said William Daley, who is running the White House effort to pass the accord.
Representative Lowey, whose district is in the New York City suburb of Westchester County, said she had become convinced that the agreement would spur economic growth.
"If I believed that the Nafta would accelerate these inequities or eliminate jobs, I would vote against it," she said. "The fact is that Nafta will, on balance, make the United States and the New York region more competitive."

HEADLINE: Rise in October Retail Sales Confirms Recovery's Vigor

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Shoppers spent 1.5 percent more in October, the seventh straight gain and the biggest since April, the Census Bureau reported today.
The greater-than-expected advance, which lifted sales to $177.32 billion, was strong confirmation that the economy had gained momentum since late summer. It was also regarded by some as a sign of at least a satisfactory holiday season. 
 "Consumer spending continues to improve," said John E. Silvia, economist for Kemper Financial Services, a unit of the Chicago-based insurer. "For all the popular talk about consumer attitudes being depressed, retail sales are doing just fine."
As further evidence of a seeming disparity between what shoppers say and what they do, the University of Michigan reported today that its mid-November reading of consumer confidence edged down to 82, from 82.7 in late October.
The October retail sales gain was led by the automotive sector but was broadly based, with durable goods -- those meant to last more than three years -- up 2.6 percent and nondurables up eight-tenths of 1 percent.
Yet economists continued to fret because retail spending, which accounts for a third of the economy, is rising faster than incomes, eroding the rate of saving and increasing consumer debt levels.
For now, things look pretty good, said Rosanne M. Cahn, economist at the First Boston Corporation, but "the consumer isn't earning enough income to support these gains." She said she could not say how long heavy spending was likely to last.
Patrick J. Moriarty, a vice president at Bank Julius Baer, concurred, calling earnings gains "mediocre" and evincing concern about the languishing job market. "There's not a lot of reason to expect a big Christmas season," he said.
About 15 percent of the October gain reflected the 4.3-cent rise in the Federal gasoline tax, which took effect at the start of the month, according to one calculation.
Excluding automotive, the October advance was nine-tenths of 1 percent, compared with six-tenths of 1 percent without autos in September, today's report showed. The auto sector thus dragged down total sales in September, which posted an overall rise of just one-tenth of 1 percent, and then swelled the total last month.
These figures are adjusted for recurring seasonal patterns, but analysts cautioned that this process was unreliable during the period of new-model introduction.
Still, it was clear that consumers were spending freely and that cars and rebuilding from Midwest floods were just two of several strengths.
"They were also in the malls, shopping centers and on Main Street," said Tracy Mullin, president of the National Retail Federation. She predicted a minimum 3 percent gain for the holidays from 1992 levels.
Auto dealers' receipts rose 3.6 percent for the month while those for merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes rose 3.5 percent.
The third major durable-goods category -- furniture, home furnishings and equipment -- eased three-tenths of 1 percent after gaining eight-tenths of 1 percent in September.
Among nondurables, sales rose 2.9 percent at gasoline service stations, 1.1 percent at department stores and other places selling general merchandise, eight-tenths of 1 percent at restaurants and bars and seven-tenths of 1 percent at food stores.
Sales fell eight-tenths of 1 percent at drug and proprietary stores and two-tenths of 1 percent at apparel and accessories stores.

HEADLINE: Another Kind of Challenge;
For Many Who Don't Run, the Marathon Still Offers a Serious Contest: Marketing

 BODY:
There has been a lot of talk of finishing times and "hitting the wall." Plenty of people have speculated about the seven-figure turnout of fans.
But who has considered the 30,000 sponges? 
 The New York City Marathon has attracted 26,402 runners and their friends, and they all have had to be fed, entertained and marketed in the frenetic, yet oddly controlled manner at which New York excels.
Just mull the ramifications for the restaurants that emptied their kitchens of tons of pasta this week.
And consider other feeding frenzies. Who will address the annual problem of how to procure a bagel on First Avenue around noon tomorrow, without either being trampled by the well-toned calves of runners or being forced to wait behind the throngs of spectators who cannot decide, once they have reached the counter, between Nova Scotia salmon and lox?
The estimated gain to the city for putting on the product known as the New York City Marathon is $80.9 million. Behind all of the training and sweating there is selling, two-stepping, sweeping and pizza eating.
There are the restaurants, like Cafe Europa on 57th Street, that are offering 24-hour pasta specials. There are the hawkers who have gravitated to the Sheraton New York Hotel, where lots of runners are staying, to hand out fliers for sneaker sales.
 
A Gaggle of Actuaries
 And there is the New York Road Runners Club, the sponsor of the event, which compiled a tome of statistics on the runners so comprehensive that it boggles the mind. (Did you know that there will be 43 actuaries running this year?)
The marathon has drawn runners from every state and 100 countries, and a wee bit of each culture seems to be represented. Renee Gavin, 41, a llama farmer from Bozeman, Mont., who runs a marathon somewhere each year with her sister, trained for this race by jaunting through country roads with her livestock.
"I'm kind of partial to Marmaduke," said Mrs. Gavin, referring to her favorite llama, which is not permitted to run the race and therefore will not take first place in his class, though he apparently runs faster than any human. "He's very athletic and very gentle."
But back to excess. Could Gary Muhrcke, the winner of the first New York City Marathon in 1970, when it was confined to Central Park and offered a first prize of a cheap watch, ever have imagined that the pot for the winning male and female runner would grow to $20,000 and a Mercedes-Benz E320 sedan? (If the winner is an American, he or she will receive a $120,000 bonus.)
And surely Pheidippides, the first marathoner, who crossed the plains of Greece to announce victory over Persia, would be confounded by Borden's Elsie, the self-proclaimed marathon cow who insists on "hoofing" her way from the United Nations to Tavern on the Green during the race.
It's all about progress, really. Consider that last year, Michael Paolillo proposed marriage to Linda Harris on live television at the finish line. This year Tom Young and Pam Kezios will be married on the run, in the middle of the race.
Before the race, the biggest challenge has nothing to do with romance, but rather how to provide enough carbohydrates.
 
Loading Up on Pasta
 "We've done copious amounts of pasta," said Scott Geraghty, the executive chef at the Sheraton. "Runners have a tendency to load up a few days before the race, so we've been offering lots of pasta buffets."
Other preferred treats include bananas (the Sheraton has gone through nearly 500 pounds), bottled water, fruit juices and cereal. "We serve more oatmeal this time of year than we do all year long," Mr. Geraghty said.
When they are not eating, runners are often shopping. The Sheraton set up a maze-like Expo Gift Shop, where those who enter are immediately flanked by women with clipboards, pleased to help browsers select from the plethora of hats, videos, books, official plaques, posters, a block of T-shirts and telephone cards.
Runners are greeted at the door of the Expo with a plastic shopping bag filled with items every runner surely needs: Cracker Jacks, Advil, some fizzy bath cubes, a sample of Tic Tacs and a small can of L'Oreal's light step foam conditioner.
When it is all over, who will take care of the littered scraps of the feasts and the 30,000 discarded sponges used to mop the perspiring runners, as well as the 1.6 million paper cups and 18,000 yards of barricade tape? Browning-Ferris Industries, the waste-management company from Texas, will recycle the cups and plastic water bottles.
The city's Department of Transportation estimates that the event will cost about $30,000 to clean up, not all that large compared to, say, a ticker-tape parade.

HEADLINE: Disavow Attacks on Israelis, Clinton Warns P.L.O. Chief

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Worried about eroding Israeli public support for the accord between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization, President Clinton and Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel called on the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, to condemn recent Arab attacks on Jewish settlers, saying he was duty-bound to do so.
President Clinton planned to use the visit of the Israeli Prime Minister to the White House today to highlight a package of economic and military benefits that Washington was offering Israel, in hopes that it would make the Israeli public more comfortable with the notion of trading land for peace with Syria in the near future, and thereby widening the circle of peace. 
 Mr. Clinton promised that the United States would not cut its annual $3 billion in assistance to Israel and that it would help Israel use loan guarantees to finance the cost of Israeli troop withdrawals from Gaza and Jericho. He also said the United States was rewriting American export laws to allow Israel and other countries to buy advanced computers for military uses and that it was ready to sell Israel more military aircraft.
 
Firming Up the Accord
 But in their talks and joint news conference the two leaders dealt as much with how to consolidate the Israel-P.L.O. agreement as with prospects for widening the circle of peace around Israel.
The Israeli Army said today that it had arrested five members of Mr. Arafat's own Fatah organization from the West Bank on charges of involvement in the killing of a Jewish settler on Oct. 29.
"We consider it a great and dangerous violation of the commitment of the P.L.O.," Mr. Rabin said of the Fatah link to the attack. "In the letter that was signed by the chairman of the P.L.O. to me, he committed himself to renounce and reject terrorism. Keeping commitments is the basis for the advancement of peace. We will keep our commitments. We demand then that they keep their commitments, and to come out openly in renouncing and taking the discipline measures" to which Mr. Arafat has committed.
Mr. Clinton also endorsed this view.
"I agree with what the Prime Minister said," Mr. Clinton declared. "I think that Chairman Arafat now, under the terms of the agreement, is duty-bound at a minimum to condemn it. I think we all recognize that he may not have total control over everyone who acts in the name of Fatah, but he is now bound by the terms, the clear terms of the agreement to condemn it."
 
Concern About the Pace
 Mr. Clinton also expressed concern that Mr. Arafat has been slow to set up the economic and security institutions that the P.L.O. requires to begin implementing the agreement with Israel by a Dec. 13 deadline. But the President expressed some understanding for Mr. Arafat's plight, noting that the P.L.O. is not a state, still lacks many basic institutions and therefore is entitled to a certain degree of patience.
"I wish that the pace had been more rapid," Mr. Clinton said, "but I think it is important to recognize that the P.L.O. itself, by its very nature, by the nature of its organization and its activities over the last many, many years, has never had the responsibility of going through the mechanics that have to be discussed in this agreement. You know -- how do the lights get turned on in the morning, how is the food distributed, how are the houses built, how are these things done.
"So I think, in fairness, I would be quite concerned if I thought that the fact that we're a little bit slow in the pace here was the result of some sort of deliberate desire to undermine an accord they had just signed off on. At the present moment, I really believe it is more a function of the whole organization not being organized for or experienced in the work in which they must now engage."
While President Clinton said, "We are working on an agreement to make available a number of planes to the Israelis," Israeli officials said they still have not decided which aircraft they want. They are likely to purchase some top-of-the-line F-15E's, which have the capability to fly from Israel to Iraq or Iran, and some older F-16's being decommissioned by the United States Air Force, officials said.
President Clinton made clear that he was seriously considering Mr. Rabin's request to commute the sentence of Jonathan Pollard, who is serving a life term for spying for Israel. Mr. Pollard, a former civilian intelligence analyst for the Navy, was arrested in 1985 for passing classified information to the Israelis. The intelligence agencies and the Justice Department have been hostile to the idea of commuting the sentence of Mr. Pollard, who was paid thousands of dollars for his services by Israel. But Mr. Clinton left himself a lot of room to maneuver.
"I explained that under our procedure here, I cannot make a decision on the Pollard case until the Justice Department makes a recommendation to me," he said. "Under the U.S. Constitution, I do not have to follow the recommendation of the Justice Department, but under our procedure I have to get one. When I get one, which won't be too long in the future, I will then review it and make a decision."

HEADLINE: Family Doctors Gain a Niche in New York

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Dr. John Falencki is an anomaly in a city teeming with specialists, where patients see orthopedists for ankle sprains and neurologists for headaches. One of the few physicians in New York City with a full service family practice, Dr. Falencki's patients include 9-day-old infants and 90-year-old great-grandmothers. He does childhood immunizations, Pap smears and minor surgery.
Ten years ago Dr. Falencki would have been seen as a dinosaur doomed to extinction. But today, as health policy experts in Washington have emphasized the need for comprehensive primary care, he and others like him are regarded as a new vanguard. After years of struggling, they have gained new respect and their practices are thriving. 
 "It used to be very hard to work as a family doctor in this town, but the barriers are dropping, since all the hospitals know that they are going to need better primary care," said Dr. Falencki, who opened his practice on lower Fifth Avenue in 1980. "And my experience is that the public is very receptive. People are happy to have a doctor who takes care of all of them, not just their foot or their kidney."
There are only about a dozen board certified family doctors in broad- based private practice in Manhattan, and perhaps slightly over a dozen more in clinics in the borough, said Dr. Neil Calman, president of the Institute for Urban Family Health. But that is more than a decade ago. Although there are no reliable statistics about the number of those board certified family doctors in New York, there are signs that this type of practice is growing and gaining acceptance, both in Manhattan and in the boroughs.
Family physicians have long been popular in rural areas, whose sparse populations cannot support both an internist and a pediatrician, and where specialists are out of the question. Family physicians, whose residencies last three years, are trained in treating adults and children, and can also do small surgical procedures, including delivering babies.
But family physicians have been largely excluded from the cities, where specialists abound and where, until recently, health maintenance organizations would not hire family physicians and hospitals would not give them admitting privileges. When Dr. Falencki came to New York in 1980 after finishing a residency in Seattle, he went into private practice because he could not find a group that would hire him. He said that H.I.P., one New York City H.M.O., told him it promised patients "that their kids will see pediatricians."
That is changing, thanks to the persistence of the few family physicians in New York, as well as the fluctuating demands of the health care marketplace.
"A few trailblazers spent that last decade proving to hospitals that we practice high quality medicine," said Dr. Robert Massad, chief of the new academic department of family medicine at Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx. "But more important is that the hospitals are now on a drive for self-preservation. It has become clear that if they want to survive, to fill their beds, they're going to need a lot of primary care physicians. So hospital have had to swallow their objections."
While Dr. Falencki was the only family doctor affiliated with Beth Israel Hospital 10 years ago, today there are 20. And one by one over the last five years, more than a dozen of New York's hospitals have allowed family physicians onto their staffs. It was within the last year that Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan and Einstein established departments of family practice. By next year, both will have active family-practice training programs with the goal of turning out family doctors for urban care.
New York and other urban centers in the Northeast have lagged far behind cities elsewhere in the country in embracing family practice. On the West Coast, even the most prominent academic medical schools, like the University of California at San Francisco and the University of Washington, have strong departments of family practice and turn out many doctors in the field.
Family physicians differ from the old-time general practitioners in their years of specialized training and in the array of services they can provide to patients of all ages. General practitioners, who typically had only one year of training after medical school, usually saw only adults and have no proficiency in some of the new minor surgical procedures that family physicians can do.
The actual number of doctors qualified to practice comprehensive family medicine in New York is difficult to tally, since many of the doctors who describe themselves as "family physicians" in medical directories are not board certified or limit their practice to adults.
Dr. Calman predicted that the family physicians would be crucial to providing health care for the inner city, because they are so self-sufficient and can do many of the procedures that specialists are eager to provide to the well insured. But, he added, a family doctor can also be an attractive option for the middle class and the rich, since families who would usually visit half a dozen doctors to tend to their medical needs could consolidate care with one physician who knows them well.
"This is not just a model of care that works just for poor people or people who live in remote places," Dr. Calman said. "We have people practicing on Fifth Avenue and their offices are mobbed as well."
 
An Inhospitable Environment
 Claire Watson, whose husband and 5-month-old son also see Dr. Falencki and his partner, Dr. Jerry Clements, said: "When doctors are seeing the whole family there's a kind of continuity that really nice. They're generalists in the best sense, trained in all areas, and that's been extremely helpful." She said that the doctors helped manage her recent pregnancy and took care of skin problems that would previously have sent her to a dermatologist.
The dearth of family physicians in New York City has a lot to do with the traditionally inhospitable environment, particularly in Manhattan. Although most of the borough's smaller hospitals, like Beth Israel and St. Luke's-Roosevelt, now allow family doctors on their staffs, its large academic medical centers -- Columbia Presbyterian, New York Hospital, Mount Sinai Medical Center and New York University Medical Center -- do not, although some are reviewing that decision.
What is more, none of Manhattan's medical schools have departments of family practice or residencies in the field. As a result, they have perennially turned out fewer family practice doctors than any others in the country. Last year, Cornell University Medical College had none, New York University had one, Columbia had three and Mount Sinai School of Medicine, six. The Institute for Family Urban Health is aggressively recruiting medical students at Manhattan's medical schools, in the hopes of increasing output.
A few large hospitals in the other boroughs, like Montefiore in the Bronx and Downstate in Brooklyn, have had small family practice programs for more than a decade.
Medical students in New York City say they are dissuaded from entering the field by the lack of role models, leaving them with the feeling that family practice is irrelevant to urban life.
During the last 20 years a few doctors have successfully braved this hostile terrain. Dr. Steve Tamarin practices on West 81st Street in Manhattan, where he sees 2,000 patients. "I feel like a small town doctor on the Upper West Side," he said. "In some families I have four generations under my care."
"It had always been said that you couldn't open a family practice here, that people would prefer a specialist, that you couldn't get hospital privileges, but I always thought it would fly," he said.
Although he initially opened shop on the Upper East Side, he feels his practice is more suited to his current location: "This is a real neighborhood, everyone knows everyone else, and I get many of my referrals through word of mouth."
In addition to routine visits for children and adults, Dr. Tamarin does several office procedures, including skin biopsies; fiber-optic examinations of the colon to detect early cancer, and minor surgery to remove precancerous growths on the cervix.
 
Work With Specialists
 Dr. Tamarin and other family doctors say they offer only those procedures they feel competent to perform, and say they request specialists when they are in over their heads. For example, Dr. Falencki said that while he handles outpatient pediatrics on his own, he sometimes consults pediatricians when young patients are hospitalized.
Advocates for family practice say that family doctors will be crucial to improving health in poor urban neighborhoods,
The Institute for Urban Family Health, which is setting up a family practice residency with Beth Israel Hospital, has already established one at Bronx-Lebanon Medical Center, which has been turning out 10 family doctors a year since 1989.
To encourage graduates to stay in the neighborhood, the institute has set up several small group practices in the south Bronx, where the doctors work for competitive salaries.
The Bronx-Lebanon program, he said, tried to insure that its doctors could provide all the services the community needed. For example, he said, in New York's poorer neighborhoods there is a great shortage of gynecologists to treat women with abnormal Pap smears who are on Medicaid or are uninsured. Abnormal tests must be followed with a procedure called colposcopy in which the doctor takes a closer look at the cervix for signs of cancer and, if that test is abnormal, does minor office surgery to shave off abnormal cells. All of the doctors trained at Bronx-Lebanon can do a colposcopy, he said.
Dr. Calman said that the family practice doctors affiliated with the institute would soon be learning to do abortions, because this simple office procedure can be difficult for poor women to obtain.
"In rural areas there are geographic access problems, but here there are economic access problems or language access problems and the results are the same," Dr. Calman said. "If you have no insurance or don't speak English, you can wait three months in this city to get follow-up for an abnormal Pap test and that's crazy."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Painful Lessons for Mexican Labor

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PUEBLA, Mexico, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Standing almost in the shadow of Mexico's twin volcanoes, long lines of new Volkswagen Beetles -- remarkably unchanged from those sold in waves in the United States until the 1970's -- give an impression of steadiness and continuity.
But that belies the turmoil that has shaken Volkswagen de Mexico over the last year and may be a precursor to the painful transition that all Mexican businesses are about to undergo, with or without a North American Free Trade Agreement. 
 Last year, VW, which had the most inefficient car plant in Mexico, went through a bitter strike over a new contract, followed by a 43-day lockout that ended with the dismissal of all 15,000 union employees. Most were rehired, but only after they agreed not to press legal actions against the auto maker and to accept Japanese-style work rules and pay scales based on productivity and not seniority.
 In Mexico, the lockout has become a labor watershed because of the way it was handled by Volkswagen and by Mexico's federal Government, which backed VW's hard-line approach by declaring the strike illegal and sending in police officers with shotguns to deter any violence. Union leaders and labor rights experts in the United States have pointed to the strike to explain their opposition to the trade pact, saying it demonstrates that Mexican labor laws do not protect workers and their right to strike.
Volkswagen officials say the dispute stemmed from a split in the leadership of the union, with one side agreeing to make the pay and work rule changes and the other objecting. But no matter how painful or costly, the battle was necessary if the German company was to compete successfully in an open Mexican economy, they said. And they say that where VW has gone, most other companies will someday have to follow.
"We didn't have a very competitive labor contract with our people," said Juan Manuel Rodriguez Jado, who came in as president of Volkswagen de Mexico last spring, eight months after the lockout ended. "Changing that was an unprecedented move, and I think we paid dearly for being the pioneers."
Volkswagen, with the approval of the Government, locked out and then dismissed all assembly-line workers who walked out of the plant and camped outside in protest over the changes in work rules and wage structure. Then, after the Government sided with the company, VW offered to rehire all of those who renounced the dissident union leaders who had led the walkout. Carlos Fernandez de Real, a legal adviser to the dissidents, said 2,000 workers were not rehired because they followed the dissidents.
"The Government was at fault," Mr. Fernandez said. "The workers just wanted to elect their own representatives. You can't do that in Mexico. It was a ferocious repression."
The role of Government in the Volkswagen strike is important, said Huberto Juarez Nunez, a researcher at the Workers University of Mexico, because it shows the weakness of Mexican labor laws and the degree to which unions here are apt to side with management, under pressure from the Government, over the interest of their members. Mexican officials saw Volkswagen as a crucial step in the transformation of the auto industry, and they sent a clear message to workers at other plants about accepting Japanese-style work rules.
Once the new rules were in place, the start-up was rocky and months passed before the factory managed to build a car that it could ship.
 
 
Bad Time for a Strike
 During the 43-day lockout, VW may have lost as much as $2 million a day. Worse is that the strike came just as VW was preparing to build its first new Golf and Jetta designs in several years, cars that it hoped would lift its flagging share of the United States market. By the time workers finally returned, they not only had to learn how to build the new models, but how to work in the newly formed teams.
That delayed delivery of the cars for nine months, leaving long-suffering VW dealers in the United States with little to sell.
Having slid from strength to near disappearance in the crucial United States automotive market, Volkswagen has hitched its hopes for recovery to the 28-year-old plant in Puebla, about 80 miles southeast of Mexico City. Until August, when Brazil resumed limited production, Puebla was the only plant in the world still producing the Beetle. The factory also produces redesigned Golfs and Jettas, small stylish cars that are sold around the world.
Joaquin Vasquez, 34, has worked at the plant for 10 years. He lives in Puebla, as do most of the 14,000 VW workers. He has worked many jobs on the assembly line, but now he is part of a team that assembles a large part of the dashboards of Jettas.
"The changes are good, I think, but they could have come a bit more slowly," he said. "It's hard for some of us to adjust."
The team concept is a direct result of last year's labor problems. In a country where unions have a great deal of political clout, VW's independent union was among the largest and most powerful. As last year's contract was being negotiated, most workers thought the big struggle would be over wages. A 35-hour strike at the beginning of July 1992 helped to bring wages up 20 percent, to an average of $15 a day, among the highest in Mexico.
But the new contract restructured the way work would be done. VW wanted to join the most advanced auto companies, who are following Japanese lean-production systems. Workers would do more than one job and would work in teams.
Company executives say they held meetings, some lasting more than 18 hours, with 182 union delegates to negotiate the work rule changes. But a group of union members, including officials who had lost control of the union a few months before, asserted that provisions calling for the rule changes had been kept secret from the rank and file.
Hence, thousands of workers refused to work and staged a sit-down protest outside in July 1992, just a few days after the new contract had been signed. VW officials contended that since the union had already signed a contract, the strike was illegal. Moreover, they said, it was really a conflict between the two union factions.
"It looked like a bunker," said Mr. Juarez Nunez, who taught at the University of Puebla during the strike.
 Mr. Rodriguez, the VW president, says he thinks the plant is more efficient and the quality of the cars is improving. VW says that if the free-trade agreement is approved, it will be able to meet a content requirement of 62.5 percent North American parts, because more than 55 percent of the value of its parts purchases now come from the United States, Canada or Mexico.
Mr. Rodriguez, who worked for VW in Argentina and Spain before coming to Mexico, called the strike "an old and painful story" that he would rather not dwell on.
This past summer, a contract was negotiated under the new work rules. Workers received productivity bonuses and there was no violence.
Fausto Lara Paisano, a union leader, said the last year had been among the most difficult of his 14 years at Volkswagen. "But tensions are starting to disappear," Mr. Lara said. "The workers have a little more confidence now because the biggest changes have already been made and they start to see that everything maybe can turn out all right."
