HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD;
Little Voices Roar in the Chorus of Trade-Pact Foes

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
President Clinton has been going after Big Labor for orchestrating a campaign against the North American Free Trade Agreement.
But Big Labor, meaning the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s bureaucracy in Washington and most of the 33 union presidents who lead it, is the least of his problems. 
 For all its lobbying, petition drives and $3.2 million in billboard and radio advertising, the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations maintains that it is the people in the hinterlands -- and, interestingly, many of them in nonunion jobs -- who are driving the effort. Among loose, grass-root coalitions of workers, farmers, small-business people, the clergy, civil rights groups and environmentalists, the trade agreement is stirring local passions as never before.
For example, nonunion garment workers in Georgia are putting pressure on Representative George Darden, a Democrat, to oppose the trade pact. Other Congress members are facing similar pressure from farmers and business people in Minnesota and from citrus and vegetable growers in Florida. In San Francisco, where most garment workers are nonunion, they have joined union members and even some contractors to defeat the accord.
 
A 'Bottom Up' Issue
 "This is one of those issues that is bottom up," said Mark Anderson, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s director of trade affairs. From thousands of local unions, he said he had been swamped with requests for information about the pact. "We have probably sent out more material on Nafta than on any other issue, ever," he said.
Jose Alvarez, political director of the 143,000-member Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, said: "The nerve center is the American people. American men and women see the Government in one scheme after another that gets rid of their jobs."
To the extent that the drive against the trade accord is being orchestrated, one leader is the agreement's chief opponent in Congress, Representative David E. Bonior, the Michigan Democrat who is the majority whip. Grass-root opponents mainly rely on him for head counts in Congress. Another is the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s biggest union, the 1.3 million-member International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which has far out-pamphleted and out-demonstrated all other unions.
But the main coordinator of the effort is a tiny lobby here, the Citizens Trade Campaign, which operates out of a one-room office with a staff of six and a budget of $400,000 this year. Of its 41 supporting organizations, 13 are labor unions
 
Other Foes of Pact
 Among the other chief opponents are United We Stand America group, the political party formed by Ross Perot; the Sierra Club; Greenpeace and Friends of the Earth; the National Farmers Union; the National Council of Senior Citizens; Ralph Nader's Public Citizen; Jerry Brown's We the People, and Jesse Jackson's Rainbow Coalition. Some of these groups, like retirees and small farmers, have credibility among Republican legislators, which the A.F.L.-C.I.O. lacks.
But it is the Citizens Trade Campaign, with offices in 47 states, that has been doing much of the organizing. State and regional captains, most on loan from citizen groups, are organizing parades, speeches and visits to legislators' home offices. Jim Jontz, the director of the campaign, an Indiana Democrat who is a former House member, says most of his work involves advising local campaigns and providing speakers for demonstrations.
"We are not the A.F.L., and they are not us," he said. "Our campaign is the base of the Democratic Party. People see this very much about whether they're going to have control over their communities or leave it to corporate board rooms."
Frank Jackalone of Public Citizen, who has been leading the drive against the pact with groups in six Southern states, said the region's economy had blossomed with the relocation of Northern and Midwestern industries. But he said workers now saw the agreement as likely to hasten the exodus of those industries to Mexico.
In recent years, Mr. Alvarez said, workers have seen cut-and-sew apparel companies move to Mexico. "Pack a sewing machine in a box and you move a factory," he said. He said the trade accord would give industry confidence to invest heavily in high technology there.
Because unions have organized little of the Southern textile industry, some members of Congress there say they are rarely lobbied by labor leaders. But they see plenty of the new coalitions.
"The opposition, and the workers who are in greatest peril in my district, apparel and textile workers, are nonunion," said Mr. Darden, a Democrat from Marietta, Ga., who said he was leaning against the agreement. "It seems quite spontaneous."
In Minnesota, a strong union state, Representative David Minge, a Democrat, had heard many other voices before deciding a few days ago to oppose the agreement. He received a petition, signed by 33 farmers and business people, from Bud's Place, a cafe in the village of Gluek. "We would like you to vote 'no' on Nafta," it said. "We do not believe selling our rural America is the proper thing to do."
Mr. Minge said, "That kind of response was important to me."
Mr. Minge also heard from the Minnesota Fair Trade Coalition, the local branch of Mr. Jontz's group. "All our effort was focused on Minge for a couple of months," said Larry Weiss, the local captain.
Republican fence-sitters are also hearing from local opponents. For instance, Representative Dan Miller of Sarasota, Fla., said he had been contacted most by citrus and vegetable farmers in his predominantly agricultural district. "Perot got 23 percent of the vote in my district," Mr. Miller said of the Presidential race last year. "There are not a lot of people who feel strongly in favor of Nafta. There are a lot who feel strongly opposed."
Within the labor movement, the campaign against the accord extends far beyond the industrial unions that have been most directly affected by jobs' moving to Mexico. "Our self-interest is very similar," said Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers. When factories close, he said, community tax revenues plunge, so teachers lose wages and jobs.
 
Drive to Oust Backers
 Local union leaders and their nonunion allies, and not just Mr. Perot, are threatening to purge Congress of members who support the agreement.
Dominic Chan is an organizer for the West Coast garment workers and a member of the coalition opposing the pact. Only 1,600 of the San Francisco Bay area's 20,000 garment workers are union members, but they and even some garment companies that cannot afford to move have joined Mr. Chan in fighting the accord.
In next year's Congressional elections, he said, the workers will try to oust legislators who favor the accord. One is Mr. Chan's representative in Congress, Nancy Pelosi, a Democrat. "We're going to oppose her," he said. "We're going to find a serious candidate to run against her."
John P. Morris, who leads 140,000 workers as the top teamsters official in Pennsylvania, a highly unionized state, said he would support whoever ran against legislators who favored the accord. "We will take up a collection to get that Congressman a ticket on a bus to Mexico," he said.
To be sure, most top union officials plan to make peace, regardless of how next week's vote on the pact turns out, so they and the Administration can work together on issues like health care. "We disagree on this single issue, and that's it," Thomas R. Donahue, the federation's secretary-treasurer, told a news conference Wednesday.
But pass or fail, other opponents of the agreement say, the struggle is likely to cast a long political shadow.
Every time a factory departs for Mexico, Mr. Jackalone said, "Clinton is going to get hell."

HEADLINE: Good Retail Sales Data Help Dow Climb 22.08

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Propelled by another report of good economic news, the stock market bounded ahead yesterday in a rally led by issues that have foundered for much of the year.
Investors flocked to forest-products, tobacco and other cyclical stocks, whose earnings are sensitive to the pace of the recovery. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 22.08 points, to 3,684.51 in heavy trading, bolstered by Philip Morris, up 2 1/2, to 59 1/4;, International Paper, up 1 1/2, to 65 7/8, and Woolworth, up 1, to 22 1/8. For the week, the Dow rose 41.08 points.
The Dow Jones transportation average, which has broken several records in the last month, hit another high. It shot up 17.09 points, to 1,752.07, surpassing its closing of 1,742.24 set on Nov. 1. Its standouts included UAL, up 1 5/8, to 148 3/8; AMR, up 1 1/4, to 71, and Burlington Northern, up 1 1/2, to 56 1/2.
The market got a jolt of energy yesterday after the Government reported that retail spending rose 1.5 percent in October. Moreover, the National Association of Realtors said housing demand was growing because of low mortgage rates. The announcements were interpreted by many investors as a sign of a strengthening economy.
And the bond market, which has slumped in recent weeks in response to good economic news, held steady, propping up stock prices. Some analysts have noted in recent weeks that rising bond yields might encourage some investors to switch to fixed-rate securities from stocks.
"If this stock market is to continue making new highs, then it has to be led by the cyclicals," said John H. Shaughnessy, a senior vice president at Advest Inc. "We are beyond the stage where this market is going to be driven by the prospect of lower interest rates. We are into the second phase, the earnings- and dividend-driven phase."
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 326.2 million shares, up from 287.1 million shares on Thursday. Advancing issues led declining issues by about 3 to 2.
Among the broad indicators, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 2.75 points, to 465.39. The American Stock Exchange composite index increased 1.62 points, to 479.60. And the Nasdaq composite index edged up 0.34 point, to 779.32.
The Dow Jones utilities average, which had slumped to a 10-month low on Thursday, rebounded slightly yesterday, closing up 0.98 point, to 224.95.
A report that shipments for linerboard products grew in October and recommendations from several analysts helped paper stocks, which have suffered for much of the year.
Besides International Paper, Federal Paper Board rose 1, to 23 3/8; Temple-Inland shot up 4 3/8, to 50 1/8; Stone Container increased 1 3/8, to 10 1/8; Weyerhaeuser was up 1, to 44 3/8, and Georgia-Pacific surged 3 5/8, to 73 7/8.
Tobacco stocks continued their hot streak after Philip Morris and American Brands told distributors that they were raising prices about 4 cents a pack. Besides Philip Morris, RJR Nabisco edged up 1/8, to 7; American Brands shot up 1, to 35 3/8, and UST rose 1 1/2 to 27 1/2.
Among other issues, Dreyfus rose 3 5/8, to 46 1/4 after it was upgraded by Oppenheimer & Company. Takeover rumors have swirled around Dreyfus in recent days. Caterpillar fell 1 1/8, to 89 1/4, after thousands of its workers in two states walked off the job, angered by the suspension of a union representative.
In Nasdaq trading, Vital Signs plunged 6 1/2, to 13 3/4, after Prudential Securities reduced its recommendation on the stock. And Boston Chicken, the most successful initial public offering in years, continued its slide, falling 2 1/4, to 39 3/4. When the stock began trading on Tuesday, it promptly skyrocketed to 48 1/2, more than double its initial offering price of $20 a share.
In Tokyo, Japanese stocks rose yesterday, rebounding from the sharp declines of the last two weeks. The Nikkei average of 225 issues gained 335.03 points, or 1.85 percent, to close at 18,493.55.

HEADLINE: Bonds Rebound From Early Selloff

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Treasury bond market rebounded strongly yesterday, recovering from an early selloff set off by the Government's report of a surge in October retail sales.
By the end of the day, the price of the Treasury's 30-year bond jumped 23/32 of a point, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, tumbled to 6.15 percent, from 6.20 percent on Wednesday. 
 The bond market was closed Thursday for Veterans Day.
In early trading, bond prices had fallen as much as 20/32 after the Commerce Department reported that retail sales rose 1.5 percent in October, the biggest gain in six months. The surge was led by the automotive sector but was broad-based.
Analysts said the Government report had initially raised concern that economic growth could aggravate inflation pressures, which can reduce the value of bonds. But the market reversed course after buyers emerged to take advantage of the cheaper bond prices. In addition, analysts said that many investors had taken a second look at the retail report and decided it was not so bearish for bonds after all.
 
Higher Prices in the Picture
 Marilyn Schaja, money market economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, said that much of the 1.5 percent increase in retail receipts resulted from higher consumer prices, not greater sales.
For example, sales soared 2.9 percent at gasoline stations, but a large part of that was a 4.3-cent-a-gallon increase in the Federal excise tax on gasoline, which took effect Oct. 1.
Also contributing to skepticism about the economy's strength was a University of Michigan consumer confidence survey; that index fell to 82.0, from 82.7 in October, according to financial market participants who saw the results.
But there was doubt that the bond market could sustain its upward trend after its dramatic plunge of recent weeks, touched off by worries that the long-running bull market was nearing an end.
"I don't think we've now gone into a renewed bull market by any means," said Alan Levenson, money market economist at the UBS Securities unit of Union Bank of Switzerland. "I don't know if today's action tells us anything."
Prices of short-term Treasuries were 3/32 to 5/32 of a point higher, while intermediate maturities rose 9/32to 10/32 of a point. The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, rose 3.01, to 1,311.36.
The discount rates on Treasury bills slipped. The rate on three-month bills fell one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, to 3.09 percent. The discount rate on six-month bills dropped three basis points, to 3.22 percent, and the rate on one-year bills fell one basis point, to 3.37 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 102 11/32 , up 2/32 from late Wednesday. The average yield to maturity was unchanged at 5.60 percent.

HEADLINE: Housing Resale Prices Rose in 3d Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
Demand spurred by low mortgage rates drove up prices of previously owned homes in the third quarter, particularly in smaller inland parts of the nation.
The National Association of Realtors said today that "second tier" markets were thriving in much of the West, Midwest and South from July through September, compared with the similar period of 1992. 
 The median price jumped 6 percent in the South, to $97,400, and 5.2 percent in the Midwest, to $85,700. Both regions were hurt less and recovered earlier from the recession.
California, whose economy remains depressed, limited the overall appreciation in the West, which posted a 1 percent loss despite double-digit gains in some areas. The median price in the region was $143,100.
Prices in the Northeast, which has been slow to recover, slumped 2.2 percent, to $140,400.
"Sales of less-expensive homes have been the big force behind many markets," said the association's president, William S. Chee. "Over the past quarter, the lower-priced segment of the market has continued to draw the most buyers."
Mr. Chee said the lowest mortgage rates in two decades had increased demand in the lower price ranges, by allowing more first-time buyers to enter the market.
The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation has reported that mortgages averaged 6.91 percent last month.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Prices Retreat as Traders Discount Talk of Cutbacks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Crude oil prices retreated yesterday, giving back half of Thursday's gains, as traders dismissed speculation that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries might be preparing to reduce its output.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for December delivery fell 18 cents, to $16.72. December heating oil dropped 0.17 cent, to 51.61 cents a gallon, and December unleaded gasoline lost 0.94 cent, to 45.37 cents a gallon, its lowest in five years. 
 "Nothing has changed" in the downward trend of oil prices, which have fallen more than 10 percent in a month, said Tom Bentz of Quantum Financial in New York.
But prices jumped more than 2 percent on Thursday amid speculation that Saudi Arabia, OPEC's largest producer, would push for a production cutback at the group's next meeting, on Nov. 23. OPEC's production ceiling, set at 24.52 million barrels a day in September, is too high, traders said.
A senior official at Saudi Aramco in Riyadh called production cutback reports "rumors and speculation."
OPEC produces about 37 percent of the world's oil supply. Rising non-OPEC output and weaker-than-expected demand have sent prices down. In addition, Iraq is to begin talks with the United Nations Monday about ending economic sanctions against it, including the oil embargo. Iraq's return to the market could add 1.5 million barrels a day to already glutted markets, traders said.
On other commodity markets, coffee prices fell sharply for the second session. Traders are disappointed that Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer, has bought only 10 percent of the coffee it agreed to buy in an effort to push up prices.
On the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, coffee for December delivery dropped 2.10 cents, to 72.90 cents a pound, its lowest in a month.
Brazil agreed in September to participate in a plan to retain 20 percent of its own coffee exports in warehouses until prices rose above 75 cents a pound but is not buying enough, said Judy Ganes, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slips Despite Report Of a Pickup in Retail Sales

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday, slipping to a four-week low against the Japanese yen, as traders shrugged off positive economic news and focused on next week's uncertain Congressional vote on the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The dollar usually gets support from signs of an improving American economy, but a Commerce Department report showing the strongest pickup in retail sales in six months failed to push up the currency. 
 "Traders are not that confident about holding positions ahead of Nafta," Carlo Ceresa, foreign exchange manager at Credit Commerciale de France, said of the House vote scheduled for Wednesday. "As we get nearer, it will affect positions more and more."
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said yesterday that the Administration was within 10 votes of the 218 needed in the House. But the pact faces strong opposition in Congress and from organized labor.
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 105.65 yen, from 106.40 on Thursday. It also dropped to 1.6845 German marks from 1.6931.
 
Dealers Still Bullish
 Gold prices also fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery lost $2.80, to $373.60 an ounce.
Despite the dollar's weaker tone, dealers still maintain bullish forecasts for it, given recent signs of economic growth. Some said it had to retrace before heading higher.
"We're definitely seeing improvement on the economic front," a New York bank dealer said. "But if the dollar's going to get to 1.75 marks, we're going to have to see more of a retracement to build a base beneath."
Furthermore, some dealers expect the Bank of Japan to support the dollar if it falls much further because a weaker dollar would hurt Japanese exporters.
The British pound closed in New York at $1.4937, up from $1.4760 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Thursday's quotes, included: 1.4870 Swiss francs, down from 1.4980; 5.8650 French francs, down from 5.9000; 1,652 Italian lire, down from 1,657, and $1.3133 (Canadian), down from $1.3152.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Employee Pension Plans Can Suffer From Neglect

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty

 BODY:
WHEN R. Theodore Benna happened upon an obscure paragraph in the tax code 13 years ago, he made a discovery that would drastically alter pension planning in America.
"I had no idea" how big it would become, Mr. Benna, then a little-known benefits consultant in Bucks County, Pa., said in a recent interview. His discovery -- section 401(k) -- led to a type of pension plan that has since attracted hundreds of billions of dollars in employee retirement savings. By the year 2000, these worker-financed plans -- the fastest-growing of defined-contribution pensions -- will be America's "largest source of personal wealth," Mr. Benna predicts. 
 But 401(k)'s have an image problem. As the millions of employees who get memos on the subject this fall will vouch, the plans are boring.
Investing can be full of excitement, from the nail-biting of an initial stock offer to the dropped jaws of market-roiling news from abroad. But 401(k)'s -- basic investments, regularly made, for, yawn, retirement -- are about as sexy as their name. If they were food, they'd be potatoes; if they were shoes, they'd be sensible.
What's more, the plans need some getting used to. Take employees. Instead of just collecting the monthly checks issued under traditional defined-benefit pensions, workers must decide if and how much to contribute to these plans and then select and monitor the investments.
For some, it's an unaccustomed role -- and it shows.
A plan's investing options might include a money market fund, a bond fund and a stock fund. But a 1993 survey by John Hancock Financial Services found that almost half of 401(k) participants thought money market funds contained stocks and bonds. Only a quarter knew that declining interest rates signaled the best time to buy bond funds.
These false impressions surface as bad investment choices. More than half of the plans' assets are in conservative investments -- like money markets or guaranteed investment contracts -- that may not grow fast enough to support a retirement, Mr. Benna said.
But the really bad news is that only 17 million of the 24 million workers eligible for the plans participate.
"They're by far the best deals out there," said W. Boyd Griffin, president of Retirement Advisors Inc., a Hearst Corporation venture. Besides deferring taxes on both contributions and earnings until retirement, most plan participants can get matching funds from their employers. "The most common match is 50 cents on the dollar up to 3 percent of annual income," Mr. Griffin said.
Thus, even if a worker opts for an investment yielding 3 percent, matching may lift his first-year's "return" to a whopping 54.5 percent, counting interest on the match.
Even when they do participate, "people aren't putting in enough," Mr. Benna said. Although some restrictions apply to salaries above about $64,000, many workers can contribute about 15 percent of annual income up to a maximum this year of $8,994. The average annual contribution is 4 percent of income.
Of course, some people cannot afford to contribute; indeed, participation rates rise sharply with income. In many companies, workers can rely on traditional pensions, profit-sharing and other programs. In estimating their retirement needs, workers should count all income sources.
Employers also have new roles to play in the 401(k) world, and some, like their employees, are stumbling. (Most companies have been deft, however, in grasping the worker-financing aspect of the plans.)
With 401(k)'s, a company must decide what options to offer and must select a bank, insurer, broker or mutual fund company to run the plan and furnish the investment vehicles.
"Early on, a lot of plans didn't have many investment choices, and they had high fees, paid either by the participants or by the employer," said Kurt Brouwer, president of Brouwer & Janachowski, investment advisers in San Francisco. "Some companies just had a C.D. at their local bank."
Employees should scrutinize their plan's fees and investment options. They should check out the plan manager's resources, too; many large ones offer 401(k) newsletters, like Fidelity's Stages and Scudder's focus.
If employees don't like the company plan, "they should tell their human resources people," Mr. Benna said. Many employers may be responsive. Under voluntary Labor Department guidelines effective in January, companies can gain some liability protection for poorly performing investments if their plans satisfy rules on the number and variety of investing options, periods when employees can switch investments and so on.
Employees should also ask their companies to look into the latest wrinkle in 401(k) education: independent advice. Commonly, the institution that manages the assets also designs the plan and educates the employees. When the purveyor of the investments is also the plan designer and educator, "the fox may be watching the chicken coop," Mr. Griffin said.
Last August, such suspicions led Mr. Griffin to introduce 401(k) Dimensions, a quarterly newsletter sold to employers for distribution to employees. Standard & Poor's also publishes an independent newsletter, Your Financial Future, which goes to 500,000 people.
Perhaps to atone for all the confusion he has caused, Mr. Benna recently started the 401(k) Association forplan participants. The annual $35 fee buys a retirement-planning workbook, the S.& P newsletter and other resources. (800) 320-401K
Most important, don't procrastinate. Read the pile of 401(k) memos consigned to the far corner of the desk. Like cleaning out the closet or shining one's shoes, dealing with Mr. Benna's discovery is boring -- but increasingly necessary.

HEADLINE: Observer;
The Short-Run America

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
The bleak side of capitalism is the ruin it leaves behind after, having worked its magic, it moves on. Backers of the North American Free Trade Agreement are naturally reluctant to dwell on this gritty historical fact, yet there is something cruel, offensive and faintly dishonest in their argument that any pain felt by the working classes will be only a "short-run" experience.
The argument comes easily to people with the financial security required to live in the "long run." Corporate America and the Washington establishment, both ardent for this agreement, consist of people who can afford to wait for the year of Jubilee. 
 For working stiffs, however, life is lived in the "short run." The rent is due at the end of the month, the grocery money every Friday. Politicians, tycoons and media stars exhorting such people to ponder the comforts to come in the "long run" can only sound like hypocrites or visitors from another planet.
The truth most likely is that the agreement will indeed bring benefits in the long run to something called "society," which will include the comfortable people now hot for free trade. History, both modern and antique, suggests that it will also bring a great deal of ruin to the people who now fear losing their jobs.
Besides trying to sell the empty notion that everything will work out in a long run that is meaningless to many working people, advocates of the agreement should also be thinking of ways to deal with some of the ruin inescapable for short-run people.
An unpleasant characteristic of capitalism is the ruination it periodically creates: ruined landscapes, ruined societies, ruined people. Since capitalism is the national dish, we ought to be aware of this dark side of its nature so we can be ready to soften its nastiest results as it rollicks from place to place, first doling out money prodigiously, then suddenly skipping town and leaving a wasteland behind.
In this fashion it made England rich with the Industrial Revolution and introduced a century of human misery. In America it has left ruined New England mill towns, a "rust belt" of ruined steel towns, ruined railroad towns from one end of the continent to the other and, most recently with more to come, ruined auto towns like Flint, Mich.
Mining has left the ruined landscapes of West Virginia and Kentucky, the real-estate boom has left the ruined farmlands of the lush Piedmont, the miraculous chemical industry has left ruined flora and fauna, and the auto industry has left a ruined sky and a junkyard ruin in every other town in America.
State capitalism is now showing that it too can turn boom to ruin. For details, see Joan Didion's recent New Yorker article about the ruin of the California town that lived high and fat until military-spending cuts shut off the Pentagon's money to McDonnell Douglas that had made it boom.
The problems created when capitalism visits these periodic ruins upon us include despair, anger, misery, hatreds, social upheaval and the rise of new political ideas, some dangerously crackpot, others as dangerously intellectual as Karl Marx's Communism, one result of the ruins of the industrial revolution.
Some sort of dangerous economic disturbance is obviously in progress. American labor is being priced out of jobs by East Asian workers who will do the same work for less. American retailers now fill their racks with low-priced clothing made by sweated child labor in South Asia.
Even more alarming is the recent trend in industry's extensive firings: first, blue-collar workers, then white-collar people, then lower-level technicians, and now middle- and upper- management people. Some say this is the work of the computer, which enables industry to keep production high while drastically cutting employment.
In brief, the people who say it's a new world and we'd better face it quickly have a point. Unfortunately, they are not being honest about the price many people will have to pay. In this computerized world they don't even talk much about maybe retraining old-timers who are potential losers to use computers. This isn't surprising; our schools don't even prepare many young people to qualify for employment in this new cybernetic America.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Mexican Mine Interest On the Block

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

 BODY:
Asarco Inc., a major American mining company, said yesterday that it expected to be able to sell a portion of its stake in Grupo Mexico, one of the largest mining and mineral producers in the world, when that company joined the ranks of at least 30 other Mexican concerns whose shares are now traded on United States exchanges.
The Mexican concern, whose full name is Grupo Industrial Minera Mexico, S.A. de C.V., plans an international offering in the near future, although the company and Asarco executives declined to specify on what exchange the shares would be traded. At present, Grupo Mexico shares are only traded on Mexico's stock exchange, the Bolsa. 
 Asarco closed yesterday at $20.50 a share, up $1.25 in light trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
Grupo Mexico's international offering will take place after Grupo Mexico absorbs a privately held subsidiary, known as Medimsa, which comprises all of Grupo Mexico's assets. Medimsa is now 28 percent owned by Asarco, based in New York. Asarco's book value for the interest in Medimsa is about $300 million.
 
Asarco to Own a 23% Share
 After the merger, Asarco will own 23 percent, or about 158.7 million shares, of Grupo Mexico's total 690 million shares outstanding, said Gerald F. Corbett, an Asarco spokesman.
Asarco declined to say how much of its Grupo Mexico stake it might sell.
Recently, metal prices have been depressed as consumption has declined during the worldwide recession. Some analysts expect slight increases in demand for metals in 1994.
Asarco has had Mexican mining interests since its founding in 1899. But Asarco has lost money during the four previous quarters and its Mexican mines have not paid a dividend since 1988, Mr. Corbett of Asarco said.
"They've had an illiquid investment for a while," said Wayne Atwell, a metals analyst for Morgan Stanley. Medimsa's copper mine near the Arizona border needs millions of dollars in investment to improve its efficiency, he said. Asarco "didn't want to put the cash in."
 
Chairman Voices Optimism
 In an interview, Richard de J. Osborne, Asarco's chairman, said he expected that Asarco's remaining stake would rise in value since Grupo Mexico would be able to tap other sources of capital and perhaps retire some of its $1 billion in debt.
Medimsa is Mexico's largest mining company and last year produced 242,000 tons of minerals such as copper, lead, zinc, silver, gold and molybdenum. Its two copper mines, which were purchased from the Mexican Government since 1988, have substantial reserves.
Last year, Grupo Mexico had earnings of $123 million on sales of $905 million.
Ten of Mexico's stocks trade as American depository receipts on the New York Stock Exchange, including Telefonos de Mexico , the Mexican phone company. An additional 20 companies' shares are traded over the counter, according to the Mexico Investment Board.

HEADLINE: THE IMPACT: The Elderly;
Those With Large Bills See Aid in Clinton Plan

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
Millions of older Americans share the problem of paying for expensive prescription drugs and long-term care at home. The Clinton health care plan includes three broad provisions that are likely to be special boons for them.
*It would create a prescription drug benefit, under which those eligible for Medicare would pay an extra $8 a month, and in return the Government would pay for most of their medications, after a $250 deductible. 
 *It would provide some money for long-term home care for disabled people who need help with daily tasks like eating, dressing and bathing, or for those with serious mental impairments.
*It would assure health insurance for those who retire early, and do not become eligible for Medicare until they turn 65.
"People's first reaction to this plan may be confusion or being overwhelmed, but once they sort through it, they're going to see that it's got some substantial benefits," said John Rother, the legislative director of the American Association of Retired Persons.
It is no accident that the Clinton Administration, desperate to win the allegiance of the elderly -- and the powerful advocacy groups that represent them -- has produced a plan that should appeal to older people.
The new drug benefit would be a great help to people like Howard Rosenzweig, 77, who, considering his diabetes, his heart condition and other medical problems, spends more than $200 a month on medications. As he says, the rising cost of prescription drugs, coupled with the low interest rates his savings now yield, have changed his retirement from comfortable to constricted.
"I had to give up going out for dinner so I could pay for my medication," said Mr. Rosenzweig, a retired New York City garment worker. "I think, Is it food or is it medication?"
 
Vague on Long-Term Care
 The Clinton proposal's long-term care sections are not as well defined as the prescription drug benefit. Indeed, there are no specifics about how much help the Government would provide to people with physical disabilities or to those with severe retardation or dementing illnesses like Alzheimer's disease.
What the plan does say is that under a new long-term care program, the Federal Government will provide money for some home-based care and other non-institutional care for people who need help with three of the five basic tasks of eating, dressing, bathing, going to the toilet and getting out of bed, and for those with severe mental impairments.
But many experts say that, given budget restraints, it is unlikely that significant long-term care benefits can be provided to all who need them. And the plan makes only a nod to perhaps the thorniest problem of long-term care: the high price of nursing-home care.
Because few families can afford nursing-home costs -- which can exceed $50,000 a year -- many Americans in need of care but unable to pay now find themselves in the difficult position of having to impoverish themselves to qualify for Medicaid. The Clinton health plan would allow people to keep $12,000 of assets -- instead of the current $2,000 -- and still qualify for Medicaid. And nursing-home residents on Medicaid could keep $100 of their monthly Social Security checks as a living allowance, instead of the current $30.
 
Early Retirees' Insurance
 The Clinton plan does tackle a problem that plagues employers and older workers alike: health insurance for early retirees. Most Americans retire in their early 60's, but they are not eligible for Medicare until they turn 65. Many lose their health insurance when they retire, or find they must pay high premiums for minimal coverage.
"I retired last year when I was 59," said Sandy Warshaw, who worked as a manager in New York City's government. "I had thought of moving to Boston, where my grandchild is, or to Arizona, where it's warmer, but decided I shouldn't because of insurance. Under my insurance from the city, I pay $10 each time I see one of the preferred doctors, and those doctors are all around here." Under the Clinton plan, which offers universal, fully portable coverage, Ms. Warshaw could go wherever she wants without losing insurance benefits.
The plan guarantees anyone who retires between 55 and 65 access to comprehensive health insurance at a community-wide price through the new regional health care alliances, once they are set up. Beginning in 1998, the Government would pay 80 percent of the premiums for all but the most affluent early retirees.
Over all, the Clinton plan envisions a day when most older Americans would be covered through the same regional health alliances as younger workers, instead of through Medicare. Once the plan is in effect, people turning 65 would be allowed to choose either Medicare or insurance through an alliance.

HEADLINE: If The French Can Do It, Why Can't We?

BYLINE: By Steven Greenhouse; Steven Greenhouse, a reporter in the Times Washington bureau, was a correspondent in the Paris bureau for five years.

 BODY:
Pascal Favre-Rochex is in the midst of that morning tightrope walk parents know so well -- settling his son in preschool. His knees are scrunched up against the pint-size table as he hams it up, reading "Monsieur Rigolo" to 3-year-old Clement. A moment later he gives his son a hug and is out the door. The teacher, Maryse Corne, invites Clement, Antoine, Ines, Mehdi, Stanislas and 16 other toddlers to sit on the gray rug at her feet. First they recite rhymes about escargots and bumblebees, and then they sing "Frere Jacques," pumping their right arms up and down to ring imaginary church bells.
By French standards it's just another day in preschool. But through American eyes what's going on in this Parisian preschool is extraordinary. This class is part of a free, full-day, public preschool, or ecole maternelle. Many New Yorkers, Washingtonians and Californians pay $8,000 to $14,000 a year to send a child to preschool or a day-care center, if they are lucky enough to find a place. In France, 99 percent of 3- 4- and 5-year-olds attend preschool at no or minimal charge. 
 In sharp contrast, just one-third of American 3- and 4-year-olds attend preschools or day-care centers, and in many communities the nonaffluent need not apply. But with the strong backing of left and right, the French spend $7 billion a year to make sure every child -- rich, middle class or poor -- gets off to a good start. They feel the benefits outweigh the cost.
Comparing the French system with the American system -- if that word can be used to describe a jigsaw puzzle missing half its pieces -- is like comparing a vintage bottle of Chateau Margaux with a $4 bottle of American wine. The first child-care centers were built in the early 1800's to protect the children of women who took jobs in rapidly industrializing Paris. But it was only after World War II that the system exploded in size as the battle-scarred nation sought to protect its young from starvation and disease. Today, for France's 4.5 million children under the age of 6, the constellation of child-care offerings is vast and all of them are linked to health care. The three major categories are day-care centers and day-care homes, for children 3 months to 3 years of age, and preschools, for children 2 1/2 to 5 years old. Day-care centers, or creches, and day-care homes charge fees on a sliding scale. Public preschools, or ecoles maternelles, are free; parochial preschools are heavily subsidized.
"Our objective is to be both a place of learning and a place that stimulates children," says Josiane Mattei, the director of the preschool Clement attends, off Avenue du General Leclerc. Mattei coordinates the curriculum for 210 children and, since this is France, sees to it that the children use proper table manners.
"We don't want parents to feel that they're leaving their kids at a baggage claim," she says.
Preschools run from 8:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; parents can pay $300 a year for wraparound programs that provide supervised activities from 7:30 to 8:30 A.M. and 4:30 to 6 P.M.
Local government supports the day-care centers, which are normally open from 7 A.M. to 7 P.M. The overall cost of sending a child to a Parisian day-care center is $10,000 a year. Poor families pay $390 per year, middle-class families pay about $3,200, and the rich pay $5,300. When we lived in France, our son, Jeremy, attended a creche in the Latin Quarter. The fee was $3,850 a year.
The staff of 19 was responsible for 72 children. The director, Odile Caplier, is a registered nurse who spent two years studying child development. Like all municipal creche directors, she has an apartment in the same building, enabling her to keep a child past 7 P.M. in an emergency. The staff includes a deputy director (also a registered nurse) and two teachers (each with the equivalent of four years of college). The 12 child-care aides are high-school graduates who have taken a one-year course in child development.
What wowed my wife, Miriam, was the food. She often mailed copies of the creche's weekly menu to friends in the United States so they could salivate over the poached fish, cauliflower mousse, parsleyed potatoes and Camembert cheese -- not bad compared with the peanut butter sandwiches served at so many American preschools.
Concluding that our daughter, Emily, would do better in a more intimate situation, we sent her not to a day-care center but to a day-care home. France has 30,000 such homes -- what amounts to a network of full-time government-licensed baby sitters who look after 57,000 children under the age of 3. Baby sitters must pass medical and psychological exams, and their homes are inspected for safety.
Once a month, Daniele Naudin, the matronly director of a municipal day-care center in western Paris, goes on her rounds. She pushes open the door of a turn-of-the-century brown brick building, walks up two flights of stairs and presses the doorbell of one of the eight baby sitters under her supervision.
"Bonjour, Mme. Naudin," Malika Akdim says, as she opens the door to her apartment, where she is looking after two girls, 11 months and 19 months old.
Naudin organizes monthly training sessions for the baby sitters, teaching them how to cope with emergencies, keep children clean and prepare healthful meals. One morning a week, the baby sitters take their charges to the center, where they play with other children and are examined by doctors.
Eager to encourage baby sitters to work within the system instead of in an off-the-books limbo, the French are trying to make the job more respectable and lucrative. Akdim, who emigrated from Morocco 15 years ago, has three school-age children and earns about $1,000 a month as a baby sitter. The local government provides bedding, bottles, toys and strollers for the children she cares for. The national Government has created an incentive for parents to use licensed sitters by refunding the Social Security taxes they pay (about $800 a year). Just imagine the grief this would have saved Zoe Baird and Kimba Wood.
France also offers parent-run day-care cooperatives and short-term drop-in programs. Municipalities put up money to build the cooperatives and provide a child development specialist to work with parents. Government-run "garderies," which are akin to indoor playgrounds, offer a few hours' respite for parents. Paris is experimenting with a center for children in "difficult" family situations that provides special care night and day supervised by a psychologist and social worker. Called Enfant Present, it works with the court system and social service agencies.
Small wonder that many American educators and child-care experts -- including Hillary Rodham Clinton -- have looked to France as a model. Four years ago, as chairwoman of the Children's Defense Fund, she was one of 14 American experts who took part in a study of French child care sponsored by the French-American Foundation. "We found that most programs in France looked as good as the best American programs," says Gail Richardson, director of the foundation study. "What you see for everybody in France is what you see for just a small percentage of people in the United States."
French child care is not perfect, Richardson concedes. Though the ratio of children to teachers in French preschools, sometimes more than 25 to 1, is high by American standards, it is offset by the use of teachers' aides and by extensive teacher training. Most French preschool teachers have the equivalent of a master's degree. But don't expect the First Lady to make a big push for a French-style system anytime soon. The simple reason is cost.
Even if the White House were to unfurl a grand plan for child care, Federal, state and local governments would no doubt squabble over how to finance and control it. American and French taxpayers' attitudes toward spending on social services are very different. Almost half of France's gross domestic product goes to taxes, compared with less than a third in the United States. Even after the conservatives ousted the Socialists in the April elections, and amid signs of growing worry about France's budget deficit and high payroll taxes, the French are clamoring for more, not less, spending on child care.
In Paris over the last decade, creche enrollment has doubled to 22,000. But in some neighborhoods, there still aren't enough places for all the children that need them. And in this year of deep recession throughout France, local officials say they are feeling intense pressure to hold down the cost to the taxpayer. The solution: continue building day-care centers while charging parents, especially the rich ones, more.
During the 70's, most middle-class and rich French parents preferred to use nannies. But attitudes changed radically after research demonstrated that socialization is important and that children who had been in creches and ecoles maternelles did better in the first years of elementary school.
"Nowadays, most parents want collective care, which is exactly the opposite of 20 years ago," says Sylvie Rayna, a researcher for the Ministry of National Education. "Now, everybody seems to be demanding a place at a creche."

HEADLINE: Moment of Decision For Health Care

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
IT was only two or three years ago that the phrase "job-lock" began to appear in public discourse. The ugly new term described an ugly new condition faced by millions of people: fear of leaving or switching jobs out of a well-founded concern that health coverage, once given up, might not be regained because of price, "pre-existing conditions" or other factors.
Now less than three weeks after President Clinton's 240,000-word proposal for health care was placed before Congress, now as months of intensive debate begin amid a chorus of hope about the goals and a cacophony of warnings about the details, it is easy to forget the serious underlying problems -- spreading job-lock being symptomatic of them -- that led to calls for drastic change on the scale of the New Deal or the Great Society. For his part, Mr. Clinton was moved to gamble his own place in history on an issue that had been a nonstarter for many Presidents before. 
 Now the President and Hillary Rodham Clinton, his chief torchbearer on health care, are doing their best to remind everyone of the costs to individuals and the economy of inaction. Thus their mantralike descriptions of a health-care system that's "badly broken," their endless promises of "security" and of "comprehensive benefits that can never be taken away."
If there is no consensus on how to fix things, there is wide agreement that two intertwined problems -- an erosion of health insurance and a rocketing of medical costs -- are jeopardizing the security of families and the economic health of the country.
Some 37 million Americans, mainly the working poor, live without the basic peace of mind offered by health insurance. Every other industrial country provides something close to universal coverage and the ever-growing number of uninsured Americans has long been seen by medical experts as an index of national shame.
Still, it was not a sudden rise in compassion for the poor that suddenly thrust health care to the top of the national agenda. Increasingly, middle-class Americans have tasted the fear, degradation and risk of financial catastrophe that come with a lack of health insurance. As costs soar, insurers have found more ways to discriminate among customers, excluding those most likely to run up large bills, and to avoid or pile huge charges onto individuals and small groups that cannot spread expenses among large numbers of payers. Tearing away further at the insurance net are changes in the job market, including increased layoffs and the spread of part-time work and jobs without benefits.
The number of the uninsured at any point in time, in some ways obscures the real problem. A little more than half have been without insurance for more than a year. But the rest are part of a constantly changing mix of people who spend anxious months without coverage before regaining it through employment, qualifying for government programs or other means. In an era when the bill for an afternoon's visit to a specialist, including tests, can reach $1,000 and outpatient surgery can cost $15,000, the fear is palpable.
Federal experts estimate that over the next two years close to one in four Americans will spend time uninsured. Thus the White House has sought to redefine the debate, focusing as much on the insecurity of the currently covered as on the plight of the chronically deprived.
"All these trends add up to a growing sense of unease: 'Yes, I'm insured today but will I be tomorrow?' " says Henry Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution.
At the same time, many economists say, runaway medical costs have eroded wages and threatened the competitiveness of American industry. Certainly they threaten the solvency of the Federal Government.
This year, about 14 percent of the gross national product will be devoted to health care, one dollar in every seven. By comparison, no other country devotes more than 10 percent of its economy to health. By the year 2000, according to Federal projections that assume no radical policy changes, health spending would reach 19 percent of the economy. And by that year, the Medicare program for the elderly and the Medicaid program for the poor would eat up an astounding 23 percent of the entire Federal budget, dooming any hopes of taming the deficit.
If it were just a question of guaranteeing universal coverage the country would face a relatively simple task. But assuring coverage cannot, alas, be considered apart from the vastly more complex and divisive question of cost control. Continued inflation would not only fling ever more people into the ranks of the uninsured, but also drive the costs of any subsidy scheme through the roof.
Mrs. Clinton said the goal is "to preserve what is right and works about the American health care system, but, finally, to fix what is wrong." But there is no agreement yet on how to reshape American medicine in a way that will prune out waste while preserving quality care, on how to bring discipline to the sprawling "medical-industrial complex" without stifling innovation.
And so now the country, with a set of sweeping proposals on the table, must decide just how badly broken the system is after all, and what price it is willing to pay to fix it.
The Clintons wanted "a great national discussion." That they have. Whether the issues can now be engaged in an understandable way, whether members of the public can connect their own preferences with practical alternatives, whether Congress and the President can clarify the choices and pass a coherent plan -- all are the stiff questions facing American democracy.

HEADLINE: Growing Consensus on Covering All, but How?

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

 BODY:
PRESIDENT CLINTON and Hillary Rodham Clinton have won the first battle of health care, with hardly any notice of how important the victory was. Business, labor, consumer groups, the elderly, doctors, nurses and hospitals, the insurance industry and even many once-reluctant members of Congress have come together on a central issue as never before. They agree that the nation needs universal health care coverage.
This success has gone largely uncelebrated, mainly because the perils of the long march ahead allow no indulgent, if deserved, respite for self-congratulation. Reconstructing the way Americans relate to doctors, hospitals and insurers is the most profound social task Congress has undertaken since the 1964 Civil Rights Act, and it is being mounted without the same national sense of moral command that underlay that law. 
 But the commitment of the major players to universal coverage is a monumental first step. Since last year's campaign, the Clintons have focused and crystallized the public's anxiety about the rising costs of health care, and especially its fear of suddenly losing insurance. Of the President's campaign promises, that was the one that mattered intensely to voters in 1992. His willingness to stake his Presidency on the issue has transformed the question of whether to have a national health care program to what program would be best.
Still, there is no certainty that the Clintons' formidable weapons of tenacity and eloquence can convert the apparent consensus over universal coverage into agreement on his proposal, or, more realistically, on some combination of his proposal and other competing plans.
These are the problems:
*The issue is complicated, and the Clinton solution, on which debate focuses, hardly matches his claim of simplicity.
*Congress has jurisdictional and partisan divisions that often tie it up, and the central issue of requiring employers to pay insurance premiums is one that could bring on paralysis.
*The organizations that have coalesced behind universal coverage have seemed to move quickly beyond that point and now spend more energy demanding a better break for themselves than advocating the idea generally.
*The public's commitment is general, rather than precise.
*Disputes over how to deal with abortion could fragment Democratic supporters.
On the other hand, here are the reasons more lawmakers expect action than foresee stalemate:
*As House Speaker Thomas S. Foley describes the mood in Congress, "Clearly, there is a virtual consensus that we need to reform the health care system." He said, "There are hardly any voices who say 'This is not broken, don't fix it.' '
*The rank-and-file agreement is buttressed by the evident desire of such senior committee chairmen as Senator Edward M. Kennedy and Representatives John D. Dingell and Dan Rostenkowski to crown their careers with this achievement.
*About half the Senate Republicans, having abandoned their filibuster mode of last spring, plainly want to see major changes enacted.
*The Clinton Administration has come up with one of the best political slogans in years, "Health care that's always there," and an equally snappy visual gimmick, the red, white and blue health security card; both are important devices for public persuasion.
The plan they are selling would revolutionize the financing and delivery of health care in the United States. The plan spelled out in the 1,342-page bill submitted to Congress last month would try to insure that every legal resident of the United States has health insurance and try to curb rising health-care costs.
Most employers would be required to pay the bulk of their workers' insurance premiums, with small business heavily subsidized. No employer would have to pay more than 7.9 percent of payroll. The self-employed would be required to insure themselves. The Government would cover the poor, now treated through Medicaid, and the unemployed, so that workers would no longer be, in the Clintons' phrase, "only a pink slip away" from losing their insurance.
States are likely to have considerable latitude in managing the system. But except in a few states that might choose a "single-payer" system where the Government pays the bills, the actual insurance would be provided by insurance companies. They would have to offer a broad standard package of benefits set by Congress and adjusted by a National Health Board, including doctors' and hospitals' bills and prescription drugs, and would compete in ways of delivering it, such as through a Health Maintenance Organization or a more expensive, traditional fee-for-service plan.
To connect insurers and consumers, states would create insurance purchasing alliances representing hundreds of thousands of people. The alliances would use large-scale bargaining power to negotiate the lowest possible rates from companies, and then send consumers comparative information on prices, ways of providing service, and quality ratings -- from customer waiting time to immunization rates. Consumers would choose among plans annually, although some plans might become "full" and closed to new patients.
Companies with more than 5,000 employees could choose to self-insure their employees if it would save them money, but would have to offer them the standard national benefits package.
The elderly would continue to be covered by Medicare, but would be given a new benefit of prescription drug coverage and inclusion in another new program for long-term care in homes and communities, but not in nursing homes. The new benefits would be paid for, in rough balance, by cuts in the expected growth of Medicare and Medicaid.
Over all, three-fourths of the health care dollars would come from the same sources they do now, from individual and employer payments. Subsidies for small business and the poor would come from other Federal savings and from about $100 billion in cigarette taxes and taxes on big employers that do not join alliances.
Besides the savings it envisions from greater competition among insurers, the Administration's hopes for controlling costs rest on restrictions on insurance-premium increases.
The biggest questions raised about the plan relate to its complexity, its cost controls, the overall financing and the requirement that employers pay premiums.
The President argues, with good reason, that nothing could be as complicated as the existing system. But descriptions of his plan, especially of how the alliances would work, have left lawmakers baffled. Thomas Mann, a political scientist at the Brookings Institution, says, "The belief that it's too complicated is seeping through."
The insurance premium limits are sharply criticized by Republicans who say price controls are not only wrong but do not work. Republicans like Senator John Chafee of Rhode Island would rely much more heavily on competition and restructuring the insurance industry for savings.
The doubts about the financing of the system run in two streams, one Congressional and one administrative. Many outsiders, and many lawmakers, too, doubt that Congress can muster the courage to impose the proposed Medicare and Medicaid cuts and avoid the pressures for more coverage -- from more frequent mammograms to more generous mental health benefits to greater small business subsidies. Meanwhile small-business owners wonder whether those subsidies will outlive a future round of budget cuts.
But even lawmakers who don't share those reservations recall how much the costs of Medicare exceeded the expectations, and doubt that anyone, even with the best intentions and the ablest computer programmers, can foretell the expense of a vast new Federal program. And no one thinks the estimates will be low.
When the Clintons delivered their bill to Congress last month, they had reshaped the financing to try to answer those doubts. It plans to lay aside enough money to provide a 15 percent "cushion" above cost estimates it says are already conservative, in order to provide a reserve fund if costs spurt beyond the estimates. The President defines his plan as a "capped entitlement." That means that if health-care costs outrun the money made available to pay for them plus the 15 percent, Congress will have to cut health benefits, cut other programs or vote to raise more money, presumably by raising taxes. Other entitlements, like Social Security, expend whatever funds the law calls for, whether they go over budget estimates or not.
The clearest dispute is over the requirement that employers pay premiums for their workers. Mrs. Clinton told the House Education and Labor Committee that since most employers now pay for insurance, this is the least disruptive way to approach universal care. But most Republicans, and many Democrats, fear that such a rule would kill off small businesses.
Senator Chafee would try to get everyone covered by requiring individuals to buy insurance. But that approach has a political problem of its own: the specter of the Internal Revenue Service. He said recently that to enforce the mandate on individuals, "you will have to show on your tax return that you have health insurance." Enforceability, in other words, is a key difficulty here.
The Clinton program was put together over several months of closed-door brainstorming led by Mrs. Clinton and Ira C. Magaziner, the President's top health policy aide. It was assembled through painstaking negotiation with all kinds of organizations. Small business was promised subsidies. Big business was assured that the Government would pick up its share of insurance for early retirees. The elderly were told their prescriptions would be included. There was more tinkering after a draft of the program was shown to Congress in mid-September.
But the result has not been altogether satisfying for the Administration. Some groups sound like Rickey Henderson, the baseball player who signed a rich contract and then pouted for years after other players were paid more. While the Administration may have had no realistic alternative, when a program is offered like candy, some children worry that the next kid is getting more. The President's deal-making to get his bill passed only invites organizations to keep asking for more.
After a public relations triumph with the plan's initial selling by the President and the First Lady, the Administration has been disappointed in its hope of leading a popular bandwagon of support. Many groups whose backing it hoped for, like the National Association of Manufacturers and the American Association of Retired Persons, have focused on the negatives.
"It's a lot easier for a critic to get an attractive sound bite, a catchy phrase," observed Bill Kovach, curator of Harvard University's Nieman Foundation for journalism. But he said newspapers and magazines had failed, too: "One of the trends in journalism is to emphasize the negative aspects of public debate on any issue."
The view of the public is somewhat favorable -- though not by large margins -- but people are not in general confident of their knowledge of the proposal. A CBS News Poll in October showed that 37 percent thought the plan would make health care better, and 26 percent said it would make it worse. But only 18 percent, down from 23 percent soon after Mr. Clinton's speech and his wife's testimony, said they thought they had a "good understanding" of it.
The Administrartion has a lot of work ahead before that understanding goes much higher, as effective as the "health care that's always there" slogan. On Sept. 22, Mr. Clinton cited six principles by which to judge the program: security, simplicity (which took the most words), savings, choice, quality and responsibility.
But there is no equally effective three- to five-minute explanation to solidify support and to translate interest into real and essential commitment.
The President cannot, certainly, afford to rely solely on unions, who are now fighting with him over the North American Free Trade Agreement, or the American Association of Retired Persons or any other single special-interest group. He knows he has to build the same kind of broad consensus for enacting his plan as he built for the belief in the need for it. Former Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio is in charge of that, traveling the country trying to create state and local organizations to keep the pressure on.
But this will not be easy. Congress will probably not even begin voting in committees until late winter or early spring. Jurisdictional rivalries, especially in the House, could delay action further. Many Republicans and conservative Democrats seem committed to fighting hard against the plan. The Administration must deal with them without angering liberal supporters of a national "single-payer" system -- a group of five Senators and 89 representatives who want, at the least, to make sure the system is generous enough to those in the greatest need and is truly universal.
Effective dates, and almost anything with a number in it, may change.
But universality is probably the only truly non-negotiable issue for the Clintons. As Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said recently, universality "clearly is seen by a lot of people, including a lot of Southerners, as the kind of inner glue to the whole proposal."
Senator Kennedy, who has been pushing for national health care for most of his 30 years in Congress, spoke with relief about the consensus on universal coverage. But, he said: "We can't afford to miss this once-in-a-generation opportunity to achieve health security for all Americans." And he observed, "If we can't do this, people will wonder why have a Congress at all."
It will not be easy, nor without moments when all seems lost. But the odds are that before the voters get to pose that question at the polls a year from now, Congress will have passed a bill that somehow reaches the goal of universal coverage.

HEADLINE: THE IMPACT: The Consumers;
More Choices, but Also More Costs

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
The heart of the Clinton strategy for holding down medical spending is to make people aware of the true cost of their health care. And that may be jarring for many who receive generous benefits at work.
In the structure outlined by the White House, many people may find themselves choosing among unfamiliar new health plans and accepting new limits on their freedom to choose doctors or hospitals, or paying extra to use the system as freely as they are accustomed to. 
 The question remains whether the lower-cost health maintenance organizations into which many people might be pushed will offer long lines and second-class medical care, as some critics fear, or efficient, prudent, top-flight care, as officials predict.
 
How Much for Coverage?
 Under the Clinton proposal, everyone would be required to have health insurance and to contribute to its cost. All companies would be required to contribute for workers and their families, with the employers paying 80 percent of the cost of premiums and workers 20 percent.
Officials estimate that the average premium in 1994 would be $1,932 a year for individuals and $4,360 for families; so an employee would pay an average of $388 for individual coverage and $872 for family coverage. The self-employed and unemployed would be responsible for the entire amount, but depending on income, could be eligible for subsidies.
Individuals and most companies would no longer directly buy their own health insurance. Instead they would sign up with large cooperatives, or regional health alliances, which would present their members with a choice of health plans that have the same basic set of benefits. These plans would be made up of groups of doctors and hospitals, often organized by insurers.
A company employing at least 5,000 people could function as its own alliance or join the regional alliance.
The proposal envisions three basic kinds of plans. They are:
*"Low cost-sharing" plans, H.M.O.'s in which patients pay $10 per office visit to affiliated doctors.
*"High cost-sharing" plans, which allow patients to visit any doctors and health centers on a fee-for-service basis, but require families to pay a deductible of $400 and 20 percent of all subsequent bills, to a maximum of $3,000 per family per year.
*"Combination" plans in which patients pay little to use affiliated doctors and more to use others.
In more populated areas, an alliance might offer several plans with varying premiums. Any patient could choose any plan; the idea is to force plans to compete for customers by offering the best price and quality.
In turn, financial incentives would be used to nudge more people into the most cost-effective H.M.O.'s. Through stiffer deductibles and co-payments consumers would pay heavily for the ability to choose any doctor -- an amount, officials say, that fairly represents the extra cost of unmanaged care.
Thus, while many Americans might be able to choose more generous plans that cost them little more than they have paid in the past, others might find themselves spending more to keep the same freedoms.
 
The Choices
 One of the hottest issues raised by the proposal is freedom to choose one's doctor. Critics attack the plan as restricting choice, while the White House says it will be opening more choices. Both are right.
More than 41 million Americans are already in H.M.O.'s. But to the extent that more people feel pushed into them, they will face new limits. These groups usually allow a choice of primary physician among affiliated doctors, but patients must go through this "gatekeeper" to visit specialists, who must also be in the group.
Critics raise the specter of chronically ill patients ripped from a trusted doctor. This might happen, but the chances would be reduced if virtually all doctors sign up with health plans, as the proposal envisages.
Administration officials also point out that large numbers of Americans do not now enjoy the hallowed freedom of choice. Some 37 million are uninsured and the 30 million people on Medicaid, the program for the poor, often have trouble finding decent care.
Health maintenance organizations save money not only by negotiating lower fees with doctors, hospitals and other suppliers but also by scrutinizing medical decisions and discouraging wasteful, costly services. At best, this could produce fine care and weed out useless and harmful procedures. At worst, doctors' groups and H.M.O.'s could be tempted to scrimp on costly but useful care, jeopardizing health, and on personnel and equipment, producing long waits.
Administration officials say their proposal would insure high-quality care. As they make their annual selection of health plans, consumers would vote with their feet, shunning plans that perform poorly. A national program would develop ways to measure the quality of care offered by health plans. But critics question how consumers can adequately compare medical performance.

HEADLINE: THE IMPACT: The Providers;
Reshaping the Medical Marketplace

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
If the health care proposals of the Clinton Administration become law, they would throw into fast forward trends that are already reshaping the fates of doctors, hospitals and the insurance companies that pay them.
Doctors would win a victory that leading medical organizations like the American Medical Association have long sought: guaranteed insurance coverage for tens of millions of the uninsured. 
 But physicians would find that under the plan they would have even less autonomy than they do now. The market could be expected to force doctors to find patients by signing up with health care networks run by insurance companies and health maintenance organizations. Even when they treat patients who are not members of such networks, they would be required to charge them according to a schedule of fees approved by regulators for every service, the type of arrangement that has applied to Medicare and Medicaid.
The impact of the plan would probably be just as great on the hospital industry. As hospitals and treatment centers are drawn into managed care networks, they, too, would be put under growing pressure to cut costs. Experts say the Clinton program would probably speed the pace at which such institutions are already shutting down wards, merging with other hospitals or closing their doors.
 
The Big Five
 In addition, the plan says teaching hospitals would be forced to stop turning out so many highly paid specialists and to redirect their efforts to training lower-paid, primary-care physicians. And the plan is expected to bring changes in the medical marketplace that would force a significant number of specialists to retrain.
Some of the most drastic changes, however, would be seen in the health insurance industry. Most of the nation's 500 or so health insurers are expected to be driven out of the field, and among the likely beneficiaries would be the five giants of industry -- Prudential, Cigna, Aetna, Travelers and Metropolitan Life -- as well as the more than than 70 Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans.
The Clinton plan offers a bit of relief to insurance companies that sell workers' compensation and automobile insurance. The plan would merge the $40 billion in medical coverage now offered by workers' compensation and automobile policies into standard health care plans. But it assures property-casualty insurance companies that now sell such coverage that they will be allowed to stay in those lines of business by providing coverage through the alliances.
What ties together the future of all sorts of medical providers, doctors, hospitals, health maintenance organizations, pharmacies and laboratories, is the requirement under the Clinton plan that Americans receive their health coverage through the yet-to-be-created purchasing groups.
These health alliances, region by region, perhaps metropolitan area by metropolitan area, would tell insurers and health maintenance organizations what minimum requirements they must meet before they would be allowed to offer coverage to the public.
By assuring that all Americans have complete medical insurance coverage, the Government is guaranteeing that millions more patients and tens of billions more dollars will flow into doctors' offices. In addition, by permitting the 30 million people who are now covered by Medicaid to be covered by the alliances, the Clinton Administration would create legions of patients who are suddenly more lucrative to treat.
But the plan also spells out major constraints on doctors. The plan says insurers may still offer the current type of insurance that lets doctors bill patients for each procedure performed. Since such plans are expected to be the most expensive, however, planners say the majority of consumers will choose managed care plans. As a result, doctors searching for patients will find themselves joining managed care plans as well.
Such plans vary greatly, but one common element for doctors is that they have to agree to work under the rules of an insurance company or a health maintenance organization that closely supervises how much care and what kind of procedures should be given.
In addition, they are often paid by a system designed to motivate doctors to think twice before they go ahead with expensive and time-consuming procedures.
Under this "capitation" system, an insurer might offer a doctor a fixed fee for treating 100 patients. If the patients need less care than the average for such a group, the doctor makes more profit, but if the group needs more care than the average the expense comes from the doctor's pocket.
Doctors may decide to join such networks, but executives at some large health insurance companies say that over time, they expect more and more doctors to affiliate with one network or another.
In some specialized fields that have many practitioners in a given area, like hematologists in New York City, there may not be enough spaces in networks for all the doctors. The result may be that many such highly trained doctors will have to retrain in a lower-paying field of primary-care medicine.
Much of the nation's hospital industry has already been shaken in the past five years by the need to get rid of excess beds and lower their costs. As hospitals, too, find that they have to affiliate with managed care networks, the process will certainly speed up.
Another section of the report suggests a five-year phase-in period in which academic hospitals would try to decrease the number of specialists they train.
For the nation's $300 billion health insurance industry the future is one of transformation. The vast majority of the hundreds of health insurance companies in the United States offer the old-fashioned fee-for-service plans. Those plans are already losing customers to managed care networks, and under the alliance system, economists say, most would have to leave the business entirely.
What would remain, health economists predict, would be a limited number of H.M.O.'s, insurance health plans and similar networks run by doctors and hospitals.
The largest health insurance companies that have invested heavily in managed care networks say they hope to move swiftly to reduce costs. One executive said his company's goal was to reduce its work force.
