HEADLINE: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN;
A New Framework for Health Care

 BODY:
To control medical costs and provide secure coverage to all, President Clinton has proposed a vast restructuring of the health care system, to be phased in over several years. The proposal would use financial incentives to encourage consumers to join low-cost health maintenance organizations, and would push doctors, hospitals and insurers to join toether in networks. The strategy is to make consumers conscious of the ture cost of their care and, by fostering competition among plans, to force the plans to cut costs and offer better service. If competition does not drive down costs, mandatory ceilings on the growth of insurance premiums would aim to keep total spending in line with the growth of the economy.
 
THE OVERSEER
 
A seven-member National Health Board, appointed by the President, would monitor state compliance and the functioning of health alliances, interpret the standard benefit package and make recommendations about new benefits to reflect changing technology and needs, and set regional medical spending ceilings. It would develop indicators ofthe quality of service and care offered by health plans and publicize the results to promote informed consumer choices. A committee would monitor drug prices, raising questions to the pharmaceutical companies about those drugs it deems unreasonably expensive.
 
THE PAYERS
 
Employers: Would pay the bulk of the cost. The plan requires them to pay at least 80 percent of the average cost of premiums in thier region, and to support family coverage for married workers.
 
Employee: Would contribute an average of 20 percent toward their own insurance premiums, plus any required deductibles or co-payments.
 
Self-Employed and Nonworkers: Would be required to buy insurance, paying the full cost of premiums, unless they qualify for government subsidies. The cost would be fully tax deductible. Currently only 25 percent of the cost is tax deductible.
 
Government: Would subsidize costs for many small and low-wage businesses and for individuals (like part-time workers and the unemployed) who have incomes below 150 percent of the poverty line. Medicare payments would continue for the elderly and disabled. Medicaid would continue to pay for the poor, but through health alliances.
 
Large Corporations: Would have the option to negotiate directly with insurers for their employees' coverage, but would still be required to pay at least 80 percent of employees' premiums.
 
THE BROKERS
 
Health Alliances: The core of the plan. Run by the states under Federal scrutiny, these regional purchasing groups would collect and distribute premiums, certify health plans and offer them to consumers, insure that average premiums grow no faster than Federally set limits, collect and publish data on performance of health plans and negotiate with local doctors and hospitals to set fees for services provided outside H.M.O.'s
 
Access: All citizens and legal resident would be covered.
 
Cost: Alliances would determine a target range for average premiums charged by plans in its area. Plans would not be eligible if their charges were higher than the range.
 
Eligible Plans: Alliances would write a contract with any plan that met state requirements.
 
Options: Alliances would offer a range of medical plans of three types: an H.M.O., a fee-for-service plan, or a combination of the two. Patients could not be turned away unless a plan is overshubscribed.
 
Quality: Allance would publich information to help consumers compare the service and the medical perfomance of various plans.
 
Size: Alliance size would be based on population, so the number of alliances in each state would vary.
 
Structure: Alliance structure would be determined by states. Could function as nonprofit corporations or state agencies, but consumers and employers would have to be equally represented in the management of the alliance
 
Corporate Alliances: If these employers decided to negotiate directly with insurers and form their won alliances, they would still have to offer the guaranteed benefits package and a choice of plans, though their employees might have fewer providers to choose from.
 
THE OPTIONS
 
Most alliances would offer a large selection of plans, but all must include at least one fee-for-service options offering free choice of doctors. The administration estimates that the average plan cost would be $1,932 a year for an individual and $4,360 for a family, but costs would vary by region. Plans of any type would vary in price; people choosing costlier ones would pay a higher share of premiums. Plans could offer supplemental policies, covering items like extra dental or mental health benefits; employers could choose to pay for these or consumers could buy them with after-tax dollars.
 
H.M.O.: The least-expensive option. Patients sign up with a health maintenance organization and only consult doctors affiliated with that organization. Subsribers typically pay only $10 for an office visit. If they visit a doctor outside the plan, they pay a share of the bill.
 
Combination Plan: The middle option. Patients sign up with a group for most of their care, but reserve the right to consult outside doctors by paying 20 percent of the fee for those visits.
 
Fee For Service: The most expensive option, offering the widest choice of doctors. Patients can see any doctor they choose, but must pay deductibles ($200 for an individual and $400 for a family) and 20 percent of the cost of office visits and hospitalization, up to a limit of $1,500 for an individual and $3,000 for a family.
 
THE BENEFITS
 
All Americans would be issued a "health security card" that would enable them to receive the guaranteed benefits listed below.
 
Dental: Most care for children. Adult preventive benefits phased in by 2000.
 
Drugs: Prescriptions
 
Eye & Ear: Routing vision and hearing examinations; eyeglasses for children only.
 
Extended Care: Nursing homes or rehabilitation centers (as an alternative to hospital stays). Maximum of 100 days each year.
 
Home Care: As an alternative to hospitalization; re-evaluated every 60 days.
 
Hospice Care: For terminally-ill people.
 
Hospital Stays: Semi-private room; private rooms only when medically necessary.
 
Mental Health: Limited psychotherapy; limited inpatient services and psychiatric hospital stays.
 
Office Visits: Professional services, emergency care and other outpatient hospital services; laboratory tests and ambulance.
 
Medical Equipment: Braces, artificial limbs or prosthetic devices, when equipment improves functional abilities or prevents futher deterioration.
 
Outpatient Therapy: Physical, occupational or speech therapy to restore skills lost from illness or injury. Re-evaluated every 60 days.
 
Preventive care: Immunizations, mammograms, Pap smears, prenatal care and cholesterol screening.
 
Substance Abuse: Limited outpatient and inpatient services.
 
The plan excludes services that are not "medically necessary or appropraite," citing cosmetic orthodontia, hearing aids, contact lenses, sex-change surgery and in-vitro fertilization as examples of such services.
 
 
 
A Consumer's Guide: How Different Groups Would Be Affected

 
IF YOUR SITUATION IS...
 
Working, with Good Insurance: Many employees would see little difference, especially if they have already joined an H.M.O., and some would have more plans to choose from. Workers opting for free choice of doctors would often pay more up front toward premiums and have higher costs as theyreceived care. Companies would be required to pay 80 percent of average premium costs, but could pay more if they wished. If currently offered, company-sponsored benefits behond those in the standard package remian tax-free to employee for 10 years.
 
Working, Uninsured: Employers would be required to contribute and employees would be required to purchase coverage, paying 20 percent of the cost if they chose an average-priced premium, less if they chose a cheaper one. Workers would receive a subsidy toward their share, on a sliding scale, it family income is below 150 percent of the poverty line. The poverty line in 1992 was $14,340 for a family of four; 150 percent of that is $21,500.)
 
Non-Worker or Unemployed: Those with little income would pay little to keep full coverage; those with uneraned family income would contribute on a sliding scale, paying full cost if income exceeds 250 percent of the poverty line.
 
Part-Time Worker: Employers would contribute toward premiums for those working from 10 hours to 30 hours a week on a prorated basis. Depending on total family income from all sources and eligibility for subsidies, workers pay the remainder. In general, those who have purchased individual policies in the past would benefit from cheaper large-group rates.
 
Self-Employed: Self-employed individuals would pay under a complex formula that treats them like a small business, potentially eligible for subsidies, and an employee. As contribtuion toward the employer share - 80 percent of average premium cost - they would pay from 3.5 percent to a maximum of 7.9 percent of business income, depending on income level. They would also pay employee's 20 percent share, or less if family income was below 150 percent of poverty. Combined payments would approach full cost of premium at income of about $30,000. All premium payments would be tax deductible, compared with 25 percent now.
 
Two-Earner Family: In most cases entire family would sign up for same plan, but spouses may be allowed to join different ones. Each of the two employers would contribute toward each earner, but the two earners together would not pay more than the normal family share - 20 percent of the cost if they chose an average-priced premium. Whether most families would pay more or less than now depends on many factors.
 
Household Employee: For those working more than 10 hours a week and considered an employee by Social Security, employer would make a contribution based on wages, ranging from 3.5 percent of annual wages under $12,000 to 7.9 percent of $24,000. Employees would pay the remainder with subsidies for families below 150 percent of the poverty line.
 
Early Retiree: Initially, early retirees not yet eligible for Medicare would have guaranteed access to insurance at community-wide rates. Beginning in 1998, the Government would pay 80 percent of the cost of an average premium for all but the most affluent people. Part-time work or a spouse's earning would alter this subsidy.
 
Medicare Recipient: The elderly would continue to receive the same benefits, plus new prescription drug and home-care coverage. States have the option of bringing Medicare beneficiaries into health alliance, but only if benefits equal or are better than current coverage and a fee-for-service plan is offered. Monthly premiums would rise, especially for affluent retirees. Once alliances are established, people turning 65 have option of remaining in their former health plan, paying any differnce between Medicare contribution and plan cost.
 
Medicaid Recipient: Poor people on Medicaid would receive mainstream medicine, signing up for a plan through the alliance. In most cases the Federal and state government would make set payments to the health plan, rather than paying providers on a per-service basis with a fee schedule as in the past. Recipients could choose any plan with premium at or below the regional average without making additional payment.
 
Student: Students attending school full time in a distant location, but covered under their family's policy would sing up for coverage through the alliance where they attend school. A Portion of family and employer premium payments would be transferred from the home alliance to the alliance providing coverage.
 
Illegal Immigrant: Illegal immigrants would not be eligible for coverage through the health alliance but could still receive emergency and other care as they do new.

HEADLINE: THE DEBATE: The Red Tape;
Less Paperwork or New Headaches?

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
President Clinton's promise to cut the mounting paperwork clogging the American health care system will be welcomed by consumers befuddled by complex benefit forms. And it could save a great deal of money for doctors and hospital administrators who have to employ staffs to cope with the bewildering range of forms and requirements imposed by insurers.
But at the same time, critics are asking whether Mr. Clinton's proposed new layers of state and Federal agencies would simply replace one set of costly bureaucratic headaches with another. 
 Under the Clinton plan, hundreds of existing insurance forms would be replaced by a single simplified claim sheet for both doctors and patients. And because standardized benefits packages would replace the widely varying benefits now offered by insurers, consumers would find it easier to compare plans, and doctors and hospitals would save billions of dollars now spent paying administrators to decipher what is covered under each patient's policy.
But even if the Clinton plan makes life simpler and less expensive in these ways, many health care experts are asking just how much huge new Federal and state agencies and boards would cost, and whether they would simply create more red tape for consumers, doctors, hospitals and businesses.
 
Specter of Monster Agencies
 "There is a tremendous potential for this to become highly bureaucratic and highly regulatory," said Uwe Reinhardt, a professor of political economy at Princeton University. "The kind of people who run the department of motor vehicles would be the kind of people who would staff the alliances. Who else would staff it?"
Under the Clinton plan, most people and companies would buy health insurance through large regional alliances that would represent perhaps a million consumers or, in big cities, even more. These alliances, set up by state governments, would determine which medical groups and insurers could offer health plans to the public and how much they could charge. They would collect and distribute most insurance premiums and collect and publicize data on the performance of health plans.
Because these alliances are charged with many responsibilities, critics say they could grow into monsters that would be unresponsive to consumers' problems and become the focus of a new industry for lobbyists and regulatory consultants. The result, they say, is that overall savings in administration may not be as great as the President hopes.
"In the end, I frankly don't think it will simplify things at all," said Joseph A. Califano Jr., a domestic policy aide under President Lyndon B. Johnson and Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare under President Jimmy Carter.
Still, everyone agrees that paperwork and duplication plague the current system, and some of the Clinton proposals are widely cheered.
Large hospitals now employ entire departments of highly specialized workers just to determine what each patient's insurance policy covers, what information each insurer demands, whether a second or third type of insurance may supplement the patient's primary coverage, and how to redistribute the costs of the uninsured among the bills of insured patients.
 
Paperwork Everywhere
 In his speech in September, the President cited the example of Washington Children's Hospital, saying it spent $2 million a year filling out unnecessary forms. If doctors and other medical providers were freed of that paperwork, he said, the hospital could treat 10,000 more children a year.
Medical groups say that many private offices have also been forced to hire administrative staffs to handle forms, and that some doctors spend more than 20 hours a week on paperwork.
The White House estimates that administrative costs account for at least 15 cents of every dollar paid to insurance companies in premiums. The Clinton plan would cut four to six cents in current administrative costs, Administration officials say. The new alliances and other new administrative costs would add about 2.5 cents in costs, they say, for a net reduction of 1.5 to 3.5 cents for each dollar spent on health care. "If you are familiar with the incredible disorder now, you know that things can be better," said Paul Starr, one of the President's advisers on health care. "This plan will be a huge help to small businesses and to consumers." The White House contends that the Clinton plan would simplify things in several ways.
In addition to the standardized benefit packages and streamlined claims forms, the Administration hopes that employers will no longer need to employ health benefits specialists or pay health insurance agents and brokers to find their employees the best health plans. That would be left to the alliances and the employees themselves.
The White House also says the Clinton plan would simplify Federal regulations on Medicare and Medicaid and cut bureaucracy by merging the medical benefits of workers' compensation and automobile insurance policies with the health plan's coverage.
 
'Major New Bureaucracy'
 Mr. Starr said consumers would be safeguarded by the requirement that the alliance's boards include equal numbers of representatives of employers, consumers, the self-employed and other covered groups.
The alliance boards would not include people associated with health care providers, law firms involved with health care, pharmaceutical companies or suppliers of medical equipment and services.
But a number of health economists and public policy specialists say the plan could create bureaucracies that would be at least as expensive as those in the current system. Their concerns center on the alliances.
"I am not sure there is going to be that much savings," said Patricia M. Danzon, a professor at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania who has studied the administrative costs of health care in Canada and the United States. "It all adds up to a major new bureaucracy that is duplicating functions that today are being performed elsewhere in the system." Experts predict many alliances will collect and distribute more money than the governments of the states in which they operate.
Professor Reinhardt said he feared that in cases where consumers found that the alliance had an incorrect address or Social Security number, they might face civil servants who were less responsive than workers at large insurance companies.
Mark Pauly, the chairman of health care systems at the Wharton School, said another cost to society of the Clinton plan would be new industries of lobbyists and consultants who specialize in guiding their clients through the various alliances in each state or through dealings with a new Federal entity, the National Health Board, which would oversee the state alliances.

HEADLINE: THE DEBATE;
Some Fear Rationing of Care

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
Of all the facets of President Clinton's plan for overhauling health care, few have generated as much heated debate as his proposed constraints on medical spending. The proposal has prompted warnings that it will undermine the quality of care and possibly lead to rationing.
Braking medical spending as sharply as the President proposes -- cutting annual growth by more than half of what it has been in recent years -- could force strapped medical groups to shortchange patients, denying them useful tests and treatments, some doctors and insurance executives maintain. While these critics also fear for their own incomes and profits under the Clinton plan, their warnings are echoed by many economists. 
 Nonsense, Administration officials say. They and many medical experts portray an American system so replete with inefficiency, duplication, overcharging and overuse of procedures that huge sums can be squeezed out for many years to come.
Right now, health care consumes 14 percent of the gross national product, up from 10 percent in 1981. Under the Clinton plan, spending would bulge in the next three years as uninsured Americans were covered, reaching 17 percent of the economy, but officials hope it would stay on a plateau at that level for years to come.
The White House wants to curb spending by limiting premium increases in health plans, limiting Government expenditures and pressuring drug companies to hold down prices.
Without the Clinton overhaul, Government experts predict, medical spending in the year 2000 would reach 19 percent of the gross national product, with tens of millions of people still not covered, and would keep climbing.
"When an American physician tells you that at 17 percent of the G.N.P. we'll have to ration, that seems bizarre on its face," said Uwe Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University and an expert on European health systems that spend far less.
But Dr. Reinhardt added, "The issue is the speed of the slowdown in spending, not the ultimate level."

HEADLINE: THE DEBATE;
A.M.A. Challenges the President's Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The American Medical Association has urged doctors to lobby patients to oppose central elements of President Clinton's health plan, including Federal regulation of health insurance premiums and cuts in the growth of Medicare and Medicaid.
At a political education conference here and in documents sent to all doctors across the country, leaders of the A.M.A. punctured the spirit of bipartisan euphoria that briefly hovered over the plan after Mr. Clinton presented it to Congress in September. 
 The association said some parts of the plan, like the proposal to guarantee health care for all Americans, were good for patients. But in a letter to 670,000 doctors and 40,000 medical students, leaders of the association said they would "activate an unprecedented national network of physicians" to persuade Congress to make substantial changes in Mr. Clinton's proposal. Hundreds of doctors, organized by the association, have taken their case to Capitol Hill in a lobbying blitz.
The doctors do not have a veto over legislation but are expected to wield considerable influence in Congress because many are prominent in their communities and contribute to political campaigns. The association itself has a $7 million budget for lobbying.
Dr. Lonnie R. Bristow, chairman of the association, said: "The President has offered the country a prescription for what ails our health care system. While we agree with his general diagnosis, we disagree with some of his treatment decisions. He's prescribing some pretty stiff, new and untried medicine. We are worried that no one really knows what the side effects are going to be."
Previously, the association's tone had been conciliatory, as it worked quietly behind closed doors to influence Mr. Clinton's proposal. The Administration has swung between seeking the cooperation of the A.M.A., whose opposition has proved fatal to a long series of health care proposals, and preparing to do battle with it.
The A.M.A.'s tone has become more aggressive as members have focused on details of the Clinton plan. The doctors said their positions reflected their patients' interests, not just their own economic interests.
At the conference, doctors booed and hissed Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, when she told them of the President's proposal to limit medical malpractice lawsuits, a proposal the doctors see as inadequate.
While vowing to be constructive, the doctors criticized crucial parts of Mr. Clinton's plan to hold down health costs and reshape the medical system. Administration officials rejected the criticism but said they would work with doctors toward a compromise.
The association said it "unequivocally opposes a national health spending budget," which Mr. Clinton proposed.

HEADLINE: AMERICANS REACT: VIEW FROM MIDDLE AMERICA;
Voices of the People: Struggles, Hope and Fear

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa

 BODY:
For four families in the middle of America, President Clinton's promise of health care coverage "that can never be taken away" has hit home, addressing what is clearly a shared yearning.
In interviews before and just after the President's speech to Congress in September proposing a new national health care system, the families, including people who are insured and uninsured, employed and unemployed, healthy and sick, all said they welcomed the promise of secure health insurance for all. They were first interviewed about their health and needs in May. 
 They welcomed the President's promises of Government-guaranteed care for all and the right to insurance even when they lose jobs. The elderly were especially pleased by his promise to preserve Medicare and, for the first time, to include prescription drugs in the program.
Some fear that under Mr. Clinton's proposals they might have to pay more from slim incomes for the insurance plans they already have. Some are skeptical -- about the President, about gridlock in Washington, about the financing of the plan and about the influence of lobbyists representing doctors, drug companies and insurance companies. But all are relieved that a President has finally taken on the health care tangle.
"I liked everything he said," said Debra O'Connor of Lisbon, Iowa, a single mother of three young boys who worries about layoffs at her company and fears that she is only a pink slip away from losing her health insurance. "I think it can work if everybody gives it a chance."
Ms. O'Connor, who works at an aerospace company, said she took her relatively low-paying job not because she liked the work but because she would pay only $7 a month for a comprehensive health plan. She expects to have to pay more if the Clinton plan succeeds, and so be it, she says; at least her dread about the consequences for her children in the event of being laid off will be reduced.
The two families with the most to gain were those of Leo and Elma Patten of Cedar Rapids, who are unemployed and largely uninsured, and Maria Weirather, who has been driven to poverty by bills for cancer surgery. But the Pattens worry that under the Clinton plan they might not be able to keep the doctor who they say has helped them get through an onslaught of medical problems, and Ms. Weirather is skeptical about the Government's ability to carry out the Clinton plan.
An older couple, William and Gertrude Coen, now find themselves very comfortable with Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly. But they are concerned about the possibility that an illness requiring long-term care could drive them into poverty.
Here are the stories of these four families, their hopes and their fears:
 
The Pattens
Access to Doctors Is a Major Worry
 Leo Patten, 62, and his wife, Elma, 58, are both unemployed because of their health. Mr. Patten, whose emphysema has cut his lung capacity to 40 percent of normal, is only partly insured. His wife, who is unable to get insurance, is a diabetic who has had numerous operations for a host of problems, including double bypass heart surgery.
So they were happy to hear Mr. Clinton's promise of secure medical coverage for everyone by 1998 -- security that they have desperately needed.
But as they watched the President unveil his plan on television, they worried that they could lose access to the one person they credit for keeping them going: their family doctor, Jo Lynn Glanzer.
"She treats us so good," Mrs. Patten said. "She'll call and ask how we're doing."
The Pattens worked all their adult lives until their health forced them to stop. Mr. Patten says smoking -- he quit in 1975 -- and the foul air of the factories where he worked as a machinist brought on his emphysema.
He has Medicare because he has been disabled for more than two years, but because of his pre-existing condition he cannot get supplemental insurance to pay for doctors' and hospital bills that Medicare does not cover, or for any of his medicine. Because of her medical history, Mrs. Patten said, the price of health insurance is far beyond anything she can afford.
Working until a year ago, most recently marking prices on goods at a women's clothing store, she had insurance from employers that covered most of her huge medical expenses, including the heart bypass surgery, a mastectomy, a hysterectomy and two wrist operations for a repetitive motion injury related to her work.
After decades of middle-class security, the Pattens, whose savings are down to $2,000, fear that another setback will drive them out of their $65,000 white clapboard home and onto the welfare rolls.
"A person keeps their nose to the grindstone, works hard, pays their bills on time," Mrs. Patten said in a letter to Hillary Rodham Clinton. "Then when your health goes bad they kick you into a corner."
The Pattens' annual income is now $23,460, the total of the $1,374 Social Security disability check that Mr. Patten gets each month and $581 a month in disability compensation from his last employer.
They spend about $1,100 a year for medicine -- one expense they would largely avoid under the Clinton plan, which would extend prescription coverage to all. Dr. Glanzer accepts Medicare's payment for Mr. Patten's visits and lets Mrs. Patten pay for hers in small installments. Mrs. Patten's disability will qualify her for Medicare in July 1994, but she wonders what would happen if she needed another operation before then.
Their one worry about Mr. Clinton's plan concerns Dr. Glanzer. She has joined a group of doctors who will compete to provide health care to businesses and their employees. In theory, under the structure the President has proposed, the Pattens should be able to choose that plan, or keep going to Dr. Glanzer under Medicare. But both the doctor and her patients feel uncertain about how the new system would really run, and they wonder whether things will work out as smoothly as promised.
"They will be better off with their medicine and their insurance," Dr. Glanzer said. "But in terms of whether they keep me as a physician, I don't know. You may get a choice, but maybe not the choice you want."
 
The Weirathers
Cancer Bouts Bring On Poverty
 Marie Weirather is the embodiment of the Pattens' fears of being driven into poverty.
Ms. Weirather, who is 26 and divorced, lives with her two spirited little girls in a trailer in Iowa City that has flimsy, sheet-metal walls. Her disastrous bouts with cancer and the medical system have drained her of all her money and even personal possessions. She would welcome the changes proposed by the President, but she is skeptical about how soon they will materialize.
Her living room is also the master bedroom, with a foot-high double bed taking up the center. Her daughter, Andrea, who is 4 and entering a Head Start program soon, is asleep in the back, and Beverly, 5, is in school.
Ms. Weirather (pronounced WY-rather) is living on food stamps and welfare checks of $426 a month, because of her medical problems. She also receives an $895-per-semester Federal Pell grant to go to the University of Iowa here part time.
Once Ms. Weirather's care was simple and automatic. Her former husband had insurance through his job as a mechanic at a Chrysler dealership when, in October 1990, a malignant tumor was found on her left ovary. "I went in, and they said, 'Surgery,' " she said. "Within a week, I had surgery." After the divorce, Mr. Weirather left his job for another without insurance. Her eyes welling up, Ms. Weirather said that a year after her operation, doctors spotted another growth on the same ovary. They removed it last fall.
Public assistance paid for the operation and her chemotherapy, she said. "But I was left owing $5,000 to the hospital," she said.
Ms. Weirather owns nothing to speak of anymore. "I had a 1990 Dodge Spirit turbo," she said. "It was essential transportation." She sold it for $4,000 along with a small piece of land to pay the bill. "It was the one really nice thing that I had, and the only new car that I ever owned," she said.
And she still owes $500. After finishing a temporary job as a laboratory aide in May, she became eligible for Medicaid.
She said she welcomed Mr. Clinton's promise of nearly free care for herself, but she does not intend to wait to see the promise fulfilled. She has her own health insurance plan -- marriage in December to a man who hopes to follow others in his family into the Army. The Army provides family health care. She would complete college, having a little more than a year to go, and become a respiratory therapist.
"I'm not getting married for the financial aspect of it," Ms. Weirather said, "but it sure is a nice bonus."
She believes the health care system will take ages to fix. "The Government's going to have to put price controls on what doctors charge," she said. "That's going to be a big controversy. And the bigger companies are going to have to absorb some costs. I have a hard time visualizing it happening, even in 5 to 10 years."
 
The O'Connors
Taking a Pay Cut To Get Coverage
 Debra O'Connor is a true doubter when President Clinton talks about how he intends to finance his health care program. But when it comes to the plan's principal selling point -- guaranteed coverage regardless of job status or other factors -- she is a true believer.
After all, it was the lure of a good, affordable health insurance plan that led Ms. O'Connor to switch from a higher-paying job managing a pizza parlor to a $6-an-hour assembly job at a Rockwell International aircraft electronics factory in Coralville, Iowa, two years ago.
And now, with the aerospace industry in turmoil, it is the fear of being laid off and losing that good health insurance that has her wishing for a plan like the one Mr. Clinton has proposed.
Ms. O'Connor is a 30-year-old single mother of three boys, ages 5, 7 and 9. She lives with her parents in a farmhouse in Lisbon, Iowa, a village southeast of Cedar Rapids.
Zachary, the 7-year-old, has asthma, she said, and a simple bee sting means a trip to the hospital. "It always triggers an asthma attack," she said.
When her youngest child, Kyle, had an attack of croup and a viral infection about a year ago, Ms. O'Connor had to drive him 20 miles in the middle of the night along icy roads to a hospital in Cedar Rapids.
The hospital bill was $1,814, but her entire cost under her company's insurance plan was $100.
"I don't even fill out any medical insurance forms," she said. "For me it's very simple."
At her former job, Ms. O'Connor was told that she would have to pay $250 a month to provide health insurance for her children. "There was no possibility I could afford to do that," she said.
Since taking the job at Rockwell, Ms. O'Connor's pay has increased to $8.20 an hour, which is still much less than her previous job, which paid almost $10 an hour, or $22,000 a year. But at Rockwell, "I got full insurance benefits for $7 a month," she said. "That was a big deal for me."
She pays $10 to visit any of the affiliated doctors, $25 to use the outpatient services of St. Luke's Hospital in Cedar Rapids and $100 for any hospital stay. She also pays $3 per prescription for generic drugs and $10 for brand-name drugs.
Still, Ms. O'Connor is skittish. The rise in health care costs is nipping at her insurance plan. Until this year, she said, prescriptions were free. And she cannot be sure of what lies ahead for Rockwell.
The aerospace company recently laid off more than 100 workers at a nearby plant, but Ms. O'Connor's plant is still humming. No one has ever been laid off there, she said, but with the industry's problems, it could happen any day.
As the President put it, she is one of the millions of workers who are "just a pink slip away" from losing their health insurance. With only two years' seniority at Rockwell, she would be among the first to go if business slumps.
"I want to keep that plan, even if I'm not there," Ms. O'Connor said, and Mr. Clinton assured her she could. Even if Rockwell begins charging her more for her health coverage, she said, "that's O.K. as long as I know I always have insurance."
 
The Coens
A Good Life With a Big 'If'
 William Coen, 79, the retired postmaster of Iowa City, and his wife, Gertrude, 77, had been worried about what the Government might do to their health care coverage, but they liked everything they heard from the President. "He said he'd keep Medicare," Mrs. Coen said. "He said we'd have long-term care and mental health -- all those things. You know, when you're older, things happen."
For the Coens, health care is effective and gentle on their finances. Like 99 percent of the population 65 and older, they are covered by Medicare, the Government's health insurance program for the elderly, and they also have private insurance that covers most of what Medicare does not. "For us," Mr. Coen said, "it's O.K. the way it is. I know it's not for a lot of other people."
The couple have paid off the mortgage on their compact split-level house in an Iowa City subdivision. They have a pension, Social Security and savings that give them an income of more than $40,000 a year.
Their sole significant out-of-pocket health expenses last year were $1,939 for medicine and $1,828 for insurance for hospitalization costs not covered by Medicare. The one thing that worries them, however, is the possibility of being struck by a disabling illness that would require long-term care. Such care can eat up $30,000 a year or more and is not covered by Medicare. Mr. Coen's mother died at 93 of Alzheimer's disease after seven years in a nursing home. She was indigent by then, having exhausted proceeds from the sale of her four-unit apartment house that was also her home.
Of course, the Coens could buy insurance to pay for long-term care. But that could cost them $1,000 or more a month, and they say the policies are riddled with exclusions. "When you need it most," Mrs. Coen said, "it doesn't do you any good."
The Coens were relieved to hear the President promise to help with long-term care. But Mr. Coen wants to see the details. Mr. Clinton has mainly proposed more assistance for home care for the disabled, and has deferred any major new coverage of nursing home costs. If the proposed new nursing home assistance would cover only $30,000 of the cost of a one-year stay in a nursing home, Mr. Coen said, "then I don't think that's too great a come-on."
Mr. Clinton's proposal to cover prescription drugs through Medicare, though, came as a relief. That would have saved them almost $2,000 last year.
Mr. Coen said there was "a fear that Medicare premiums are going to be raised quite high," but he added that those costs, after the cuts in spending for drugs, might not make a big difference in their annual income.

HEADLINE: A Space Odyssey

BYLINE: By Julie V. Iovine

 BODY:
ERIC OWEN MOSS IS something of a lone ranger on Los Angeles's architectural frontier. His buildings cannot be classified by style or school. They possess an off-kilter energy; at the same time, they're grounded in modernism. However, it's modernist literature, rather than architecture, that inspires them -- Joyce's "Ulysses," as opposed to Mies van der Rohe's Seagram Building. "I'm always looking for new ways to reshuffle reality," Moss explains. "In architecture, as in life, the problems never change, just the solutions."
So in Los Angeles, where houses on spectacular sites are as ubiquitous as unemployed actors, Moss was confronted with a narrow shoebox lot with no views to recommend it. The clients wanted something special, something (to use a 60's word) "mind-bending." Moss obliged with a building that looks inward. In place of exterior views, this house has its vistas inside. 
 He began by fusing a rectangle, a cylinder and a cone into a single cataclysmic mass. The soaring interior space is crisscrossed with catwalks and flooded with light from windows placed every which way. Wherever you look, there is motion. Climbing the dizzying stairs, you might expect to experience vertigo. Instead, it's more like wonder: there is something unanticipated to see at every turn.
But the ultimate surprise is not how radical this house looks -- after all, this is Tinseltown -- but how livable it is. Here's a space that defies description, and yet, as Moss put it: "You still know where the groceries come in and where to find the terrace. The garage is exactly where it should be, and so are the kids' rooms."
Moss excels at charting an unknown path through middle-class turf, turning a workaday reality into something startling. Or, in the best modernist tradition, he makes good on Ezra Pound's exhortation: "Make it new."

GRAPHIC: Photos; On a narrow Los Angeles lot with no views, the architect Eric Owen Moss created a commanding spectacle: a house that is a merger of geometric shapes. But despite its avant-garde look, the building has plenty of conventional amenities. The stairway, installed between the kitchen and the living area, offers views at each level. The sculptural furnishings are from Dialogica; the architect designed the coffee table. HEADLINE: THE OUTLOOK: The Future;
Plan Is No Panacea But a Remedy for Costs And Major Inequities

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
Suppose President Clinton's health plan is adopted. Suppose every American gets a health insurance card and no one need worry again about being uninsured. Will the nation be healthier?
The answer might seem obvious. After all, 37 million Americans are uninsured. How could the plan do anything but improve the overall health of the country? 
 Oddly, medical and public health experts say that although the system may increase access to health care and although it may be more equitable than the current system, it will not necessarily make Americans healthier, at least by the broad measures generally used to gauge public health.
The problem, health experts say, is that the proposal for overhauling health care is not really a health program. Instead, it is a plan to pay for doctor visits, prescriptions and hospitalizations. It is a plan to insure that no one is bankrupted by medical bills. But sickness and death are often caused by poverty and dangerous habits like smoking, which will not necessarily be affected. Many people who disregard advice to have children vaccinated or to have a Pap smear or exercise or eat less fat or drink less alcohol will not change their ways because they have health insurance.
 
Benefits for Many People

 To be sure, President Clinton has always promoted the plan as what it is: a way to address gross inequities in health care and to get medical costs under control. In his address to the nation in September, he said the urgent priority was "giving every American health security, health care that can never be taken away."
And many people are expected to gain enormous benefits. For example, Uwe Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University, said: "Uninsured people now think twice before they go to a doctor for a headache or even a lump in the breast. Every contact is so, so expensive."
And Dr. Alan Garber, an internist and a health economist at Stanford University, said some people who are now uninsured would undoubtedly benefit from the plan. Others said that poor people now receiving spotty care on Medicaid might do better with a family doctor in a health plan.
But "you have to ask how much difference the health care system can make," Dr. Garber said.
Dr. Reinhardt noted that the Clinton plan was a financial security plan. In fact, it is called a health security plan. Instead of promising good health outright, the American Health Security Act promises that all Americans will have health insurance, with access to plans that meet national standards on benefits, quality and access to care.
"That is very important," Dr. Reinhardt added. "But if you want to make them healthy, get them out of poverty."
One problem in trying to decide how the health plan will affect the nation's health is deciding how to measure health. Public health officials often look at two measures, infant mortality and life expectancy. Neither statistic is likely to be altered perceptibly by the Clinton health plan, experts say.
 
The Class Factor
 Infant mortality is highest in the inner cities, where pregnant women often suffer from more than lack of health insurance and where they often have Medicaid. They may be teen-agers, they may smoke heavily, or use cocaine or heroin, and they may have a very poor diet.
Dr. Reinhardt noted that in Britain women had prenatal care through the national health service for more than 30 years. Yet, he said, infant mortality among people in the lower social classes is still triple the rate among people in the higher classes.
Dr. Garber said infant mortality was particularly troubling because "it is heavily influenced by factors outside the medical care system." Nor is longevity likely to change, experts said. Dr. James W. Vaupel, a medical demographer at Duke University and Odenske University Medical School in Denmark, said there was little relationship between a nation's health care delivery system and its average life span. The United States has an average life span of 75 years, a figure comparable to that of European countries, where health care is readily available to all. But it is also comparable to China and Costa Rica, poor countries where "the level of care is very, very low," Dr. Vaupel said. "There may not be a lot of connection between the quality or level of care and life expectancy.
"Medical care sometimes saves our lives. But the main purpose of medical care is to help us get over an acute illness." And that, he said, does not measurably change a nation's average life expectancy.
"Even if you saved 100,000 lives, it wouldn't show up in the life expectancy figures," Dr. Reinhardt said. "If you write down the equations, you realize what unbelievably dramatic changes have to happen" for life expectancy to budge.
So, Dr. Reinhardt said, "if you want to judge health reform by measurable health status indicators, you'll be sorely disappointed." While the Clinton plan's focus on preventive medicine is generally a good thing, Dr. Garber said, "we shouldn't be surprised if the effects are small" -- even in looking at specific diseases.
One reason is that many people are already receiving preventive care, like vaccines for their children, screening to detect diseases early or blood pressure checks, even if they have to pay for it themselves. So for a noticeable difference to occur, there would have to be a substantial change in the health of those who would suddenly have health insurance.
 
Hard Populations to Reach
 But many people who do not get such care are among the most difficult to reach. They often are poor and poorly educated. Dr. Robert Blendon, a professor of health policy at the Harvard School of Public Health, said: "If you remove the financial barrier, some will come in, but not all. Another group comes in after an educational effort." As for the third group, the most recalcitrant, "you literally have to send the vans out to get them," he said.
A second reason that gains will be limited is that doctors have only a limited arsenal of preventive and early detection measures. These include childhood vaccinations, screening for high blood pressure, Pap smears and mammograms. Many conditions cannot be prevented: most cancer, birth defects, many cases of heart attacks. Others could be partly alleviated by changes in personal habits, like stopping smoking or eating a low-fat diet.
A decade ago, the Rand Corporation conducted a huge study of free medical care, including preventive services. The only improvements found were among the poor people in the group: more of them got glasses and their blood pressure levels were slightly decreased. The study, which involved 3,958 people, aged 14 to 61, concluded that "free health care did not improve health status." It also said the people who received free care visited doctors more often, spent more time in the hospital and perceived themselves as sicker than those who had to pay.
And in places that stress preventive services, like Hawaii, very few people take advantage of them. "Whenever we offer preventive services, like mammograms or Pap smears or cholesterol screening," said Robert Mytinger, who is vice president for community relations at the Hawaii Medical Services Association, "we never get more than 25 percent of the eligible population."
Of course, Dr. Blendon said, there are aspects of health care that are not captured by health statistics but that do improve people's lives. "Medical care will affect pain and disability, but when you talk of mortality or life expectancy, that doesn't show up," he said. "My mother is convinced that if she has her cataract out, she's healthier. But that won't affect her life expectancy." In fact, national surveys repeatedly showed that people did not become healthier because they went to doctors.
"You go to a doctor when you're born, when you have babies, when you get really sick, and just before you die," said Dr. Donald Patrick, a professor of health services at the University of Washington in Seattle. "Otherwise, if you're lucky, you stay out of the medical system."

HEADLINE: THE MEDICAL BUSINESS: Drug Companies;
Pressure to Keep Prescription Prices Down

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Exchanging verbal thunderbolts with the companies that make prescription drugs, President Clinton has denounced high prices that force some sick and elderly Americans to skip meals to pay for medicine.
His proposals for revamping the medical system would fundamentally affect drug companies, pressuring them to hold down prices and in some ways treating them as much like a crucial social service or public utility as private profit-seeking businesses. 
 For their part, the drug makers say the President is unfairly singling them out. They assert that his proposals would cripple research budgets, delaying cures for scourges like AIDS, cancer and Alzheimer's disease.
Drug company executives say their products save money and lives by helping to avert expensive hospital stays and surgery. But critics assert that the industry took advantage of patients and payers for years by raising prices at more than double the inflation rate in the late 1980's and early 1990's.
The companies insist they have turned over a new leaf and are already holding down prices. They say this is partly because they are under pressure from health maintenance organizations and insurance discount plans. Under attack by Congress, the President and the First Lady, 17 large drug makers have promised to keep their price increases in line with the consumer price index.
Pharmaceutical executives say they are pleased that the Clinton plan would add an estimated 70 million people to the 174 million who already have insurance coverage for drugs. Drugs are included in the basic insurance all workers would get. Also, for the first time, the Federal Medicare program would pay 80 percent of prescription costs for the elderly and disabled; now, the program pays only for prescriptions for hospital patients.
But Jerome R. Brimeyer, a securities analyst at Lehman Brothers, questioned whether Congress would approve the drug benefit. It would add $14 billion to $20 billion a year to Medicare, he said, making it harder for the President to deliver on his proposal to sharply curtail increases in Medicare spending.
 
Attack on Four Fronts
 Under the Clinton plan, drug prices would come under attack on at least four fronts:
*A new National Health Board could investigate "unreasonable" prices, requiring a company to bring in its records if a drug price was higher in the nation than abroad.
*Companies would have to return to Medicare a rebate of 17 percent of their average nationwide price for each drug paid for by Medicare. The drug industry says such rebates would cost it in excess of $2 billion a year.
*The Secretary of Health and Human Services could bargain down the prices of new drugs before Medicare agreed to pay for them. If the companies resist, Medicare could refuse to pay for these drugs. Doctors would need permission from a Government official to prescribe, for Medicare patients, drugs deemed unreasonably costly.
*Most Americans would be expected to join plans that offer financial incentives to use the lowest-priced drugs. And by limiting increases in health insurance premiums, the Government would force insurers to keep reducing costs, including those of drugs.
Drug company executives argue that the Clinton proposals are price controls, which they insist do not work. They say prices should be kept low by competition. But critics noted that some companies had long exploited the demand for patent-protected drugs by setting high prices.
G. Kirk Raab, chief executive of Genentech Inc. of San Francisco, one of the most successful biotechnology companies, said the price constraints "could slow down or eliminate the volume of research" by making it harder for young companies to raise money from investors. Genentech's products include genetically engineered human growth hormone and a drug that dissolves blood clots after heart attacks.
Investors supply at least 80 percent of the working capital for biotechnology companies, and there are more than 1,000 small biotechnology companies, of which 235 have sold stock to the public. But the biotechnology industry still has only two dozen drugs to its credit and 130 more awaiting approval by the Food and Drug Administration.
Critics like Senator David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, say that companies have spent years pouring research dollars into products that duplicated already available drugs. The F.D.A. said that only 40 percent of the new drugs approved last year were a significant advance over existing ones.
