SECTION: Section 6; Page 50; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 9473 words

HEADLINE: There's No Simple Suicide

BYLINE: By Lisa Belkin; Lisa Belkin, a former reporter for The New York Times, is the author of "First, Do No Harm," a book about medicine and ethics.

 BODY:
By the time the Rev. Ralph Mero arrived at Louise J.'s tiny Seattle apartment, she had already emptied the contents of the sleeping pills into a small cereal bowl. He had suggested mixing the 40 Nembutal capsules with something sweet, to make them more palatable; Louise chose a blend of applesauce and ice cream. Years of illness had left her too weak and shaky to open each tiny pill by hand, so instead she punctured the outer coating with a hypodermic syringe. Then she squeezed each capsule gently between her forefinger and thumb until the powder spilled out in a dusty cloud.
The resulting concoction was waiting in the refrigerator when Mero rang the bell, shortly after 8 on the brisk August night. Louise's mother was already there, as was the one friend, a medical assistant, who had agreed to share this intimate moment. No one but Louise had handled the pills. Only her fingerprints were on the bowl. It would not do to implicate her new friend Mero, or her mother, or her doctor, or the handful of others who knew about and had helped her with her plan. 
 After the initial greetings, Mero sat on the couch where Louise lay curled in her favorite flannel nightgown and thick woolen socks. He took her hand in his, looked her in the eye and told her she could change her mind, that no one would think less of her for it, that she could wait until another day.
"I'm ready now," she told him.
"Once you eat that, you're going to fall asleep very quickly," Mero said. "Don't you want to go lie on your bed before you start?"
"I've never really cared much for my bedroom," Louise answered. "This room is where I want to die."
She quickly spooned up the last soupy drops. Then she lay back into the pillows and closed her eyes, as her mother stroked her hand. Her friend began to read a chapter from a fantasy novel Louise had not had time to finish. By the second page, Louise was snoring loudly.
The friend continued to read, quietly, not raising her voice above Louise's rattling slumber. She turned page after page, for nearly 20 minutes, until the chapter was over. Then she put the book down and stood with Mero and Louise's mother around the living-room coffee table, while the minister said a short prayer. He thanked God for the gift of life and for the young woman now relinquishing it. It would be cruelty, he said, for her to continue living in such pain. He asked help for all God's children who are suffering. What he did not ask aloud was what everyone was hoping silently -- that Louise would stop breathing soon.
COMMITTING SUICIDE IS NOT AGAINST THE law in Washington State, where Louise lived and chose to die. Helping someone commit suicide is. Mero sees this distinction, however, as a challenge, not a hindrance. This past spring he co-founded an organization, Compassion in Dying, to help terminally ill patients end their lives. Its members include doctors, nurses, social workers and members of the clergy like Mero, a Unitarian Universalist minister for 30 years.
What Compassion members will do is almost limitless: offer advice on lethal doses, counsel bereaved family members, convince wary doctors, literally hold a patient's hand at the moment of death. What they will not do is simple: they will not provide or administer the drugs. It is a role that some call heroic and others call heretical. Mero was either Louise's savior or executioner, depending on one's point of view.
"God in his wisdom sent me the help I need," Louise said in an interview earlier in the summer. "I can't believe that this wonderful man is willing to be there for me."
That view impels a harsh reaction from people like Ned Dolejsi, executive director of the Washington State Catholic Conference: " 'I am God, I control life and death,' that's what they're saying. God is God, and we're not. It's that simple."
Behind these polar positions lies an open secret of medicine. Assisted suicide, though generally against the law, happens all the time. In six years of reporting about health care, I've heard countless stories, offered freely and without regret, from people who have helped other people die. A minister recalled how he watched a parishioner and his wife flush two bottles of heart medication down the toilet, then sat through the night with the family as they waited for the patient to have his inevitable heart attack. A graphic designer told of lying to his own doctors, saying he could not sleep, then giving the resulting sedatives to his lover, who wanted to shorten the agony of AIDS. A wife described the peace she felt helping her suffering husband empty dozens of capsules into a vanilla pudding she had cooked for him. A social worker remembered searching the house for medication with which her cancer-ridden father could mix a lethal cocktail, finally offering him the last of her own tranquilizer prescription. As she waited for him to die, she said, she wished she had saved just one tranquilizer for herself.
Doctors tell these stories, too -- although their involvement is usually less direct and less dramatic. More than one doctor has matter-of-factly spoken of writing prescriptions for sedatives and painkillers, suspecting -- often knowing -- that the patient would consume them all in one final, desperate, swallow. And for patients who can not swallow, intravenous morphine can be prescribed liberally.
Such assistance is not offered every day by every doctor, and is still so morally and legally ambiguous that no doctor who shared his story with me was willing to attach his name to it. But one doctor, Timothy E. Quill, has gone public. In 1991, Quill, a physician at Genesee Hospital in Rochester, wrote in a New England Journal of Medicine article of a leukemia patient he had known for several years. He supplied her with a barbiturate prescription, knowing that she planned to commit suicide to end her suffering; three months later, she did. Both the Monroe County District Attorney and the New York State Health Department investigated the case, but no charges were brought.
And of course there is Dr. Jack Kevorkian, the Michigan physician who helps patients die with the help of a tank of carbon monoxide and a mask and who, in contrast to Quill, faces felony charges for violating an assisted-suicide law in his home state. Mero has met Kevorkian (the world of assisted suicide is a small one) and strongly dislikes his approach.
"I think Dr. Kevorkian is an unfortunate spokesman for a good cause," Mero says, in the slow, measured tones in which he says just about everything. "He has so personalized the issue of assisted suicide that a lot of people forget about the patients and think only about this one strange physician. He appears reckless, unrestrained, flagrant."
Those three words are unlikely ever to be applied to Mero, a cautious, deliberate man who is not necessarily joking when he says: "I was spontaneous. Once. When I was 9 years old." Even on a subject as passionate as death, he speaks with the quiet understatement of someone who long ago wrestled with the shades of gray and emerged, as he describes it, with "no doubts whatsoever, absolutely none." And when the topic is Compassion in Dying, Mero talks so slowly that a listener sometimes wonders if the next word will ever come.
"It is important that I be precise, and accurate, and careful, and not say something that might be misinterpreted," he says. "Much is at stake. Much is at stake."
What is at stake is Mero's vision of the future as a time when all doctors can openly do what many doctors are already doing surreptitiously: helping patients to die. He describes Compassion as a "ministerial demonstration project," an experiment in assisted suicide, designed to "show, demonstrate, prove, that when people make a claim for humane treatment, it can be provided in a way that does not jeopardize vulnerable people or pose a threat to the social fabric."
Compassion in Dying, in other words, is a prototype, a model for other, similar programs throughout the United States. With that in mind, Mero and the other members of Compassion have set up their organization with a constant eye toward the long term, creating written guidelines that cover every detail, from how patients are chosen to how many Compassion members will attend an assisted death. Almost everything about the rules, in fact the very existence of the rules, can be seen as a determined contrast to Jack Kevorkian.
"I personally know he is a very thoughtful and deliberate physician in his relationships with his patients," Mero says of his more visible, more vocal predecessor. "But he has not made any effort to communicate that to the American public. Dr. Kevorkian provides no information about how he selects the patients he chooses to help, no overall framework or guidelines. To many people, his penchant for publicity appears unseemly, and appears designed to focus attention on him rather than on the greater issue, that suffering people have a right to choose."
One of Compassion's most essential rules, therefore, is secrecy. Kevorkian calls the authorities after each assisted suicide -- by early November, he had been involved in 19 -- and, police radios being monitored as they are, the press and the police often arrive at the scene simultaneously. Compassion, in contrast, does not announce its assistance in a suicide. In fact, in the three cases that the organization has admitted involvement in so far, the medical examiner's office was not told that the deaths were suicides. The patients' doctors, who knew in advance of the plans, certified the deaths as expected and natural, so no autopsies were performed.
"There is no reason why death should be a public spectacle," Mero says, his voice tightening. "Death is a universal human experience, characterized by grief, loss, memory and hope. It seems poorly served to have it sensationalized and hung out like so much dirty laundry."
Compassion's code of secrecy, however, inherently limits its broader goal; it's hard to change the world if no one knows you're doing it. Mero acknowledges the conflict.
"We have to be exceedingly careful in dealing with the tender privacy of people's anguish, but at the same time," he adds, forming a scale with his hands as if weighing one value against the other, "we want the world to know what we are doing, and show that it can be done in an ethical, responsible manner."
It was that calibrated balancing act, I suspect, that made this article possible. After weeks of discussion with Mero and other members of the Compassion board, I was invited to watch the group work, in direct contradiction of its secrecy rules. There were, however, some limitations. The most significant was that Louise's real name not be given. Louise is the name her mother almost gave her when she was born, and it is the name her mother has taken to calling her now, as if to evoke the other, unborn daughter -- the one meant not to die.
Similarly, I have agreed not to identify the illness that led to Louise's decision to die; doing otherwise, Louise feared, might provide a clue for anyone trying to identify her and could expose her mother to harassment or arrest. What can be said is that Louise's condition was painful, debilitating and invariably fatal, causing, among other things, the eventual disintegration of her brain. The numerous doctors caring for her all agreed that her death was inevitable and, by the time she decided to take her own life, no more than a few weeks away.
LOUISE HAD MENTIONED SUICIDE periodically during her six years of illness, but the subject came into sudden focus in May during a somber visit to her doctor's office.
"I had an awareness of an inner shift taking place," Louise recalled. "I really wasn't having any different symptoms, I just knew something had changed. I looked the doctor right in the eye and said, 'I'm starting to die.' And she said, 'I've had the same impression for a couple of days.' "
An M.R.I. scan confirmed that the frontal lobes of Louise's brain had begun to deteriorate, a sign that led her doctor to warn Louise that her life would most likely be measured in months, perhaps weeks.
"She explained that she didn't want to scare me," Louise said of her doctor, a warm, down-to-earth woman. "She just wanted to be honest. She told me that once the disease becomes active it progresses very fast, that I would become mentally incapacitated and wouldn't be myself, couldn't care for myself anymore. She would have to look into hospice care, or the hospital, or some other facility, where I would stay until I died."
Once the doctor had finished speaking, Louise did not hesitate with her answer. "I can't do that," Louise remembered responding. "I don't want that."
Her doctor, Louise thought, looked both sad and relieved. "I know," the doctor said. "But it has to come from you."
"I just want to be clear that we're both talking about the same thing," Louise had emphasized. "Suicide."
"Yes," her doctor answered.
"O.K. That's what I'd like to do, go for as long as I can and then end it."
The doctor explained that she would be willing to help -- that in fact she had helped another patient several months earlier, a man Louise knew. The doctor would prescribe enough barbiturates to accomplish the goal, but could not agree to be there when Louise committed suicide.
"She didn't want any legal trouble," Louise later said. "I didn't want to get her in any trouble. I just wanted some help."
They exchanged several hugs, then Louise went home. The doctor wrote a carefully worded note about the meeting in Louise's chart. She made no mention of the discussion of suicide.
AS SPRING DRIFTED INTO SUMMER, LOUISE'S health steadily declined; in July the doctor called Compassion in Dying. She had heard of the organization through a hospice nurse who had come to believe that in some cases even a hospice did not meet a patient's needs. The doctor wanted advice. For all her years of medical school, she had no training in how to help a patient end her own life. Of course she had some educated theories, and a handful of literature on the subject. Both Derek Humphry, founder of the Hemlock Society, and Betty Rollin, author and television reporter, have published best-selling books on suicide; Humphry's book offers a detailed recipe.
But even with those available instructions, it is surprisingly complicated to cause one's own death, or, in the case of the doctor, to estimate what is necessary to cause someone else's. Chronic patients like Louise develop tolerance to certain medications, requiring higher doses than the literature would advise. Some have difficulty tolerating alcohol, which is recommended as an accompaniment to speed the effect of barbiturates. Other patients have trouble swallowing food and keeping it down, creating the risk that only part of the dosage will be ingested, inducing coma but not death.
The doctor's one experience with a patient's suicide had made the complications clear. The patient, also a friend, had asked for her advice. After researching the issue, she gave the man "a couple of options," which he then took to another physician in another state where he was living at the time. The doctor was not present, so she does not know which drugs were used nor the dosage, but she believes that, in the end, the friends who were with him may have had to "use the bag" -- that is, place a plastic bag over the unconscious man's head until he suffocated.
So it was with great relief that the doctor called Compassion in Dying and spoke at length to Mero.
"I was ecstatic to find someone who's doing what he's doing," she said. "I loved the fact that there were guidelines. It made so much sense. This was a human being who could help, not some book."
Mero seems to have a knack for putting people immediately at ease. He is a quiet, nonthreatening figure, with a soft voice and a friendly face all but obscured by his beard and glasses; his outer calm offers only a hint of deeply buried emotion. Most appealing, though, is Mero's ability to listen without judging. He talks of suicide as if it is just another form of medical treatment -- a welcome reaction for patients, doctors and families who expect to be met by shock or scorn.
There was no one moment, Mero says, when he developed his ease with the subject of death; the process was an incremental one. Born in Seattle 56 years ago, Mero grew up in Chicago, where he lived until he graduated from college. In 1958 he began working on his doctorate in sociology at Emory University in Atlanta, but when he told his advisers that he planned to do his thesis on the sit-in movement and patterns of race relations in the South, they rejected the topic as unacademic. Mero left school and took a job as a welfare caseworker in Yonkers, where he became active in a local Unitarian church. The minister there persuaded him to join the profession, and Mero entered the Meadville-Lombard Theological School, a Unitarian Universalist seminary in Chicago, in 1961. While there, he became active in the growing civil rights movement, joining the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.'s 1965 Selma march. By the time Mero became minister of a small church in suburban Seattle, he already had a reputation for being outspoken.
During six years of controversial stands, Mero, already married (he would later divorce) and the father of two sons, watched his congregation grow from 45 members to 145. "I always understood that the purpose of religion was to help make sense of the issues of the day, and to address the troubles of those who are suffering," he says. "In order to have any authenticity at all, religion has to alleviate the suffering of people in pain."
When a recession hit Seattle in the early 1970's, and his parish could no longer afford his $11,000 salary, Mero worked in the secular world, first with Planned Parenthood, then as the administrator of a private medical practice. The departure, which he viewed as temporary, has stretched to 20 years.
In 1988 Mero happened to attend a conference about euthanasia. The subject struck a chord. Two years earlier, his father had died a slow, difficult death from emphysema and heart disease. The elder Mero often talked of taking his own life with a pistol he had saved from his days as a World War I pilot. During one visit to his father, Mero removed the weapon from the house, believing then, as now, that violent suicide "is an unacceptable, tragic end." "There is no peace," he says. "That would have been a terribly painful experience for my stepmother."
At the same time, Mero's brother-in-law was suffering from AIDS. Mero spent much time with him, and, later, with an acquaintance who was also in the final stages of that disease. "I was utterly horrified and outraged that lovely human beings should have to die in such a decimated state," he says.
The euthanasia conference, sponsored by the Hemlock Society, which lifted the veil of silence on the subject of assisted suicide in the United States in 1980, showed Mero a way to act on that outrage. Within weeks, Mero helped start the first Hemlock chapter in Washington State, and shortly thereafter took a full-time job as the group's northwest regional director. He traveled throughout four states, speaking publicly about assisted suicide and collecting advice from doctors about methods that had worked for their patients. During those years Mero assisted in several deaths, though never as directly as he does now. People would call him, at the office or at home, often in the middle of the night, telling him of the drugs they had on hand and asking if that was enough to do the job.
"On several occassions," Mero says, "I was the last person to talk with a dying patient before they committed suicide."
In 1991 Mero once again changed his life. Although he didn't take much credit for it at the time, he was an author of Initiative 119, a voter referendum that would have made it legal for doctors in Washington to help some terminally ill patients take their own lives. No state allows such an expansion of a doctor's role; only one country -- the Netherlands -- permits physician-assisted suicide. The battle for voter opinion in Washington was fierce. Mero's camp found itself parading suffering patients before the press, trying to balance privacy with urgency. The opposition, meanwhile, spent large sums portraying proponents as ghoulish doctors intent on murdering the poor and elderly. Lost in the cacophony was the more reasoned debate between those who believed suicide could be a rational choice and those who worried that the emphasis should instead be on comforting the dying and controlling their pain.
The proposition was defeated, 54 percent to 46 percent. Mero took the loss hard. He had been touched by the stories he had helped publicize during the campaign, and was enraged when one patient, an elderly farmer in Spokane, walked into a pasture a few days after the vote, put a shotgun to his head and pulled the trigger. The man had been waiting for the election results, his wife explained to reporters. He had promised her that, if the vote turned out favorably, he would hold on for several more months, secure in the knowledge that a doctor would be there to help him die.
"It was unforgivable that people who had been counting so much on this as a sign of hope were now to be thwarted," Mero says. "I felt the way you feel when you've done all you can and it isn't enough."
Mero partly blamed Kevorkian for the defeat of Initiative 119. During the final weeks of the campaign, Mero heard that Kevorkian was timing his next assisted suicide (a double suicide, it later turned out, involving two chronically ill women) close to the referendum vote. "I called him and asked him if it was true," Mero says, "and whether he had considered what affect that might have on what we were trying to do. He was quite angry. He indicated that what he did was no one else's business and he really didn't care."
Why was Kevorkian angry? "He couldn't bear being out of the limelight," Mero speculates, alluding to the relative esteem in which the Hemlock founder, Derek Humphry, is held. "I think he was peeved that Derek Humphry's book was a best seller while his own book was sitting in a warehouse, unsold." Whatever the reason for Kevorkian's actions, their impact could not be ignored. "He helped two women die little more than 10 days before the election," Mero says. "Those deaths took place in a cabin in the woods and provided a visual image for our opponents to use suggesting that doctor-assisted suicide was reckless and macabre. It had a very negative effect."
AFTER THE DEFEAT, FRIENDS and colleagues urged Mero to put his energies into drafting a new initiative, one more likely to pass, but that tactic struck him as too slow. If the law could not be changed, and immediately, then it must be challenged.
"Initiatives are very uncertain and unlikely of success regardless of the issue," he says bitterly. "Almost all are defeated, except those promising relief to the taxpayer. If you had an initiative today on the Ten Commandments, I doubt it would pass. If Americans were asked to vote tomorrow on the Bill of Rights, some ad agency would launch a campaign against it."
So, at a Hemlock Society board meeting in March, Mero unveiled a proposal he and others had worked on for several weeks and had thought about for more than a year. He initially referred to the plan as "civil disobedience," remembers Don Cook, a retired computer manager who attended that meeting and who is now the treasurer and co-chairman of Compassion. "We later decided that was a poor choice of words," says Cook. "We wanted to be careful, not confrontational. We concluded we didn't want to break the law in any blatant sense. We wanted to test it."
By April, the national Hemlock Society leadership concluded there was no place within its organization for what Mero was proposing if he meant to break the law at all. It was suggested that a new group be formed. The parting was amicable. Although the two groups are separate, half the members of the current Compassion board also sit on the local Hemlock board, and Compassion and Hemlock have adjacent office space. The new board met in that space at least three times a week for several months, trying to work out the legal, medical and moral details of what they planned to do. They faced questions that had no precedent in any other organization's bylaws.
For weeks, members discussed whom the new group should help. For ethical reasons they decided that patients must be terminally ill and relatively close to death, disqualifying people who potentially had productive years left. By also insisting that patients be residents of Washington State, the group hopes to avoid becoming a wandering suicide squad, or the state from becoming a suicide mecca. To defeat criticism that they were making medical decisions without medical knowledge, members established an advisory committee of physicians, consultants and other health professionals who must examine all patients. And to answer the potential argument that they are giving too much power to that committee, they decided not to help any patient who lacked a doctor who both accepted the suicide plans and agreed to write the fatal prescription.
Those rules masked a wider range of opinion within the group. Sheila Cook, a Compassion board member who watched her mother die slowly of Alzheimer's, wanted to help victims of that disease. Susan Dunshee, co-president of Compassion and executive director of the Seattle AIDS Support Group, frequently encounters patients who, in the final moments of life, are unable to swallow; Dunshee wanted to help patients ingest their fatal doses through an intravenous line, but other members viewed that as too much involvement. Eventually it was decided that only lucid patients who could take their medicines themselves would qualify for help. Patients like Louise.
BY THE TIME LOUISE'S DOCTOR CALLED MERO, Compassion had already assisted in its first suicide. Shortly after Independence Day, Mero and Don Cook had sat in the living room of a 76-year-old man whose prostate cancer had metastasized to the bone. They spent an hour listening as the man reminisced about his life, which had been lived fully and happily, both in the United States and abroad. Then they watched as this relative stranger, whom Mero had met seven times before and Cook had met only twice, ate applesauce laced with 60 Seconal capsules, then took two shots of vodka from a souvenir Seattle mug. In three minutes he was asleep; in four hours he was dead.
Cook remembers feeling strangely disconnected from what he was watching. "I would like to feel closer to the patients than I did that night," he says.
Mero, in contrast, felt no conflict. "My emotional feeling was, this is very special," he says. "Sort of sacred, but not scary. Very meaningful."
For all the years Mero had spent advocating the right to assisted suicide, this was the first suicide he had attended. "I had seen deaths where people were choking, struggling, thrashing," he says, referring to his experiences in the intensive-care units he had often visited as a minister. "But this was a death of serenity, a death wrapped in sleep rather than struggle."
Mero takes solace of another kind from the cases that did not qualify under Compassion's rules and were turned down: the man with emphysema who was overwhelmingly depressed; the two AIDS patients whose doctors would not provide the needed medication. The emphysema patient still calls Mero periodically, once asking him for advice on the most effective place to point the gun. (Mero will not tell him.) The AIDS patients both chose to starve to death. Mero said that the "deep pain" he feels at not being able to help these patients is balanced by the faith he has that, by sticking to the rules, countless other patients eventually can be helped. "The temptation to make just one exception is overruled by the necessity of establishing responsible guidelines that society as a whole will accept."
When he received the call from Louise's doctor, Mero was confident of his rules. And, after hearing the details of her case, he was fairly certain Compassion would be able to help. He suggested two medications to the doctor -- Nembutal or Seconal -- and the recommended dosage of each. The doctor called the pharmacy, found they did not have the strength of Seconal tablets needed and chose the Nembutal instead. Then she made a note of the prescription in Louise's chart, adding that her patient was having trouble sleeping. The doctor made no mention of her conversation with Mero.
MERO VISITED LOUISE several days later. They sat in the living room of her small, peach-walled apartment, surrounded by pictures of Louise skiing in healthier days. Because she tired so quickly, Louise dispensed with social niceties and came directly to the point. Mero says he will never forget how relieved Louise looked to see that he did not flinch when she used the word "suicide."
Then Louise asked if he would be there with her when she died. When he said yes, Mero thought she might cry. Several days earlier, she told him, she had met with a few close friends, informed them of her plans and asked them to support her in her decision and be present during her suicide. Each friend said yes, only to call back later and say she had changed her mind. Worse than that, Louise told Mero, she had not heard from any of the women since.
"I'll be with you and I'll support you," Mero said, carefully. "But this has to be your choice." It was a caveat he would repeat many times. He wanted to be certain that Louise was certain. Morally, he never wanted to wonder whether he had pushed this patient toward a fatal decision. And, for legal reasons, he didn't want anyone else to ever wonder either.
"I do not want to die in a hospital," Louise answered Mero. "I want to do this at home. All I want these next few weeks is to live as peacefully as possible."
When Louise first met Mero, however, she already had noticed the effects of her failing brain. She found it increasingly difficult to maintain her train of thought, and prolonged conversation exhausted her. Over the course of the following weeks, her doctor had noticed other changes, too.
"She's more irritable, she's paranoid, becoming obsessed with things that aren't so significant," the doctor told me over breakfast in a restaurant a few blocks from Louise's house. Although she didn't think Louise's judgment was impaired yet, she worried that it might soon be. "The question is, at what point is her will going to be affected, and, if suicide is what she wants, does she have the right to do it when she still has the will?"
Like Mero, the doctor did not want to influence her patient. Still, she worried Louise might not act in time. "If she loses her mind and doesn't do this, she's going into the hospital. But the last thing I want to do is pressure her to do this."
IN EARLY AUGUST, NEARLY TWO WEEKS AFTER Mero's first visit to Louise, they met again. This time, Louise's mother was present, as was Louise's doctor and the friend who had agreed to help when the others had said no. It was lunchtime, and the doctor brought a vegetarian pizza. Louise ate a small bowl of cereal instead. It was the first food she had eaten since lunch the day before.
For a while, the conversation lingered on the weather, the food, the day's news, everything but the subject that brought them together. Louise's mother and friend were meeting for the first time. It was an awkward moment for the friend. A medical assistant at one of the many doctor's offices that Louise visited regularly, she and Louise had developed a friendly relationship, but not a real friendship. When the friend heard through the medical rumor mill that Louise's most trusted friends had backed away, she called Louise and offered her support. In the days since, they had formed the instant intimacy so often born of necessity. Still, the friend felt uncomfortable meeting Louise's mother. "But she was so warm, so relieved to have someone to share this with, that I felt reassured I was doing the right thing," the friend now says. "She's a grand, tough lady. She reminds me of Colleen Dewhurst. I've never met anyone that strong."
The idle talk continued until Louise, tired by the effort of eating and the noise of conversation, put down her cereal and lay back into the couch with a sigh. Mero took this as a cue to begin. He handed out a printed checklist titled "Steps to Assisted Dying," which Compassion makes available only to patients they have agreed to help. Suddenly businesslike, the group reviewed the nine items one at a time.
"One," read Mero. "It is important to have food in the stomach. Eat a small amount of food two hours before beginning the process of dying. Make it something you like: toast, applesauce, ice cream are recommended." Food, he explained, would prevent the nausea and vomiting that can result when medication is taken on an empty stomach.
Louise said she had not had any appetite lately, but if a light meal would make the process more effective, she would do her best.
"Two. After eating, take two anti-nausea tablets."
The friend said she would pick up something appropriate. Mero then explained Step 3: how to mix the medication with food and suggested several variations. Louise nodded. When Mero reached Step 4, which listed the types of alcohol and the amounts considered most effective, she stopped nodding and began to shake her head.
Her mother interrupted. "Louise doesn't drink."
"I can't drink," said Louise. "I can't tolerate it. I would throw it all back up."
Mero explained that the alcohol "potentiates" the barbiturates, making them work faster and more effectively. Without the alcohol, the barbiturates might be enough to put Louise into a coma, but not enough to kill her.
"Well, I can't drink," Louise said. "So I have to hope for the best."
There was nothing more on the list for Louise to do. The rest of the instructions were aimed at her mother and her friend.
"Five. During the process that follows, the patient's breathing and heartbeat should be monitored. Breathing will become very slow and shallow. Put a mirror in front of the nose or mouth to detect breath. A stethoscope is necessary to hear the heartbeat as the pace slows over a period of several hours."
Louise's friend offered to bring a stethoscope.
Step 6 was a list of drugs an attending nurse could administer to an unconscious, dying patient who appeared to be in pain. The friend said she felt comfortable dispensing most of them. Louise did not have several of the drugs on hand, and her doctor suggested substitutes from among the medications Louise was already taking.
"Seven. Be absolutely sure that death has occurred. Test pupil contraction by shining a bright flashlight in the eye. With a stethoscope, listen hard for a heartbeat. The extremities will cool, but this is a sign of reduced blood pressure, not necessarily evidence of death."
Sitting on the couch, Louise looked drained. Mero completed the list quickly. Step 8: After death, the patient should be washed and the sheets changed. The bowel sphincter, he noted delicately, relaxes during death. Before calling the doctor or funeral home, Mero added, make sure all extra medications are out of sight and all the dishes are washed.
Step 9: The doctor, having been contacted by the family, should call the medical examiner's office and tell him the deceased patient was terminally ill and that the death was expected. That way, no autopsy would be performed.
The doctor nodded. She would be out of town for much of the next week, but she had told her partner of Louise's plans. "You don't have to wait for me to get back," she told Louise, hinting that it might not be a good idea to wait. When Louise's mother walked the doctor to the car, the doctor was more direct, saying she worried that her patient might not be coherent enough to act if she waited past the coming weekend. And over the telephone, the doctor had often told Mero the same thing, warning that there was no way of predicting how fast Louise's ability to carry out her plans would evaporate.
The doctor and Mero discussed how pointed they should be with Louise, wanting to give her enough information to make an informed decision without frightening her into acting sooner than she was ready. They chose to be circumspect and cautious, hoping she would read between the lines.
"That's one of the more delicate and difficult aspects of this work," Mero says. "Stepping back and making sure the patient continues to take the initiative in moving the process along. That means some patients will take too long, will not be able to make things work on time. But I will always err on the side of caution and deliberation. They have to make their own choice. Sometimes, not to decide is to decide."
A few days before that meeting, Mero called me at home in New York and asked me to come to Seattle as soon as possible. He knew I planned to interview Louise the following week, but he warned me not to wait that long.
"She's rapidly deteriorating," he said. "Her physician feels if she doesn't act before the weekend, her window of opportunity will slam shut."
I left for Seattle immediately.
Louise spent our interview lying in bed, reaching for the blankets then throwing them off in alternate fits of fever and chills. In her hand she held a tube of Vaseline, which she applied almost constantly to her parched, cracking lips. At her bedside was a glass of water with a straw, which her mother had offered to soothe Louise's raspy throat. When Louise talked, it was in a near-whisper. At times her mother, who has a hearing problem, had to lean over the bed and put her ear to Louise's mouth to understand what she was saying. I, in turn, sat at the head of the bed, so close that we were practically touching.
She began our meeting as she had begun her meeting with Mero -- asking that we not waste time on small talk for which she had no strength. Louise then went on to explain why she wanted to take her life.
"I'm not depressed," she said. "I'm exhausted. Just walking from the bathroom to the bedroom, I have to catch my breath and sit down. There's so much I've lost control of. I want to be in control of this. I can't wait too long. Nobody else can do this for me. I'm tired. I'm in constant pain. I'm getting weaker by the day. I want to do this at home, before my body's here and my brain isn't."
She was not afraid of death, she said. "I think I was, early on. Before I heard about Compassion. But even then my fear was not overwhelming. It's time. This is right."
Louise was almost ready, she said, but not quite. She had nearly completed her mental list of tasks to tend to before she died: she had closed her bank accounts, familiarized her mother with her life insurance and other papers, found a home for her dog. But she still needed to sign her car title over to the friends she originally bought it from. And she was determined not to die before she could rid herself of her Hickman catheter -- the semipermanent IV line through which she received medication and some nutrition. She was too weak to use it, and it was constantly causing infection. The catheter would be removed in a day or two. Then Louise wanted four or five more days to relax with her mother. In all, she needed about a week.
I was surprised, confused and extremely uncomfortable. Both Louise's doctor and Mero had told me that her available time was measured in days. What they had not told me, and would not tell me until later, is that they had not directly explained the situation to Louise.
Without thinking, I blurted out a question: "Your doctor feels that if you don't act by this weekend you may not be able to. . . . "
My words were met with a wrenching silence. Louise blanched, her pale skin turning even paler. I was horrified with myself.
"She didn't . . . she never. . . . I didn't know that," Louise said sharply, looking at her mother.
"That's what she told me," her mother offered gently.
Louise became silent. All her calm words about being certain, of wanting to die, masked the real point. Everyone -- Mero, the mother, the doctor, the friend and, most significant, Louise herself -- had described suicide as something Louise wanted, a poetic expression of control, a triumph over the indignities of disease. But what Louise really wanted, it now became clear, was simply to not be sick any more. If she couldn't have that, then suicide was a second choice. Suicide was not a victory, but rather a nightmarish end to a nightmare, the most acceptable of the unacceptable options. Earlier in our conversation Louise had denied feeling frightened. But now, lying ashen-faced, less than a foot away, she looked terrified.
"It's O.K. to be afraid," her mother said.
"I'm not afraid. I just feel as if everyone is ganging up on me, pressuring me," Louise said. "I just want some time."
We talked a little longer, but her thoughts were elsewhere. Shortly afterward, in the middle of answering a question, Louise fell asleep.
THAT WAS ON A THURSDAY. On Friday, both Mero and the doctor left town. Mero gave Louise his long-distance beeper number, assuring her that he would be reachable 24 hours a day. If she needed him, he said, he could return within three hours. The doctor left a number, too, but would be too far away to be of any real help.
The atmosphere at Louise's apartment was tense. Louise was growing more irritable, and her mother was exhausted trying to keep pace with Louise's demands. The mother prides herself on being a strong woman, strong enough to obey Louise's wish that not even her family be told that Louise committed suicide. The mother confided only in her priest, and she never once gave way to tears in front of her only daughter. "I've locked it away in a corner of my soul," she often said. "I'll deal with it someday."
Yet she was not strong enough to say no to Louise. When the mother brought white paper towels back from the supermarket, and Louise insisted she needed blue ones, the mother returned to buy a different color. When Louise decided she needed a special foam overlay for her mattress, at a cost of more than $100, her mother set out to find one, not daring to question the wisdom of buying something so expensive that would only be used for two or three days.
In part, the mother was repenting for an earlier loss. Her own father had died when she was barely out of her teens. She was sitting at her father's bedside one day when he asked her to read him a passage from the Bible. She agreed to, but was briefly distracted by whatever bit of knitting or reading she was immersed in at the time. When she looked up, her father was dead. As a result, she had sworn never to ask Louise to wait even a moment for anything.
"If she had said 'jump,' I would have said 'how high,' " the mother says. "I wasn't going to go through that kind of guilt again."
There was more than guilt at work, however. The mother was growing less certain that her daughter would actually take her own life. The long-term investment in the mattress pad, she thought, might be a signal that Louise had changed her mind and wanted to hold on for as long as she could. But when she tried to ask Louise directly, the daughter refused to respond. "I don't want to talk about this anymore," Louise would say. "I feel like it's all we ever talk about."
The friend was also troubled by Louise's erratic behavior, although she saw something else in it entirely. The unusual irritability and irrationality were signs that Louise's brain was succumbing to illness and medication. The friend wondered: How much can you change the brain before you change the person? Was Louise still capable of making decisions about her own life and death? The friend was not averse to risk; indeed, in moving to Seattle years before, she had left a conservative Southern town and a wealthy, prominent family. But she was beginning to wonder if she was in over her head.
"This is not the woman I know," she confided late Friday night. "This is a different person. Which is the real Louise? The one who was so sure this was what she wanted, or the person who is here now, who doesn't seem sure? I hope she doesn't decline any further, because I would not feel comfortable helping her if she does. And I wouldn't want to back out on her like everyone else did."
The next morning a crisis erupted that thrust all the doubts into the open. Louise had finally reached the last item on her list of things to do -- the removal of the Hickman catheter from a vein in her chest. A private ambulance took Louise and her mother to and from the hospital where the relatively simple procedure was performed. But shortly after they arrived home, Louise felt a trickle down her chest. She was bleeding from the site where the IV tube had entered, and the bleeding soon became profuse. It took most of the rest of the morning and every towel in the apartment to staunch the flow. During most of those hours, Louise sat naked in the bathtub, so as not to ruin her clothes and her furniture.
At lunchtime, Louise's friend came to visit. Both Louise and her mother were extremely upset. "I didn't know what to do," the mother told the friend. "Do I let her die in the tub or do I call 911?"
If an ambulance came, Louise would be taken to the hospital, where she would stay long enough that her chance to commit suicide would probably pass. But if dying is really what's best, her mother anguished, why did they use every towel in the house to keep Louise alive? Did the daughter really want to die? Did the mother really want her to?
The friend offered to speak to Louise. "I kind of want to get an idea of what your time line is," the friend said to Louise in a quiet moment later that afternoon. "Where do we stand?"
Louise was silent, her eyes brimming with tears.
"I just don't want to talk about it anymore," she responded, as she had responded to her mother.
The friend apologized, saying that she thought this kind of discussion was what Louise had in mind when she asked her to come for lunch.
Louise said she would wait for Mero to return on Sunday, then ask for his opinion of her decline over the weekend and her odds for holding on for several more days.
Carefully, the friend said that she thought that was a bad idea, because the changes in Louise's temperament were so subtle they might be missed by someone who did not know her well.
Louise thought about that for a few minutes.
"Maybe I'll ask Ralph to come back a little early," she said, in a tone that indicated that the subject was closed.
LOUISE DID NOT ASK MERO TO come home early. Defying everyone's predictions and fears, and following her own internal timetable, she made it through the weekend, weak but still coherent.
By then, prosecutors in Michigan had announced that they were charging Kevorkian with assisting a suicide in violation of a state law passed specifically to stop him. Although he had helped 17 people commit suicide by that time (and has since helped two more) the indictment was for only one of the deaths -- the one that occurred after the law was passed.
Mero is not sure whether he runs the same risk of arrest as Kevorkian. His only guidance, if it can be called that, is the murky and uneven legal history of assisted suicide in the United States. Generally, every state prohibits assisted suicide, either by precedent or by statute. But the laws are rarely, if ever, enforced. In the state of Washington, for instance, the law says "a person is guilty of promoting a suicide attempt when he knowingly causes or aids another person to attempt suicide," a felony offense punishable by up to five years in jail and a $10,000 fine. But in the past 10 years, only one assisted suicide case has even been referred to the King County Prosecutor's Office, that of a man encouraging a distraught woman to carry out her threat to jump off a building. The man was never indicted because prosecutors felt there was insufficient evidence. The more recent and relevant example, that of Dr. Quill in Rochester, incurred no indictment.
Mero's legal future, therefore, will probably depend on how authorities choose to define "assistance." Like Kevorkian, Mero is present at the time of death, but unlike Kevorkian, he leaves it to the patient to secure the means of death. Like Quill, Mero's group counsels the use of barbiturates, which are prescribed in the context of the disease that precipitated the suicide in the first place. Carbon monoxide gas, on the other hand, has no similar medical purpose, and in the end is reminiscent more of Nazi death camps than sickrooms. But like Kevorkian, Mero has made it clear that he is willing to help as many patients die as he can -- differentiating him from Quill and nearly everyone else who assists in a suicide.
Compassion in Dying's board, well aware of these yardsticks, has established its policies to tread as close to the perceived line as possible without stepping over it. Leonard H. Glantz, a professor of health law at the Boston University School of Public Health, has long studied assisted-suicide laws in the United States, and says he believes Mero's group has succeeded.
"What it comes down to is, he talks to people," Glantz says of Mero. "If he did other things, like take the pills, mix them in the applesauce, hand the patient the spoon, that might be different. But it sounds as if he's careful about that. If charges were brought, they would be criminal charges, and the case would have to be proven beyond a reasonable doubt. The question is what does 'aid' mean. And I don't think talking, under those circumstances, would be construed as aid."
Whatever the risk, it is one that Mero is willing to take. "I have no interest whatsoever in going to jail," he says emphatically. "I am not doing this for martyrdom. But if that's what happens, I am prepared. I don't know if there is any legal right either in constitutional statute or case law for what we are doing. I do think that all human beings have a moral claim to humane treatment. And I believe other human beings have an obligation to try to respond to that request. It does not have to do with constitutional rights of a political state. It has to do with our membership in the human race."
OVER THE NEXT FEW DAYS, MERO checked in with Louise and her mother by telephone, but kept the conversations short. "I was measuring my phone calls," he says. He wanted to remain in the background and allow Louise to control the timing and the pace. Her growing dependence on his opinion was making him uncomfortable, and he needed to keep it clear in her mind, and his, that she was the driver and he was just along for the ride.
Periodically during those days, he expressed concern that when Louise finally did act, things would not go smoothly. He was particularly concerned that her inability to tolerate alcohol would reduce the effectiveness of the drugs. "Our first case went so well," he said. "Eventually there will be a case where something will go wrong." He hoped Louise would not be the one.
Late one afternoon, Mero came home to a message on his answering machine from Louise's mother. "Louise has chosen tonight. Could you be here at 8 o'clock?"
When he arrived, everything was prepared. Louise had got her wish: she had spent a few quiet days with her mother, watching cartoons and old musicals and talking about things other than death. The time, her friend thought, seemed to have brought back some of her old spark. She seemed like the familiar Louise that night, tired but peaceful, clear about what she wanted.
"I was comfortable being there," the friend says. "There was no doubt in my mind that she was capable of making this choice."
The hellos were said, and Mero asked Louise one last time whether she was certain of her decision. She said she was, and then handed Mero a letter formally requesting assistance from Compassion in Dying. It was the third note she had written since she first contacted the organization, filling yet another Compassion requirement. "I know I cannot continue to live in such a state of deterioration," the final letter said. "I ask again for your assistance with my death."
About an hour after Mero arrived, Louise ate the bowl of ice cream, applesauce and barbiturates. She lay on the couch, her mother sitting next to her. Mero sat on one of two chairs and her friend sat on the other.
Louise finished, took a few sips from a glass of milk, then curled up on the couch. Her friend handed her a teddy bear dressed like a crew member from Star Trek -- a private joke: "Beam me up Scotty. Get me out of here." Then the friend began to read from the book Louise had chosen, "A Wrinkle in Time," by Madeleine L'Engle.
With the bear pressed tightly against her face, Louise fell instantly asleep. When the friend finished reading, Louise's mother performed the last rites, using oil blessed by the family priest. Mero said his prayer, and the small group left the living room and moved to the kitchen. They could hear Louise's breathing as they anxiously nibbled on a cream-cheese coffee cake that a visitor had brought Louise earlier in the day.
MOST DEATHS, IN MERO'S experience, take between two and three hours. But Louise took the drugs at 9 P.M., and at midnight, Mero recalls, she was still breathing loudly, almost defiantly. Mero, exhausted, slept fitfully on Louise's bed. Louise's mother and friend sat in the kitchen talking quietly about the past, not the present or the future.
By 1:30 A.M., the women were growing nervous. The mother was deeply worried that her daughter would wake up in anguish at being alive. They decided to wait an hour before panicking, then another hour.
At 3:30, the friend began to consider calling Louise's doctor for advice, and the mother was resigned to calling an ambulance. But Mero told them he was certain that death would come eventually, and suggested that the drugs be given a little more time to take effect. He refuses to be specific about what he would have done if the all-night vigil had stretched past dawn, although several days after that evening he hinted that he would have made certain that Louise died. The Hemlock Society, whose literature Mero knows thoroughly, advises those who assist a suicide to keep a plastic bag on hand for circumstances such as these.
"I was prepared and had the wherewithal," Mero said. "But I wouldn't want to have had to do that. I would not have let her come back. With her mother there, though, it would have been very difficult. I don't think her mother could have handled the mechanics of further assistance."
Mero later retreated from those words. When I asked him whether actively intervening for Louise wouldn't break every one of Compassion's carefully constructed rules, there was a long silence. "I guess you can accuse us of being nonspecific about that," he said. "We have made it clear to people that they have to self-administer. We have also said we will not abandon them. We have to leave the rest undefined. I think most of the individuals on our board know in their own hearts what the ethically correct thing is to do. Yet as an organization we are limited to doing what we have described."
But hadn't Mero already said that he was prepared to go the extra step? He chose his words even more cautiously than usual. "I think if that had arisen, my good judgment would have prevailed. The guidelines are there for a reason. Everything can't be put in jeopardy because of the elastic conscience of one or another individual." He paused. "Let's just say it's a situation that hasn't come up. I hope to God it doesn't."
In the end, no further assistance was necessary. At 3:45, Louise's breathing suddenly changed, becoming slower, quieter, irregular. The pauses between rasps became longer, the breaths shallower. Louise's three attendants moved back into the living room, saying little, just listening to her breathing.
By 4, it had stopped. Louise had no pulse. Listening through a stethoscope, her friend could find no heartbeat. The doctor and the coroner were called. Mero contacted the funeral director and left shortly thereafter.
Louise's death was not listed as a suicide. Her body was cremated and a memorial service was held several days later. Her friends and relatives were told she died in her sleep with her mother at her side, just as she had wanted.

HEADLINE: Morelia's Colonial Grace

BYLINE: By MARGO KAUFMAN; MARGO KAUFMAN is the author of "1-800-AM-I-NUTS," a collection of travel and other essays (Random House).

 BODY:
MORELIA is not for those whose idea of a good time involves discos, Jet Skis or golf. The capital of the Mexican state of Michoacan is not a high-profile resort destination like Ixtapa or Cabo San Lucas. But the graceful colonial city, built of shimmering pink stone, is a tranquil haven for travelers who are delighted by architecture, folk art and majestic scenery -- or those who just want to kick back and get a feel for the Bajio, the Mexican heartland.
The city was founded in 1541 as Valladolid, after the Spanish town, but was renamed in 1828 in honor of its native son Jose Maria Morelos de Pavon, the revolutionary priest turned soldier who led the War for Independence. Like the city of Oaxaca, to the south, Morelia is noted for its lively mercados and artesanias, but it has yet to become a popular tourist spot. Morelia is an easy (for Mexico) four and a half hour ride from Mexico City on a toll road, or a short flight, but on a recent three-day trip, my husband and I encountered no other Americans. 
 Not that the town lacks amenities to make a visitor feel comfortable. Morelia is remarkably free of congestion and well laid out, with long wide boulevards that lead to the center of town. To get oriented, start at the picturesque main square, the Plaza de Armas, fragrant with roses and bougainvillea, and bustling with frolicking children, ambulantes touting pomegranate seeds, potato chips, and hot cakes, and wizened patrones shining shoes. You might want to try a paleta, a local delicacy made of agua purificada, sugar and frozen tropical fruit. La Michoacana, the Mexico-wide chain that sells this treat, got its start here.
The square, Plaza de Armas, is surrounded on three sides by arched colonnades and several hotels are nestled behind the sidewalk cafes. All the hotels had vacancies in August, but reservations are a must during the first week in November, when the fiesta of the Day of the Dead is held in nearby Patzcuaro.
Perhaps the most beautiful of the city's hotels is the Virrey de Mendoza, a lovingly restored 18th-century mansion with an exquisite stained-glass ceiling in the antique-filled lobby. Our small double room was immaculate and comfortable, with gleaming wood floors and an Oriental throw rug; the four-poster bed had good lighting on both sides. Particularly pleasing was the pristine black and white tiled bathroom with a huge sunken tub. Unfortunately, the only ventilation came from a window with a postcard view of the zocalo and in exchange for fresh air, we got a spirited traffic serenade. The hotel manager insisted that the noise would abate after midnight, but it didn't.
Around the corner was the Posada de la Soledad, a less impeccable but even more charming mansion turned hotel. Built in 1719 around a tranquil courtyard, it was reminiscent of a residence in an Isabel Allende novel, with old carriages parked in the cloistered corridors and brightly painted religious statues adorning the rooms. The rooms varied; the best doubles were spacious and airy, with rustic beamed ceilings and a small balcony. Our room's carpet and furniture were a bit tatty, and the bathroom was tiny, but there was plenty of hot water -- not always the case in Mexico.
IF you're looking for luxury, head for the hills outside of town and the Villa Montana, a deluxe hacienda owned by a French count, Philippe de Reiset.
The hotel has a spectacular view of the city, lush gardens filled with whimsical stone sculptures, tennis courts and a small but attractive pool. All the rooms are furnished in an eclectic combination of Early Aztec motel furniture and antiques and stocked with luxuries like a hair dryer and a clock radio.
A good place to start the day in Morelia is with breakfast at the Cafe Paraiso (103 Portal Galeana), a cheery little restaurant with excellent cafe con leche across from the Baroque cathedral. A codger with a violin, who has obviously not studied under Itzhak Perlman, appears regularly and makes hideous screeching sounds until his palm is crossed with pesos. He relentlessly works the cafes around the square and is hard to resist. After breakfast at Cafe Paraiso, a visitor can amble next door to the Palacio de Gobierno, another 18th-century mansion that was formerly the Tridentine Seminary. Famous graduates include Morelos and Agustin de Iturbide, the first Emperor of Mexico and the man who signed Morelos's death warrant.
Over the main staircase are vivid murals showing dramatic highlights from Mexican history, painted in the early 1960's by Alfredo Zace, a local artist.
To get a good look at the Baroque cathedral -- which, with two 200-foot Baroque towers, was built from 1640 to 1744 -- attend an evening concert given by the local music academy. Tickets can be purchased at the door. We heard a performance of Bach, which was played on the cathedral's 4,600-pipe organ. The interior turned out to be a Victorian hodgepodge, with crystal chandeliers and carved pews, and the organist uninspired. But it was a treat to be able to leisurely inspect the retablos, ceiling moldings and murals without feeling like we were interrupting someone else's prayers.
Another pleasant expedition is to take a taxicab -- you can go almost anywhere in town for 5 pesos, or about $1.50 -- to the ruined aqueduct, a mile-long expanse with 250 arches that was built in 1788 but looks much older. It's a pleasant stroll back through the Calzada Fray Antonio de San Miguel, a tree-lined promenade, especially if you stop at the local sweets market, Mercado de Dulces on Calle Gomez Farias.
Morelia is the candy capital of Mexico, and popular confections include crystallized tamarinds, mangos and guayabas and fudge made of honey and evaporated milk.(Those allergic to bees should be careful; wasps and yellow jackets were swarming on the treats.)
The gummy fruit drops were so sweet I could feel my bridgework rot, so I gave most of them to an elderly vendadora wearing three layers of colored petticoats. In exchange, she offered me a good deal on the tablecloth she was embroidering.
Craftsmen come from the northern villages to sell their wares at the sweets market and a visitor can find bargains like lacquered gourds patterned with fruits and butterflies ($3 or $4, depending on size) or whimsically painted wooden armadillos with bobbing heads at three for $10 -- a fifth the price in Mexico City.
Folk art enthusiasts should also stop at the state-run Casa de las Artesanias del Estado de Michoacan, which is housed in a beautiful old convent made of weathered stone. Crafts from all over the state are on sale in the shop downstairs and on display in the gallery upstairs. Some of the highlights included Ocumicho devil figurines ($7 to $10 for a single one, $45 and up for scenes), pottery from Capula decorated with pointillist flora and fauna motifs (a small platter is $15 to $20), Santa Clara del Cobre copper pots ($95 for a heavy medium-sized one) and a vast selection of gigantic towers made of ceramic pineapples from San Jose de Gracia ($175 for one that stands about three feet high).
What one does with these towers, I do not know. Prices at Casa de las Artesanias are on the high side, though not unreasonable compared with Mexico City, and the staff will box and ship purchases.
A truly memorable outing is the drive or bus ride to Patzcuaro, a little more than an hour through the scenic countryside, past pine forests and volcanoes looming on the horizon. We went via Tzintzuntzan, a tiny village below the huge ruins of the Tarascan culture's main city. Along the road is an open-air crafts market that specializes in intricately woven straw work and hand-painted dishes. A tourist seeking inexpensive but unique souvenirs can buy three-foot strings of straw Christmas tree ornaments -- bells, candy canes and stars -- for less than $5.
Across the street, woodcarvers sell the same exquisitely carved furniture on sale at the Casa des Artesanias for a third of the price. If I could have carried it home, I could have bought a six-foot-high breakfront with a carved frieze of sunflowers for $400 or a headboard in the shape of a horse's head for $45. Never one to be daunted by logistics, my husband pounced on a fish-shaped wooden planter the size and weight of a Yule log, purchased it on the spot for $12 and somehow managed to hoist it into the trunk. It flew home with us as checked luggage.
Patzcuaro, a quaint lakeside village in the Sierra Madre, has well-preserved 17th-century Spanish architecture and a nationally famous Day of the Dead graveyard ceremony on Janitzio, an island in Lake Patzcuaro. The beautiful main square, Quiroga, is shaded by great ash trees and has a fine statue of its namesake, Vasco de Quiroga, the 16th-century bishop who protected the Tarascans from the conquistadors. Wander up and down the cobblestone streets or stop at the library, with its splendid mural by Juan O'Gorman, depicting local history. The neatly arranged Museo de Artes Populares is also of interest, as is Casa de los Once Patios, a collection of boutiques selling handsome weaving and erotic figurines.
For lunch, there is the Cafeteria Dany, a pretty and very clean restaurant off the square. I ordered the famous white fish from Lake Patzcuaro that the guidebooks kept raving about and was disappointed to be presented with several scrawny fish that reminded me a lot of alewives, a low form of marine life I last encountered washed up on the shores of Lake Michigan.
They tasted a little better than they looked, but my husband's three course El Menu with rollos de carne, sopa de Tarasco and a local variation on an enchilada was the better buy. Our meal came to under $16, including tip.
For dining back in Morelia, the Fonda Las Mercedes (47 Leon Guzman; telephone: 12-6113) is a fantastic-looking restaurant. Its best design accent is a six-foot raffia Caterina, the popular skeleton wearing an 1880's dress and a huge hat. This time, the famous white fish arrived swimming in garlic -- a big improvement; My husband's chicken with corn mold -- a smoky tasting fungus is scraped off the corn into the sauce -- was infinitely better than it sounded. Dinner for two, without wine, came to around $50.
At the attractive restaurant in the hotel Posada de la Soledad, specialties include Filete Pescado de Veracruzana and a giant sirloin, with all the trimmings. With appetizers, dessert, and drinks, our bill was under $25. And their weekend brunch is excellent.
Those who are returning to Mexico City by car should leave Morelia by way of Laguna de Cuitzeo, the second largest lake in Mexico, which one can drive across on a causeway. On the opposite shore is a fine 16th-century Augustinian monastery that is in the process of being restored. A permanent collection of amazing engravings -- including some by Jose Guadalupe Posada, the 19th century artist who created the Caterina, the folk symbol represented by the well-dressed lady skeleton at the Fonda Las Mercedes -- is on display in the cloisters.
 
Planning a journey to a tranquil haven
 
Getting There
Aeromar, a commuter branch of Aeromexico, has a 20-seat flight three times a day from Mexico City to Morelia. It takes 50 minutes and costs $157 round trip. Mexicana flies direct to Morelia from Guadalajuara for $42 to $60 one way, depending on how far in advance a ticket is purchased..
We flew to Mexico City and rented an economy car through Avis for $209 for a week, with unlimited mileage. If you drive from Mexico City, it's best to take the toll road through Toluca, Atlacamulco, Contepec, and Maravatio.
Bus and train service also is available.
 
Where to Stay
 The luxurious Villa Montana is located at 201 Patzima, on the outskirts of town in the hills of Santa Maria. Standard doubles are $110 a night, Junior suites are $150 and Master Suites are $170. All prices include a full breakfast; add 20 percent for tax and gratuities. From the United States, reservations can be made by calling (800) 223-6510. The hotel's local number is 14-0231 and its fax number is 15-1423. The code for Mexico is 52; the city code for Morelia is 43.
A good value is the Posada de la Soledad at 90 Ignacio Zaragoza; 12-1888; fax 12-2111. Doubles are $66, and suites are $80. All the rooms are different so ask to see a few before you settle on one.
The Hotel Virrey de Mendoza (16 Portal Matamoros; 12-0633) is lovely, but best in cool weather because many of the interior rooms are stuffy. A double runs from $75 to $94. M.K.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 37; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk
