HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
An Investment Firm Gives Its Regard to Broadway

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
LOOKING westward from his office window, James Allwin has a clear view of 1585 Broadway, the three-year-old skyscraper on the west blockfront from 47th to 48th Street. He is head of the real estate group at Morgan Stanley Group, the global financial services firm, and he salts his speech with expressions relished by financiers:
"The question was, 'Should we go long on New York City?" ' 
 Morgan Stanley went long on New York in general and Times Square in particular last August when it submitted the winning bid of $176 million for 1585 Broadway, a 42-story building with 1.34 million gross square feet of space.
The company will occupy 1 million square feet; the rest is already occupied by the law firm of Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn under a long-term lease. Outfitting its space, which includes five huge floors at the base for trading activities, is likely to cost Morgan Stanley at least $175 million, trade sources say.
At the time of the sale, attention focused on the price, which was well above the $150 million minimum set by the consortium of banks that took over the project from the developer, Solomon Equities. The price was higher than some insiders had expected, although for a buyer able to use the space the price was considered highly favorable. The seller was a consortium of eight banks, with Hines Interests Limited Partnership as real-estate advisor.
For New York City, rooting Morgan Stanley in West Midtown as a property owner-user must be looked on as a triumph. It validates the Times Square area as a location for financial-services activity, the vision David S. Solomon was unable to convert to reality amid retrenchments as the 80's wore on.
With Bertelsman A.G., the German media company, having purchased the newly built 1540 Broadway at 45th Street for occupancy, the Times Square district gets still another sizable corporation as an owner-user.
The economic impact is also substantial. Morgan Stanley employs about 4,000 people in the city, generates tax revenue one way or another of about $100 million a year, and produces a direct and indirect economic impact of about $3 billion a year, according to the city's Economic Development Corporation. That includes salaries, taxes and other direct expenses, plus the business activity it generates.
Helping Morgan Stanley make the purchasing decision was the package of tax incentives it negotiated with New York City at a time when it was hedging its bets by optioning land for possible new construction in Stamford, Conn.
The firm's major lease of 600,000 square feet in 1251 Avenue of the Americas -- a building owned by Mitsui Fudosan (New York), and managed by Rockefeller Center -- expires in 1998.
That $39 million package was conceived before the purchase as a 10-year benefit to keep Morgan Stanley in Manhattan and Brooklyn, where it has computer space, at least that long, countering the overtures from Connecticut.
It was linked with the firm's plan at the time to renew its lease at 1251 Avenue of the Americas for five years, until the year 2002, when other Morgan Stanley leases in midtown buildings expire. In accordance with an understanding with the Dinkins administration that the offer would be improved if Morgan Stanley made a longer-term commitment, the package is now being renegotiated, reportedly to provide a benefit of roughly $80 million over 20 years.
These negotiations call attention to the key role tax-benefit packages have had to play in New York's efforts to hold major employers in the face of competing government-backed developments in neighboring states and beyond.
Another more recent package involved $31 million in long-term benefits to Kidder, Peabody & Company, currently downtown and planning to move to Rockefeller Center.
As long as the city's tax structure is obliged to support huge payroll costs and generous public services, and is skewed to blunt the strain on homeowners and regulated renters, special incentives are needed to bolster the employment base.
FINANCIAL-SERVICE concerns -- including banks and insurance companies as well as investment firms and brokerages -- are a key part of that tax base. Data from Cushman & Wakefield, the real-estate services firm, show that these concerns accounted for 5.3 million square feet, or 6.5 percent, of office occupancy in the midtown area last year and 18.8 million square feet, or 32.5 percent, of downtown occupancy.
Tenants downtown typically pay $6 to $7 a square foot per year in property taxes in Class A office buildings. New York City also imposes on commercial tenants a 6 percent rent tax, in addition to its sales tax of 8 1/4 percent and higher electric-power costs than in neighboring states.
Across the river in Jersey City, office users in new buildings make a payment in lieu of taxes that typically gives them a fixed tax cost of $2 to $2.50 a square foot a year over 15 or 20 years. Most of the new buildings are also in designated urban enterprise zones, where tenants pay no sales or wage taxes.
Tenants typically pay a total of $5.50 to $6 a square foot per year for operating costs and taxes, according to Kurt Eichler, regional vice president of LCOR Inc., the developer of the 1.5-million-square-foot 101 Hudson Street project in Jersey City. That is approximately what operating costs alone total in New York. Among others induced to move operations to 101 Hudson Street is Lehman Brothers, which is taking 340,000 square feet and 900 back-office jobs. Earlier, Merrill Lynch took 600,000 square feet and 2,500 jobs.
Under Gov. Jim Florio, New Jersey has even brought the weight of state government to bear as an equity investor in private development. The one-million-square-foot Newport Tower project in Jersey City has the benefit of a $10 million equity investment from the state, derived from a bond issue backed by revenue from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The money comes through the New Jersey Economic Development Authority and is used to offset the cost of tenant improvements and to improve building technology.
Newport Tower is jointly owned by The Limited, the Columbus, Ohio, clothing chain that at one time thought it would occupy half the building for an Eastern regional headquarters, and the Georgetown Group, a Manhattan real-estate investment firm. It had no tenants at all last year until First Chicago Trust, a midtown tenant, signed on for 240,000 square feet.
More recently Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, a lower Manhattan tenant, agreed to take 106,000 square feet.
"NEW YORK needs a long-term strategy," said Meyer S. Frucher, executive vice president of Olympia & York U.S.A., which alone owns and manages 17 million square feet of space in New York, much of it downtown. "There must be tax reduction in an orderly and systematic way," he said.
It also may be that Governor-elect Christine Todd Whitman will choose not to use revenue from the Port Authority to subsidize office buildings to the competitive disadvantage of New York City.
As for Morgan Stanley, the widely held view in real-estate circles is that it won itself a highly advantageous deal in the purchase of 1585 Broadway. It paid $130 a square foot for the space -- perhaps about half what it would cost to build new. Its occupancy costs will be lowered by the value of the Proskauer Rose lease and prospective rents from advertising signs and retail space at the base of the building.
Floors two through six will be used for trading by Morgan Stanley's equities, fixed-income, foreign exchange and commodities departments. "The real thing that sent those businesses into heaven was the layout, with the elevators at the back," said Carter McClelland, head of finance, administration and operations at Morgan Stanley. "There's a huge line of sight."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property:/Around West 34th Street;
A High-Traffic, Low-Rent Lure

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
ANN M. ARBUTHNOT, a senior vice president of J. Baker, gives a one-word rationale for why her Canton, Mass. company opened two Parade of Shoes stores on West 34th Street this year: "People."
So why not 57th Street and Fifth Avenue, or one of New York's other busy retail areas? Again, a one-word answer: "Rents." 
 She will elaborate if you insist: Parade of Shoes, which sells all its shoes for $19.98, cannot support the $250-a-square foot it can cost to be on Fifth or Madison Avenues. But it does well in high-traffic areas, and 34th Street, with its mix of tourists, Penn Station commuters and Madison Square Garden customers, certainly is that.
The chain has more than 150 stores, and the two on 34th Street are already vying for top spot on its list of those with the highest gross -- and at a "good rent" at that.
"I just wish we had come here sooner," Ms. Arbuthnot said.
A lot of people are feeling that way about the West 34th Street area. New Spectrum Realty says that from July 1992 to July 1993, there was a drop of more than 21 percent in the amount of retail space available on 34th Street from Fifth to Eighth Avenue. Only four of the street's 116 storefronts are vacant, and brokers doubt they will be for long.
"This has got to be the busiest shopping street in Manhattan," said Benjamin Fox, a partner at New Spectrum.
Office space is going fast, too. The Edward S. Gordon Company says that, as of Nov. 1, vacancies in the areas surrounding West 34th Street -- say, the stretch from 31st to 42d Street and from Sixth to Eighth Avenue -- were only 14 percent, compared with 15.2 percent for all of midtown.
"This area used to be where you went if you couldn't afford someplace else," said Lee N. Feld, a managing director at Edward S. Gordon, who manages 1250 Broadway, on 32d Street. "Now it attracts tenants on its own."
Examples abound. Five Penn Plaza, on Eighth Avenue near 34th Street, has just one floor available; 18 months ago the 24-story building was half empty. Turnover at the Empire State Building, which has a lot of small-space tenants, has been high in this recession, yet the 102-story building is again 90 percent full. Not only does the old Ohrbachs department store building at 7 West 34th Street have two clothing stores, Limited Express and Structure, at street level, but its 12 upper floors are now home to Fairchild Publications and the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York.
Local landlords are ecstatic. "This area is on a roll," said Peter L. Malkin, a part owner of the Empire State Building, of One Penn Plaza (atop Penn Station) and of the Children's Wear building, 112 West 34th.
Economics, of course, has a lot to do with it. Brokers say that space in Class A office buildings in the Penn Plaza area is averaging about $20 to $23 a square foot, about $2 or $3 more than in comparable buildings below, say, 32d Street, but $3 to $5 less than comparable buildings near Grand Central Terminal. Retail rents on 34th Street go from $90 to $160 a square foot, depending on store size.
"Penn Plaza has carved out a niche as the top end of Midtown South," observed Michael Cohen, president of Williams Real Estate.
Nowhere is the resurgence more visible than on 34th Street. Over the last two decades, as Ohrbach's, Franklin Simon, Gimbels and B. Altman's closed, the area turned into a haven for small stores of the perennially going-out-of-business variety, or for apparel stores that sold cheap goods even cheaper.
"IT was a street of layaway shopping, where people paid $10 a week toward things they took home months later," said C. Bradley Mendelson, a senior managing director and retail broker at Edward S. Gordon.
Developers, with financing from Ferdinand E. Marcos, failed miserably nine years ago, when they tried to replicate the feel -- and price -- of Madison and Fifth Avenues and other high-end retail areas at Herald Center, their 10-story mall in the former Korvette's on 34th Street and Broadway.
Now the center, which Morris Bailey and his partners bought in 1990 and which filed for bankruptcy last January, has gone the value-price route. Toys 'R' Us and Kids 'R' Us, among the first value-price tenants, just took more space. Daffy's, also an off-price retailer, contracted for four floors. Business is so good that most brokers expect the center to emerge from bankruptcy soon.
The area clearly has become more pleasant for shoppers and tenants alike. Thanks to the 34th Street Partnership, local streets are being cleaned more often, signs that are too large or too glaring are being removed by the partnership, and the police are cracking down on sidewalk vendors; since July that has included those selling printed material from tables, a group that was once exempt from a city ordinance barring sidewalk vendors from major retail thoroughfares.
Herald Square and Greeley Square are floodlit at night and taxi stations are better supervised. Mr. Malkin, a cofounder of the partnership, expects that reported crime by the end of 1993 will be 20 percent lower than it was two years ago.
The area still has a way to go before it looks like upper Fifth or Madison, though. The former B. Altman's, which anchors 34th Street to the east, still has no tenant for its Fifth Avenue side (much of its Madison Avenue side will be used for a public library). The association has sued to get the five-story Levi's jeans sign removed from the side of 22 West 34th. And there are still lots of quasi-bazaars operating on 34th Street, selling everything from perfume to electronics from unenclosed storefronts and sidewalk racks.
"Building owners can collect huge rents for tiny spaces without whipping anything into shape," complained Elizabeth M. Rodgers, a retail real estate consultant who has been active in the partnership.
Still, the clean-up has been enough to attract some powerhouse retailers. The Gap has two stores and is expanding. Conway and The Limited have several stores in the area. Thom McCann is about to open its second 34th Street store. A national videogame company, cognizant that some 2 million people a year visit the Empire State Building observatory, will soon offer a computer-simulated tour of New York in a 10,000-square-foot spot in the building, with the proviso that tickets be sold at the Observatory ticket desk.
"Retailers have finally recognized that the loss of the carriage trade and the introduction of a lot of low-end retailers hasn't changed the buying power on this street," said Mr. Fox of New Spectrum.
Many of the area's larger office buildings are poised to cash in on the retailing renaissance. One Penn Plaza, for one, has earmarked $25 million for redoing its plazas and retail concourses, in good part to coincide with the higher traffic it expects when new entrances to the Long Island Rail Road station are opened nearby. Plans include several new restaurants, most with outdoor seating, in the plazas, and some apparel and gourmet food shops in the concourse.
Mr. Malkin says retailers are already clamoring to get in after the leases of existing stores expire, even though he will be asking $60 to $100 a square foot for concourse retailing space that now goes for about $50.
The proximity to the garment district, which stretches from about 35th to 42d Street, primarily along Seventh Avenue, has had a good impact on Penn Plaza buildings as well. According to Stuart I. Romanoff, a director at Cushman & Wakefield, about half of the Penn Plaza office deals were garment-district-related this year. Mr. Romanoff's client, Congress Talcott, a garment industry factor, took 42,000 square feet at 393 Seventh Avenue, on 32d Street, when its lease at 1633 Broadway, near 51st Street, expired this year. The simple reason: The Penn Plaza space was cheaper.
"They wanted to be walking distance from their clients, and this was just as close from the other direction," Mr. Romanoff said.
As the garment industry continues its slow crawl back from recession, the overflow may be even greater. Sidney Winoker of Winoker Realty, which manages many garment-district buildings, says that a lot of new apparel companies -- particularly Asian-owned ones -- are moving into space that troubled companies vacated over the last few years. The net result is that the glut of showroom and office space is diminishing.
"I can't say the area has turned around, but it certainly has stabilized," he said.

HEADLINE: County Is First to Add Environment to Its Charter

BYLINE: By TOM CALLAHAN

 BODY:
WESTCHESTER has become the first county in the country to adopt an environmental code of conduct based on 10 principles drawn up after the Exxon Valdez accident in 1989 by the Coalition for Environmentally Responsible Economies.
The principles cover many concerns, ranging from protection of the biosphere to energy conservation and waste disposal through recycling. 
 The principles also stress careful use of natural resources, minimizing environmental health risks to employees, eliminating the use of products that damage the environment, informing the public of conditions that might harm the environment and providing yearly reports.
Under legislation signed by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke late last month, the County Charter was amended to include protection of the environment as a county purpose.
Mr. O'Rourke said that the code "publicly affirms our belief that local governments have a responsibility for the environment."
"We are formally and forever committing that Westchester County will conduct its affairs as a responsible steward of the environment," he added. "These sweeping principles will govern the actions of each and every department of the Westchester County government."
Mr. O'Rourke said that the county already adheres to the principles in day-to-day operations by, for example, developing energy-conservation systems for county office buildings and reducing the use of fertilizers on public golf courses.
The Charter change establishes a Council for Environmental Coordination to evaluate the county's environmental performance every year. The council will consist of 11 voting members, 4 of whom will be private citizens and 7 of whom will be drawn from various boards. The council will be staffed by a full-time executive director with cabinet rank. The first council will be appointed by Mr. O'Rourke on Jan. 1.
Richard A. Flynn, a Republican-Conservative member of the Board of Legislators from Mount Kisco and chairman of the Board's Committee on the Environment, said, "I think this law sends a message that this county is going to be active and responsible in protecting the environment."
The principles of the Coalition for Environmentally Responsible Economies have so far been adopted by 70 corporations. The Boston-based coalition has more than 20 members, among them the Sierra Club, Friends of the Earth, the National Wildlife Federation and the National Audubon Society.
While designed to cover business and corporate behavior, the principles can also apply to governments, said Jack Doyle, a member of the coalition's board of directors.
"County governments often operate like businesses in their purchasing," Mr. Doyle said. "There are 3,000 counties in the country. If each follows the lead of Westchester, it will have a significant positive impact on the environment." TOM CALLAHAN

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
As Sutton Said, It's Where The Money Is

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
IN AN overly warm New York conference room last week, Trevor Manuel was trying to persuade investors to put money into South Africa. A senior official of the African National Congress, he is widely expected to hold a top economic job when majority rule comes to that country next spring.
Mr. Manuel, a former community organizer who was classified as colored, or mixed-race, under apartheid, and who spent time in prison, said all the things the assembled money managers wanted to hear. He talked of making it easy for investors to repatriate their dividends and profits, of understanding the need for good profits, of a determination to end the country's harsh exchange controls. He understood the need for fiscal restraint. 
 It may not be an easy sell. For there is still fear about political violence, and worry that the A.N.C.'s determination to bring economic justice will make investors uncomfortable. Antitrust policy appears to be a high priority, as Mr. Manuel talks of breaking up the big conglomerates that control both banking and major industries.
But whatever his prospects for success, his presence at Merrill Lynch's headquarters last week spoke volumes about how the world has changed. Governments can print money, but throughout the world they can't get enough of it. More than ever before, the ability of capital to flee across national boundaries has shifted power away from governments and toward money managers and corporations. Last week money managers could also hear presentations from the Turkish Government or, at the same time the South Africans were making their push, learn of the bargains being made available as Italy sells off its state industries. Tomorrow the president of the Philippines will be in town extolling the virtues of the Manila market.
Perhaps the defining fact of the world in the 1990's is the excess of capital. That has driven down interest rates and spurred stock markets around the world as traders searched for growth. Manila has almost doubled this year.
But governments, which once seemed rich, now feel poor. Budget deficits are high, but so is resistance to spending cuts or tax increases. Washington talks of "no-money diplomacy" and the African National Congress knows full well that it must promise profits, not seek sympathy, if it is to get a capital inflow.
That reality underlies the vicious trade disputes, both here and in Europe. The emerging economies are successfully fighting for business -- just try to buy a toy this Christmas that is not from China -- and the workers and bosses of the fading First World industries are angry. Yet initiatives to liberalize trade, born when most economies were growing at a good clip, are now up for approval. That is why no new GATT deal is likely, and why Nafta is in trouble.
But even if Nafta dies this week, the trends are in place. Capital has largely escaped the control of governments, for better or worse. The winners will be those who best adapt to that reality.

HEADLINE: Boomtown U.S.A.

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

DATELINE: BOISE, Idaho

 BODY:
TO see the winding rows of new houses sprouting in former potato fields, the massive new Town Square Mall stuffed with shoppers, the parade of joggers along the river that snakes through town, it is hard to believe that less than 10 years ago people were fleeing this area and its dead-end mining and farming economy.
Now, Boise leads the nation in job growth -- 6 percent last year -- and the city is in its sixth straight year of robust economic expansion. Construction permits are up 50 percent from 1991 -- the highest rate in the country. High-technology employment has leaped 57 percent since 1987, while crumbling in California and in New England. 
 With regular appearances on the list of the most livable cities in the nation and a sunny economic forecast stretching through the late 1990's, Boise has started to exude something close to smugness. The attractions for businesses and workers are impressive: median home price, under $100,000; average property tax, $415 a year in 1990; one of the lowest crime rates in the nation; average commute time, 17 minutes; not even one worker's compensation claim paid for stress in the whole city. Not to mention the mountains, the fresh air and the great weather.
Indeed, many people here now say they feel sorry for California, the state from which about 30 percent of all the newcomers here have fled.
It is a sentiment widely held across the Rocky Mountain West these days. . After a drawn-out recession in the mid-1980's, most of these states are on a roll, spurred by a new economy that is not as dependent on the boom-and-bust cycles of timber, mining and farming but is instead using attractions like those of Boise to land many new kinds of businesses that don't need an urban center in which to thrive. Three of the five fastest-growing states in the nation last year were Idaho, Nevada and Colorado. Not far behind are Arizona and two states whose eastern portions fall within this region, Oregon and Washington. Over the last two years, employment in the Rocky Mountain West has been growing nearly five times as fast as the national average.
But beneath this gloss is another story, one that raises the question of whether cities like Boise are a model for the 21st century, with a sustainable base of good jobs, or just low-wage exurbs of Southern California that will soon be overrun and suffer problems familiar to both coasts.
For one thing, anyone coming here looking for work and a piece of paradise will probably take a big drop in pay, if a job can be found at all. Idaho still ranks near the bottom in average wage and per-capita income. Even Hewlett-Packard and Micron Technology, the two largest employers and the companies that led Boise's shift to an economy based on the manufacture of high-technology products, start their workers at just over $7 an hour.
Also, the sharp growth is creating its own problems. Housing prices are soaring, repeating the pattern in California and later Seattle. And every new company and every new worker coming here may detract, in some small way, from the vaunted quality of life that brought them to begin with.
So far, however, southern Idaho's transformation from a high-unemployment backwater overly dependent on natural resources to a more diversified economy that has become a national leader in job growth has been a dramatic success.
In the early 1980's, the Rocky Mountain West was in a deep recession, as the oil, mining and timber industries contracted. Idaho, with just over a million people, saw its population shrink and had one of the highest unemployment rates in the country. From the Governor on down, state leaders sought to change things.
Boise, with its metropolitan-area population of 215,000, has in the past been dependent primarily on four large corporations: Albertsons, the grocery chain; Boise-Cascade, the timber giant; Morrison-Knudsen, the engineering and construction powerhouse, and J.R. Simplot, the agricultural giant.
But state officials wanted a wider base of employers. They commissioned a study to find out what kinds of businesses would benefit by moving to Idaho, then targeted more than a thousand companies in 35 industries.
Boise, the only real city in Idaho, began selling itself to out-of-state firms as a low-wage haven. Like other booming Rocky Mountain states, Idaho tells employers in California that they can do business here for less than half the cost of their present location.
Removed from the major markets, Idaho pitched other advantages as well: low taxes, lower expenses for worker's compensation, short commutes, cheap electric power, low land prices, an educated work force and little crime or traffic.
It is an attractive pitch, and in the last few years, about 130 companies have left California and other more urban areas to set up shop in Idaho.
 
Idaho as a Model
 Economists have held up Idaho's economy as something other states should try to emulate. "They haven't tried to hit the home run, to bring in the next I.B.M. or General Motors, but they've concentrated on bringing in the smaller companies, and that's where most of the job growth in this country is coming from," said Tracy Clark, an economist with Arizona State University.
Other Western cities, of similar size and circumstances, have been making the same pitch. They include Albuquerque and Santa Fe, N.M.; Salt Lake City; Spokane, Wash.; Colorado Springs, and Reno, Nev. Nevada, for example, ran a print advertisement in California, with a picture of traffic gridlock and the caption "5:35 P.M. California time," next to a picture of a business-suited father hugging his small daughter at home with the caption "5:35 P.M. Nevada time." The ad said, "Nevada time costs less because Nevada has no corporate, personal, unitary, franchise or inventory taxes."
Other states, particularly Arizona and Washington, have been more successful than Idaho at luring new companies, but no state has shown more job growth than this one.
 
California Emigrants
 From afar, particularly in Southern California, the pitch has hit home. This year, Harpers Inc., a furniture manufacturer, is moving from Torrance, in Southern California, to Post Falls, Idaho, bringing 500 jobs. Spur Products, the leading manufacturer of high-speed laser-printing interfaces, moved from El Segundo, also in Southern California, to Boise in 1991.
"Labor is cheaper and the work ethic is higher, so you get more bang for your buck," said Michael Hicks, a top official at Spur. "It boils down to the cost of doing business. Each sale we make is worth a lot more because our cost of doing business here is so much less."
Similarly, officials at Micron Technology, which employs about 5,000 people in Boise, have estimated that land prices here are one-sixteenth those in California's Silicon Valley.
Hewlett-Packard, which has 5,100 employees at its manufacturing base here, says quality of life was much more of an issue than cheap labor. "Really, for us, the big question is how happy our employees are, which makes for better productivity," said Mark Falconer, a spokesman for Hewlett-Packard in Boise, where laserjet printers are made for worldwide distribution. "A bunch of us were talking this morning about what a benefit it is to arrive at work and not be stressed out by some life-threatening activity from the night before or by the commute."
The company, with its headquarters in Palo Alto, Calif., has added 1,000 employees here in the last year. Even with the low starting salary for unskilled workers, applications are pouring in. Mr. Falconer said more than 10,000 had applied to work at the Boise plant in the last year.
Mr. Hicks said that when Spur Products was still in California, some of its employees made four-hour round-trip commutes every day. California's other ills have also contributed to Idaho's gain. "The Los Angeles riots created a lot of interest in Idaho," said Alan Porter, an analyst with the Idaho Department of Commerce.
The state now spends only $100,000 a year trying to lure new companies, and has virtually eliminated out-of-state recruiting trips. The word is out about Rocky Mountain states.
"People are coming here no matter what we say one way or the other," said Randy Shroll, the state's liaison with out-of-state companies.
But the flip side is less rosy. Mr. Shroll said he has started to warn people about the potential for disappointment. Although the unemployment rate in Ada County, which encompasses Boise, is only 4.5 percent, high-paying jobs are extremely scarce, officials say.
"A lot of people are quitting good, high-paying jobs to come here, but then they find out that there is nothing here for them," said Joy Hadley, assistant manager of a state job service center in Boise. "If you come here, you had better do so with the understanding that you might have to work at a fast-food store for a year or more just to put groceries on the table."
 
The Down Side

For all its stunning job growth -- the state has been at or near the top nationwide for three years -- Idaho still ranks near the bottom for per capita income and average wage, as do other Rocky Mountain boom states. The latest census figures, released last summer, put Idaho at 43d in per capita income, with an average of $16,067. Utah, Idaho's chief competitor in the effort to lure firms from the West Coast, ranks 49th.
Idaho officials attribute the low personal income figure primarily to large families, because of the heavy Mormon influence. Also, they point out that living is less expensive here, and that personal income is soaring; Idaho's rate is 7 percent, third best in the nation.
But state officials make no secret of the fact that they target companies that are looking to cut wages as the best way to increase profits. In that sense, Idaho can be viewed the way Mexico is in the current debate over a free-trade agreement. Their efforts also draw comparisons to the South and its low-wage attractions.
Such comparisons, some Western economists say, may be too harsh. "What the South was doing was trying to get low-skill assembly jobs," Mr. Clark said. "In Idaho, they are trying to attract assembly jobs, but the skill level is higher."
Idaho has more millionaires per capita than any other state, but the average wage here is $22,591 -- nearly 19 percent below the national average of $27,808. In brochures sent to firms in California, typically with 250 employees, Idaho officials say they can reduce a company's $7 million payroll by more than 50 percent without laying off a worker.
"We don't have land giveaways or tax-free offers like some states, but the low wages is a major selling point," said Mr. Porter, of the state commerce department.
Critics from California, which has just begun a major effort to fight back, and those who are skeptical here say the low-wage pitch will eventually backfire. Worse, it could set up Idaho as overly dependent on a certain kind of company -- the small to moderate-size high-tech manufacturer. From Phoenix to Torrance, Calif., the West is littered with empty office buildings and plants from boom times that were not supposed to end.
In an otherwise glowing report on the Idaho boom, analysts at Standard & Poor's in New York warned that Idaho should try to diversify its job base. Just as the Southern California economy deteriorated when aerospace declined, so could Idaho suffer if it becomes too tied to a certain industry, the analysts said. They noted that the state's healthy mix of home-grown companies, in food-processing and timber, may balance the newer reliance on high-tech.
 
The Consequences
 But a backlash against the new economy is growing here in Idaho, as in the other big-growth Rocky Mountain areas.
Paul Zelus, director of the Center for Business Research at Idaho State University in Pocatello, took issue with his state's low-wage economic strategy. "The wage levels here are below national standards by 20 to 40 percent, and that includes top management," he said. "It is an unwise strategy. It's anti-labor, and will cause problems."
One of the biggest growth areas for employment in the West has been low-paying jobs in credit-card processing; many are part-time, paying less than $10,000 a year. Some states, notably Arizona, have passed laws making it easy for banks to bring in these jobs.
Idaho business leaders counter that they are being selective about the kinds of businesses being wooed. They have discouraged telemarketing firms paying minimum wage and companies that would harm the environment. "We can't have economic success without preserving the foundations that make Idaho great -- our natural resources and environment," said Gov. Cecil Andrus, who helped lead Idaho to a new economy.
As for critics who think outsiders may be exploiting another natural resource -- the residents themselves -- Idaho officials are not worried.
"People who come in here thinking we just fell off the spud wagon will have a rude awakening," said Shirl Boyce, manager of the Boise Economic Development Council.
But others who live here are frightened by what they see. "Idaho right now is literally for sale," Mr. Zelus said. "We are being besieged by big banks and companies from California that want to buy whole mountainsides, whole towns, and convert them to something. That kind of growth scares a lot of people."
One consequence of the fast growth: The average home price in the Boise area rose nearly 10 percent in the last year, to $97,316.
Another consequence: The building boom has gotten so out of hand that the bedroom community of Meridian, its schools bursting at the seams, has ordered a moratorium on building. State projections call for a 50 percent increase in population by 2015, to 1.5 million people. The growth should be in a half-dozen smaller communities, close to recreation areas.
"Already, our quality of life has been compromised," Ms. Hadley said, "and maybe that's the price we've paid."
 
 
 
CALIFORNIANS DEFENDING THEIR TURF
 CALIFORNIA is fighting back against raids on its businesses by states in the Rocky Mountain West.
The Golden State -- having lost 700,000 jobs since 1990 -- nearly double the entire number of jobs in Idaho -- has formed TeamCalifornia, a group of public and private sector leaders, to try to keep companies from leaving.
If you don't like Southern California, these leaders tell companies, then try a little town in Northern California. Even the much-criticized worker's compensation system has been overhauled this year.
While California can't compete on labor or land costs, it is trying to streamline the issuance of building and environmental permits, and it boasts an educated work force and advanced infrastructure.
"When a company comes to us and says, 'We are being courted by out-of-state concerns,' we listen," said Julie Wright, California's Secretary of Trade and Commerce. "We are fed up with California-bashing, fed up to the point of taking action."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1526 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary, November 7-12

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Heeeere's Al! Heeeere's Ross! It's the Nafta Follies!
It was the television equivalent of historical fiction. The subject was serious, but it had "entertainment" written all over it. As entertainment it scored: Last week's Gore-Perot "chart wars" (as a White House aide labeled it) drew the largest audience ever for a scheduled cable program. The subject was the North American Free Trade Agreement, which Ross Perot has gleefully blasted, but kernels of serious debate were hard to spot amid the charts, pictures and what were generously called facts. After the dust cleared, the battle raged hotter than ever for lawmakers' hearts as this week's House vote neared.
 
Many Mexicans did not take kindly to Mr. Perot's depiction of a destitute country almost totally lacking in customers with enough money to buy American products. "Before he opens his mouth," a Mexico City lawyer said, "he ought to come down here and take a look." And one newspaper termed Mr. Perot's comments a "series of calumnies and lies."
 
Getting, Spending: A Balancing Act
Lawmakers, by and large, decide how this nation gets and spends. If getting doesn't keep up with spending, it's clear where to point fingers. But many lawmakers are saying, in effect, "We can't do it, so make us do it." That's what a balanced-budget amendment comes down to. The idea creates some odd Senate bedfellows -- Paul Simon, liberal stalwart, who favors more getting (taxes), and Orrin Hatch, conservative extraordinaire, who advocates less spending. Cries are getting louder for a vote, but last week, bowing to Thanksgiving, its backers put it off till February.
 
A Pass Is Just a Pass? No Way!
The debate heats up daily: Where, in that vast gray area between leer and lunge, does sexual harassment lie? Several Federal courts have ruled that lawsuits should show workplace harassment so bad that it caused "severe psychological injury." Or, in effect, someone can shoot at you as long as you don't get hit. But last week the Supreme Court stepped in and stretched the definition considerably, ruling that harassment that creates a "hostile and abusive" environment is illegal. "The time for strained legal arguments is over," said Marcia Greenberger of the National Women's Law Center.
 
Inflation: It's Gone! It's Back!
Inflation was pronounced dead on Tuesday, but some people swore they saw it wink on Wednesday. First came a report that producer prices, having trended downward most of the year, fell another 0.2 percent in October. That provided reassurance that inflation had been tamed, and interest rates retreated. But then came news that consumer prices rose 0.4 percent, the most in six months. The main culprit was a higher gas tax, clearly a one-time blip, but rates headed up again.
 
And the economy is stronger, as the numbers keep showing. On Friday came a report that October's retail sales had risen 1.5 percent, the biggest gain in six months.
 
Slowing Down 10-Ton Speeders
Speeding is a big killer on our highways, but it's all relative. A sports car tooling along at 80 is far less lethal than a 10-ton truck. So last week the Transportation Department proposed a ban on radar detectors in trucks over 18,000 pounds. Independent truckers don't like it -- any more than they like the higher diesel prices that spurred last week's protests -- but most other people do, so it will probably happen.
 
Looking Joblessness in the Face
Strong as some economic statistics are, they don't help those who are left behind as this nation goes through wrenching changes and dislocations. And their pain could be seen vividly last week on the streets of Detroit, a city that has had its insides torn out by the icy streamlining of the auto industry. Detroit's jobless -- the city's unemployment rate is 13 percent, twice the national rate -- are so hungry for decent work that thousands of them lined up in the cold dawn for jobs that may never exist. The very iffy jobs were advertised by sponsors of a casino in downtown Detroit to be owned by an Indian tribe in northern Michigan. The casino has slim chances of being approved, underscoring the job-seekers' desperation. But as one applicant said, "There's nothing else happening but crime."
 
COMPANIES
 
A Drug Maker Goes to the People
Makers of prescription drugs have long stayed above the consumer fray, their prices untouched by the messiness of the marketplace. But pressures have mounted from all sides, whether it's Hillary Rodham Clinton scolding them for high prices or upstart generics turning the competitive screws. So, as in so much of the health care universe, times are changing. Last week, in a vivid demonstration of this shift, SmithKline Beecham said it would give $10 rebates for a month's supply of Tagamet, its big-selling ulcer drug. The company's patent on Tagamet runs out in May, and a generic version is on the way, so this could be a signal that name brands will try harder to hang onto their market.
 
Instant Rival for Cellular Phones
Wireless communications: two words that define a big slice of our future. But in the flick of an antenna, that future can take on a far different shape, as was proved last week when a relatively obscure company called Nextel Communications agreed to buy a bunch of mobile-radio licenses from Motorola for $1.8 billion in stock. Suddenly everyone looked at the numbers and realized that with the theoretical ability to serve 180 million people nationwide, Nextel had vaulted itself into a force that has to be taken very, very seriously by cellular phone companies. And Nextel, whose shares have quadrupled in a year, has an edge: In addition to voice conversations, it can offer built-in paging and data communications, which most cellular services don't offer. It faces a long, bumpy ride, though; the cellular industry has a huge head start.
 
Going Hog-Wild Over a Chicken
Some elf clearly went around Wall Street whispering "rotisserie chicken" in eager ears, because last week a lot of investors decided that was the place to put their money. When Boston Chicken, a franchiser, made an initial offering at $20 a share, so many investors scrambled for feathers that when trading opened, the shares more than doubled, ending at $48.50. The shares passed through a lot of hands that day: The offering had just over 2 million shares, but volume was 8.4 million. Investors' ardor cooled by Friday, and the stock slid to $39.75.
 
Paramount Does Its Own Buying
Bored with would-be buyers hammering on its door, Paramount made its own big-money acquisition last week. Paramount, which owns Simon & Schuster, agreed to pay $553 million for Macmillan, to create the world's No. 2 book publisher, after Bertelsmann. And whether it's method or madness, this adds a wrinkle to the Paramount war. The book deal is so big it already raises antitrust flags, but if QVC wins Paramount, the antitrust issue gets even thornier: Advance Publications, owner of Random House, is backing QVC.
 
And let's not forget the latest bulletin on Paramount's dance card: BellSouth has agreed to slip $1.5 billion into QVC's pocket as QVC courts the popular studio.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Haiti's Children Pay the Price
When Americans hear of the oil embargo and other sanctions against Haiti, their mental image may well be of Haiti's military rulers holed up in a bunker, isolated by rising international pressure. The reality might be far more cruel. Harvard public health experts said in a study last week that the sanctions are killing as many as 1,000 Haitian children each month. As another, less painful tack, the Administration is trying to get other nations' support for freezing overseas assets of Haiti's leaders. Starving children might prefer that.
 
Disney's French Albatross
The Walt Disney Company is probably wishing it had never tried to translate its magic formula into French. Disney is taking in plenty of money back home, but Euro Disney, clearly the victim of a sorcerer's curse, just drains away the profits. Last week, in fact, Euro Disney -- 49 percent-owned by Disney -- reported a $900 million yearly loss, dragging Disney itself into a quarterly deficit. If it doesn't get fresh cash, Euro Disney said it would face a "liquidity problem" (that's American for "no money"). While banks might fear throwing good money after bad, Disney has too much at stake to walk away.
 
Can Japan's Doors Be Opened?
Japan's economy has long been a prime American target. The goods flow out, we say, but tight regulations keep them from flowing in, giving a nasty tilt to the trade balance. Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa, three months in office, is determined to hack away at that regulatory wall. Last week a panel he appointed called for easing or ending hundreds of regulations, and even, in a nation built on monopolies, advocated strict application of anti-monopoly laws. So Mr. Hosokawa now has a snazzy bouquet to offer President Clinton when they meet in Seattle this week. But it remains to be seen whether he'll really be able to nudge Japan toward freer markets.

HEADLINE: Those Mind-Boggling Promotions

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
AMERICANS' love of a bargain notwithstanding, consumers are getting fed up with the increasingly complex promotions being served up by corporate marketing departments.
The often dizzying lists of conditions, choices and partners in today's promotions -- a loose term for incentives that typically give shoppers something in addition to the basic product -- leave many people feeling they need an accountant's eyeshade to scour ads for savings. 
 "There are so many schemes, and I don't think they pay," said Lou Nobiletti, a retired hotel executive in Hampton Bays, L.I., one of the many consumers who has given up on hunting for deals among the fine print and now looks only at prices when he shops. "They're too devious."
Such impatience often dooms big marketing efforts, notably a year-old "frequent buyer" program called Air Miles, which halted operations in the United States in May. The program enabled consumers to earn frequent-flier mileage on four airlines by buying products from a raft of big companies, including A.T.& T., Gillette, Citicorp and Procter & Gamble.
Some industry experts say Air Miles faltered because the rewards were too small, but many argue that it also required too much work, like mailing in proofs of purchase.
Consumers do embrace certain promotions, the ones that keep the fine print to a minimum and offer rewards they want. The General Motors Mastercard, for example, has been a runaway success. It gives consumers a 5 percent rebate on purchases that they can then use to reduce the price of a new G.M. car. In just over a year, the company has signed up six million accounts.
In contrast, General Electric offers a credit card with 27 marketing partners like Kmart and Macy's, which send a packet of coupons worth $250 to cardholders every three months. Each coupon has its own conditions, like $10 off a $50 purchase. For every $500 spent with the card, a shopper gets $10 that can be used only at the 27 retailers.
"You need an attache case to really use this card," said Robert B. McKinley, president of Ram Research, a credit-card research firm in Frederick, Md. "Not only is it messy, but where are the coupons when you need them?"
Broad changes in consumer attitudes are difficult to prove. But interviews with consumers and marketing experts leave little doubt that many people are wearied by deals that tax their time-starved lives.
Judith Langer, president of Langer Associates, a New York-based research firm that conducts more than 200 focus groups a year, said that she often hears complaints from consumers about information overload. "The feeling is very much, 'It's too much, and I need to simplify my life,' " she said.
The publisher of The Tightwad Gazette newsletter, Amy Dacyczyn, can work up enthusiasm for almost any penny-pinching idea, including buying huge stuffed animals at yard sales and eviscerating them to make Halloween costumes. But she finds today's proliferating promotions a turnoff. "If I don't have time to sit down and figure them out, I ignore them," she said.
Nevertheless, surveys of the packaged goods industry -- considered a bellwether of the broader marketplace -- suggest that companies are spending a growing percentage of their marketing budgets on promotions, often joining forces in complex deals.
A joint Nabisco and Sony promotion that started this month can earn customers up to $28 worth of rebates. To reach that figure, they must buy four combinations of the companies' products chosen from a list of more than 45 items -- including Nabisco cookies and crackers and Sony compact disks and video games -- and then send away for the rebates. Ten million booklets are being distributed to help explain the offer.
GQ magazine has sponsored a program called Return on Investment in which the 10,000 shoppers who spend the most in men's departments at various Dayton's and Marshall Field stores in Illinois and Minnesota, paying with the stores' own credit cards, can earn credits on what they buy. And what are those credits worth? That depends. The shoppers who qualify will not know until they spend their credits, but there's another catch: Those credits can only be used at "auctions," where customers bid on merchandise donated by GQ and the stores.
IN September, Cathay Pacific Airways offered members of American Airlines' frequent-flier program a way to earn 80,000 frequent-flier miles -- or 50,000 without even leaving the ground: Simply call the airline and give it the names of 10 people whom you expect to fly round-trip between Los Angeles and Hong Kong in Cathay Pacific's first- or business-class before next March.
Oh, and if the travelers also want bonus miles, they can stay at an Inter-Continental Hotel and earn 5,000 bonus miles, but only after their fourth stay. That is separate from the hotel chain's regular 500 miles, but that's earned per night. Got all that?
Why are many promotions so complicated? For one, programs with many partners are often born out of companies' desire to pool their resources to create bigger, splashier promotions that they hope will stimulate sales in the sluggish economy.
Those promotions are also often designed by the companies themselves, rather than by an outside agency. The results may appear simple to insiders but confuse consumers.
And many promotions are intentionally complex. Companies hope to get top dollar from affluent customers with demanding jobs and little time to jump through the hoops of a promotion.
Finally, the marketing whirlwind is often whipped up by a brief promotional success that other companies rush to match. Ford, for example, soon matched General Motors' offer of a credit card that earns rebates. That, in turn, leads to disagreement over whether such deals are ultimately beneficial.
Al Ries, a marketing consultant in Greenwich, Conn., said proliferating promotions detract attention from the products' merits. A deal can help win customers, but they can just as easily be lured away by competitors.
To wit, much of the current promotional flurry seems to have been inspired by the popularity of frequent-flyer programs. The advantage won by American Airlines in 1981 when it introduced the first program was quickly lost after the other major carriers started their own versions. Now those outstanding frequent-flier miles represent enormous liabilities for the airlines.
"In a sense, you're not building anything," Mr. Ries said. "All this endless extra effort, on both the consumers' and manufacturers' part, is not good for the economy."
COUNTERING that, Chris Sutherland, executive director of the Promotion Marketing Association of America in New York, said that the general rise of promotions -- complicated or otherwise -- reflected healthy competition that could only be considered good for consumers.
"These marketing programs will work to the exact extent that the public will tolerate them," he said. "It's a wonderfully democratic process."
Many companies also defend their sometimes complicated promotions. NBC teamed up with Kellogg's, United Airlines and Marriott hotels this fall for a promotion to attract viewers to their new fall shows. They then faced competition from a similar cross-promotion by CBS and Kmart. Their respective promotions required a half-page each of fine-print explanations in a Sunday coupon insert.
But that didn't worry the network executives, who say they are more concerned about putting together a promotion big enough to cut through the advertising clutter than they are about confusing consumers.
"Even if you were overwhelmed by that, we just got exposure for our shows," said Alan Cohen, senior vice president for marketing for NBC TV.
Executives at Northwest Airlines, which is among the more prolific carriers in devising promotions with fine print, said they attract customers who might not have flown. In one recent offering, the more friends, family or colleagues who signed up for the same flight at the same time, the greater the discounts. Savings were also based on the origin and destination of the flight.
"The consumer can wade through it, if it's a good enough deal," said Susan Edberg, director of passenger marketing for Northwest. Promotions, she added, "become complicated in order for it to be win-win."
But complications may produce a loser.
Keith Mills, chairman of the Loyalty Management Group that ran Air Miles, said, "You're struggling to get a share of the brain capacity that consumers have left."
 
 
 
MAKING A BID FOR SIMPLICITY
 APPARENTLY recognizing the consumer backlash against the rising complexity of many promotions, some companies are marketing simplicity.
"Humans do not like complexity," Oxford Health Plans Inc. said in a full-page newspaper ad promising "less paperwork and more care." It adds, "Keeping things simple makes humans happier and more compatible with the fellow humans." And other advertisers are trying a similar tack.
Continental Airlines trumpets the bold-type phrase "No Restrictions" in advertisements for its new Peanuts Fares. In contrast, a recent -- and more traditional -- ad for the Delta Shuttle lists 17 restrictions.
A.T.&T. started offering a "Personal Choice Calling Card" this fall that lets customers choose their numbers, rather than being dictated a lengthy string of digits. "Some customers have been telling us that they would like to see less complicated products," an A.T.&T. spokesman said.
A recent survey by the Marketing Corporation of America found that 53 percent of supermarkets were using so-called everyday low pricing to some degree, up from 46 percent last year. This strategy is an alternative to the industry's "high-low" pricing, in which losses or reduced margins on sale items are offset by higher-priced non-sale items.
In addition to supermarkets, big chains like Staples, Wal-Mart and Home Depot have combined cavernous stores with steady prices to build high volume and profitable sales. The Saturn car division of General Motors has won praise from consumers for its no-haggling sales policy.
The Sheraton hotel chain and Zenith Data Systems both lowered suggested prices, putting them closer to the levels that people actually pay after discounting.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.

 BODY:

For Poor Women, Training In Entrepreneurship
 The American Woman's Economic Development Corporation and the Woman's Center for Education and Career Advancement are offering an entrepreneurial training program for poor women. The program, financed by the city's Department of Employment, will offer students instruction in business skills as well as counseling on personal matters like child care. 
 "We are looking for women who are serious about the business they want to be in," said Elisa Moore, director of special training programs at the development corporation. "Our applicants must be highly motivated and willing to commit to attending one seven-hour day from 2 P.M. to 9 P.M. each week for 27 consecutive weeks of classroom training."
Orientation sessions are planned tomorrow and Thursday and on Dec. 2 and Dec. 7. For information, call (212) 692-9100.
 
Along With Your Paper Comes a Quart of Milk
 It's a return to the past on the Upper West Side, where Mitchell's Newspaper Delivery Service has branched out into the milk delivery business with its subsidiary, the Milkman.
The company, which has been delivering newspapers in Manhattan and the Bronx for 45 years, purchases milk from Elmhurst Dairies in Jamaica, Queens, and charges its newspaper customers 91 cents a quart or $1.65 a gallon, delivered to their doors between 4 A.M. and 6 A.M.
About 1,500 of Mitchell's 35,000 Manhattan newspaper customers have signed on for milk. The company hit Lincoln Towers on the West Side first, and hopes eventually to extend service to the East Side and the other boroughs.
"Manhattan residents are always running out of milk," said Mitchell Newman, president of the Milkman. "They don't have cars to get to the store four or five blocks away, particularly in inclement weather."
 
From Bankers to Anchors: Breakfast Honors Women
 The New York Woman's Agenda, an organization of 36 national and local women's groups that works to promote the economic and political power of women in New York, is planning its second annual Star Breakfast to honor women of achievement.
Gloria Steinem will preside over the breakfast, which will take place Wednesday, Dec. 1, at 7:30 A.M. at the New York Hilton, Avenue of the Americas at 53d Street. The women honored this year will be Carol Parry, managing director of Chemical Bank; Beth Bronner, president of Revlon Professional; Caroline Jones, president and chief executive of Caroline Jones Advertising; Kaity Tong, news anchor at WPIX-TV, and Suleika Drinane, executive director of the Institute for Puerto Rican and Hispanic Elderly. Tickets are $45. For information, call (212) 687-2484.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 36; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 524 words

HEADLINE: About Foreign Capital

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"How to Get, and Keep, Foreign Capital" (Viewpoints, Oct. 31) ignores that for every seller there must be a buyer, for every borrower there must be a lender. 
 The fact is that we get foreign capital automatically whenever our imports exceed our exports. When we buy a Toyota (certainly if it is made in Japan and not Kentucky), we pay for it in dollars. At the moment the Japanese acquire those dollars, they have invested in the United States. They may then buy stocks, bonds, Treasury bills or Rockefeller Center, but that is merely a matter of portfolio adjustment. They gave us their capital when they sold us the Toyota.
If the Japanese try to sell dollars and get yen, where must they go? To other Japanese. But that simply means that the identity of the Japanese providers of capital to the United States has changed. There has been no pull-out. If they get into, say, German marks, then the German sellers of marks are left with the dollars and the identity of our foreign investors has changed nationality but there has still been no pull-out.
Indeed the only way that foreigners can pull out of their investments in the United States (other than to give them away) is to buy United States goods. If our import surplus changes to an export surplus, the foreign investments will be drawn down.
As the writer, Madis Senner, points out, when foreigners try to pull out of a currency they lower its value. That, he might have added, may offer its own corrective. If the dollar falls enough, we will have that export surplus and foreigners will indeed be withdrawing their capital. But then, of course, we will not need it.
It is not true, by the way, that a lower exchange rate raises interest rates. A central bank, such as our Federal Reserve, may foolishly make money scarce and raise interest rates in an effort to keep an exchange rate from falling. And the view that this may not succeed -- that the exchange rate will fall further -- will raise domestic interest rates as investors demand compensation for the exchange rate losses. But the lower exchange rates in themselves, except possibly to the extent they make the economy more prosperous and raise the demand for funds which the Fed does not accommodate, will not raise interest rates.
The central mistake, an all too common one in financial circles, involves a failure to look at the economy as, simply enough, both sides of a transaction. Foreigners cannot "withdraw" from their American investments any more than there can be a general withdrawal from the stock market. There may be a "wave of sellers," as commentators frequently put it. But for every seller there must be a buyer.
As with the stock market, a surge of foreign dollar selling will lower prices. But the big losers will then be the foreigners themselves. The value of their dollar investments in terms of their own currencies, which must be their ultimate concern, will fall.
 
ROBERT EISNER
Evanston, Ill., Oct. 31
 
The writer is the William R. Kenan Professor of Economics at Northwestern University and a past president of the American Economic Association.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

SECTION: Section 13; Page 4; Column 2; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1198 words

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Dreams Advertised Before the Curtain Rises

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

 BODY:
BOTH Nancy Coyne and Matthew Serino are fond of saying that the products they represent don't have any shelf life. She is the creative director and chief executive and he is the president of Serino Coyne, the advertising agency that handles the majority of Broadway shows. And the economics of producing on Broadway are more dubious than ever; it's a rare show indeed that can hang on if the promise of a sustained audience isn't established right away.
"If you were starting out in advertising and had to pick a business to specialize in, it wouldn't be theater," Ms. Coyne said the other day from her aerie 36 floors above the theater district. "How many products are there that can disappear in one night?" 
 The agency represents 12 of the 18 shows currently on the boards; it is already at work on campaigns for "Grease" and "Damn Yankees," shows that are months away from their Broadway premieres, and it has several shows on the brink of opening, including Neil Simon's "Laughter on the 23d Floor" and "Perestroika," part 2 of Tony Kushner's "Angels in America."
But the focus of the moment is "The Red Shoes," an $8 million musical based on the 1947 movie about the ballet. The show, which stars Roger Rees as the impresario Lermontov and Margaret Illmann as the prima ballerina, is in previews at the Gershwin Theater for an official opening on Dec. 2. This is a crucial period, as the production stands on its first, rickety legs and everyone keeps a wary eye on the box office. It's also a time in which word of mouth and advertising begin to coalesce in anticipation of the first reviews, which will help determine the post-opening marketing strategy.
"During the previews we're deciding what to sell," Ms. Coyne said. "Is it the star? Is it the dancing? Is it the songs? By opening night we've decided on strength. If the critics agree with us, it's terrific. They've done our work for us. If they don't, we continue to sell what we were going to sell. We just don't have their help."
To that end, she has been roaming the Gershwin, listening to the audience during intermissions and after the show. (The women's room, she said, is particularly good for research.) "One of the things I'm hearing loud and clear is that the ballet scene itself is magnificent," she said. "If we do a post-opening commercial, it'll be filmed, I'd almost bet you."
"The Red Shoes" may have to run a year to earn back its investors' money, and Serino Coyne has been hired to make sure this happens. But it's also in the agency's own interest. Its commission-based billings are
tied to the amount the client (that is, the producer) spends on media placement.
"So if we design an ad for a Broadway show that closes, and the ad doesn't run, we don't get paid," Ms. Coyne said.
It is also true that the advertising budget ordinarily starts at 10 percent of the production cost and is generally 10 percent of the gross after opening night. But money available for ads often ends up being pinched by other concerns. If changes in the script mean that a character needs another costume and there's no money left in the costume budget, it will probably come out of advertising. That makes some sense; a blank billboard is probably less devastating to a show than a leading man onstage without his pants.
So the real money for a Broadway ad agency comes from long runs, when television and newspaper ads serve to perpetuate the interest in a known quantity.
One reason Serino Coyne is the leading agency on Broadway -- its chief competitors are LeDonne/Wilner & Weiner and Grey Entertainment and Media -- is its reputation for aggressiveness. Another is its affiliations with the producer Cameron Mackintosh and the Shubert Organization, which produces shows and owns the theaters that house Mr. Mackintosh's "Cats," "Les Miserables," "Miss Saigon" and "Phantom of the Opera."
Serino Coyne is responsible for the American campaigns for all these shows, with the advantage of having inherited the famous logos, now indelible symbols -- the Phantom mask, the helicopter of "Miss Saigon," the eyes of "Cats," and Cossette, the waif from "Les Miz" -- from Dewynters, Mr. Mackintosh's agency in England, where the shows originated. Of course, Serino Coyne has developed some indelible imagery of its own -- the rolling dice for "Guys and Dolls" and the winged "A" of "Angels in America."
The agency, which employs 70 people and bills about $50 million annually, 60 percent of which is from the theater, was started in 1977 by Ms. Coyne, 47, Mr. Serino, 50, and a third partner, Nick Nappi, who has since left. They had defected together from the powerful company Blaine Thompson, now defunct; among their first clients were "A Chorus Line" and "The Wiz."
It had been only eight years since Broadway started advertising on television, with an animated spot for "1776," and three years since live action was introduced, with Bob Fosse's famous ad for "Pippin." Not every show can afford to advertise on television (it now costs $100,000 to $200,000 to produce a 30-second spot, not including air time). But Serino Coyne made it a specialty, proving television's effectiveness when its ads for "Evita" in 1979 turned the tide on a show that had been critically strafed.
Three years later, the agency filmed a pivotal ad for "Torch Song Trilogy." Widely perceived initially as a gay show, "Torch Song" ran nearly three years and won a Tony, spurred by the landmark "testimonial" ad in which a clearly diverse collection of theatergoers praised the show.
For "The Red Shoes," Serino Coyne got a high ad budget, just under $1 million, and was able to make a 30-second television spot of snippets from the movie, because the rights had been secured free by the show's producer, Martin Starger. The rest of the money is being parsed out according to a strategy aimed first at the most likely patrons.
"We've gone right to the ballet audience," Ms. Coyne said, referring to direct mailings offering discounted tickets to subscribers to major dance companies and readers of dance publications. "They serve as advance notice for people who like to be there first," she said, "and they help fill up previews so the word begins to get out."
Ads featuring the show's logo -- a spare, clean painting of a pair of ankles and feet, clad in toe shoes and poised as though to start a dance -- are at train stations and on billboards. It usually takes two or three months for a logo to provoke instant recognition, Ms. Coyne said, but with such a simple iconographic reiteration of the show's title, that should be accomplished sooner.
The idea is then to begin reaching wider and wider circles of people who need more and more corroboration of a show's quality before buying tickets. Tony nominations in May bring on a whole new attack.
Asked for the eventual target audience for "The Red Shoes," Ms. Coyne smiled and offered the deviously composed copy for the flier being spread around New York hotel lobbies: " 'The Red Shoes,' on Broadway," the flier reads. "For girls everywhere, their mothers, their grandmothers and all the men who love them."
That would be everybody, wouldn't it?

PUB-DATE: November 14, 1993

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 22; Column 3; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 808 words

HEADLINE: GARDENING;
A Softer Approach to Growth Problems

BYLINE: By JOAN LEE FAUST

 BODY:
WHEN a particular plant fails to perform as expected, the solution sometimes is a cursory examination followed by an application from a spray can. Much better is taking a sampling of the plant's problem to a professional consultant for a proper diagnosis and suggestion of treatment.
Many gardeners now have a handy reference library so they can do their own homework. Greater use of town, garden and nature-center libraries has encouraged this. 
 But the trend now, especially among professionals, is to look at the total picture. There is a realization that a plant is part of a bigger whole. Underneath are the soils and above is the tree canopy formed by other plants surrounding it.
There are also other factors involved in the growth pattern, such as climate, temperature, rainfall and light. An excess or deficiency of these factors can stress growth and exacerbate problems.
When sprays are used to control the two-spotted mite, for example, the problem often worsens because the insect rebounds after the pesticide application. The spray application kills off the beneficial insects.
This sort of secondary reaction can happen when a single remedy is suggested to control a pest or disease. The beneficial insect or environmental factor that solves the problem naturally is destroyed and the plant problem often worsens. Some of these environmental factors may be as simple as cool weather, which may slow down a problem or hot weather, possibly making it worse, depending on the insects and their life cycles.
Quite often a predator or insect is introduced to control or better a particular need, only to have that introduced insect be the problem. Remember what happened to the gypsy moth, which was innocently introduced to the United States as a benefit to a possible silk trade in this country? The pest has now spread far and wide and during its population peaks, the insect's caterpillars are devastating.
Solutions now being sought are the less invasive means of control. For this reason many of the newer, gentler, less invasive control systems have been winning favor. The Integrated Pest Management system accents plant well-being as well as going after problems.
Even Thomas Jefferson saw the need for maintaining vibrant plant growth and has been noted in writing, "I suspect that the insects which have harassed you have been encouraged by the feebleness of your plants; and that has been produced by the lean state of your soil."
One of the factors gleaned from this philosophy is the need for garden sanitation: cleaning up hiding places of insects, which like to nest quietly for the winter or lay their eggs in protected places.
There are two references that may prove helpful in following the softer approach to pest-disease control. One is "The Healthy Garden Handbook," put together by the editors of Mother Earth News and published by Simon & Schuster. On the title page of this handy paperback book is this subtitle, "Building good soil and nourishing crops can keep most garden problems from ever occurring."
The other reference is quite a large tome (716 pages), "Common-Sense Pest Control: The least toxic solutions for your home, garden, pets and community," by William Olkowski, Sheila Daar and Helga Olkowski and is published by The Taunton Press. It is not a lap book, but well worth having or consulting.
Not every facet of pest control is following this trend, however. Scientists in pest-control research are seeking to solve the problems chemically and through the efforts of biotechnology. This sort of research is directed toward the support of a huge agricultural industry.
Some of the goals the researchers look for in the development of new insecticides are effectiveness, minimizing the insect's development of its own resistance to the insecticide, targeting, freedom from causing secondary effects in the insect's population, nonresidue in the food chain and cost effectiveness.
Dr. Susan W. Fisher expressed the research goals in a discussion of this problem in "Pesticides for Tomorrow," published in a recent issue of The American Nurseryman. She said, "Regardless of which insecticides emerge in our quest, the need for integrated pest management will remain. As with existing products, insect resistance to chemicals of the future is a great concern. By limiting chemical application to the most effective and well-targeted uses, I.P.M. can retard the development of resistance, extending the useful life of both newly developed and traditional insecticides.
"The magic bullet -- an economical product that would eliminate all undesirable pests without harming nontarget organisms or the environment -- is an impossible dream," Dr. Fisher said. "But with intelligent design and judicious application, we should be able to hold our own in the ongoing battle with pests."

Dr. Susan W. Fisher expressed the research goals in a discussion of this problem in "Pesticides for Tomorrow," published in a recent issue of The American Nurseryman. She said, "Regardless of which insecticides emerge in our quest, the need for integrated pest management will remain. As with existing products, insect resistance to chemicals of the future is a great concern. By limiting chemical application to the most effective and well-targeted uses, I.P.M. can retard the development of resistance, extending the useful life of both newly developed and traditional insecticides.
"The magic bullet -- an economical product that would eliminate all undesirable pests without harming nontarget organisms or the environment -- is an impossible dream," Dr. Fisher said. "But with intelligent design and judicious application, we should be able to hold our own in the ongoing battle with pests."
