HEADLINE: Marital Status Ruled Irrelevant in Deportation

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13

 BODY:
An immigrant's status as an unwed father was none of the Government's business and should not have been cited as a reason to deport him after a drug conviction, a Federal appeals court has ruled.
Citing recent laws that repealed previous bans on immigration by adulterers, homosexuals and polygamists, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit said Congress had determined that "private sexual conduct among consenting adults should no longer be considered a legitimate basis for making immigration decisions." 
 In fact, the court said, a genuine parent-child relationship, regardless of marital status, must be regarded under the law as a factor against deportation.
The court also said the Board of Immigration Appeals appeared to be taking an overly narrow view of evidence of rehabilitation by an alien who has been convicted of a crime.
The unanimous ruling, first released on Oct. 8, was reissued in amended form on Friday.
The case involved Rigoberto Yepes-Prado, 38, an East Palo Alto resident and an employee of a San Jose meat market. He entered the United States legally from Mexico with his family in 1974 but has remained a Mexican citizen.
In 1986 Mr. Yepes-Prado pleaded guilty in Superior Court to possession of about a half-ounce of heroin for distribution and spent eight months in jail. Under Federal law, a noncitizen can be deported because of a drug conviction, but deportation is mandatory only if the prison term is five years or longer.
 
'Anti-Social Behavior'
 An immigration judge found several factors in Mr. Yepes-Prado's favor, including a history of legal residence and employment, strong family ties and the lack of any other criminal record, but he ordered deportation anyway. Besides the drug conviction, the judge said Mr. Yepes-Prado had shown "anti-social behavior" by fathering three children out of wedlock.
Asked why he had not followed the judge's previous order to marry the children's mother, Mr. Yepes-Prado said the woman was not sure she wanted to marry.
The appeals court said the immigration judge should have disregarded Mr. Yepes-Prado's marital status and considered his undisputed parent-child relationships and economic support for his children as a positive factor. It ordered reconsideration of the case by the Board of Immigration Appeals, which had upheld the judge's ruling.
"Private sexual conduct between consenting adults cannot be considered as a negative factor in an immigration proceeding, at least absent specific Congressional authorization," said the opinion by Judge Stephen Reinhardt.
He said Congress had shown its intent since 1981 by repealing other laws that prohibited immigration because of private sexual activity. Immigration law also specifies that "a family relationship is to be counted as a positive factor," Judge Reinhardt said.
 
Lack of Criminal Record
 In addition, he rejected the board's conclusion that no evidence of rehabilitation appeared on Mr. Yepes-Prado's record. Rehabilitation can be shown by an absence of criminal conduct after release from jail, Judge Reinhardt said, noting that Mr. Yepes-Prado had no subsequent criminal record, had attended a rehabilitation program and had submitted several testimonials to his good character.
Mr. Yepes-Prado's lawyer, Martin Guajardo, said the ruling was important for legal residents who have criminal convictions.
Because of the ruling, Mr. Guajardo said, "I think they now have a better chance of being able to show rehabilitation and being permitted to stay in the United States." He said the appeals court had also put immigration judges on notice that family relationships were a positive factor, even if a judge considered an immigrant "culturally misaligned."
Mr. Guajardo said that the Justice Department had told the court it wanted the ruling reconsidered and that the department was awaiting instructions from Solicitor General Drew S. Days 3d on whether to appeal further.

HEADLINE: U.S. Officials Reveal Clues That Led to Brink's Suspects

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Federal investigators who seized three men and recovered millions of dollars in one of the nation's largest armored car company robberies unveiled a web of evidence yesterday linking the suspects to one another and to money orders, new bank accounts, duffel bags full of cash, a new car and sunny vacation trips.
The suspects seized in New York City and Rochester on Friday night in the $7.4 million Brinks depot holdup in Rochester in January -- a priest, an illegal Irish immigrant with a criminal record and a retired police officer who was a Brink's guard at the time of the holdup -- are known to espouse the Irish Republican Army cause in Northern Ireland. 
 But Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political arm, and Noraid, which raises money in the United States for families of Irish prisoners, disavowed any connection with the robbery or the suspects. And Federal investigators said they knew of no direct link between the men and the I.R.A. and had no evidence that any of the stolen money went to the rebel cause.
"We do not know at this time if it was intended for the I.R.A.," William Y. Doran, a special agent in charge of the criminal division of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's New York office, said at a news conference at which piles of money -- duffel bags and suitcases full of it -- were displayed, and the details of a nine-month undercover investigation were disclosed.
 
Postal Money Orders
 Mr. Doran and other officials said that postal money orders, some for as much as $4,000, had been bought by the suspects while they were under surveillance. Postal money orders have serial numbers that can be traced, and investigators said it might be possible in coming days to determine where they were cashed.
If links to the I.R.A. are established, other investigators said, the case could signal a major shift in tactics by supporters of the Irish cause in the United States, who have largely confined their activities to legal fund-raising for the I.R.A.'s Provisional wing, or political arm, though some cases of arms shipments to Northern Ireland have come to light in this country.
One suspect, the Rev. Patrick M. J. Moloney -- a 61-year-old Melkite priest who was born in Ireland and arrested there in 1980 on a charge of attempting to smuggle weapons into Ireland for the I.R.A. -- was held in lieu of $1 million bail at an arraignment yesterday before Chief Magistrate A. Simon Chrein in Federal Court in Brooklyn.
"We're with you, Paddy!" supporters and relatives shouted as the short, gray-haired priest was led out of the courtroom.
 
Time in Irish Prison
 Samuel I. Millar, 38, who served at least six years in an Irish prison on explosive and firearms charges and for membership in the outlawed I.R.A., and who was smuggled into the United States in 1984, was held without bail by the chief magistrate, who said the defendant "represents a signficant risk of flight."
The third suspect, Thomas F. O'Connor, 54, who retired in 1982 after 20 years as a Rochester police officer, met Mr. Millar on a trip to Ireland a year later and became a Brink's guard three years ago. He was arraigned in Rochester Friday night and was also held without bail.
All three were charged with receiving or possessing stolen money, which carries a penalty of 10 years in prison and a $5,000 fine. None were accused of direct participation in the robbery, but officials said further charges might be made in the case, which broke late Friday night with coordinated raids at the suspects' homes and other places that had been under surveillance.
Standing before bundles of $5, $10, $20 and $50 bills -- many still in Brink's bags or packed in duffel bags and suitcases -- Mr. Doran and other investigators said that the money had been traced to the robbery through serial numbers. Most of it was found in an apartment on the Lower East Side.
 
Half of Stolen Cash Missing
 The investigators did not emphasize the Irish ties of the arrested men and declined to say if more arrests were expected, though they said the inquiry was continuing. Noting that only about half of the stolen cash had been found, they said it was unclear what had happened to the millions still missing.
But the investigators sketched a detailed picture of what they called an inside job at the Brink's depot and gave an elaborate account of nine months of intensive undercover surveillance, during which the suspects, all apparently unemployed, met frequently, bought money orders, opened bank accounts, bought a car, and paid for vacations in Hawaii and Florida, all with cash.
Officials said two men wearing ski masks and armed with handguns entered the Brink's depot in Rochester, a transfer point for money collected from businesses and banks, on the night of Jan. 5 and confronted three guards, including Mr. O'Connor. No alarms were triggered, and the gunmen bound the guards, collected $7.4 million in cash and took Mr. O'Connor away in handcuffs, later dropping him off five miles away.
Almost from the start, investigators said they suspected Mr. O'Connor had been in on the holdup. They said he gave inconsisent, erroneous and misleading accounts of what happened, declined for four days to give a sworn statement and refused to take a lie-detector test.
 
 Investigators also learned that Mr. O'Connor had been active in Noraid, raising money for the Irish cause, and had helped smuggle Mr. Millar into this country a decade ago.
Mr. Millar, a native of Belfast, Northern Ireland, had been refused an entry visa because of his criminal record. His wife, Bernadette Fennell, also entered the United States in 1984 on a visa that has since expired. Mr. Millar and Ms. Fennell lived at various locations in Rochester and New York and both were associated with Noraid, investigators said.
After investigators discovered that tire marks found at the robbery scene were similar to treads on a 1984 Plymouth Voyager minivan owned by Mr. Millar, a surveillance of Mr. Millar, now living in Queens, and of Mr. O'Connor was begun on Feb. 9.
Later that month, Mr. Millar and Ms. Fennell and their children went to Florida on a vacation paid for in cash. In July Ms. Fennell and a friend, Margaret Booth, took a vacation in Hawaii, also paid for in cash, investigators said.
 
Various Bank Accounts
 In March, investigators said, Mr. Millar opened bank accounts in various names with $25,000 in cash and was later seen purchasing numerous postal money orders, some for up to $4,000. Officials said neither he nor his wife were employed, but Mr. Millar's lawyer, Frank Durken, said he operated a comic book shop store and was hard working.
During the summer, the investigators said they saw Mr. Millar with Father Moloney, the director of Bonitas House of the Lazarus Community, a shelter for troubled teen-aged boys. Though arrested in Ireland in 1980 on weapons charges, he was not prosecuted, though his brother, John, was found guilty and jailed.
Father Moloney, who was seized at home at 606 East Ninth Street, bought a 1993 Ford Explorer minivan for $26,000 in cash on June 23, but only Mr. Millar was seen driving the vehicle later, officials said.
In August, investigators focused on a 10th-floor apartment at 330 First Avenue near East 19th Street, where Mr. Millar was seen entering with nylon duffel bags and Father Moloney with a backpack. The apartment's resident, Charles McCormick, 29, was taken into custody briefly yesterday, but was released without charges. Officials said his flat had apparently been used in his absence and without his knowledge to store and count the money.
 
350 Pounds of Cash
 In a raid at the apartment Thursday, investigators said they found card tables, an electronic money counter, and duffel bags and suitcases full of cash -- so much that they described it by weight rather than dollar value, which had not been determined late yesterday.
"I would say that roughly half has been recovered, but we cannot say that definitely until the money has been counted professionally, which will not be done until early next week," Mr. Doran said. He said the money was "in excess of 350 pounds."
As for the missing cash, he said: "I don't have any idea where the other half of the money is. In view of the spending habits of these people and the obvious purchase of large numbers of money orders, I'm sure much of it has been spent."

HEADLINE: True or False, Account Leaves Ministers Stung

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Either way, says the Rev. DeForest B. Soaries Jr., the damage has been done.
Whether one believes Edward J. Rollins Jr. when he said this week that the campaign of Christine Todd Whitman had funneled money to black ministers so they would not urge their congregants to vote, or believes Mr. Rollins when he later retracted the comments, angry ministers say one thing is clear: Mr. Rollins has diminished the credibility of the black clergy at a time when blacks can least afford it. 
 "It's devastating," Mr. Soaries said. "I've gotten calls from my own members, who know I talked with Mrs. Whitman and Florio before the election. They call me to say, 'Reverend, how much money did you get?' "
 
Having to Defend Honor
 Mr. Soaries, pastor of the 3,500-member First Baptist Church of Lincoln Garden in Somerset, Middlesex County, said he tells his questioning members that "unequivocally not only did I not receive any money," he does not believe any black minister in New Jersey did either. And because his congregation knows him and because, he said, he climbed into the pulpit the Sunday before Election Day and preached about the desperate need to vote, he thinks his flock will believe him. But the very fact that he must defend his honor is insulting, he said.
"How do you quantify the damages?" he said. "There is no way to measure it. All over the state I talked to ministers and they are outraged about the fact they have now been placed in a situation to appear to be money-grabbing political opportunists."
Mr. Rollins, who served as campaign manager for Mrs. Whitman, boasted on Tuesday that the campaign had used $500,000 in "walking-around money" to pay black ministers and Democratic Party workers in exchange for promises not to rally votes for Gov. Jim Florio. The next day, he retracted his remarks and issued an apology through an irate Governor-elect Whitman, saying his comments were "an exaggeration that turned out to be inaccurate."
 
Vital and Stricken Force
 Still, the comments struck at an institution that remains very important to many black Americans. A 1988 Gallup poll found that 57 percent of all respondents and 75 percent of black respondents agreed with the statement "religion can answer all or most of today's questions."
And as an institution, the importance of the black church rises beyond even the issue of spirituality. For many blacks, the church is a haven, a source of strength and understanding, a second home.
"Many, many years ago, no matter what the age of the man, he was 'boy' all week," said the Rev. John Harris Jr., pastor of Galilee Baptist Church in Trenton and a native of Arkansas. "But when he came to church on Sunday morning he was Mr. Somebody, Deacon Somebody, Reverend Somebody. Here was the one place we could walk on equal ground."
 
Less Dominant a Force
 But even as individual churches still thrive, the vision of the church as the dominant institution in black neighborhoods has diminished. Many congregations are filled with women and older members, and have few younger men. Mr. Soaries and others said that while the church is struggling to combat the violence and drugs devastating black neighborhoods, the implication that black ministers can be bought is destructive.
"Anything that assaults the credibility of a basic institution like the black church is very dangerous to the black community," said the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference.
"Unless they defend themselves, unless they make this out a lie, it could severely damage the clergy," Mr. Lowery said. "I personally don't believe it. I find it incredible that any minister would accept money to keep people from the polls."
Mr. Soaries said that at his church, members often go out recruit young men they find loitering on the street, unemployed and uninvolved.
 
'A Breach Between the People'
 "We invite them to buy into a new life style predicated on a value system that says it is more honorable to make $5 an hour working in McDonald's than $500 an hour selling drugs," he said.
"Our entire message is undermined by the notion that we are dishonorable," he said. "It creates a breach between the people who need us most and the institution that represent a hope for the people."
But former Representative William H. Gray 3d, who is now president of the United Negro College Fund and is the pastor of a Philadelphia church, said it was "nonsense" to suggest that all black clergy had been tainted by the incident, even if Mr. Rollins's original comments were true.
"That would be paramount to saying one corrupt doctor makes all doctors corrupt," he said.
Mr. Gray did not comment on the truth or falsity of Mr. Rollins's remarks, but he said the real issue was whether or not Whitman workers paid money to have people refrain from encouraging others to vote.
 
'Tragic for Democracy'
 "If it occurred it would be tragic for democracy and tragic for those who participated in it," he said. "If their names are ever revealed I think the community will take its own punishment." But several ministers said the original comments had already sown seeds of doubt.
Mr. Harris said that when he returned home Thursday evening his wife told him their phone had been ringing all day.
"She said the children had called her wanting to know how could a preacher do such a thing?" he said.
Mr. Soaries said a woman called him Friday morning, anxious because her church had received an anonymous $10,000 donation. She was convinced it had come from the Whitman campaign. But he said the church pastor told him the money came from a member whose husband had died. Now that minister must decide whether to protect the woman's anonymity and risk suspicion among his members, or to break his word and reveal the source of the gift.
 
Crises of Faith
 Even the faithful can have crises of faith. Although he has come to believe that Mr. Rollins's comments are untrue, Mr. Harris said he did not immediately dismiss them.
"No, to be truthful I didn't," he said. "To any rule, there's always the exception. But the rule is it just does not happen because too many people look up to their clergy as leaders. Too much has been entrusted to us."
Mr. Harris, a Florio supporter, said he does not like politics from the pulpit. But he did urge his congregation to vote, and he will raise politics again this Sunday, he said.
"I will go to my pulpit and I will tell my young people to have faith in the Lord and in their clergy," Mr. Harris said. "Because the vicious vile tongue of one man does not make it so for a whole people."

HEADLINE: The Supercollider's Demise Disrupts Many Lives and Rattles a Profession

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
Still stunned by the Congressional decision last month to terminate the $11 billion Superconducting Supercollider project, hundreds of scientists are casting about for new positions in high-energy physics, in hopes not only of pursuing their profession but also of continuing to support their families.
But their prospects seem bleak.
Many of the 200 or so physicists dispossessed by the demise of the big Texas accelerator hope to find jobs at CERN, Europe's premier accelerator laboratory, on the border of France and Switzerland near Geneva. CERN now seems destined to be the world's center for high-energy physics research well into the 21st century. 
 For the last decade, CERN has been the leading competitor of America's major accelerator laboratories, and if the Europeans succeed in building their Large Hadron Collider at CERN, which is scheduled for completion in 2002, CERN will move into a pre-eminent position in this field of research.
The Hadron collider, like the supercollider, will smash beams of protons together in the hope of revealing the mysterious mechanism that gives mass to all matter. But the Hadron collider will be far less powerful than the supercollider, and many physicists give it only about one chance in three of finding this scientific quarry, known as the Higgs mechanism. Physicists say they believe that the supercollider's energy would certainly have shed light on the Higgs mechanism, and that if a special particle associated with this mechanism exists it would have been found.
 
Problems of Its Own
 CERN itself has financial problems because of the European recession, and unless the United States Congress chooses to grant American scientists substantial dowries to take to the European laboratory, employment prospects there seem poor.
Dr. Christopher Llewellyn Smith, the British physicist who will become CERN's director on Jan. 1, said in an interview, "We must try to find a way to make it possible for many of our stranded American colleagues to come to CERN." But, he added, "this will take difficult negotiations, because it's quite obvious that there would have to be financial contributions from the United States" to pay for the added CERN staff and the experiments that they would undertake.
The demise of the supercollider project, Dr. Llewellyn Smith said, "will be a catastrophe if it turns out to mean that the United States is leaving the field of high-energy physics, which that country pioneered."
 
Blessing or Curse?
 Dr. Stanley G. Wojcicki, who is a professor of physics at Stanford University and the chairman of the High- Energy Physics Advisory Panel -- a group of physicists who advise the Department of Energy and other Federal agencies -- says that there is little left of the Federal funding pie to divide up. "Congress has spoken rather firmly that this country is not willing to embark on any large scientific projects," he said.
Such views are by no means those of all scientists, many of whom regard the passing of the supercollider as a blessing.
Delighted by the recent action of Congress, Dr. Rustum Roy, a professor of materials science at Pennsylvania State University, said in an interview that "this comeuppance for high-energy physics was long overdue."
 
Discouraging Scientists
 Dr. Roy expressed the view of many scientists that "there is an acute oversupply of scientists in the United States," and that it is the responsibility of the educational system to try to reduce it.
But to Dr. Roy Schwitters, who was replaced as director of the supercollider last week, the United States is about to lose "the best and brightest" of its high-energy physicists.
"But for most of the thousand or so scientific and engineering staff members of the S.S.C., the future is terrifying," he said, referring to the supercollider. "Many have sunk their life savings into houses near Waxahachie, and now they face jobless futures in a collapsing real estate market."
Among the victims of the supercollider demise, he said, are 180 foreign scientists, many of them Russians, who are working in Texas on visitor visas. They will presumably have to leave the United States soon. "We talk a lot about finding alternative work for ex-Soviet nuclear weapons scientists, to keep them from working for terrorist states," Dr. Schwitters said, "and that's exactly what we were doing."
 
A Costly End
 Dr. Schwitters believes that Congress is unlikely to provide the financial contribution that the European research consortium will demand in exchange for hiring American physicists. "Congress won't spend the money in Texas, so why would they spend it in Switzerland?" he asked.
The cost overruns that plagued the supercollider in life seem likely to affect even its funeral. Congress voted to provide $640 million to close the project down, but it appears that this will not be nearly enough. Environmental regulations, for instance, will require the filling-in of all the tunnels and shafts already completed for the supercollider, which was to have been 54 miles in circumference. This will be costly. Dr. Wojcicki said he had seen estimates as high as $1.5 billion.
Other problems that will have to be resolved include the disposition of the land that was seized from private owners to make way for an accelerator that occupies most of Ellis County, Tex., as well as the hundreds of houses that were moved off the site and onto tracts of storage land. The large factories built at the supercollier site to mass-produce huge superconducting magnets, as well as a stockpile of completed magnets, will have to be dismantled and, presumably, sold for scrap.
Dr. Schwitters, however, said he hoped that the uncompleted site and its materials could be kept intact for scientists in the future who might be able to resume the supercollider's work.
 
Others Could Benefit
 Perhaps the one bright spot that accelerator scientists see in the supercollider demise is the possibility that Congress will spend some of the savings on other physics projects.
Leading the list of potential applicants is Fermilab in Illinois, which is still the highest-energy accelerator in the world. Scientists believe that Fermilab's Tevatron accelerator has a reasonable chance of finding the "top" quark -- the only one of the six hypothesized quark types that has not yet been discovered. Fermilab's decade-long quest for the elusive quark has so far failed to find conclusive evidence of its existence.
Finding the top quark would neatly fill out the "Standard Model," the generally accepted theory of how the basic building blocks of matter fit together. With luck, Fermilab might also find evidence of "supersymmetry," a theoretical mechanism that might relate the force of gravity with the three other known forces of nature: the electromagnetic force, and the strong and weak nuclear forces.
 
Quarks, Matter and Antimatter
 But the Tevatron's two trillion electron-volts of colliding energy have so far failed to reveal the top quark or supersymmetry, and physicists believe the accelerator's colliding particle beams may not contain enough protons to yield a good statistical chance of success. For this, the machine needs a new "main injector," and the hope is that additional money will be found to hasten completion of the main injector.
Another promising accelerator project, the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center's "Asymmetric B-factory," will get $237 million in Federal money, President Clinton announced on Oct. 4. One of the objects of this project is to discover why the newborn universe seems to have contained slightly more matter than antimatter. This assumption explains why, after the primordial matter and antimatter annihilated each other, a small residue of matter was left over, from which the present-day universe formed.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
The Sad, Angry Vigils at Rifkin's Court Hearings

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I.

 BODY:
Ever since Joel Rifkin was arrested in June and confessed to killing 17 women, Margarita Gonzalez has missed only one of his court appearances in the nine counties where he said he disposed of his victims' bodies.
"And that one hearing was way out in Riverhead in Suffolk County," she said. "I'm sorry I missed it, but I think Jenny would understand." 
 Jenny Soto, her 23-year-old sister, was among the young women strangled by Mr. Rifkin and listed in his confession, the police said. Her body was found in the Harlem River in May 1992.
"It's his hands that I can't take," she said during a break Friday in a weeklong pretrial hearing in which Mr. Rifkin's lawyer sought to have his client's grisly confession declared inadmissible.
"I'm O.K. except when I see the hands that killed my sister," she said. "Then I want to put my own hands around his neck. The only way we're ever going to get justice is when he is dead."
Ms. Gonzalez, who lives in Brooklyn and is studying to become a computer operator, traveled to the courthouse here by bus and train, a trip that took more than two hours. She sat in a front-row seat, less than 15 feet behind the defense table, where Mr. Rifkin, wearing rumpled tan trousers, a gray sweater and gold-rimmed glasses, sat slumped in his chair, his eyes avoiding those of Ms. Gonzalez and her new friend, Zaida Dandridge.
Mrs. Dandridge, who lives in nearby Rockville Center and is a New York City housing police officer, is the sister of 25-year-old Iris Sanchez, another woman thought to be a victim of Mr. Rifkin, whose body was found near Kennedy International Airport in June.
"I think he killed more than 17," Mrs. Dandridge said. "How can anyone believe he's telling the truth?"
Ms. Gonzalez and Mrs. Dandridge, who often come to the courthouse with their mothers, said they could not understand why the courts were taking so long to put Mr. Rifkin in prison, since he had already signed a confession admitting to 17 murders.
They sat patiently throughout Friday's hearing, during which the defense lawyer, Michael Soshnick, questioned the methods used by the chief investigator, C. Thomas Capers, the New York State police officer who took charge of the arrest of Mr. Rifkin on the morning of June 28 and obtained his confession.
 
Attacking the Confession
 Mr. Soshnick, who walks to the courthouse from his offices across the street on Old Country Road, spent the entire day trying to discredit the methods by which Mr. Capers obtained Mr. Rifkin's 12-page confession. It includes detailed information about his victims, where he picked them up and where he buried their bodies in graves throughout the New York area.
Mr. Rifkin, a 34-year-old unemployed landscaper, was arrested after a high-speed chase that began when troopers tried to stop him for a routine traffic violation. The chase ended when he ran into a utility pole near here at Old Country Road and Washington Avenue. The corpse of a Manhattan woman, Tiffany Bresciani, 22, was found wrapped in a blue plastic tarpaulin bag in the back of his van.
Mr. Capers, who first took the witness stand on Wednesday, told the court under direct questioning by Fred Klein, the assistant Nassau County district attorney, that Mr. Rifkin had admitted shortly after his arrest to killing Miss Bresciani, but declined, at first, to answer questions about other killings.
"I said, 'Mr. Rifkin, why can't you answer the question yes or no,' and there was no answer." Mr. Capers said Mr. Rifkin's continued silence aroused his suspicions.
He said he then began a guessing game with the suspect, asking him if he had killed more than 10 people, more than 20 people, or more than 10 but fewer than 20.
After admitting to killing two other women he had picked up in Suffolk County, Mr. Capers encouraged him to go on, saying it would be "a good time to clear his conscience and get it off his chest." He said it would be a way he could help the families of his victims and end his troubles sleeping at night.
"You want these people to have a proper burial, don't you," Mr. Capers said he asked Mr. Rifkin.
Mr. Rifkin then admitted to killing the 17 women, using a calendar and maps provided by the police to show where they were buried. He wrote it all down, reviewed it with the police and signed it.
But Mr. Soshnick is now attempting to establish in court that the arresting officers illegally searched the van and failed to read Mr. Rifkin his rights, informing him that he had the right to a lawyer and that anything he might say could be used against him in a court of law.
 
An Unaccustomed Witness
 Mr. Klein was the first person from the Nassau County District Attorney's Office to arrive at the scene of Mr. Rifkin's arrest on June 28, and could soon find himself in the unusual position of being on the witness stand, questioned by Mr. Soshnick about the arrest and confession.
Mr. Klein said outside the courtroom on Friday that he hopes Mr. Soshnick will, instead, place Mr. Rifkin on the witness stand.
"I doubt he'll do it, but you never know," he said. "There is no precedent when it comes to serial murder cases."
Mr. Klein said the police had "probable cause" to search Mr. Rifkin's van without a search warrant. He said the officer who opened the plastic bag and found the body did so because the shape in the bag was that of a human body and the smell coming from the bag was recognized by the officer as that of decaying human flesh.

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD;
TRADE PACT GOING TO MEXICAN SENATE

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 12

 BODY:
While all eyes are focused on Washington for next week's key House vote on the North American Free Trade Agreement, the Mexican legislature also is expected to take up the pact, although the only suspense here is how long opposition parties will spend denigrating the Government before the agreement is approved.
In Mexico, the agreement is considered a treaty and would have to be approved by a two-thirds vote of the 64-member Mexican Senate. The party of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, controls 61 of the 64 seats. 
 Of the three opposition party members, the two belonging to the Democratic Revolutionary Party are expected to hammer out a long line of complaints against the treaty and the Salinas administration, which has supported it from the beginning.
"There are people in North America, Mexico and Canada who have reservations about the treaty, but they haven't been heard," said Porfirio Munoz Ledo, the leader of the opposition and a member of the Senate who said he opposes this agreement but supports economic integration between Mexico and the United States. "What the Mexican Senate does is irrelevant. They are an executive branch, not a legislative branch. They receive orders from the President and that's it."
 
An Invitation to Gore
 Mr. Munoz Ledo said the only debate that mattered would be among officials of the Mexican, Canadian and United States governments, and he invited Vice President Al Gore to discuss the free trade agreement with him publicly. "Something like that is the only possible alternative," he said.
Strictly speaking, the Mexican Senate has no chance to revise the treaty. Its role is restricted to examining the pact to determine if any of its provisions violate the Mexican Constitution. If they do not, the Senate, according to Mexican law, is bound to approve the treaty.
Carlos Fereya, a spokesman for the Senate, said a vote had not been scheduled until now because it had taken so long for the members to go through the 2,000-page agreement.
"We ought to be ready to present it to the full Senate sometime in the next week," Mr. Fereya said, possibly on Tuesday, before the House of Representatives votes in Washington on Wednesday.
But many Mexican political analysts think it is unlikely that the Senate would do anything to embarrass President Salinas, who has made the trade agreement a priority of his Administration.
 
'A Safe Shot'
 "The reason is very simple," said Juan Molinar, a professor of political science at the Colegio de Mexico, a research-oriented institution in Mexico City. "Approving Nafta on the Mexican side is a safe shot since the party controls 61 of 64 seats. It would be an embarrassment for them to pass it and then find it rejected in the United States."
President Salinas, former President George Bush and former Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada signed the agreement last Dec. 17. The Canadian House of Commons approved the agreement 140-127 on May 27.
In Washington, many members of the House of Representatives still say they are undecided on how they will vote. After a House vote, the United States Senate will also have to vote.
In Mexico, there is no doubt about the outcome of a vote. But if the pact is defeated in the United States, it is expected that Mr. Salinas could then use a Senate debate to put his spin on what happened.
"You could expect to see a series of nationalistic speeches," said Denise Dresser, a political scientist at the Colegio de Mexico, "It would be a sham debate, basically designed to allow Salinas to save face and convince the nation that what happened was not a defeat, which of course it would be."
 
Speaking Their Minds
 It is not just the opposition Senators who have trouble with the trade pact. Members of Mr. Salinas's own party have voiced concerns about its impact and have recently shown a willingness to speak their own mind. Last summer observers were shocked when five Institutional Revolutionary Party members of the lower house publicly voted against a set of constitutional changes Mr. Salinas had proposed to reform the electoral process.
Five votes out of 500 did not make for a palace revolt, but in a country where the party line has long been strictly adhered to, it was enough to make people in the Government glad that the free trade pact would not have to go before the lower house.
"Controlling the lower house is not as secure as controlling the Senate," said Professor Molinar. "In the Senate the agenda is easy to control, and you can be sure they will vote for the treaty, even if they have to hold their noses while they do it."

HEADLINE: THE FREE TRADE ACCORD;
Nafta: Something to Offend Everyone

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's biggest problem in promoting the North American Free Trade Agreement is that the seven-inch-thick pact contains something to offend almost anyone.
Truckers, vegetable growers, dolphin lovers, seamstresses, nurses and human rights activists have all been critical of the agreement for very specific reasons. The Clinton Administration's supplemental agreements on labor and environmental issues placated some environmentalists but alarmed conservative Republicans afraid that the agreement's international commissions would infringe on American sovereignty. 
 Much of the focus of public debate, however, has centered on a few broad questions: whether American jobs will be created or destroyed, whether American wages will fall and whether the Federal budget deficit will grow.
 
Simple Goal
 Heavier than many Thanksgiving turkeys, the 15-pound agreement was drafted with a simple goal: to allow goods and services to be traded freely across the length and breadth of North America. If approved by the House and Senate in the coming week, it would take effect on Jan. 1 and gradually eliminate the taxes and other restrictions that Canada, Mexico and the United States now impose on each others' goods.
Most economists say the elimination of trade barriers would eventually increase the prosperity of all three countries. It would allow each country to specialize in producing whatever it can make most efficiently, while importing the rest.
But labor groups contend that American workers will lose jobs to Mexican workers earning a fifth or less of their wages. Even American factory workers who do not lose their jobs will face demands from employers to reduce their wages or risk watching their factory equipment moved to Mexico, critics warn.
 
Debate Over Jobs
 The International Union of Electronic Workers, which represents many low-skilled assembly workers, has shrunk to 150,000 members from 360,000. Its president, William Bywater, believes that, "pretty close to 100,000 jobs" have been lost to Mexico in the last several years.
Administration officials respond by saying that most businesses will conclude that American workers are worth the extra money and that low-skill jobs have been moving overseas even without the pact. "American workers are more than five times more productive than their counterparts in Mexico, because they have better tools, they have better training, they have a better infrastructure," Vice President Al Gore said during his debate with Ross Perot on Tuesday."
To help American workers who do lose their jobs because of competition from Mexico, the Administration has inserted a $140 million job retraining program into the pact. And to prevent Mexico or Canada from gaining a commercial advantage by systematically failing to enforce labor laws, Administration trade officials spent their first six months in office negotiating a supplemental agreement establishing fines and trade sanctions for patterns of failing to enforce these laws.
 
Will Side Agreements Work?
 Labor unions have dismissed the supplemental agreement for two main reasons. The penalties only apply in cases involving minimum wages, child labor and health and safety regulations, but not industrial relations laws regarding organizing labor unions. And any penalties can only be imposed at the end of a bureaucratic process that can last several years and allows ample opportunity for two out of three nations to block action.
Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, promised last spring that the supplemental agreements would have "real teeth." But Mr. Bywater and other labor leaders are dissatisfied.
"If these teeth were in the mouth of a lion, it'd only be able to eat Pablum," he said.
While labor unions have focused on job concerns, consumer groups have been critical of the agreement on the ground of national sovereignty. The pact allows challenges to American safety regulations, they say, like the permissible level of pesticide residues on imported fruit.
The agreement allows such challenges because American exporters have suffered in the past when foreign countries have protected their industries by introducing safety rules barring production methods used mainly in the United States. For example, in the late 1980's the European Community limited imports of American beef produced with hormones that European cattle ranchers seldom use.
Administration officials have defended the rules on challenges by emphasizing that a Mexican or Canadian challenger to an American safety regulation would have to prove that there was no scientific basis to the safety standard. But consumer activists are worried about what will qualify as a scientifically based rule.
"I hope that their definitions are all right -- I don't know if they are," said Lori Wallach, the trade director for Public Citizen, a consumer group founded by Ralph Nader.
 
Odd Alliance
 Consumer and environmental groups have formed an odd, informal alliance with the travel industry and conservative Republicans in criticizing an accompanying budget for the pact and a companion program to clean up the border with Mexico. Federal law requires that as current American taxes on Mexican goods are eliminated, the lost tax revenues must be replaced with new taxes or with cuts in mandatory spending programs.
To raise the needed money, President Clinton has proposed several accounting changes, a four-year tax of $1.50 on international air and sea travelers entering the United States and the creation of a new bank that would issue bonds so as to lend money for anti-pollution and economic development programs.
Consumer advocates and environmentalists have complained that the bank is not big enough, while some Republicans have complained about the temporary tax on airline passengers.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Effects on the Budget" shows Administrations estimates on how Nafta would effect the budget over five years
 
Chart: "What's What in the Trade Pact"
 The product of more than three years of work spanning two Administrations, the NORTH AMERICAN FREE TRADE AGREEMENT is a comprehensive, three-volume plan to bind together the economies of Canada, Mexico and the United States. If approved by the House and Senate during the coming week, it would take effect on Jan. 1, 1994. The pact is intended to eliminate various taxes and rules to allow goods and services to be sold freely from the Arctic to Acapulco.
President Clinton has attached a wide range of agreements and special deals to the trade pact since President Bush signed it on Dec. 17, 1992. The Clinton Administration completed supplemental agreements on labor and environmental issues and on surges of imports on Aug. 13. To win support in Congress for the agreement, the Administration has also struck several side deals with Mexico in recent weeks to address the concerns of specific industries and has proposed several new Federal programs to cope with the agreement's effects, among them a retraining program for workers who lose their jobs as a result of the agreement.
Because the United States and Canada already entered into a free-trade agreement on Jan. 1, 1989, the North American pact would mainly affect trade between Mexico and the United States and between Mexico and Canada.
Unlike the European Community, the North American free-trade zone created by the agreement would not involve common tariffs and other trade barriers toward the rest of the world. Nor would it involve a common foreign policy or efforts to combine currencies, welfare programs and immigration policies.
 
THE BASICS
What the agreement covers: Goods and services produced in the United States, Canada and Mexico. Some goods, like television sets and cars, must also be assembled partly or entirely from North American components to qualify for tariff-free treatment. The nationality of a factory's owners does not matter -- a Japanese-owned auto factory in the United States can qualify for duty-free status if it uses enough North American parts.
Tariffs: Taxes that the Federal Government collects on goods from other countries. Agreement phases out tariffs immediately or over 5, 10 or 15 years. Mexican tariffs on American goods average 10 percent.
Emergency Action: If one of the three countries finds that a surge of imports is devastating a domestic industry, it may temporarily raise tariffs on the product to pre-Nafta levels. The country raising tariffs must compensate the exporting country by lowering tariffs more quickly.
Immigration: Corporate executives and professionals would be allowed to cross borders with fewer formalities. The Clinton Administration contends the pact would also discourage illegal immigration from Mexico by creating jobs there; critics say that the pact would fuel illegal immigration by throwing thousands of Mexicans out of work in uncompetitive industries like corn farming.
Investment: No investment from another North American nation could be seized without full compensation. Investors would be guaranteed the right to convert profits into another currency and take them out of the country. A North American investor facing discriminatory treatment in another North American country could seek binding arbitration from a three-nation panel.
Consumer safety: Current inspections of imported food and other products would continue. Existing American safety standards for pesticide residues and other hazards would be subject to Mexican or Canadian challenge as unfair trade barriers if they discriminate against imports. But the challenger would have to prove that no scientific basis existed for the standard.
 
THE KEY INDUSTRIES
Agriculture: The United States and Mexico will eliminate 57 percent of their trade barriers immediately, 94 percent after 10 years and the rest over 15 years. The slowest phaseouts are for uncompetitive crops like cantaloupes grown in the United States and Mexican corn.
Automakers: Would immediately eliminate the United States' tariff of 2.5 percent on cars assembled in Mexico. Would cut the 25 percent U.S. tariff on light trucks to 10 percent and then phase this out over five years. Would immediately cut Mexico's tariffs on American-built cars and light trucks to 10 percent from 20 percent, then phase out the 10 percent tariff over 10 years for cars and over 5 years for trucks. Would eliminate over 10 years Mexico's requirement that carmakers export two cars from Mexico for each car they import.
Banks: Would dismantle Mexico's virtual ban on American banks. American banks would be allowed to take over up to 15 percent of the Mexican banking market by Jan. 1, 2000, and up to 25 percent by 2004. All limits would disappear by 2007. Mexican banks are already allowed to buy American banks.
Brokerages: American securities firms would be allowed to gradually take over up to 30 percent of the Mexican market by 2004; no limits after that.
Clothing and Textiles: eWould liminate many Mexican tariffs immediately and American and Canadian tariffs over 10 years. Garments that qualify for tariff breaks must be sewn from North American fabric that is woven from North American yarn.
Energy: Mexico would be allowed to retain its ban on foreign ownership of oil and natural gas reserves. But American drilling companies would be allowed for the first time to share in some of the profits from striking oil in Mexico.
Trucking: Mexican and American truck drivers would be allowed to drive anywhere in each other's countries by the end of the century. American companies would be allowed to acquire majority stakes in Mexican trucking companies in 2000 and own then entirely in 2003.
 
THE SIDE AGREEMENTS
North American Agreement on Environmental Cooperation: Would create a special office in Canada to investigate environmental abuses anywhere in North America. Sets of a series of steps that can lead to fines on countries that do not enforce their own environmental laws. Trade sanctions of up to $20 million a year could be imposed on the United States and Mexico if they did not pay the fines.
North American Agreement on Labor Cooperation: Would create a special office in Washington that can only investigate labor abuses when two out of three countries agree. Also creates national administrative offices in each country that can do their own investigations. Fines or trade sanctions only possible if countries fail to enforce worker safety regulations, child labor laws and minimum wage standards.
 
TH DEALS BETWEEEN MEXICO AND THE UNITED STATES
Sugar. Mexico would not be allowed to export more sugar to the United States by substituting corn sweeteners for sugar in Mexican bottled drinks and processed foods.
Orange Juice. If Mexican shipments increase sharply and American juice prices stay low for five straight days, the United States would impose steep tariffs on the extra Mexican shipments.
Wine, bed frames, car window glass, household appliances: Negotiations would start on Jan. 1 to accelerate reductions of Mexican tariffs on these goods. The current agreement provides for a slow phase-out of tariffs.
 
THE MERCHANICS
Worker retraining. $90 million would be spent over the first 18 months of the agreement to retrain and financially support workers who lose their jobs because of the agreement. After 18 months, these workers would be included in a new Federal program, being designed now by the Labor Department, that would cover all displaced workers.
North American Development Bank: The American and Mexican Governments would spend $450 million to set up a bank, which would then borrow $3 billion by selling bonds. The bank would lend money to communities hurt by the pact and to environmental clean-up projects on American border with Mexico.
U.S.-Mexico Border Environmental Commission: Would spend up to $8 billion from the North American Development Bank, World Bank and Inter-American Development Bank to clean up air and water pollution and toxic waste dumps.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Bonuses for Adding Games and Losing Weight

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Deion Sanders received the biggest bonus of the 1993 season, $1.75 million, but Julio Valera benefited from the most unusual.
Valera, a California Angels pitcher who tends to the chunky side, had a body-fat bonus in his contract and earned $7,500 from the provision. Valera's contract called for him to have his body fat measured on the first day of each of six months during the season, and each time he met the stipulated percentage, he would receive $2,500. 
 He succeeded three times, including the first testing date, May 1, when he had to have 20 percent or less body fat.
Runner-up on the unusual-bonus list is the $15,000 Stan Belinda earned. Belinda finished the season in the Kansas City Royals' bullpen but received $15,000 for having the most Rolaids reliever points for the Pittsburgh Pirates.
 
Just Being There
 Sanders, who dabbles in two sports for Atlanta teams, gained his hefty bonus for just being there. That is, his contract provided for $1.75 million to be added to his $1 million salary if he was available to render his services to the Braves through the end of the season or the post-season.
In other words, the Braves offered him that inducement to stay with them instead of moving to the Falcons for the start of the football season.
Because of the Sanders payment, the Braves paid out the second largest amount of bonuses among the 28 major league teams, $3,753,750. The Chicago White Sox were first, paying out $4,515,000, including $1.55 million to Ellis Burks for number of plate appearances and time on the roster and $1.5 million to Bo Jackson for number of games he was available to play.
Burks and Jackson were third and fourth on the bonus list. Jeff Russell of Boston was second, receiving $1,675,000 for number of games pitched and time on the Red Sox roster. Orel Hershiser of Los Angeles (games started), Eric Davis of Los Angeles and Detroit (roster time) and Jeff Reardon of Cincinnati (games pitched) each earned $1 million in bonuses.
The Montreal Expos paid out the least in bonuses: zero. The San Diego Padres were next, giving Tony Gwynn a $25,000 bonus for making the All-Star team. Hershiser was the only member of the Dodgers who got a bonus.
Several teams showed unusual generosity in giving players bonuses they had not contractually earned.
 
Bonus Without Earning It
 Alan Trammell fell three games short of reaching the fourth level of bonuses in his contract for games played, but the Tigers gave him an extra $127,500 -- $7,500 for each of 17 games he played beyond the third level.
Fernando Valenzuela of Baltimore, Edwin Nunez of Oakland and Luis Aquino of Florida each had bonus provisions based on points compiled from games pitched. Each received the bonus for the next level he didn't reach. Valenzuela and Nunez each got an extra $50,000 and Aquino got $10,000.
Then there was Pat Hentgen, who received a $25,000 bonus for making the American League All-Star team in July even though his Toronto contract included no such provision.
 
Thompson Back With Giants
 The free-agent signing season produced its first major result last night when the San Francisco Giants re-signed their second baseman, Robby Thompson, to a three-year contract for at least $12 million. Previously, three pitchers who filed for free agency had re-signed with their teams, each for one year at $800,000 -- Danny Cox with Toronto and Joe Boever and Storm Davis with Detroit.
The most attractive players are in the process of determining which teams are interested in them. Will Clark, for example, visited the Rangers in Texas last week and plans to visit the Orioles in Baltimore this week because the San Francisco Giants haven't made it worthwhile forgoing the market.
"We have respectfully disagreed about Will's market value at this stage," Jeff Moorad, Clark's agent, said. "All things being equal, Will would prefer to return to San Francisco but we will explore some other opportunities."
Although their first preference would be to re-sign their young first baseman, Rafael Palmeiro, the Rangers have interest in Clark because Palmeiro rejected a five-year, $26.5 million offer and is exploring other possibilities.
Andres Galarraga is the third first baseman available in a market that is far less glittering than last winter's. The Colorado Rockies' negotiating stance has not enticed the National League batting champion to re-sign with them.
"We have some serious disagreements," Jim Bronner, Galarraga's agent, said. "We're beginning to explore different opportunities."
Noting Galarraga's age, 33 before midseason next year, the Rockies want their .370 hitter to accept a contract averaging less than $3 million a year and calling for declining salaries each year.
The Rockies apparently have an internal oddity. They have an owner, Jerry McMorris, who has said he is prepared to spend to improve the team, but a general manager, Bob Gebhard, who is reluctant to depart from his baseball front-office upbringing in Minnesota and Montreal, where they don't like to spend. More often, it's the general manager who is eager to spend but the owner who puts economic handcuffs on him.
 
Randy Johnson Is in Demand
 If Randy Johnson were available in the trade market, general managers would be lined up three deep waiting to talk with Woody Woodward, the Seattle Mariners' general manager. The Mariners, however, are trying to sign Johnson to a four-year contract and keep him beyond next season, after which he could be a free agent.
Barry Meister, Johnson's agent, has made a counterproposal and is waiting to hear from the Mariners, who may be waiting to make their next move until Johnson returns later this week from a Tahiti honeymoon.
If the two sides cannot reach agreement, the Mariners are expected to begin talks with interested clubs, try to make a trade, then give the lucky team a chance to reach agreement with the pitcher before making the deal final.
Johnson, a 30-year-old left-hander, gave notice this year that he is about to become one of the most dominant pitchers in either league. He led the majors in strikeouts (308), strikeouts per nine innings (10.86), batting average against (.203) and hits per nine innings (6.52).
His strikeout ratio was the fourth best ever, and his 112-strikeout lead over Mark Langston of California was the fifth biggest ever.
 
Tartabull's Problems Grow
 As for high-priced players, the Yankees wouldn't mind trading Danny Tartabull. At least some members of the club hierarchy believe the offense he can produce isn't worth the aggravation they feel he has created.
The Yankees are incensed that Tartabull, whose shoulder injury made him solely a designated hitter for most of the past season, postponed surgery on the shoulder, had cosmetic surgery, then went off to Europe on vacation.
Dennis Gilbert, the agent who two years ago induced the Yankees to give his client a five-year, $25.5 million contract, said much has been made about nothing. He refused to discuss the cosmetic surgery or even confirm that Tartabull had it -- "That's personal and nobody's business," he said -- but he said the Tartabulls had planned, and paid for, the European trip long ago.
"It's my understanding that Dr. Jobe said his rehabilitation time would be about a month," Gilbert said, referring to Dr. Frank Jobe, the Los Angeles orthopedist who will do the operation. "Danny had plans since April to take a vacation. If it was something that would jeopardize Danny's playing the outfield during the season, Danny would've canceled or delayed his trip. But I think Dr. Jobe will shed some light on this thing."
Dr. Jobe, however, was not available to do any shedding. A secretary in his office said he was in Hawaii and she did not know where he could be reached.
Gilbert said Tartabull would be back in "a couple of weeks" and planned to have the surgery as soon as he's back.
"It's just a little scope to make a minor repair," the agent said. "It's not like they have to do any major reconstructive surgery. He'll have December, January and February to be 100 percent and even March. The season doesn't start until April. Danny expects to be the opening-day right fielder for the New York Yankees."
Unless the Yankees sign Rafael Palmeiro and trade Tartabull. Would they trade him? "We'd trade anybody just about to help our ball club," General Manager Gene Michael said.
The Kansas City Royals have been mentioned as being desirous of getting Tartabull back, but Herk Robinson, their general manager, said a trade was highly unlikely.
"Hal McRae has always liked Danny," Robinson said of the Royals' manager, "but we have to take a close look at our priorities. We'd be filling one hole, but we'd be creating others. I don't see that. We'd like a big bat, but I don't see how that would be feasible."

HEADLINE: Nov. 7-13: Disney Loses $900 Million;
More Trouble at France's Magic Kingdom

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
Euro Disney, a victim of Europe's lingering recession and the hubris of its Californian parent, reported a staggering $900 million loss for its first full fiscal year, sending its stock into a nose dive and raising the possibility that Mickey's stay in Europe may be singularly brief.
In effect, the 18-month-old theme park, which opened amid endless hoopla and occasional grumblings about a "cultural Chernobyl," is now in need of rescue from Walt Disney. Without a substantial injection of new capital -- analysts reckon something close to $2 billion -- Euro Disney will buckle under about $3.5 billion of debt and the cost of running a resort that is still well short of paying its way. 
 For now, Walt Disney has promised to pump in money. But despite increasingly radical attempts to slash costs and accommodate European tastes (alcohol is now served in the theme park), the resort still looks oversized and under-frequented as gray drizzle and recession settle over the Paris suburb of Marne-la-Vallee for another long winter. ROGER COHEN

HEADLINE: Nafta's True Importance

 BODY:
There's more at stake than a simple trade pact when the House votes on the North American Free Trade Agreement this Wednesday. For President Clinton, the vote will test his, and the Democratic Party's, ability to shape major legislation. For the U.S., the vote will test its longstanding commitment to open trade -- the primary locomotive of world growth for a half-century.
Republican and Democratic Administrations alike have urged Latin and South Americans to adopt market reforms and open their borders to U.S. exports. If the U.S. now rejects Nafta because it fears competition from an economy one-twentieth its size, it will look like the hemisphere's biggest hypocrite. 
 The treaty would gradually phase out tariffs between Canada, Mexico and the U.S., creating a large open regional market, and would provide tight legal protection to foreign investors. The Administration says Nafta will produce an economic renaissance; critics say Nafta will destroy jobs, cut wages and damage the environment. The truth is, by comparison, prosaic.
Will Nafta create or destroy jobs? Neither. Trade affects where in the U.S. people work, but not how many people work. Under Nafta, Mexico will export more clothes, vegetables and brooms to the U.S. And the U.S. will export more automobiles, computers and computer software to Mexico.
Employment will rise in some industries and fall in others but is likely to change little over all. That is because it depends less on trade than on the monetary policy of the Federal Reserve Board. If, contrary to predictions, Nafta leads to a flood of Mexican imports, and higher unemployment, the Fed can pump more money into the economy and push employment toward its original level.
Will Nafta suck American industry south of the border to take advantage of low Mexican wages? Critics raise the specter of U.S. firms closing factories and fleeing to Mexico. Some companies will relocate, but the numbers won't be large. Mexico might attract about $15 billion in extra investment. But that's a small fraction of the $500 billion invested in plant and equipment every year in the U.S.
Mexican wages are low because the Mexican economy isn't very productive. They are not a huge draw for U.S. companies and Nafta does not make producing in Mexico any cheaper.
Are Mexicans too poor to buy U.S. goods? Ross Perot's demeaning sound bite is belied by the facts. Mexico is the third-largest buyer of U.S. exports and currently buys more goods from the U.S. than the U.S. buys from it. Nafta would lower Mexican tariffs by a lot and U.S. tariffs, because they are already low, only a little. That means the price of U.S. goods in Mexico will fall enough to make U.S. exports more affordable to Mexicans.
Will wages of low-paid workers rise or fall? Many U.S. workers fear their wages (after accounting for inflation) will fall because they have done so for the better part of two decades. But the anguish is misdirected. Trade explains only a tiny part of the trend and Nafta won't make matters any worse.
Some U.S. companies will cut back employment as they relocate; and some Mexican exports to the U.S. will increase. On both scores, U.S. employers will cut wages to stay competitive. But this is only half the story. Nafta will raise U.S. exports, and the U.S. industries that are likely to expand hire about as many low-paid workers as the U.S. industries that are expected to shrink. Nafta's impact on wages will be negligible.
Will Nafta harm the environment? Most major environmental groups in the U.S. support Nafta. And for good reason. It explicitly protects U.S. environmental regulations and builds in a mechanism for sanctions if Mexico fails to enforce its own environmental laws, which are already strict. Critics charge that the agreement would invite U.S. companies to flee south to evade tough U.S. enforcement; but few U.S. companies spend as much as 1 percent of costs on compliance -- which is too small an expense to justify relocating in Mexico.
The case against Nafta isn't sound. But proponents should not dismiss the pain of those Americans -- probably a few hundred thousand over a decade -- who will be laid off. That amount of fluctuation happens month by month in a 120 million-member labor force. But to the victims, the problem is severe. The answer isn't to throw the entire economy into a protectionist straitjacket, but to provide ample retraining and education.
After weighing the economic pros and cons, Nafta comes out slightly ahead. But the other stakes -- the vitality of the Clinton Presidency and the future shape of the U.S. relationship with Mexico and the rest of Latin and South America -- loom even more important. They are the reasons that Democrats, in the party of Bill Clinton, and Republicans, in the historic party of free trade, ought to vote yes.

HEADLINE: In America;
The Real Mexico

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico has opened up markets and improved conditions for big business, both foreign and domestic, but he has done it by keeping the heavy boot of repression on the throat of Mexican workers.
A magazine ad sponsored by the state of Yucatan earlier this year showed an American businessman complaining, "There is no way I can get my labor costs down to $1 an hour." The ad copy below the photo extolled the availability of cheap Mexican labor and concluded, "Yes you can, in Yucatan." 
 The ad was eventually yanked because Mexican officials feared it would hurt the chances for approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The American workplace is a paradise compared with Mexico's. The average hourly compensation, including benefits, for a production-line worker in the United States in 1992 was $16.17; in Mexico, it was $2.35. The minimum wage in the U.S. is $4.25 an hour. In Mexico, it is $4.60 a day.
A Green Giant plant that left 200 American workers jobless when it moved from Watsonville, Calif., to Irapuato, Mexico, in the early-1980's was able to cut the wages it paid to vegetable trimmers from $7.58 an hour to 83 cents an hour.
These are some of the reasons why workers in the United States are afraid that big companies will continue taking their jobs south, and that Nafta will accelerate the trend.
The plight of Mexican workers is grim. They don't have much in the way of rights by American standards and President Salinas is committed to keeping it that way. His overall economic strategy is to move away from protectionism, opening Mexico up for foreign investment. There is no better way to attract investment than to insure that labor costs remain low.
Mexican labor unions are tightly controlled. They have to apply to the Government for permission to strike. There were more than 7,000 applications to the federal Government in 1991, according to Harley Shaiken, a labor expert from the University of California at Berkeley who has studied the Mexican economy. Only 136 of them were approved.
There is only the tiniest chance that a truly independent union will even be recognized by the Government. A dispute has arisen over how many have been recognized in the past decade or so. Said Mr. Shaiken: "Some say it's been one. Those that use a broader definition say it's been two."
But Mexico is not just a country that deliberately sacrifices the well-being of its workers in the name of economic development. It's also a land of torture and extreme poverty.
Several respected human rights organizations, including Amnesty International and the United Nations Committee Against Torture, have complained about the extensive use of torture by federal and state police officials in Mexico, and the failure of the Government to make substantial efforts to stop it.
Carlos Salinas (no relation to the President) is an official with Amnesty International. In testimony before a U.S. Congressional subcommittee last month, he said, "Mexican violators are not accountable and they are brazen."
He told the committee "they beat and kick their victims"; they "introduce carbonated water with chili pepper up the victim's nose"; they "semi-asphyxiate" them by putting plastic bags over their heads or submerging their heads in water; they shock them with electric prods or leave them hanging by their wrists for long periods of time.
President Salinas, mindful of the negative impact that human rights abuses could have on Nafta, has instituted reforms, but there is little real enforcement. The torture, according to Amnesty International and the other organizations, continues.
It is estimated that more than half of the 82 million Mexicans live in poverty, and 18 million in "extreme poverty." Amid these conditions a million new workers enter the job market each year and two-thirds cannot find full-time employment.
It will be a long time before we see tremendous purchasing power in Mexico. What we have now is an enormous sponge ready to soak up the low-paying jobs offered by large corporations answering President Salinas's call to invest in Mexico.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Trade Debate Rubs Salt in Canada's Wounds

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am a Canadian who experienced strong flashback feelings after listening to the Nov. 9 debate on the North American Free Trade Agreement between Al Gore and Ross Perot. Vice President Gore's comments took me back to 1988, when Canada adopted a Free Trade Agreement with the United States. Many of his comments could have been scripted by the Progressive Conservatives, the party that brought free trade to Canada. 
 We were told that free trade would improve the Canadian economy by making it more competitive.
We were told that free-trade would create, not eliminate, jobs.
We were told that not to vote for free trade would mean succumbing to a politics of fear. Anti-free trade sentiments were thus just a manifestation of some inferiority complex.
Finally, we were told this was a historic moment and that if we didn't take advantage of it by moving into the future with confidence, we would lose out on a one-time opportunity.
Well, free trade has indeed been a historic moment for Canada. Since 1988 we've lost more than 500,000 manufacturing jobs. Unemployment levels remain disturbingly high (approximately 11 percent nationally). Still mired in an economic recession, Canadians are looking at an alarming erosion of our social system -- especially in medical care, education and the environment.
Five years later, we're still waiting for the free trade miracle in Canada.
Incidentally, we had another historic moment north of the 49th parallel. The Progressive Conservatives were given the boot by Canadians last month -- dropping from more than 150 seats in Parliament to a mere 2. A free-trade-related vote? Who can say for sure? But Bill Clinton and Al Gore might do well to take note of this history.
 
HILARY CUNNINGHAM
Montreal, Nov. 10, 1993

HEADLINE: Trade Debate Rubs Salt in Canada's Wounds;
Neither of the Above

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I wish there had been a third debater on the Larry King program on Nov. 9, along with Vice President Gore and Ross Perot. Perhaps then, instead of a mass media event, we could have witnessed a constructive discussion focusing on some of the real issues of international trade:
* The debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement is not a clash between "free trade" and "protectionism." Neither of these code terms accurately describes the accord or the positions of most of those who oppose it. These terms just make it harder for people to focus on the agreement's actual provisions and their likely effects.
* Before the North American Free Trade Agreement was negotiated, and whether or not it passes, the strategy of transnational business has been, and will continue to be, to move operations to lower-cost sites. The issue is whether or not we will change our trade policy to discourage that strategy.
* When the European Community countries formed their trading bloc, they made agreements that will raise the wages and standards of the countries at the low end of the scale.
* There is significant opposition to the North American Free Trade Agreement in Mexico (as I learned when I studied there this year) from independent unions, small farmers and community groups. They fear the trade agreement will bring more exploitation of low-paid Mexican workers; increased unemployment of some of the higher-paid workers employed by Mexican companies that cannot compete with higher-tech companies based in the United States; radical changes to the traditional culture of Mexico, and benefits for a very small number of upper- and middle-class Mexicans.
* If this version of the North American Free Trade Agreement is defeated (and I think it should be defeated), trade with Mexico and Latin America will continue.
The real issue, as I see it, is whether or not the people of the United States, Mexico and Canada will demand a trade policy that promotes real development of the Mexican economy and that sets and enforces decent standards of living for workers in North America and throughout the world.
 
KEN MARGOLIES
Director of Labor Programs
School of Industrial and Labor
Relations, Cornell University
New York, Nov. 10, 1993

HEADLINE: Trade Debate Rubs Salt in Canada's Wounds;
The European Example

 BODY:
To the Editor:
When Vice President Gore asked Ross Perot what Mr. Perot specifically would change in the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mr. Perot responded that he would study other free trade agreements. He indicated that he thinks the United States could learn from the experience of the European Community in integrating Spain and Portugal. 
 If Mr. Perot studied the case of Spain and Portugal, he would see that not only does it not present a good example for the United States, but also he would strongly oppose any attempt to treat Mexico as the E.C. has treated Spain and Portugal.
The European Community does not have a mere free-trade treaty with Spain and Portugal. These countries have been fully integrated into the E.C. social, economic, legislative and political structure. Behind their rapid economic progress are tremendous European Community subsidies and developmental aid.
Europeans pay dearly for this at tax time and with outrageous prices for agricultural produce to subsidize farmers in developing parts of the European Community.
Before Spain and Portugal were integrated, the Community had a simpler free-trade agreement with them, as it now has with some North African countries, Turkey and Israel. These agreements are motivated by foreign policy, security concerns and a desire to give economic aid, and are disadvantageous to the E.C. in economic terms. None of these agreements are between the E.C. and one of its top five trading partners. And none are as comprehensive as the North American Free Trade Agreement and its side agreements.
Mr. Perot would spend his entire fortune to oppose any European Community-style foreign aid subsidy for Mexico.
 
ROBERT J. TOLCHIN
Scarsdale, N.Y., Nov. 10, 1993
The writer is a lawyer.
