HEADLINE: M.B.A. Programs Fight for Shrinking Pool of Students Interested in Business

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
For years, business schools have taught students the importance of knowing their markets and their products. But now business schools across the country are finding that they must heed their own message.
In the last few years, interest in business careers and business education has slid. "We're all like the airlines after deregulation, suddenly faced with really having to compete," said Stephen Christakos, director of admissions at the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University. 
 And competing they are. Even the Harvard Business School, though it has not experienced a decline, is scrapping its old ways of training future executives. Under a proposed new curriculum disclosed earlier this week, Harvard business administration students would focus less on specific disciplines and more on combining skills to solve problems.
"We're not just competing with other schools," said James I. Cash, chairman of the Harvard M.B.A. program. "We're competing with other professions."
 
More Rounded Curriculum
 Many business schools are setting up special programs in international business, information technology or other high-profile subjects. Many, too, are increasing liberal arts courses in their M.B.A. programs while they play down the number-crunching ones. And some are offering study abroad and courses on foreign languages and cultures.
The Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley has replaced a basic accounting course with a broader one that covers how businesses are set up and governed, how they manage people, how they market their services and how they compete internationally. Next year the school will begin offering a special certificate to students who take a certain number of foreign language and culture courses.
Under Harvard's proposed program, first-year M.B.A. students would take more general courses like "Managing Products and Services" and "Leading People and Organizations" instead of specific courses like marketing and operations. And the school said students would often work together in teams to solve business problems.
The Harvard program, which must be approved by the faculty, was the result of more than a year of internal review. The business school hopes to have most of the program in operation by the fall of 1995.
In past recessions, business school applications rose, but the recession of the 90's produced the reverse. "People no longer feel that loyalty and productivity and, yes, a business degree are keys to success," said Ronald J. Patten, dean of DePaul University's College of Commerce in Chicago.
The average starting salary offered in 1993 to a graduate of a business school without a technical undergraduate degree was $36,513. For those with technical undergraduate degrees -- say, engineering or computer science -- the salaries offered averaged $40,980.
Another factor fueling the decline in M.B.A. applicants is that the definition of "success" has changed for many students, said Charles W. Hickman, director of projects and services at the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business, which accredits business schools.
"Today's students view contributing to society and improving lives of other people as more important than high financial reward," he said. "Many are choosing professions other than business."
Indeed, numerous surveys show that the number of undergraduates planning to major in business has dropped by a third since 1987.
 
Apathy About Business Careers
 Among women, the group that drove up the enrollment figures of business schools in the 80's, the drop has been even steeper. In 1987, 20 percent of first-year female undergraduates wanted to major in business; in 1992, only 12 percent did. "The business schools have been blindsided," said Dr. Kenneth C. Green, director of the Center for Scholarly Technology at the University of Southern California.
Undergraduate apathy toward a business career has already shown up in the number of people taking the Graduate Management Admissions Test, which most graduate business schools require applicants to take. In the last two years the number of applicants taking the test has dropped nearly 18 percent.
This year, the Graduate School of Business at Stanford University has seen a 20 percent decrease in applications. The Wharton School's highly selective joint degree program with the Joseph H. Lauder Institute, its international cousin at the University of Pennsylvania campus, received only 310 applications for its 55 spots this year, down from 325 the previous year.
Elsewhere, the Amos Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College received 2,077 applications this year, as against 2,663 in 1990. Even the Kellogg School, which has ranked No. 1 the last three times in Business Week's biannual business school survey, has seen its applications drop to 4,328 in 1993 from 5,016 in 1991.
 
New Emphasis on Teaching
 As many business schools focus on overhauling and broadening their curriculums, many have begun to pay attention to professors' teaching skills, a radical change for academia, where published research is often the only route to tenure and promotion.
"At Iowa, we turned down a would-be professor with excellent research credentials because we heard his teaching abilities were not great," said George Daly, former dean of the College of Business Administration at the University of Iowa. In August, Mr. Daly took over as dean of the Leonard N. Stern School of Business at New York University, which is now emphasizing teaching skills as much as research in its tenure decisions.
Perhaps most unusual is that business schools are now marketing their new offerings as aggressively as Campbell markets soup. The schools are putting together brochures that tout their resources, placement records and new curriculums.
The schools are also easing the application process, allowing students to pay fees by credit card and to apply electronically via computer modem. They are holding receptions for foreign applicants in Tokyo, Frankfurt, London and other foreign cities. And, increasingly, deans themselves are being sent to woo potential students.
 
Holding the Line
 In addition to Harvard, business schools that have not seen decreases include Babson College in Wellesley, Mass., and the business schools at Columbia University and the University of Illinois. But these schools are working doubly hard to make sure their enrollment figures remain solid. Babson, for example, has hired a full-time director of marketing and has put Howard Rubenstein, a New York public relations expert, on retainer.
Having to seek out students is a new and bitter pill for business schools, which had grown accustomed to growth. In 1972, only 12 percent of master's degrees were awarded in business; by 1990 that number had risen to 24 percent, although it dropped slightly, to 23.3 percent a year later. In 1972, only 4 percent of M.B.A.'s were granted to women; by 1991, the proportion had grown to 35 percent. In 1974 there were 389 M.B.A. programs in the nation; now there are nearly 800.
 
Shifting Student Demographics
 Today's college-age students are a much smaller group than the baby boomers were, and more of them are members of minorities. By 2000, educators says, 28 percent of college-age men and women will be black or Hispanic; at present those groups comprise only 8 percent of M.B.A. enrollments.
In another tactic to combat the decline, many schools are trying to attract students early. The Tuck school at Dartmouth is encouraging students to apply directly from college, rather than wait until they have had a few years' business experience, a break with business school tradition.
And the University of Richmond's undergraduate School of Business, which previously did not allow liberal arts undergraduates to apply to the business program until their junior year, now offers first-year undergraduates who scored 1,200 on the Scholastic Assessment Tests a guarantee: provided they maintain a 2.8 grade point average, they will automatically be accepted in the business school in their junior year.
"We used to need a moat with alligators around us to keep the students away," said R. Clifton Poole, the Richmond business school's dean. "Now we're having to form bonds with them as soon as possible."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 3, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Nov. 14 about revisions in M.B.A. programs referred incompletely to changes at the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley. An international business course replaced an accounting course at the undergraduate level, not the graduate level.

HEADLINE: Building's New Look Shaped by Old Zoning

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
ZONING calculations with a skin strapped on." That is Richard S. Hayden's description of the architecture at 320 Park Avenue, an obsolete 32-year-old office tower that he and his colleagues are redesigning from the bones out as the new headquarters of the Mutual of America Life Insurance Company.
 Mutual bought the 34-story structure from the ailing Olympia & York last year for $130 million and is spending $73 million to reconstruct it. Since 320 Park Avenue was constructed just months ahead of the 1961 Zoning Resolution, it has about one and a half times as much floor space as would be allowed in a new building on the same site, making it well worth an owner's while to rebuild it rather than replace it. Mutual plans to occupy 10 floors and lease the rest when the building reopens in the spring of 1995. 
In the redesign by Swanke Hayden Connell Architects, the most obvious change to the flat-topped tower between 50th and 51st Streets will be the addition of a 52-foot-high gabled peak, which is to cover the rooftop mechanical equipment.
 But the building will change in other significant ways. Floor space will be carved out of the second floor, to create a more voluminous lobby, and shaved off five mid-rise floors. At the same time, floor space will be added to 10 high-rise floors, where Mutual expects to command the highest rents from its tenants. The mechanical core of the building will be expanded to put more air-distribution rooms on each floor. That, in turn, will permit overhead air ducts to be smaller, meaning that ceilings can be higher.
 Low ceilings are only one of the shortcomings at 320 Park Avenue, which was the ITT Corporation World Headquarters before that company moved out in 1990. The structure is also full of asbestos, as a building of its era would be. And its design -- glass-and-aluminum shoeboxes stacked atop one another -- owes more to the dictates of the Zoning Resolution than to architectural impulse.
 BUT zoning also works in its favor. Ungainly though it may be, 320 Park Avenue has 626,000 square feet of space. Under current zoning, a new building on the same lot could have about 441,000 square feet. In other words, Mutual effectively gets 185,000 square feet more than it would were it to start from scratch.
 Mutual of America is moving only four blocks from its current headquarters, 666 Fifth Avenue, between 52d and 53d Streets, but the journey took almost a decade.
 "The economics were such that we felt we had to leave New York City eight or nine years ago," said William J. Flynn, Mutual's chairman and chief executive officer.
 Westchester County was first to be explored but the stumbling block was the Throgs Neck Bridge, Mr. Flynn said, since so many Mutual employees live in Brooklyn or Queens or on Long Island.
 Long Island came next. Six sites were seriously examined, in Huntington and Garden City, among other places, but all fell through for a variety of reasons.
 By then it was 1990. And, Mr. Flynn said, "Everything had changed so radically that we came back to looking at New York." Among buildings under consideration was 60 Broad Street, at Beaver Street, the former Drexel Burnham Lambert headquarters.
 In the course of this search, Mutual's advisers at Kidder, Peabody & Company came across 320 Park Avenue, which fit several key criteria: it was for sale (Mutual no longer wanted to pay commercial rent tax as someone else's tenant), it offered 250,000 square feet of contiguous space for Mutual (which is now scattered through 666 Fifth Avenue), it was in the right part of mid-Manhattan (between the Avenue of the Americas and Lexington Avenue) and it was not too large.
 "It could be no greater than 750,000 square feet," said Manfred Altstadt, senior executive vice president and chief financial officer. "We didn't want to take too much in the way of rental risk."
 Several other factors influenced Mutual's decision to buy the building. One was the passage only days earlier of a bill that froze real estate assessments for eight years on office towers south of 96th Street that underwent modernization.
 "The decision to do this was based on economics," Mr. Flynn said, "rather than wanting a fancy house on Park Avenue."
 "In many ways, we're a quiet company," said Thomas J. Moran, the president and chief operating officer. "When we moved from Park Avenue South to 666 Fifth Avenue, it was to enhance our recognition. Moving to Park Avenue, as an owner, is another step in that direction."
 Mutual's headquarters were at 360 Park Avenue South, at 26th Street, until 1976, when it moved into one 62,000-square-foot floor at 666 Fifth Avenue. "To get the kind of people you wanted," Mr. Flynn recalled, "you had to be in a better neighborhood."
 Since then, Mutual has grown into 175,000 square feet of space at No. 666, occupying the 4th, 10th, 11th and 19th floors. When its original 15-year lease expired in 1991, Mutual negotiated five one-year extensions, to preserve its flexibility in moving.
 Although the company is not expanding -- it has 750 employees -- it will occupy much more space in 320 Park Avenue than it does at 666 Fifth Avenue, taking 275,000 square feet. Individual work areas are being enlarged, as is the cafeteria, and training and conference rooms are being added.
 Asbestos is now being removed from the building. That work is to be finished in February. In the next two months, removal of the existing curtain wall is scheduled to begin.
 Mutual is to occupy floors 2, 6 through 12, 34 and 35. Other floors are to be leased. (The floor count will change to 35, since Mutual is eliminating the designation of 13 -- "Superstition," Mr. Altstadt explained.)
 The reconstruction of 320 Park Avenue was already in the works when Mutual bought the building. In 1990, with the impending departure of ITT, Olympia & York Companies (U.S.A.) planned a $130 million rebuilding, to designs by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. Every floor would have been altered under this approach, with floor area taken off the bottom and added to the top. And the entire facade would have been clad in stone, Mr. Altstadt said, which would have required reinforcement for the steel frame.
 "WE did look hard at the S.O.M. plan," Mr. Altstadt said. "But the one thing that caused us to pause was the dollar amount. If we had to spend $130 million for the core and shell, the economics would have changed radically. We would have had to charge rents of $70 a square foot to make it economically viable." (Asking rents on Park Avenue are now about $40 a square foot a year, according to the Edward S. Gordon Company.)
 "From the beginning," said Mr. Hayden, the architect, "our goal was to take this building that was designed by zoning and start to see how we could create something that was driven by sculpture and design -- and keep it at a responsible budget level."
 "When you walk by that building," said Mr. Moran, Mutual's president, "we want you to have a sense of who we are. It will have a clean, sharp, modern look to it -- yet conservative -- which is how we see ourselves."
 The architects limited the use of stone to the lower 11 floors, where it would be seen by pedestrians. After the first setback, above the 12th floor, the cladding would change to painted aluminum panels. The vertical piers that separate the window bays would be capped by stainless steel moldings.
 "We felt that developing a striking and sophisticated lightweight facade was a better use of money than throwing more money into the structure," Mr. Hayden said.
 The architects made models in two different palettes, one predominantly gray and the other predominantly brown, echoing St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church and the former General Electric Building, both of which are directly across Park Avenue.
 A granite known as Sardinian gray was chosen, even though its color would seem to be at odds with the landmark church. "There are lots of ways of relating that aren't mimicking," Mr. Hayden said. "If you look at St. Bart's in detail, it's got quite a lot of gray stone to it. Although brick is the dominant tone, there's a large amount of limestone in the gray direction and marbles and tiles in a number of colors."
 Moreover, Mr. Moran said, "Browns and reds have been overused in the city."
 Inside, a number of significant changes are to be made. While floor area is reduced on five mid-rise floors, it will be increased in 10 high-rise tower floors. "We're adding space in what we call the high-rent district," Mr. Altstadt said. Those tower floors, which now have 8,000 square feet, will grow to more than 12,000 square feet.
 Another major alteration involves the mechanical core. "We've broken down the supply of air, which is the biggest consumer of space above the ceiling," said Altan O. Gursel, an associate principal at Swanke Hayden Connell. "The air-handling system has been broken down into two or three distribution points rather than one mechanical room on the floor with large ducts coming out."
 By the curious mathematics of zoning, 320 Park Avenue will grow smaller on paper even as it grows larger physically.
 THE building now has 626,000 square feet of gross floor area above ground. Mechanical space, however, is not counted against the floor area that is allowed by zoning. In the existing layout, 49,000 square feet of space is deducted, leaving a building of 577,000 square feet for zoning purposes.
 After reconstruction, there will be an increase in the gross area, to 656,000 square feet. But because the mechanical areas are growing so considerably, the deduction rises to 87,000 square feet. That yields a building of 569,000 square feet for zoning purposes.
 "We went to the limit of what we could put in without any variances being necessary or required," Mr. Moran said.
 On the mid-Manhattan skyline, the most notable facet of the reconstruction will be a gabled peak that is to be illuminated at night.
 "Since this tower is only 35 floors," Mr. Gursel said, "and we had to renovate the mechanical systems on top of the building, we thought that Mutual, as a newcomer on Park Avenue, would like to be recognized."
 Different treatments were studied. There was, for example, a more flattened top with openings cut into it. Mr. Moran likened this to a "sniper's nest." There was a more pinnacle-like top. This, too, was rejected. "It went too far," Mr. Gursel said. "It was as if we were building another church across the street, only it was so tall. It became too powerful, too much of a spire. It looks like we're racing to catch the eye first."
 "One thing we agreed on quickly," Mr. Altstadt said, "is we have to be careful not to do anything that would give the appearance of trying to compete with the church."
 But Mutual did seek a distinctive profile. After all, Mr. Moran said, "when you think about the skyline, there are few of us who wouldn't want to be a part of it."

In a letter dated Dec. 14, a reader reported correctly that it was Kapell & Kostow Architects, not Skidmore, Owings & Merrill.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
'Animal Crackers,' Marx Fun Once More

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

DATELINE: MILLBURN

 BODY:
NOW that the Paper Mill Playhouse's first musical of the season, "Paper Moon," misguidedly or perhaps just prematurely announced as Broadway bound, isn't, how about "Animal Crackers?" It's raring to go.
The 1928 Marx Brothers musical, the comic anarchists' third and last Broadway show (after "I'll Say She Is" and "The Cocoanuts"), represents the Paper Mill at its freest, with everything going sublimely, ridiculously right, under the light and flowing direction of Charles Repole, who staged the musical's terrific revival at the Goodspeed Opera House in Connecticut last year. 
 The demonic threesome who created a blissful commotion at Goodspeed are gracefully reunited here. Consider Frank Ferrante, the leering Capt. Jeffrey T. Spalding, "the noted African explorer," Groucho's most celebrated creation. "What? From Africa to here, $1.85?" he protests as he is hoisted on a litter by a pair of Africans in a most anticipated entrance.
Next on is Robert Michael Baker (Chico) as Signor Emanuel Ravelli, a musician who explains, in perfect nonsense, his unaffordable rates for not playing and for not rehearsing.
Les Marsden (Harpo) follows as the silent Professor of whatever it is he professes to be.
It is Zeppo, soon to disappear from the brothers' act, the "fourth of the Three Musketeers," as one song goes, who introduces the lunatic three to the terminally social Mrs. Rittenhouse's Long Island manse, smashingly designed by Michael Anania. Mrs. Rittenhouse is throwing a soiree to welcome Spalding and to unveil a pricey, world-famous oil painting, "The Hunt," which was donated by Roscoe W. Chandler, the philanthropist, who is really a Czech fish peddler, Abie Cabibble.
Before long, there are three such paintings, counting the original, floating about in and out of the frame, being folded and unfolded in and out of the Professor's baggy pockets.
Add such duplicitous characters as a pair of wicked sisters; Hives, the head butler with a swindler's past, and a couple of "making whoopie" subplots. One involves Arabella, the daughter of Mrs. Rittenhouse, a debutante, and Wally Winston, "a tabloid dirt disher."
That gives Bert Kalmar's and Harry Ruby's score more added evergreens than it had at Goodspeed. Count "I Wanna Be Loved by You" and "Nevertheless" to augment "Three Little Words," the most popular of the previous additions to the original score's five songs.
From the zesty overture, conducted by Keith Thompson, replete with Harpo's tooting taxi horn, the Paper Mill production is musically delicious. The score's grab bag is capped by "Hello, I Must Be Going," with its mock Gilbert and Sullivan choral responses, and "Hooray for Captain Spalding," which became Groucho's signature song on the television quiz show "You Bet Your Life." Mr. Marsden's second-act lyric harp solo provides a sweet interlude, and somewhere there's even a sendup of Eugene O'Neill's "Strange Interlude."
In a perfectly giddy supporting cast, John Hoshko has Zeppo's part -- Jamison, Spalding's secretary -- and Carol Swarbrick acts the ineffable Margaret Dumont role, Mrs. Rittenhouse, with skillful comic restraint.
Michael Lichtefeld's sparkling choreography, which is, throughout, intrinsic to the delirious goings-on, erupts at times in mid-dialogue. In what must be a major release after creating the dances for the dour "Secret Garden," Mr. Lichtefeld has also come up with snappy, elaborate production numbers, show stoppers all.
Restorations to George S. Kaufman's and Morrie Ryskind's original script and selections from the 1930 film adaptation, which was mostly nonmusical, include one classic Marx Brothers non sequitur and routine after another. Try to figure out Spalding's invertedly logical theory on the economic viability of the seven-cent nickel. Or the Professor's card-sharking caper.
Altogether, the new stage "Animal Crackers" is more tightly structured than the screen version. In its irresistibly wacky way, it winds down to a bittersweet ending that has the Professor flattening the whole company and himself with Flit spray, and they all fall down. It's a real knockout. Literally.
"Animal Crackers," produced by the Paper Mill Playhouse, Brookside Drive, Millburn. Performances through Dec. 12: Wednesday through Sunday at 8 P.M., Thursday at 2 P.M. and Saturday and Sunday at 3 P.M. Box office: (201) 376-4343.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Members of the cast of the musical comedy "Animal Crackers," playing at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, are, from the left, Robert Michael Baker, Frank Ferrante, Les Marsden, John Hoshko and Carol Swarbrick. (Gerry Goodstein)

HEADLINE: Front-Porch Seat on Backyard History

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI

DATELINE: PURCHASE

 BODY:
HERE is a little-known cemetery on the grounds of the State University of New York here. A Revolutionary War hero, Col. Thomas Thomas, was buried there in 1824, and for the few who had taken note of the site, this seemed to be its chief historical significance. But to Dr. Lisa Keller, director of SUNY Purchase's College of Letters and Science's new Institute for Westchester and Local History, the small burial ground can provide far richer historical insights.
The land used to be part of the Thomas family estate, Dr. Keller said, and in a break from common custom, the family requested that their slaves be buried alongside them instead of in a separate plot. The cemetery is one of the few integrated burial grounds in the county from that era. 
 In Dr. Keller's view, this is another example of how local history -- in this case, quite literally the history of the college's own backyard -- can provide a paradigm for understanding major themes in the country's history.
"Why were the Thomas slaves put there?" Dr. Keller asked. "Why did they break from the tradition of the times? Burial customs touch to the heart of many things. When students pursue this, they will get a whole examination of America's race relations, land-pattern uses, as well as social and economic relations."
 
An 'Arranged Marriage'
 In keeping with the goals of the institute, which was established last month, the research on the cemetery will connect the academic world with the community. Students will visit historical societies in Rye and Harrison to search for letters, diaries, deeds and other documents of the Thomas family. But the institute's mission also reflects a growing academic trend among historians -- a resurgence of interest in the significance of local history.
"This is an arranged marriage that should have been made years ago," Dr. Alfred N. Hunt, dean of the College of Letters and Science said. "This is a very historically rich community, and it needs a lot of resource help. We have students who have the resources but need something to work with. For them, it's so much better than just reading books on history. At the same time, we are creating guardians of the public trust. There are two winners here." He was referring to documents being preserved and the undergraduate students who will work on them.
In addition to an internship program for academic credit, the institute will offer courses on historical and research training and in the use and organization of archives and manuscript collections. Public events like lectures and academic symposiums will also be held for the college community and the general public.
 
The Age Before Divorce
 As part of the institute's research program, a large-scale scholarly investigation of the County Archives in Elmsford will also be a priority. Dr. Keller describes the resources there as both "extraordinary" and underappreciated.
"I was stunned when I first went there," Dr. Keller said. "I've worked in public records offices in London, small libraries in Athens. I've seen all kinds of places, and when I got to this place I couldn't believe it. Not only did they have the best organization and the best physical plant I'd ever seen but they also had phenomenal documents and lots of them."
Dr. Keller said that at the County Archives she read deed books from 1686 as well as records from the same period of couples who, in the age before divorce, simply went before a public official and declared their marriage to be over.
"They would say, 'So and so has decided he no longer gets on with his wife and they are going their separate ways,' " Dr. Keller said. "These are documents from 1685, 1687, and they are very hard to read. This stuff was literally moldering away in basements, and the archivists have gone to great lengths to literally put the pieces together and bond the old parchment onto rice paper. This is an extraordinary resource."
Dr. Keller stressed that students would have extensive training before being allowed to handle documents that were hundreds of years old. But she also reiterated the importance of records that chronicled the changing experiences of everyday life and its implications for understanding the county's history beyond battle dates and war heroes.
"For instance, little has been done about the role of ethnic migrations into Westchester," she said. "You can't talk about the development of ethnic and cultural trends in the nation without looking at a neighborhood study of how, in fact, this changed from an Irish to a black neighborhood or a working-class rural neighborhood to an urban one."
 
Forget the Kings and Queens
 Once the purview of genealogists and town archivists, local history was long viewed in academic circles as among the least consequential sources of research material. But today, many historians are mining land deeds, marriage records, letters and diaries.
Dr. Hunt said: "There has been a worldwide movement and interest in the common folk and how they lived. Forget the generals and the queens and the kings. Small-town studies can add up to something that has important implications."
A classic example, Dr. Hunt said, was conducted at Harvard University in the 1960's and 70's. Graduate students in history studied the surrounding small towns of Needham, Dedham, Chelmsford and Concord. "Each student's own local study was not necessarily important in its own right, but the local histories added up to a regional history, which added up to a very important segment," Dr. Hunt said. He added that a study of this type has not yet been done in Westchester.
 
On-Site Experience
 The Institute for Westchester and Local History has the practical goal of linking the college to the many historical organizations in the county as well as in Rockland, Putnam and the Bronx. Through research, teaching and historical preservation, the institute plans to offer students a hands-on approach to history.
The internship program will give students on-site experience in working with documents and archives at more than 50 historical societies, museums and libraries. Students will work with municipal historians as well as at the County Archives. The SUNY Purchase faculty, local historians and scholars in specialized fields will share their expertise.
The program should benefit not only the students but also the organizations for whom they will be working, Dr. Keller said. She said that many such groups are chronically understaffed and underfinanced. When she sent out a questionnaire to historical societies asking if they could use interns, Dr. Keller immediately received 50 requests for 100 interns.
Dr. Keller concluded: "Suppose you put together a study of New Rochelle, Ossining and Yonkers. There is a lot that you can get out of these places that goes far beyond the Revolutionary War: the contributions of the Irish and the railroad and how housing patterns developed and how school systems changed.
"In what sense did this develop our sense of national character? There is tremendous relevance in studying our own backyard."

LENGTH: 1723 words

HEADLINE: A Pilot's Ultimate Flight of Fancy: An Airplane Built at Home

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
SOME people build model rockets. Others might try their hand at a deck or a picnic table. Mathew P. Fairy of Norwalk is building a Sonerai single-engine aircraft in his spare time.
After two years, it still doesn't look like an airplane, he acknowledges, because it's in pieces scattered all over his house.
"It's a tremendously absorbing hobby," Mr. Fairy said. "You work on it in your attic, your basement, your garage. Basically, wherever you have a slab of space, you're putting something together."
 
Putting Passion to the Test
 When he is finished in a few years, he will have a plane that will have cost him about $12,000 that would match a factory-built craft costing well into six figures. Then it will be time to put his passion to the test, and take the first flight. 
 "You really have to believe in your abilities," Mr. Fairy said. "If you're confident with your own work, then do it. If you're not, then go see United Airlines."
Mr. Fairy is among a growing number of Connecticut residents who, for a variety of reasons, are building their own aircraft, said state officers of the Experimental Aircraft Association, a group that promotes private plane-building projects.
 
Cheaper Than Factory Planes
 Experimental aircraft, as owner-built planes are known, are cheaper than factory planes, and because they incorporate newer technology they can often outperform factory craft. In addition, because so many small plane manufacturers have gotten out of the business, there are fewer used factory-built aircraft available on the market each year, so experimental aircraft have eased an availability problem. Membership in the six Connecticut chapters of the association has reached about 1,100, up about 20 percent in the last three years, and some chapters have grown even more quickly.
Earl E. Folsom of Shelton said membership in the Danbury chapter of the association, which he heads, stands at 70 now. There were only 20 members when he joined four years ago. Members have 20 plane-building projects underway, and another 12 have been completed in the last few years, ranging from reproductions of World War I biplanes to a Glassair III that cruises at 265 miles an hour.
"Despite the recession, I'm amazed at how the interest is building," Mr. Folsom said. "Every week I get two or three calls from people interested in building an airplane."
 
Large Turnout at Conference
 Interest in amateur-built aircraft, as they are known, was demonstrated by the turnout at a recent conference at Windham Airport sponsored by the association, the supplier Aircraft Spruce & Specialty, and Kit Planes Magazine. More than 300 people from throughout the Northeast turned out for tips on woodworking, welding, shaping composite materials, using fabric to cover wings, and other tips from professionals.
Dozens of the experimental aircraft were on display, ranging from the conventional (which looked like copies of Cessnas and Pipers), to the rear engine Long-EZ, a modern design that always looks like it's flying backward. People who had built their own designs offered advice to novices. W. R. Keith Browne of Hampton, for instance, was advising people who were interested in the Sonerai 2L design to put on a removable cockpit.
"Heat removal is the big problem," Mr. Browne said as a half dozen people gathered around. "It gets hot in there in the summer. You feel a bit like a casserole." Then he regaled them with tips on grinding rivet head for the least amount of drag on the wings.
The manager of the airport, Norvald Oygard, said when he arrived in 1974 there were perhaps one or two experimental aircraft; today there are 10.
Experimental aircraft can range from airplanes that are constructed entirely from plans and raw materials, to kit airplanes that are put together according to detailed manufacturer's instructions.
 
Aircraft Must Be Inspected
 Experimental aircraft must still be inspected by the Federal Aviation Administration, and they have several restrictions: They must have a label designating the planes as "Experimental" in plain view in the cockpit; there must be a placard displayed in the passenger area noting that it does not meet F.A.A. airworthiness standards; and they cannot be used for commercial purposes.
Still, the restrictions and warnings don't seem to put people off.
"If you're new to general aviation, you might think, 'Build an airplane -- are you kidding?' But with the kits that are out there if you've got some mechanical ability you can do it," said William J. Shanahan of Avon, who is earning his pilot's license and plans to build his own plane. "It's not really as intimidating as it might seem, but it does mean a commitment of time."
 
Anxiety During First Flights
 But Mr. Shanahan said that most pilots would have to feel a little anxiety the first time they take to the sky in something they put together.
"The first flight you'd probably be pretty nervous," Mr. Shanahan said. "You'd probably be thinking the whole time, 'Did I do this right, and did I remember to do that?' But if your own safety is riding on it, you'd pay pretty good attention to detail while you're building it."
Many people contemplating building an aircraft at home will join the association, because the chapters usually will lend specialty tools, have experts who can advise you on construction techniques, and print newsletters announcing upcoming training sessions.
A director of the Hartford chapter, William Welch of Hampton, said the group's 52 members have more than 18 projects underway and another 14 completed in the last few years, so there is a wealth of information available to newcomers.
 
Expensive Factory Planes
 Mr. Welch said it was probably no surprise that Connecticut residents are becoming interested in home-built aircraft, given the state's history in the aviation industry -- Pratt & Whitney in East Hartford and Textron-Lycoming in Stratford have long made aircraft engines, and Sikorsky in Stratford has long made airframes.
Mr. Welch said one reason experimental aircraft were becoming more popular was that the cost of factory planes has become so high, largely because of liability insurance. For an aircraft costing $150,000, $75,0000 will go to the manufacturer's insurance premium.
"The lawyers have wiped out the factory-built market," Mr. Welch said. "The liability situation has just become completely untenable."
In 1992, he said, pilots registered about three times as many amateur built aircraft as factory built.
 
A Few Years of Hobby Work
 The editor of Kit Planes Magazine, David A. Martin, in an interview during the recent conference at Windham Airport, said the Avid Flyer, a kit plane incorporating modern technology, could be built for about $18,000 "and a few years hobby work, nights and weekend in your basement or garage." It compares to the Taylorcraft, which has a $45,000 base price and was designed in the late 1930s.
Then there is the Lancair IV, a kit that has set all kinds of speed records, and will cost perhaps $40,000, including the engine, Mr. Martin said.
"There's really nothing comparable to it commercially," Mr. Martin said. The plane is designed out of composite, making it extremely lightweight, which allows it to outperform the old designs factories keep turning out, he said.
"All of the fastest general aviation airplanes now are home-builts," Mr. Martin said.
 
Hard to Register New Designs
 "In addition, some of them are built by people who want a decent, modern aircraft, which they can't get from a factory," Mr. Welch said. Piper has a 10-year-old design, the Malibu, but most other factory designs are from the 1950's, Mr. Welch said, with much of the technology from 1945. Federal regulations make it so difficult to register new designs for commercial use that plane manufacturers have concentrated on the upper end of the market, such as $1 million corporate jets.
Thomas A. Peghiny, president of Flightstar, a company based at Ellington Airport that makes ultralight aircraft kits, said home-builts are also becoming more popular because as costs decrease general aviation production, there is more space for home-builts at airports.
"We're moving in where the dinosaurs were," Mr. Peghiny said.
Henry M. Bouley Jr., who owns Windham Precision Airparts and operates the Questair kit manufacturer out of Windham Airport, said that kit craft demonstrates the advances that have been made over factory-built craft.
The Venture, one of the kits he sells, has set seven world records in its category for speed, climbing ability, and in other areas. It was the first single plane to cruise at more than 400 miles an hour, averaging 402 during a timed two-hour, nine-minute trip from Chicago's O'Hare Airport to Logan in Boston, and used only 34 gallons of fuel, less than someone would use in a large car.
 
Beating the Judges
 During another time trial in July, Mr. Bouley went from Palm Springs, Calif., to Chicago, about 2,000 miles, and beat the judges, who were flying in a factory-built jet.
"They were supposed to be there to take my picture, but they had a 12 minute fuel stop on the way," Mr. Bouley said. He used 89 gallons; the jet used about 420 gallons.
Mr. Bouley operates a center where people can come in and build their planes under his direction, getting help with some of the tougher jobs, and passing the flight test over to a professional pilot.
The center is booked through mid-1995, and Mr. Bouley is considering opening several others to keep up with demand.
 
'Sense of Accomplishment'
 "There's a tremendous sense of accomplishment, with all the work and sweat and checking and inspecting that goes into a project," Mr. Bouley said. "By the time they actually take it out, they've got years into this thing."
Stuart A. Hipkins of Coventry, who was browsing at the experimental aircraft conference in Windham, said after 10 years as an inspector at Pratt & Whitney Aircraft, he wants to put his knowledge to use building his own plane.
"I've been riding motorcycles since I was 15, and I think flying is safer than bikes. I feel more secure in the air than I do on the ground," Mr. Hipkins said. "And experimental is really the only way for the private pilot to do anything in general aviation these days."

HEADLINE: Main Street's Struggle for Survival

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
DESPITE changes taking place on the street outside his appliance store, Martin H. Painkin still cleaves to a dream that has sustained him for more than four decades: when he retires soon, he wants his two grown sons to carry on the family business.
But on a recent afternoon, as he tallied his ledger at a desk in the rear of Leibert Brothers Appliance Discount Center, the 68-year-old Mr. Painkin momentarily lost heart, worried that his dream might be just that. 
 In White Plains, once known as the City of a Thousand Stores, Mr. Painkin said it has become increasingly difficult for small business owners to make ends meet. Like many other shopkeepers here and those in other downtown areas in the county, his business has been hit hard by competition from large discount stores and malls.
 
Battling Market Forces
 Some storekeepers have packed up and moved away from downtown here -- at recent count, the vacancy rate among the smaller shops on Mamaroneck Avenue and its sidestreets was more than 25 percent, according to the White Plains Merchants Association. And those who remain worry that the old values many small businessmen pride themselves on may no longer be in fashion.
"Main Street U.S.A., personal service, reliability, longevity -- all of the things that we stand for don't seem to matter much anymore," said Mr. Painkin, who bought the store from Jack and Harry Leibert 40 years ago. "Today, there is no such thing as consumer loyalty because the dollar is king."
Like Mr. Painkin and his sons who work with him in the store -- Gerald, 43, and Howard, 39 -- merchants here are battling market forces that threaten their viability, especially as the holiday shopping season approaches. Their struggle is one that is being repeated in many older downtown areas nationwide, experts say.
Across the United States, the recession has dramatically altered consumers' spending habits, driving shoppers to seek bargains and discounts. As in other parts of the country, large discounters in the county -- chain stores like Tops Appliance City in Hawthorne and Bradlees in Yonkers -- have drawn business away from neighborhood shops.
One of the first blows to White Plains shopkeepers came 13 years ago, when the Galleria, an 880,000-square-foot downtown mall, opened. As they have more recently, many neighborhood stores shut their doors then, while others hung on. The area rebounded in time, with new stores moving in, especially during the boom years of the 1980's.
 
A Recession-Related Factor
 More recently, there have been renewed threats to White Plains's downtown shops. Ground was broken earlier this year for a million-square-foot mall, anchored by Neiman Marcus and Nordstrom,on Maple Avenue and Bloomingdale Road. Another mall, which would include Saks Fifth Avenue and Bloomingdale's, is also planned.
Another mall, the Westchester Pavilion, which is to include discount stores like Toys 'R' Us, is about to open at one end of East Post Road, not far from Mr. Painkin's store. Mr. Painkin said that may be "good for my store, or bad," explaining that the shoppers might only stay in the mall and not venture out onto the streets where the smaller stores are. "At the least," he added, "maybe the cars will see Leibert's when they come around the corner."
In addition to competition posed by discounters and malls, there is a recession-related factor that has taken its toll in White Plains: some large corporations like A.T.& T. have moved employees elsewhere, and others like I.B.M. have reduced their staffs -- eroding the base of lunch-time customers who have traditionally patronized local stores.
Edward M. Murray, executive vice president of the Westchester County and White Plains Chambers of Commerce, said: "Our store owners have a three-hour window, 11 A.M. to 2 P.M. And what they don't sell then, they don't sell, because after 6 o'clock in this city, everyone goes home."
White Plains, the county seat and an area dense with office buildings, has a population of 49,000, which swells to 250,000 on weekdays during business hours.
Mr. Murray said that at its peak, in the 1950's and 60's (when East Post Road was known as the Fifth Avenue of White Plains), there were more than 1,000 stores in the downtown White Plains area; today, he said, there are only 314.
"It's also a different mix now," he said. "It used to be old-time U.S.A., and now it's convenience food, a lot of hairdressers and drugstores."
Although small shopkeepers in downtowns nationwide are struggling, experts are optimistic that areas like White Plains will be able to adjust to economic shifts.
 
Different Sets of Circumstances
 Elizabeth M. Rodgers, a partner in Rodgers and McCauley, a Manhattan- and Philadelphia-based retail consulting firm, said: "Main Streets U.S.A., as they have been known, must change. As retail centers, they cannot stay the same in these times.
"Each Main Street has a different set of circumstances, and each has a different set of problems, and although I believe there will always be a Main Street U.S.A., we have to reinvent it." Ms. Rodgers was a consultant for nearby Stamford, which has seen its local merchants threatened by the development of a large mall, the 875,000-square-foot Stamford Town Center.
Her recommendation to small business owners:
"Find a niche in the market and don't duplicate what the big stores are selling."
Julian Didonato, the 40-year-old owner of Dakota Cotton Outpost on Mamaroneck Avenue here, described his store as "a cross between a Gap and an L. L. Bean, but still unique," carrying competitive lines of down jackets, turtleneck shirts and casual outdoor sportswear not found in chain stores. Mr. Didonato said he also caters to a trade seeking the personalized service that mall stores often don't offer.
 
'An Awful Lot of Empty Stores
 Mr. Didonato, president of the 60-member White Plains Merchants Association, also said that if smaller retailers are to compete, they have to cut overhead and become aggressive merchandisers like the discounters. "I'm not making a killing, but I am making a good living," he said. "It just means watching every dime."
Although the Merchants Association said the vacancy rate was 25 percent in the downtown area, the City Planning Department said that their studies showed it was only 13.4 percent. Mr. Murray of the White Plains Chamber of Commerce said, "Whatever it is, if you take a look at the downtown, there are an awful lot of empty stores."
At the Washington-based International Downtown Association, which represents nearly 700 members, Dale D. Doyle, director of program development and communications, agreed that in addition to smart merchandising, small stores need to offer something different.
"A mall is a mall is a mall," she said. "And by that I mean, they are all the same. You can predict the mix -- a Gap, a Banana Republic. Downtown areas, by contrast, can present a unique mix."
Some downtowns, like Bronxville's, have found the mix, she said, "causing drivers to go out of their way to find that something different."
Joy A. Kilbourn, president of Bronxville's 230-member Chamber of Commerce and owner of Cliffhangers, an upscale gift shop in the village, said local shopkeepers were not threatened by nearby malls because they had "cut out a niche in the market and were therefore able to hold onto the independent retailer."
 
Optimistic Outlook
 Peter Mosbacher, executive director of the New York Main Street Alliance, based in Mount Kisco, said the emphasis in that community is on "shops that offer services for the people who live and work here." The alliance is a statewide nonprofit organization that assists downtown revitalization projects.
Mr. Mosbacher added: "The question has to be, 'What can we sell that Wal-Mart does not?' Main Street merchants may have to wake up and face the fact that the days of customer loyalty are over, but that doesn't mean Main Street is dead."
Leon Silverman, a White Plains Realtor, said, "It is a matter of making the city more user friendly," by offering better parking and other amenities "to compete with the malls."
Mr. Painkin said he is optimistic that the efforts of the merchants' association and pledges made by a new administration coming in to City Hall will help revitalize the downtown area. During his campaign, Mayor-Elect Sy J. Schulman promised to address the problems faced by small businessmen.
"I'm still hopeful," Mr. Painkin said. "But if after all this time, we had to shut the door, I would wonder, What have I done with 40 years of my life? Both sons have been with me here since they were each 9 years old, sweeping floors, dusting. Now they are my partners, and I would be so sad to see that go."

HEADLINE: CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
Same-Day Delivery From the North Pole

BYLINE: By Jim Gladstone; Jim Gladstone manages events and special promotions for the Philadelphia Free Library System. His fiction has been published in Christopher Street.

 BODY:

HARVEY SLUMFENBURGER'S CHRISTMAS PRESENT
Written and illustrated by John Burningham.
Unpaged. Cambridge, Mass.
Candlewick Press. $15.95. (Ages 5 to 8) 
 THERE are good tidings for parents fed up with the commercialization of Christmas in John Burningham's latest picture book, a hardscrabble but unsentimental tale of the tough work and valiant efforts that go into making the holiday pay off for the kids in these economically strained times. Just as Mr. Burningham's pooped, blue-collar Santa is sacking out after his annual gift-giving run, he notices that a single present for little Harvey Slumfenburger, a poor boy who lives in a hut at the top of the Roly Poly Mountain "far, far away," has gone undelivered. Dragging himself back out of bed, Santa earnestly schleps halfway around the world in order to deliver the precious parcel.
After young readers watch old Santa trudge over tundra, motorbike across ice, skate, ski and scale his way to young Harvey's bedside, they can't help being impressed. They'll realize that some of us work to make Christmas happen. "Harvey Slumfenburger's Christmas Present" is a book that encourages gratitude.
It also encourages careful and repeated readings. Mr. Burningham, whose books, from "Mr. Gumpy's Outing" to "Hey! Get Off Our Train," are enjoyed here and in Britain, has, in fact, tucked plenty of nifty gifts into his prose and illustrations, but they are not wrapped in flash and dazzle. His palette -- ranging from pale washes of pink to daunting black fields -- is richly sophisticated, and his subtly emotive figures are more like the cartoons in The New Yorker than the ones on Saturday morning television. Adults will get great pleasure out of teaching children how much there is to appreciate here.
You can elicit laughter by pointing out the bedpan discreetly provided for the sick reindeer tucked in their cozy beds (the fact that this Santa has only two deer -- and no elves -- suggests that hard times have reached the North Pole, too). You can summon up awe through the vast, Rothko-like sweeps of color signifying the tremendous distances Santa must travel to reach the Slumfenburger home. You can offer a lesson in politeness and modesty when, each time he meets a helpful stranger, Santa reaches out his white-gloved hand and says, "Excuse me, my name is Santa Claus."
"Harvey Slumfenburger's Christmas Present" is at once accessible and challenging, a book with a simple initial appeal that doesn't spoon-feed readers its deeper delights. The detailed texturing of Mr. Burningham's pen and watercolor illustrations, from the beautiful blue striations of sky that Santa traverses in a yellow biplane to the tiny town scratched into the paint at the foot of a mountain landscape, reveals more elements with each examination.
On the last page, curly-haired Harvey wakes up on Christmas morning to receive his one little gift, tagged with his name and wrapped in polka-dotted paper. The parting stroke is Mr. Burningham's refusal to reveal what's in the box. He leaves it to readers to conclude that the real gift, like the bulk of his tale, is in the giving. This is one sweet raisin of a book. Its wrinkle on the holidays is much needed.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Illustration by John Burningham from "Harvey Slumfenburger's Christmas Present.")
